ipc-html-content-inner-div: After suffering a devastating lost, Gorr (Christian Bale) seeks to destroy all the Gods. Thor (Chris Hemsworth) must save the children of New Asgard who have been kidnapped by Gorr. Jane Foster (Natalie Portman) is dying from cancer. She is chosen by Mjolnir to be the Mighty Thor. They are joined by King Valkyrie (Tessa Thompson) and Korg (Taika Waititi). Russell Crowe makes a memorable appearance as Zeus.This is trying very hard to be funny. Sometimes it is funny. Sometimes it's a little awkward. It's a little worst when compared to Ragnarok. I never bought into the Thor and Jane Foster romance. Basically, Jane turns into a girlie puddle in the presence of Chris Hemsworth's muscles. It's fine but it's no Romeo and Juliet. At least in this one, Natalie Portman has many dimensions to play. Her character has so much more. With more daring, this would be a two person journey. Thor could really dig into his relationship with Jane. In the end, I love these characters and I like this movie enough.

ipc-title__text: Too much of a good thing
ipc-html-content-inner-div: While I really enjoyed the last THOR film, RAGNAROK, LOVE AND THUNDER proves that you can have too much of a good thing. Waititi goes all out to make an absurdist comedy here and inserts himself into the film way too much, not only co-starring but narrating the darn thing too. And a little of his trademark humour goes a long way, as it turns out. The storyline's okay, Hemsworth is very funny too, but Portman's return is mishandled and her character arc so serious to be completely at odds with the overwhelming goofiness elsewhere. Good CGI and a great Christian Bale can't disguise the all over the place nature of the storyline.

Round two ... my internet really pulled one on me. I had the complete review written and then it ... well it went away. So from the start - and probably a bit different than the other review I wrote. A bit like the Thor you get here. Taika reinvented him for Ragnarok - and he even went further with this installment.You have to dig what he does - and his humor too of course. I understand that some do not like the humor. You can't fault the movie technically speaking though. Ask (your) kids - maybe you got a bit weary, but they surely haven't. And the darkness that Christian Bale brings to his role (great as always of course), will not faze them either.Bale who gets introduced first in the movie. Might be a (new) trend for Marvel. Giving us the bad guy, before we see the good guy(s). Moon Knight did the same (Ms. Marvel did not of course), but let's keep an eye out for that.Bales character is not alone when he gets introduced. There is someone with him. And while you may want to forget about it. Bale will not let you. He will keep talking about that character - so much so, that you may get a bit annoyed. But there is a reason (or two, no pun intended) for that.Everyone except Bale can show off their silly side. Adding a bit of gravitas from time to time. But the darker tone and mood is kept for Bale and his character. He may not have much screentime, but the movie called Thor (whoever that might be - you probably have seen the trailer so you have an idea I reckon).But apart from reintroducing characters to us, the movie is also reintroducing the Thor (movie) mythology to us. So if you or the little one you are with or whoever have not seen the previous movies, you get a "what happened" at the beginning. Not everything will be rehashed. There is another flashback kept for later in the movie.This is the fourth Thor movie and aside of Hugf Jackman as Wolverine, no one has played a comic book character as long as Chris Hemsworth has. And the latter has gone through quite the transformations. I understand if you are not into the humor.I myself had an issue with another character (that you may already know is in the movie). The portrayal and the accent seemed weird to say the least. But even though I had my own preconceptions about that ... I'll call it character, I understand that Taika only wanted to do his thing. I did not know he was part of the Marvel comic book cannon to be honest, but I am not as involved in the comics as others are.So while there is not much story here (getting from point a to b and all that), there are a lot of cool set pieces. And a lot of weird (Taika) humor. Like him expanding the God universe if you want to call it that. Which is sort of the scene I was talking about above.It all makes sense in the end though and for me the balance between silly and drama did work. You have to suspend your disbelief, maybe drink a little bit of that kool aid and just go with the flow.I for my part am happy Thor is back. At the end of Avengers Endgame, no one seemed to know (apart from Kevin Feige probably), if any of the surviving (and available, no pun intended to the "old" man, who passed on ... well you know what) characters would return. So seeing Thor get into the Guardians of the Galaxy ship really made me hope he'd return. I thought it would be in a Guardians movie, but it's them who were in this ... at least for a little bit. A funny little bit that is.And then you have the end credits scenes. People should be aware of them, but still some get up and leave. As with most MCU movies (minus Endgame), you get some bonus and look into the future. One scene during the credits and one after ... both are promising and really great to say the least.So sit back, relax and let the (mostly) lightness wash over you ... it would be a shame if you couldn't. I just had to laugh, because there is a moment where Thor is naked. You don't see a front shot of that, but you do get to see his behind ... uncensored, if that means anything to you. It's another joke and it does work quite well too (no pun intended).Edit: almost completely forgot a few important things. One thing I am surprised by. Well the non reaction from people who are into religion (no matter what kind) that is. Because the movie essentially is critisizing almost everything about religion. It does make fun of Gods ... no pun intended. This is more than the silly depiction of Thor. This is kind of an atheist ... well heaven (another pun I know). It is underlying, but it is not subtle to be honest.And of course the music - Guns N Roses for the win as some might say. Music apparently played a big role during the making of the movie. And if you don't mind classic rock as I reckon people would call it now ... well you could do a lot worse.

The last worshiper of God Rapu, Gorr (Christian Bale), crosses the desert with his daughter that dies of thirsty and starvation. He reaches an oasis and sees Rapu that mistreats Gorr. The powerful Necrosword choses Gorr that beheads Rapu and he promises to kill all the gods. Thor (Chris Hemsworth) and the Guardians of the Galaxy are fighting Sif and Dr. Jane Foster (Natalie Portman) is under treatment of a stage IV cancer on Earth. When Gorr kidnaps all the children of New Asgard, Thor, Jane Foster with Mjolnir, King Valkyrie (Tessa Thompson) and Korg go to the Omnipotence City to ask Zeus (Russel Crowe) to join an army of gods to fight Gorr, but Zeus don't care to his request. Now the quartet needs to fight Gorr to rescue the children and avoid the God Butcher from reaching the Etenity's gate."Thor: Love and Thunder" is an adventure that aspires to be funny, but most of the scenes of comedy are unfunny. The adventure is not bad, and Gorr is a creepy villain. The corny conclusion is silly, with Thor raising the daughter of his enemy. The American Jane Foster reaching the Valhalla is hard to be understood. My vote is six.Title (Brazil); "Thor: Amor e Trovão" ("Thor: Love and Thunder")

Initially when I saw the trailer for director Taika Waititi's 2022 "Thor: Love and Thunder" movie, then I wasn't overly impressed. And I have to admit that this wasn't a movie that I was going to be rushing out to the cinema to watch.But now that it has become readily available for the streaming masses, of course I opted to watch it. Granted, I am not really much of a superhero movie fan, but I do watch them for their entertainment value. And Marvel Studios do tend to make some entertaining enough superhero-based movies.Writers Taika Waititi and Jennifer Kaytin Robinson managed to put together a very entertaining movie here. And I don't really understand all the grief that this movie has been getting. But hey, I suppose every movie franchise has a group of toxic fans. I was genuinely entertained by "Thor: Love and Thunder". And it turned out to be a good combination of archetypical superhero movie mixed with comedy. I liked that particular approach that director Taika Waititi took with this movie.The storyline was good and well-written. It definitely felt like a "Thor" movie, and also like something you would find within the pages of a Marvel comic book. So thumbs up on that accomplishment.Something that really impressed me with "Thor: Love and Thunder" was the cast ensemble. This movie has so many talents on the cast list, granted lots of them in smaller roles, but it was such a great cast ensemble. But the real stars of the movie were the two giant goats. They just cracked me up.Visually then "Thor: Love and Thunder" was everything you would expect from a Marvel Studios movie. Lots of great visuals, vibrant colors, fantastic costume designs, amazing sets, and so forth. So you are in for quite a visual treat here with this movie.As for the music in the movie, well, that was a mixed bag of nuts. The score was good, but the songs in the movie, well, not so much. I just didn't find Guns 'n Roses to be a particularly fitting band for a movie such as this.I am rating "Thor: Love and Thunder" a solid six out of ten stars.

ipc-title__text: "So, how you feeling with the old stab wound?"
Actors and their kids cook up an entertaining Superhero movie.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Right away this Marvel movie comes across as different. It is more whimsical and has more humor built into the script. All of which, for me, make it a more fun movie and the almost 2 hours passes rather quickly.What is it about? Well Thor has sort of gone into semi-requirement and has a beer belly. But when he learns that a rogue god is on a mission to kill all the other gods, and gain immortality for himself, he gets re-energized and rounds up the band of superheros to fight to make things right.As you watch more and more of these they begin to seem all alike, until this one, which has much more fun with the topic. And the town of New Asgard with all the kids, incidentally played by many of the children of the main actors and the director.Not a memorable movie but my wife and I enjoyed it at home on DVD from our public library.

This film tells the story of Thor and his team fighting a villain that is determined to destroy the heavenly world.The first half tries very hard to be funny, but I don't find it funny. The jokes are predictable and stale. In the second half, when Thor is mostly wearing his superhero cape, the film gets a lot more interesting and captivating. I actually wish that the first few scenes are cut, as they are really the weakest link.

ipc-title__text: This is worthwhile addition to the super hero genre that's a must see for fans of the Marvel Universe
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Thor: Love and Thunder (2022) is a movie my wife and I caught in theaters last night. The storyline follows Thor post Thanos searching for meaning. Meanwhile Jane Foster, his one true love, is back on Earth, dying. In her research she discovers Thor's hammer has healing effects and she tracks down his shattered hammer. The hammer, recognizing Jane, rejoins and turns her into a female Thor. When a God killer emerges in the galaxy destroying worlds and religions everywhere what better to stop it than two Thors?This movie is directed by Taika Waititi (Jojo Rabbit) and stars Chris Hemsworth (Snow White and the Huntsman), Natalie Portman (The Professional), Christian Bale (American Psycho), Tessa Thompson (Creed) and Russell Crowe (Gladiator).I'm not sure what I liked better, the legendary GNR soundtrack or the screaming goats...both stole the show. There's very little not to love about this film. The cast is well selected and Bale's villain is perfect in every way (cause, attire, makeup, etc). The special effects, CGI and cinematography are all classic Marvel and tremendous creating wonderful environments, characters and action scenes. The Guardians of the Galaxy opening was a perfect way to kick the movie off and the dialogue throughout is spot on and hilarious. There's also some memorable cameos sprinkled in here and there and they did a pretty good job with pacing as the storyline unfolds well and doesn't feel drawn out like a lot of super hero movies recently.Overall this is worthwhile addition to the super hero genre that's a must see for fans of the Marvel Universe. I would score this a solid 7.5/10 and strongly recommend it.

Greetings again from the darkness. With a steady stream of Marvel movies and TV serials, maintaining coherent and connected storylines has become challenging. In fact, it's probably best if fans take these at face value, rather struggling to connect the dots, only to end up frustrated. Perhaps no one understands this better than Taika Waititi, the director behind what many (including me) consider the best MCU film, THOR: RAGNAROK (2017). Waititi and co-writer Jennifer Kaytin Robinson once again embrace the blend of quick quip comedy and expected action sequences, supplemented this time a love story.The pre-opening credits sequence provides the backstory for the film's villain, Gorr the God Butcher, played by Oscar winner Christian Bale. Gorr has spent a lifetime worshipping the Sun God, only to realize his worshipping has occurred in an actual God-forsaken world that costs him dearly. Gorr ends up learning the lesson of 'never meet your heroes', and this confrontation gives him the power and curse of the Necrosword, and sets him on a revenge mission to kill all Gods. We have to respect a villain who has a legitimate claim to his mission - it's not just a thirst for world domination. Gorr wants the Gods to pay for their ambivalence.We then pick up Thor Odinson (Chris Hemsworth) as he has been fighting with the Guardians of the Galaxy since the end of AVENGERS: ENDGAME (2019). With no shortage of characters who excel in comedy, this sequence shifts us into laughter and light-hearted mode after the bleak Gorr opening. It's this pacing that holds for most of the movie ... Waititi never lets things stay too serious for very long. Soon, Thor splits off from the Guardians, as he returns to New Asgard, being run by King Valkyrie (Tessa Thompson). Now based on Earth, New Asgard is a theme park and tourist attraction. One of the features is the theater acting group we've seen previously, and this time Matt Damon, Luke Hemsworth, and Sam Neill are joined by Melissa McCarthy as Hela. While this is going on, we learn Thor's old flame, astrophysicist Jane Foster (Oscar winner Natalie Portman) is now an author being treated for Stage 4 cancer. A trip to New Asgard provides her strength as the shattered Mjolnir hammer magically re-forms in her presence. Jane's story boils down to whether she wants to try to extend her life through science or live every remaining day to it's fullest.Gorr kidnaps the Asgardian kids, forcing Thor, Valkyrie, Korg (voiced again by Waititi), and Mighty Thor/Jane Foster to track him to the Realm of Shadows. Their plan is to stop by Omnipotence City to request assistance from the almighty Zeus (Russell Crowe). They are shocked to discover that Zeus is little more than a colorful televangelist with a Borat accent performing a whiz-bang show so that he can get on to the next orgy. Zeus refuses to assist with an army, but he does manage to chain Thor and strip him nekkid centerstage. The good guys nab Zeus' golden lightning bolt and head off to rescue the kids and confront Gorr.In a reverse Wizard of Oz twist, the films turns to Black & White when they reach the Realm of Shadows. It's an eerie environment befitting Gorr. Bale is certainly at his best when he is terrifying and menacing, although the writing is a bit inconsistent for the character, and sometimes it drifts into Pennywise mode, a definite drop in suspense. The action sequences are fine, but really nothing we haven't seen before. And that's probably the biggest issue with all superhero/comic book stories these days. Anything new must come from the story or the characters, and we know the characters far too well at this point.Waititi's version delivers many laughs throughout. Among the best is the odd relationship between Thor and his hammer Mjolnir and his axe Stormbreaker. Thor's jealousy of his ex-hammer hooking up with his ex-girlfriend is almost as funny as Stormbreaker's jealousy of Thor trying to steal back the hammer. Also cool is Thor's homage to Jean-Claude Van Damme, and the look of the Altar of Eternity, where one last wish is granted. Maybe not as effective is the apparent Guns 'n Roses fetish or Jane's struggle to come up with a catchphrase. Sure to be a divisive element is the recurring gag of bleating goats ... I found them hilarious, but many won't. Another piece that simply didn't work for me is Ms. Portman's performance, especially in the scenes with Hemsworth. Her comic timing can't match his, and it's a match that just never clicks.Obviously, the characters originated from the minds of Stan Lee and Jason Aaron in Marvel Comics, and it's Taika Waititi who brings his unique touch to the project. Since he directed THOR: RAGNAROK, he won a screenplay Oscar for JOJO RABBIT (2019), and I've been a fan of his style dating back to EAGLE VS SHARK (2007), and on to the brilliant HUNT FOR THE WILDERPEOPLE (2016), and TV series "What We Do in the Shadows". Waititi is scheduled to direct a Star Wars movie in the near future - one surely to be divisive among that fan base. As for this latest Thor movie, it may be tonally jagged and have a few too many zippy quips for some, but it manages to be silly and tender and emotional, while having the look and feel of a comic book come to life. Stay for the two end-credit scenes.Opening in theaters on July 8, 2022 (Thorsday)

ipc-title__text: Another score for Marvel, very colourful.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: I enjoyed the last Thor: Ragnarok a lot so I was expecting something similar with Thor: Love and Thunder and I can't say I was disappointed. This new Marvel movie was of the same quality as the previous one. Very colourful, bombastic, spiked with again some good humorous scenes mostly because of funny one liners. The CGI's were again very spectacular. The cast consists of very good actors so you know you won't be disappointed by them. Christian Bale's character was creepy so credits to the make-up artists for that. The story is easy to follow, with a lot of action, no dead moments at all. If you're a fan of this genre of Marvel movies, action with a bit of humour, you won't regret watching this new Thor adventure. Up to the next one!

Gorr finds that his god refuses to save his daughter, doesn't care that the rest of his people are dead, and only cares about himself. So it is no wonder that he grabs the Necrosword and vows to kill all deities. Christian Bale gives his best performance since American Psycho, and at the risk of being blasphemous, I believe it's actually even better than that one. No, really. For more than two decades, I didn't think that would ever happen. While he has too little screen time, he's probably the best thing about the entire film.For one thing, while all of the action looks cool, it's only when he's involved that we feel any sense of danger. And another, he manages to tear the movie out of the rut it's otherwise stuck in, of humor that is marred by an insistence on being a constant throughout the running time, and the feeling that the talented cast, like in Thor 3, are trying desperately to outdo one another, all of the time. I realise that not everybody thinks the romantic comedy aspect works. Personally I thought it was great. You can tell that these are people who can act, who enjoy working together, who share immense chemistry, and who have shared a lot of screen time by now.This features a lot of risque references, a little strong language and brief nudity. I recommend this to big fans of Ragnarok. 7/10.

THOR: LOVE AND THUNDER (2022) *** Chris Hemsworth, Natalie Portman, Christian Bale, Tessa Thompson, Taika Waititi, Russell Crowe, Jaimie Alexander, Chris Pratt, Dave Bautista, Karen Gillan, Pom Klementieff, (voices of Vin Diesel & Bradley Cooper) Frequently entertaining Thor vehicle in the MCU with the still-nursing-his-heart Avenger facing an intergalactic crisis with the threat of Gorr The God Butcher (scary good Bale) hellbent on a vendetta to wipe out the gods that be and kidnapping the children of Asgard as collateral damage. Enlisting the help of his ex, the cancer stricken Jane Foster (Portman in a welcome return to the fray) who has embodied her own version of The Mighty Thor in the process, they team up with their old cronies Valkyrie & Korg (Thompson & writer/director Waititi) to do justifiable ass-kicking battle. While the visuals are still triumphant buoyed by a Guns'n'Roses jukebox the film labors until its final (and surprisingly poignant) act.

'Thor: Love And Thunder (2022)' feels like an absolute rush job. Seriously, it's like a half-hearted first draft. Lacking the charm, wit, wonder and chaotic energy of Taika Waititi's previous foray into the MCU, the film chugs along at its own meandering pace as it tells a simple story as straightforwardly as it can. Some of it has a lot of potential and some of it is even fairly good, but all of it is undercut by the almost oppressively unfunny screenplay that has no idea how to balance its tone. I could probably sue for neck injuries thanks to a couple of these instances of total tonal whiplash. The movie just isn't fun, either. It certainly isn't the sort of devil-may-care comedy you may expect from those involved. Despite a handful of jokes that I recall making me think "that's quite funny" (but, crucially, never making me laugh), the experience of watching this is a maddeningly straight-faced affair. I mean, it's like the easiest 'you laugh, you lose' challenge in the world, so much so that most of the humour doesn't even seem like it's trying to make you laugh even though it obviously is. The whole thing is actually kind of embarrassing, the equivalent of watching a screening of someone's University work that they clearly scraped together mere moments before they were due to present it. I'll highlight the few things that I feel work about the picture. Firstly, Jane's storyline has a lot of potential and comes close to being affecting on a couple of occasions. It unfortunately isn't capitalised on fully, but it's undeniably the heart of the story and brings the chemistry between Natalie Portman and Chris Hemsworth back into the fray. Secondly, Gorr's motivation is believable and his presentation is often fairly unsettling (thanks, in no small part, to the stellar work from an out-of-place Christian Bale). His introductory sequence is mostly stellar, until it eventually gets too silly for its own good, and the payoff to his arc is as mature as it is satisfying (despite the denouement's somewhat clumsy handling of its consequences). Finally, there are a couple of action sequences that are presented with distinct aesthetics that bring to mind the best work of Zack Snyder. The golden shower skirmish is probably the movie's most entertaining set-piece, whereas the gang's extended stint in the shadow realm builds on the flick's most disquieting scene to present a relatively eerie battle that's genuinely aesthetically interesting. Despite these limited successes, the picture is easily one of the worst in the entire MCU. Much like 'Doctor Strange In The Multiverse Of Madness (2022)' before it, it simply doesn't feel like an actual film. It has all the elements that ought to make for a strong superhero story, but it squanders each and every one to emerge as nothing more than an absolute mess.

ipc-title__text: Thor's cosmic adventure has enough thunder and laughs, but enough boring love too.
ipc-html-content-inner-div:
Thor: Love and Thunder (2022):
Movie Review -Marvel Studios' Thor: Love And Thunder, starring Chris Hemsworth, Christian Bale, Tessa Thompson, Russell Crowe, and Natalie Portman, introduces you to some new Superheroes, Gods and Villains. Some of them are too good even as newcomers, while some are too predictable as the old ones. From the trailer, you get the overall idea of the script, be it characters, suspense, or adventure, and the final outcome doesn't go beyond that, except for one thing. However, it makes sure to fulfil all the criteria of Marvel's Superhero Entertainer, which leaves you satisfied by the end. Love, Thunder, and Laughs: Thor's cosmic adventure ticks all three boxes, despite a few boring aspects. I wish Thunder was in the lead, though.Thor 4 starts off with an introduction scene of the antagonist, Gorr, who becomes the God Butcher after his God fails him. We get back to New Asgard, which is quite like a corporate city and visually lavish, where Korg (Taika Waititi) keeps telling the legends of Thor, aka God of Thunder. Thor (Chris Hemsworth) attempts to find inner peace after losing the love of his life (three times, OMG!), but must return to action to prevent Gorr from murdering the Gods. Valkyrie (Tessa Thompson) and Korg join his army, and then appears Thor's ex-girlfriend Jane Foster ( Natalie Portman), aka Mighty Thor, with Thor's ex-weapon, Mjolnir, to support him, of course.Thor: Love And Thunder might just bore you with typical romance and illogical reconciliation (you might even end up asking why it was there if it wasn't supposed to make any sense, and you won't even get answers), but it covers the loss with explosive action and thrilling adventures. It's a topic of discussion why every superhero film should have a romantic angle to spoil the structure. Of course, not every superhero film can be intellectual like "The Dark Knight", and Marvel never wished to match Nolan's intelligence with their money-spinner entertainers. Yet we have that boring romance, parting and reconciliation just to look down and check if our popcorn is finished or not. Thor: Love And Thunder has many moments like this. It's unfathomable how Thor and Jane's love story was left incomplete before the mighty assembly of Avengers, and how it suddenly pops up in the post Thanos era. 8 years or something, as Thor says, who was counting anyway, and what was she doing in the meantime? One of the most pressing questions is why the Guardians of the Galaxy suddenly disappeared. Let's not expect any answers from Marvel.Coming to performances, Thor: Love and Thunder is blessed with Christian Bale's supremacy. He is truly deadly and dark as Gorr and makes you forget many former villains with his impeccable presence. Thor, aka Chris Hemsworth, gets back into his old shoes again and the size still fits him. Not just the physical transformation, but his verbal transformation also clicks well. This time he is more funny and child-friendly, that's some good change after "The Dark World" and "Ragnarok". Tessa Thompson and Taika Waititi have limited space but do well, whereas Natalie Portman is charming as Mighty Thor and damn boring as Jane Forster. I was expecting Russell Crowe to spread a surprise, but the screen time and role both came out quite underwhelming. Nevertheless, he has a surprise for you in the end credits scene that might just erase previous low grade marks.Marvel's cosmic adventure is visually splendid, and you don't expect anything less in this department, at least. But still, Thor: Love and Thunder goes beyond expectations to leave you in awe with some enchanting and colourful visuals. This may surprise you, but Thor: Love And Thunder also has some dark visuals, and they are unexpectedly awe-spiring. The background score and cinematography seemed okay, while the editing remained crispy most of the time. The tedious romance could have been trimmed a little and easily been replaced by action scenes or comedy to make it more engaging, but what's done is done now.Taika Waititi will be remembered for bringing a bewitching change to Thor's universe with "Thor: Ragnarok" (2017). This man pulled Thor out of a dark and intense world and made him more funny and amusing with his commercial vision. With Thor: Love and Thunder, he continues the flow and keeps you smiling all the time. Taika has increased humour and children-oriented theories that should widen Thor's reach to different age groups. However, he fails to make a theoretical sense. But who cares about that when you are watching an MCU product? Chuck the brain, let the chicks and eyes enjoy the show. As a whole, Thor's cosmic adventure is as entertaining as you'd expect, with some new surprises in store.RATING - 6/10*

ipc-title__text: Light-hearted mixed bag, just add muscles
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Short and sweet: the movie rides on Hemsworth's charisma, it looks good, and Bale offers up one of Marvel's best villains. Given the doomerism in the world today, my thirst for succinct escapism was quenched, and I had a few good laughs. Job adequately done as far as I'm concerned. This would be rated higher if not for the soundtrack, which completely baffled me.Remember when "Thor: Ragnarok" opened with Led Zeppelin? I thought that was a novel change of pace; it really set the tone and melded nicely with the character depicted as a rock god. "Love and Thunder" had a different take apparently, and it's stocked almost entirely with Guns and Roses. It is absolutely awful.

Many people were afraid of what this film would do: replace Chris Hemsworth with a female Thor, destroy the legacy of Marvel's greatest hits, foul the spring of superhero purity and so on and so on. It's good that Waititi didn't give a rat's behind about anything and just made an entertaining film instead! If you liked Ragnarök, you will probably like this one, too.It's not all perfect, though. The first half an hour felt like a long exposition on an amateur theater stage. The next half of hour seemed like every friend of Taika's showed up for a cameo and a free lunch. The film never takes itself seriously, which is either good or bad, depending on your expectations. Also, it felt like a lot of stuff was crammed into one hour and a half and maybe a two hour movie wouldn't have been so... staccato.Yet the pros are stronger than the cons: Christian Bale did great with the few scenes where he got to act, there was a lot of humor and the Guns'n'Roses theme of the film helped a lot with the heroic battle scenes. Hemsworth's charisma was at full strength and even Natalie Portman's character, usually a filler with little agency, was interesting and fun. Too bad about Sif, who had like two scenes in the entire film and didn't leave it intact.Bottom line: a godly rock'n'roll extravaganza, bordering on parody, but entertaining. Just don't try to take it seriously.

ipc-title__text: It seems that during the past decade or so . . .
Unfunny to me, but doesn't deserve the panning
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Thor reunites with Jane Foster.This is an okay Marvel adventure that for me is not as bad as people say, but it had the potential to be so much better.As a story I think it starts and finishes very well with some good emotion, comedy and moments for several characters. However, what happens in between, particularly the humour I found to be very hit and miss. I do appreciate though that humour is in the eye of the beholder and others may find that it works.There is one concept associated with the Jane Foster character that was a great idea and the most serious aspect of the plot. Having this in a screenplay that tries to be mostly funny could have worked had the comedy been better, however for me the jokes are not strong enough to pull it off.The funniest parts involve the Guardians of the Galaxy characters interacting with Thor. From then on it relies exchanges between Thor, Valkarie and Jane to entertain. The actors do a great job with the lines, but I don't think the banter is funny or witty enough during the majority of the scenes.The scene involving Zeus is not overly bad, but again I didn't find the material good enough to be played as much for laughs as it is. Personally I think they should have done it as a suspenseful dramatic sequence, with light elements of humour and have the heroes emerge triumphantly to the same piece of music.Christian Bale's performance is a big positive and he brings to life one of the better MCU baddies. Chris Hemsworth leads it very well. Natalie Portman is good and so is Tessa Thompson.As you would expect from a Disney product, the visuals are quite spectacular, but for me scenes of superheroes battling various computer generated monsters all blend into one these days. There is a memorable sequence involving children in battle that is the best moment of spectacle for me.

I saw in IMAX a few hours ago which was mostly great, the action is top notch, surprising amount of comedy, along with so so writing although Christian Bale is one of the best things about the movie! Very enjoyable Thor despite anything Love and Thunder is epically entertaining should be praised a fair amount. Well directed fun Marvel experience that has the right elements a bulk of the time! Has an amazing soundtrack that flows well with everything especially the glossy colorful scenery. I understand the hate as well but there's a lot to enjoy.

This review will come off as very negative, but I had a decent time, laughed a lot, and was fairly entertained. As a big-time MCU fan though, Love and Thunder is highly disappointing, even more so for an OG Avenger.For reference, I loved all of the previous Thor movies. Many people view the first two as bottom tier MCU but I think they're beastly and beautiful in a Shakespearian way, while also being funny and visually stunning. Then they went in a new direction with Ragnarok, and I was completely on board. I enjoyed the infusion of style and almost all of the humor works.Love and Thunder goes so far past Ragnarok in every way. So much of it doesn't work for me. So much of the humor is predictable and goofy, to the point of bordering on cartoonish. And there isn't nearly enough serious to balance out the comedy. Combine that with some odd decisions later in the movie and... it kind of feels like they're turning Thor into a joke.And don't get me started on a repeated joke involving two goats that made me think of Jar Jar. I didn't laugh the first time or the 20 times after.Other than the comedy, a lot of Love and Thunder doesn't feel fully natural. Something feels off. The action scenes aren't memorable. By comparison, Ragnarok has multiple action scenes that make my jaw drop. There are some beautiful shots, but not nearly as often as the artwork in the previous ones.But my biggest disappointment is the villain. I don't watch trailers and didn't know Christian Bale is in this movie. He is my favorite actor ever, and has been for the last 15 years. Even with all the amazing talent in this remarkable MCU cast list, IMO Bale stands out above them all. I was ecstatic...Until I realized he's barely in the movie. He gives a great performance, but the script does not flesh him out, does not explore his character, and in effect, turns him into another forgettable MCU villain. Wasting Bale like this is a horrendous decision...Especially after an amazing opening scene that made me think this movie might be on a different level. I can only imagine what could have been if 40% of the movie was dedicated to that character. I can only imagine how amazing it would have been if they treated the God Butcher like The Dark Knight treated Joker.Why couldn't they balance out the serious and the funny? A good example: Guardians 2 is so funny and can get pretty goofy, but it has tons of serious and emotionally powerful scenes. Another example: Deadpool 2 is primarily a comedy but has SO many emotional moments, some to the point of tears.IMO, Love and Thunder doesn't come close to the last two MCU movies (Multiverse of Madness and No Way Home). As it stands today, this is bottom 3 in the MCU for me.EDIT: I decided to give this another shot. Sometimes it's easier the second time without the hype and knowing what to expect. But I felt pretty much the same. I enjoyed a lot of it, but the stuff I disliked bothered me just as much.The two things that stood out to me the second time around, Bale's performance is amazing and they are idiots for underutilizing him. And the goats are the single worst thing in the entire MCU. Changing rating from 6 to 5 stars. (2 viewings, opening Thursday IMAX 7/7/2022, IMAX 7/20/2022)

"Thor: Ragnarok" is, for me, one of the highlights of the MCU so far. The broadest comedy of the series and almost a reinterpretation of the character of Thor that sticks to this day. So, anticipation was high for "Love and Thunder", perhaps too high, as having seen the film it's a 'like' rather than a 'love' for me.Having received a distress call from Lady Sif (Jamie Alexander), Thor (Chris Hemsworth) returns to New Asgard in time to intercept an attack from Gorr The God Butcher (Christian Bale). He is not alone though, as alongside Valkyrie (Tessa Thompson), Jane Foster (Natalie Portman) has taken the power of The Mighty Thor by reuniting the shattered Mjolnir. Though they repel Gorr's attack, his minions kidnap the children of the town forcing the three heroes to begin an assault, but not before they look to the other gods for assistance.For me, the problem wasn't too much humour, or too weak humour. I thought that Christian Bale's Gorr was a compelling villain and like many MCU antagonists was justified in his rationale. I liked the performances, even some of the ones that people have found controversial, such as Russell Crowe's Zeus. I thought the film looked excellent and the transitions into the black and white sections were great. I think my problem was that it skirted over a bunch of ideas without ever going deep enough on any of them, particularly when some of them have been anticipated for a while. Asguardians of the Galaxy was fun whilst it lasts, but over before the film really starts. The kingdom of the gods, again amusing, but lacking in cameos we might have expected (Khonshu?) and really not much more than a way of padding the film out. Even Jane Foster's Mighty Thor isn't in the film enough to be explored properly. I appreciate that not all actors are willing to do nothing except play their Marvel characters, but I'd have preferred two separate films, one for the adventures of Thor with the GOTG and another full film for Jane to become accustomed to her powers, then have them reconnect. I'd also have liked slightly fewer call backs, the attempt to recapture the Immigrant song moment is overdone, as are the returns for the acting troop.Again, I don't think that this is the disaster that some other reviewers have made it out to be but it's certainly not all I hoped it would be.

ipc-title__text: "Thor: Love and Thunder" does not innovate and follows the studio's usual structure and formula and the feeling is of wasted potential with the themes and characters
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Taika Waititi is once again in charge of the production, bringing his comedic approach, half parody and half sketch, which transforms Thor into a kind of crazy Flash Gordon. Many critics and a good portion of the public really liked what Waititi did in "Ragnarok", presenting us with a pastel space opera bursting with color, rock, humor and lots of action. Unfortunately, the sequel fails to reach the same level of quality and fun as the previous film. The film's main problem is that the plot has a lot to deal with in its two hours or so of projection. And it is precisely this ambition of wanting to deal with so many materials at the same time that becomes a double-edged sword for the film. Thor, Jane and Gorr have their own narrative arcs (with Jane and Gorr's being particularly interesting) that share the screen with King Valkyrie dictating the future of New Asgard, with the typical New Asgard gags and with the usual expansion of the Marvel Cinematic Universe. It's all very good, but the narrative has difficulty balancing all of this - and the production having four editors working on the film in the editing room didn't help.One of the negative aspects of the work begins with the Guardians of the Galaxy. In terms of continuity in the MCU, it's strange that the group of heroes is basically a footnote in the film. It would be genuinely fun to have an adventure between them and Thor, especially in regards to the chemistry between Hemsworth and Chris Pratt. However, considering the salary of some actors, the script that is already bloated without the group's participation and even the work to reconcile the schedules of so many artists, it is possible to understand in terms of production why the Guardians' participation is quick. But the main problem with the sequence is the fact that it is only the first of many isolated blocks of the film, with Taika structuring the narrative in a fragmented way. We have the block in New Asgard, then in the pantheon of gods, later in the Shadow Dimension and so on. It is a script full of "mini-adventures", which are types of sketches, all disjointed and poorly connected.The director is unable to explore the different scenarios in depth as he had done on Sakaar in the previous feature. Take, for example, that whole sequence with the gods, where the full potential of a truly crazy nucleus is restricted to a discussion between Thor and Zeus (Russell Crowe), with the Greek god doing some dances and the Asgardian team defeating some soldiers without expression. The New Zealand director's total lack of creativity is unbelievable, summing up his cinematic approach to showing Thor without clothes and placing Crowe in a totally embarrassing role. The scenes in New Asgard, despite being fun with the Disneyland thing, follow a similar path, little exploring society or any aspect of the people of Asgard so that there is more time for the play with special appearances by Matt Damon, Luke Hemsworth, Sam Neill and Melissa McCarthy. Even the dramatic segment of Jane Foster's (Natalie Portman) return is handled with an irritatingly superficial narrative economy, problematizing the issue of cancer in just four scenes. There is no time for anything in this film, for the characters to be developed, for the adventure to breathe and for all these space scenarios to be thoroughly enjoyed.The second problem is the way the narrative makes transitions between adventure blocks. Taika simply has the characters travel left and right through their weapons, demonstrating an immense laziness to build a truly organic story. There is an obvious sloppiness in the conduct of plots and the use of certain characters in the work, such as the exclusion of Valkyrie (Tessa Thompson) from the final act, with the character being completely unnecessary and underused throughout the production, and also in the way Gorr is used as an antagonist. The script uses the Butcher of the Gods in the worst way that an antagonist can be developed: he is there more to move the plot than to be a counterpoint to the hero, so much so that we rarely see Gorr and Thor have any kind of interesting dialogue with each other. It's a shame, because the god slayer is a conceptually interesting character, far from being Manichaean and Bale, despite some occasional histrionics, is really committed to the role, even giving more dimension and nuanced empathy than he received from the script. There is a sequence that sums up why Gorr doesn't work in the film: when the villain makes that trap to catch the Stormbreaker, Waititi's direction is very efficient in creating a macabre atmosphere at the character's entrance, accompanied by wonderful monochromatic photography, a soundtrack sinister and a Bale committed to the character's psychopathy, and then Thor makes a joke about a dentist. It's so anticlimactic, it completely breaks the construction of the scene and, worse, it takes Gorr's threat off the table.Just like all the scenes with the villain, we never feel any real threat coming from the villain, disappointing everyone who follows the character in the comics, to the detriment of the absurd need to try to insert jokes every five minutes into the script. There is no weight in the threat of the villain, nor in the dramas (see how much drama could have been extracted from the plot involving terminal cancer). All of this is broken with a joke, not always as well inserted as in "Ragnarok". This time, the jokes seem to be inserted in an inorganic and forced way, it is as if "Ragnarok", praised by many, was written again with much more exaggerations in all aspects, especially in narrative convenience and humor, which this time does not work so well. You see: the joke with the goats screaming is funny the first and second time, but it gets diluted when done for the thousandth time. It's as if the script doesn't know when to stop and loses control as the plot progresses."Thor: Love and Thunder" will receive a lot of criticism because of the humor, but the comedy is not a problem as a proposal. The potential of the work is, in fact, very high, and could have been an even more insane version of what we saw in "Ragnarok" . The criticism lies in the lack of creativity of Taika Waititi, and also of co-screenwriter Jennifer Kaytin Robinson, in the narrative construction and cinematic approach. Waititi even gave interviews saying that the film was the craziest he had ever made and that he didn't it shouldn't have even been made. Where was all this madness? The action scenes are mostly generic, like the sequences on the streets of New Asgard and in the center of the gods, where the heroes defeat faceless armies, or the clashes with the Gorr himself that doesn't have any inventive choreography beyond the clash of weapons. There are some interesting visual ideas, like Mjolnir shattering, the Thors fighting together, the army of children taken from the best children's films, and, of course, all the block in Dimension of Shadows, but these are sparse moments and which, honestly, seem more like a merit of the technical team than staging ideas or any minimally memorable set-piece from the direction. It is, in fact, a creative and noteworthy film in terms of production design, but the impression given is that the director and screenwriter was working with a lot of freedom due to the prestige achieved previously, and does this work on autopilot to offer some kind of brand or expressiveness that we saw in his previous productions. After the film's release, Waititi said that he only made the Thor films for the money and that he had never read any Thor comics as a child before making the first film. Perhaps this explains the feeling of sloppiness when we see this production.Regarding the story itself, "Thor: Love and Thunder" does not innovate and follows the studio's usual structure and formula. However, there is one plot point that proves to be useless and irrelevant to the overall narrative, being merely a marketing strategy to sell the upcoming film. The main objective of the protagonists is not fulfilled in this deviation and something that was supposed to be essential ends up becoming a kind of MacGuffin in the third act. The action set piece is easily forgettable and Russell Crowe's interpretation becomes an unbearable caricature, using an accent so absurd that it ends up removing all seriousness from his character, damaging an eventual powerful presence in future works. Finally, the action of "Thor: Love and Thunder" meets the minimum requirements. The black and white sequence takes the trophy, the first act with the "Guardians of the Galaxy" brings good levels of entertainment, but everything involving generic CGI monsters born from shadows... I understand the intention of trying to save time and money with "remains" of visual effects, hiding the imperfections in the darkness of the night - a well-known workaround - but, unfortunately, most of these scenes become a sometimes-incomprehensible mix of CGI, where it becomes difficult to understand what is really happening.Despite all the problems, the film has its funny moments, like the screaming goats and Jane looking for a catchphrase, and there are several interesting themes regarding mortality, fatherhood, romance and purpose that fill the dramatic arc of a character who becomes made him truly curious behind the jokes. The script is smart in subverting some things, from Gorr's dilemma, the sacrifice of Mighty Thor and a truly beautiful and cute ending with the protagonist becoming a big daddy. In the end, phase 4 is heading towards being the least connected phase between MCU productions, whether in theaters or on Disney Plus, where at this moment the focus is on leaving the darker and mystical side of "Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness " aside to focus on the more colorful, playful and flashy side of "Thor: Love and Thunder".

ipc-title__text: Not even mad- just sad and disappointed I didn't like this more

ipc-html-content-inner-div: Of ALL the Trek movies, this had to pay homage to...Star Trek V?! Now, yeah, V has kinda grown on me over the years and it's definitely no longer the worst one. But still, Thor: Love and Thunder is helluva lot better.In a rare occurrence, the Thor quadrilogy joins both the Spider-Man Home Movies and the Mission: Impossible franchise as the few series that gets progressively better with each chapter. About half-way through this, I thought I liked Ragnarok more. That all changed in the highly enjoyable final act.Thor is BACK, baby. Well, from his Dad-Bod ways and as he's helping out the happy underdogs across the universe, he discovers both Love and Thunderous rage from a God-Butcher. Pray Thor makes it out of this one.The funny thing about this movie that reunites Chris Hemsworth with Natalie Portman: I wasn't 100% looking forward to that reunion prior to starting this adventure-comedy. Truthfully, she is NOT one of my favorite actresses and I'll get right to the point: She practically steals Thor's Thunder throughout this film. She was spectacular and my favorite part of this movie. And this may be my favorite role for her.Now, that said, I thoroughly enjoyed Chris Hemsworth - he was having a ball and it shows he really enjoys entertaining the masses as the title character. The rest of the cast was equally awesome, except, well, The Bland-Batman.I mean, Christian Bale as the Baddie. He was fine, but really uneven. He almost acted like the Joker/Riddler at some moments and then menacingly quiet and composed the next. And back and forth he went. Unfortunately, he was never likable enough to gain ANY sympathy from me - even though his character had well-defined motivation and depth.While this had a KILLER soundtrack, was absolutely hilarious and is technically better than Ragnarok, it's not by much and it's a perfect companion to that third one. Needless to say, if you loved Ragnarok, this will have the same impact for you. And you might as well forget those first two Thors. Just stick with the two best: Ragnarok & Love & Thunder.***Final Thoughts: I HATE that Marvel makes us stay through the credits. Literally, it's my least favorite part of the MCU. BUT, every once in a while, an MCU chapter will change my mind, albeit temporarily. You simply MUST stay through to the very last few seconds. I liked the first one pretty well and LOVED the last one.

ipc-title__text: Failed attempt to make a Thor edition of Spaceballs
ipc-html-content-inner-div: There are movie series, and there are parodies of movie series, and somewhere in between those is Thor: Love and Thunder, which attempts to be both a big budget superhero movie and a silly comedy that hits somewhere between the Muppets and lesser Mel Brooks.A lot of the very silly humor is strained, with Thor often being almost absurdly dumb, although I never tired of the screaming goats gags. To make it worse, this broad, silly humor does battle against serious issues like cancer and child death.Parts of the movie work, like a child-army action scene in the last section, but attempting to make a movie that is as exciting as Black Panther, as funny as Blazing Saddles, and as touching as A Star is Born was doomed to fail.Director Waititi managed to pull off impressive tonal shifts in Jojo Rabbit so perhaps he thought he was up to creating this Turducken. But there was serious intent behind that movie and this is just a popcorn flick with an everything-but-the-kitchen-sink approach.Still, it's got some good action, Natalie Portman manages to pull off the combo of pathos and badassery Waititi so desperately wanted, Russell Crowe is genuinely funny (who knew), and if you like superhero movies you might as well go ahead and watch it. Just don't expect too much.

ipc-title__text: The pendulum has swung too far the other way
ipc-html-content-inner-div: The Thor movies can't seem to get the balance right. Thor was serious, Thor 2 was too serious. Thor: Ragnarok was goofy, and Thor: Love and Thunder is too goofy. It feels like kids wrote the screenplay. Its tone is wildly inconsistent, the story doesn't make a lot of sense, and they maybe should have cut a joke or two instead of leaving in everything every writer submitted. When screaming goats are the funniest thing about your film, you should probably try some rewrites. I did smirk a few times, and Christian Bale really puts some effort into his character, but this Thor: Love and Thunder mostly fell flat for me.

ipc-title__text: Thorpool: Thor keeps losing more things he loves

ipc-html-content-inner-div: This period of history will be remembered by those who survive it as a time when the Rule Book was thrown out the window and chaos reigned. A hundred years ago, monopoly laws prevented the concentration of media in corporate hands. Beach movies in the 1960s always included at least one lonely millionaire wandering around in the cast -- lonely because he owned a TV station or radio station or newspaper and could only sell it to another lone millionaire. The Clinton era changed that. Four conglomerates today own 99% of the western media. Disney buying Marvel was arguably the coup de grace. You now have companies creating markets for content rather than content for markets. Sometimes it works (WANDAVISION). Sometimes it does not. (THOR LOVE & THUNDER). But it is now their game. The rest of us have become merely players. ((Designated "IMDb Top Reviewer." Please check out my list "167+ Nearly-Perfect Movies (with the occasional Anime or TV miniseries) you can/should see again and again (1932 to the present))

ipc-title__text: Pricey Cartoon Not Worth Your Time - Thor: Love and Thunder
ipc-html-content-inner-div: If this had been the cartoon movie it should have been, I would have given it four, and maybe even five stars. But actors acting like cartoon characters do nothing but make the final product.....cartoonish. A marvel comic book from the 60s is more entertaining than this film. Every sequence is overdone; every line of dialogue is painful to listen to. Everything is a joke, so no one takes the plot seriously. I felt pretty much the same about the original film, but it was certainly much better than this exercise in the obvious. I could not recommend that anyone spend their hard-earned money on stuff you could see on TV reruns of cartoons. Pass on this one.

ipc-title__text: Not as good as the 1st movie.

ipc-html-content-inner-div: An empty, with special effects overloaded dose of - nothing. I just can imagine that the paychecks are enough compensation for the actors to be involved in such a point- and artless mess. The whole movie looks like all involved (writers, director, actors, production crew) worked on auto-pilot and half-asleep. Terrible empty, this is and with every movie it just gets worse.

Greetings from Lithuania.I kinda forced myself into watching "Thor: Love and Thunder" - i enjoyed the first one back in the day, second was awful but third one was very funny one. And yet i hardly remember when was the last time i actually enjoyed Marvel movie. And "Love and Thunder" did not change that unfortunately - this is simply a bad movie.First, its simply boring, uninvolving and doesn't make any sense. Like humor for example is so dumb that "Dumb & Dumber" feels like "Godfather" in comparison. And yet at the same time there are running themes about death of children and cancer of last stage. I mean what? The villain played by Christian Bale was boring as well - its not the fault of the great actor and besides of interesting make up it was nothing to see there. And for the story - i mean what story?Overall, "Thor: Love and Thunder" is a highly dissapointing and just plaid bad movie. Its highly all over the place and one of those movies were watching it you just feel that no one in from of the camera did not care. This goes as well for the director.

ipc-title__text: Taika Waititi's Worst Film To Date
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Taking all that was good & refreshing about Ragnarok and overcooking it to the point where all of the good stuff is rendered useless, the 29th instalment in the Marvel Cinematic Universe has its priorities all over the place and has no idea whatsoever about what made the previous entry such a vibrant cosmic delight. The story does have a heart but it is buried beneath all the vapid goofiness that's overdone to the point of annoyance.Co-written & directed by Taika Waititi (Hunt for the Wilderpeople & Jojo Rabbit), Thor: Love and Thunder isn't devoid of the flavours that made its predecessor work but the balance is certainly missing this time around. The film looks & feels like its own parody, for Waititi here overdoses on his own style and fails to properly handle the drama, romance & comedy elements. The premise is promising but when it comes to execution, it is lacking in restraint & consistency.For a $250 million production, the imagery & visual effects look as underdeveloped as they are uninspiring. Editing focuses on all the wrong stuff here as the film could've done more with less Korg, less eccentricity, less quips and certainly more emphasis on developing the dramatic bits. Every now n then, it does strike a heartfelt chord but with the narrative being a tonal nightmare, the effectiveness of those moments is either vastly diminished or wholly nullified by the silliness on display.Overall, Thor: Love and Thunder isn't entirely the disaster that many are calling it to be but it is definitely a step down in quality & coherence that the last chapter exuded in spades. The story isn't without its merits but they are few n far between. Enormously underwhelming & downright forgettable, the film showcases Taika Waititi's worst tendencies as a storyteller, certainly ranks amongst his weakest directorial efforts, and suffers from problems of its own makings. In short, Marvel Studios' latest is as empty as it is cringe.

Thor: Love and Thunder is a vast improvement on the previous entry. Ragnorak was a poor film so I felt like this one needed to be a step up.The absolute highlight of the movie was the performance of Christian Bale. He was fantastic, adding much needed depth and acting quality to the show.Chris Hemsworth was his standard self and it was nice to have Portman back but she felt like the character misfit the movie.The action sequences and special effects are good enough but they are monotonous and too much of a crutch for the plot (as will ALL superhero films at the moment).Love etc rebuilds a little of the magic of Thor but has a long way too go to return it to its lofty origins :)

This latest addition of the Thor franchise sees several key returning characters such as Natalie Portman (Jane Foster) playing a large role as her character is given more depth.After the greatness and success of Thor Ragnarok, it would be quite difficult to top that, and Thor: Love and Thunder does not reach the heights of Ragnarok nor really comes close.A five year delay (due to covid-19) is quite something and there was most definitely a lot of hype surrounding this film. However it feels somewhat flat.There are decent moments of action and good chemistry but it feels a little too comical and trying too hard to be funny. Whereas Ragnarok was naturally funny and engaging all the way through. The tone of this film should have been a little more serious, where it seems like it was a copy of Ragnarok.Christian Bale delivers a great villain but feels a little wasted. The other leads are still great but considering this is the fourth film, the freshness is gone. The brief scenes of the Guardians of the Galaxy was a welcome sight but it was very brief that by the end of the film, we completely forget about it and it felt almost pointless.Thor Ragnarok isn't terrible but it isn't groundbreaking and somewhat of a letdown considering the hype it had.

The Gods of Chore desecrate with poor humour, this must surely be, a Marvel lampooner, while a dark necromancer, a metaphorical cancer, wages war with his shady black tumours. There's a Crowe God takes us to new lows, waffles along with ridiculous prose, but he isn't alone, most of this makes you moan, you're relieved when it gets to the close.Taika Waititi fails to pull another Jo Jo Rabbit out of his increasingly emptying bag, in a film that leaves you groaning and squirming, from the ridiculous to the inept, from the absurd to the disengaging and detaching disconnect. Not sure why Christian Bale presents as Marilyn Manson but it's probably the only thing that works, although possibly not as intended.

Thor has to do battle with new enemy Gorr (Christian Bale) who goes mad when his daughter dies and acquiring the weapon, the necrosword, which can destroy all gods, he sets out to do just that.Whilst Thor: Ragnarok laced its adventures with a good deal of enjoyable humour, this is really more of a comedy, and not a particularly good one at that, laced with some largely unexciting set pieces. The difficulty is that the comedy bounces around familiar ideas about the hammer vs the axe, Thor being a klutz, Korg being dry and witty etc but nothing new and indeed there are long scenes of plain waffle. The renewed romance between Thor and Jane is dull and not remotely touching and Portman's character including her rather odd reason for returning seems poorly written. There are a couple of good action set pieces and Russell Crowe as Zeus is fun, but overall this is just nonsensical, silly and a big disappointment after Ragnarok.

There is such a word in my native language. "Bambili"
After the 3rd movie,Thor became "Bambili". Visually it was a great movie, the script and the dialogues trying to be funny were bad. Gorr was great, his motivation was great too. Christan Bale gave a great performance. The first half of the movie tries to be funny, it's ridiculous, it's bad, but I like the the second half. I only laughed at a few scenes. Overall I didn't like the movie. The goats were not funny at all, they were constantly shouting. Is this funny? Yes, it was at first scene but unnecessary to show it 145 times. It's like a parody movie. And this scene... Korg. Didn't he have a mother in the previous movie? Does he have 2 fathers now ? What and Why ? What are you trying to do ? Somebody force you for this ? Come on. . .Anyway, Christan Bale was perfect.The movie was kind of enjoyable but not good movie.By the way Natalie was ok.

ipc-title__text: YOU GOT YOUR ZANY COMEDY IN MY MCU FILM...!
ipc-html-content-inner-div: The latest MCU film starring Chris Hemsworth as the God of Thunder. Hemsworth has dropped the weight he had put on in Endgame but gained more in the form of the Guardians of the Galaxy who he's hitched a ride with to pass the time having adventures with but things are at a lull for him as he contemplates retirement but then Gorr: the God Butcher, Christian Bale, is wrecking havoc across the galaxy murdering deities in an effort to extract revenge on higher beings who let him down when his daughter perished from thirst even though his prayers were loud & often. Meanwhile back on Earth, Thor's ex, returning champ Natalie Portman (not seen since The Dark World), is suffering from stage 4 cancer & she's at the end of her rope until she decides to make a trip to New Asgard for a cure which comes in the form of a reconstituted Mjolnir & her becoming the Mighty Thor which sends main Thor into a tizzy since he wants his woman back (& his hammer as well). What's a god to do when his plate is full? Taika Waititi is back (after directing Ragnarok) bringing oodles of his absurdist humor & kitchy visuals (a lot of it reminded me of 1980's Flash Gordon which I think Waititi is making a new animated version of) to bear w/the jokes & gags coming a mile a minute (just by the sheer volume not all of them hit the bullseye) & w/a game cast even the stingiest of Marvel fans will give up a smile.

ipc-title__text: Another great Taika Waititi MCU flick
Why is everyone whining, this was hilariously epic and probably the best superhero writing I've seen in a long time.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Sure it was cheese, but it was Pule cheese, the best there is. I'm shocked how many reviewers can't count past one, because production value alone is worth at least five stars. I really wasn't expecting much with all the negativity, but wow was I pleasantly surprised! Just when I thought the industry ran out of superhero writing ideas, this little gem comes along, and we were all in tears laughing so hard. Even the story-telling narration was a brilliant touch and elevated the plot and the laughs. The entire screenplay had everything and something for everyone. The humor, the romance, family dynamics, and so on, everything imo was perfection. All casting and performances were outstanding. The almost 2 hour runtime flew by with the excellent pacing. The set designs, S/VFX and cinematography were amazing. The score and soundtrack were spot-on. I can't wait to see this one again, as it's now one of my favorite superhero films of all time. If you haven't seen it, ignore the whiners, this is one heck of a fun, entertaining and hilarious popcorn flick. It's a 9.5 rounded up to a perfect 10/10 from me.

"Thor: Love and Thunder" is an Action - Comedy movie and the fourth movie of the Thor franchise in which we watch Thor, Valkyrie and Jane Foster trying to stop Gorr the God Butcher who wants to vanish all the gods.I enjoyed this movie very much because it had plenty of action that was well combined with funny moments. There were also some dramatic moments that changed the plot and the concept of the movie, something that I did not expect and it was a nice surprise. The direction which was made by Taika Waititi was very good for one more time and he did an excellent job on the way that he presented the evolution of the story after the events of Endgame. The interpretations of Chris Hemsworth who played as Thor, Christian Bale who played as Gorr, Natalie Portman who played as Jane Foster and Tessa Thompson who played as King Valkyrie. Another interpretation that has to be mentioned was Russell Crowe's who played as Zeus. All in all, I have to say that "Thor: Love and Thunder" is a nice movie and I highly recommend everyone to watch it.

Someone with a sword that can kill Gods goes on a vengeance binge to the navel of the Universe to destroy all the gods in one fell swoop - or something to that effect - unless the increasingly clownish heroes of the MCU can stop him. The film is one long series of extravagant images, childish jokes, and goofy sight-gags, to the point of almost being a witless parody of the worst excesses of the genre. The CGI is technically impressive but artistically unimaginative (an exception being the B/W sequence), the story is dull and derivative, the A-list cast is stuck delivering a D-list script that would have been at home in a 1970's Saturday morning cartoon, the climatic fight is cretinous (but not unexpected from a production company that once gave the world the Mickey Mouse Club) and the maudlin ending risible. I forced myself to finish the film (mostly watching with one eye and 1/10 of my brain (which was still more than needed)). The film is not just awful, its annoyingly and irritatingly awful but, sadly, it still made money, so I'll save a 1/10 score for the inevitable next installment.

ipc-title__text: Bad Writing, Awful Jokes & Destroying Thor's Legacy
Taika Waititi nailed another fun Thor adventure in a stylish action packed sequel.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: 5 out of 5 stars.Thor: Love and Thunder is an awesome superhero sequel which Taika Waititi brought his style and energetic direction that is fun and action packed.The film has plenty of action sequences throughout. Taking Thor, Valkyrie, and Almighty Thor who is Jane Foster (Natalie Portman) going on a space adventure to stop Gorr the God Butcher (Christian Bale) who is hellbent on killing all gods.The plot is great. It covers theme of finding self purpose, love, and meaning. The film does have a lighthearted theme. Even the opening sequence of showing Gorr and why he became the way he is and his motive for killing all gods was a neat addition of giving some emotional depth to the characters. Same goes for Thor who is trying to discover himself as well when he starts off with some space missions with Guardians of the Galaxy which they were trying to get him to go on his own.The film is fast paced and moves quick from one set piece to another. The visual effects are colorful and awesome. The cast ensemble is great. Christian Bale delivered a great villain performance and stands out compared to other villains with his horrifying and creepy performance.The film does have some fun and dumb humor just like Ragnarok from Taika Waititi script which the actors seemed to be having fun with improvising and adding a little humor every now and then.Michael Giacchino music score is also a great addition to the Thor film as well. The film has two scenes in the mid and post credits which was worth it to see where it can go next.Thor Love and Thunder is a fun action packed adventure that shines and stands out as a 80s rock em up marvel adventure.

ipc-title__text: Well, We Have Some More Thor
A solid story that touches on themes of grief and loss that finds itself suffocated by directorial excess and an overly jokey tone
ipc-html-content-inner-div: While working alongside the Guardians of the Galaxy, Thor (Chris Hemsworth) and his companion Korg (Taika Waititi) part ways with the Guardians after learning of a distress signal from his Asgardian comrade Sif (Jamie Alexander). As Thor comes to Sif's aid he learns someone known as Gorr The God Butcher (Christian Bale) has been murdering the various Gods throughout the universe using the Necrosword and now has his sights set on New Asgard on Earth. Once there Thor fends off Gorr's shadow monsters alongside New Asgard leader Valkyrie (Tessa Thompson) and is met by surprise when he learns Jane Foster (Natalie Portman) now wields Mjolnir which unbeknownst to Thor was a last resort by Jane to stave off her aggressive cancer. When Gorr manages to abduct the Asgardian children, Thor, Jane, Valkyrie, and Korg team up and set out to find help from the other Gods and stop Gorr's rampage.Shortly after the enthusiastic reeception and box office success of Thor: Ragnarok, Taika Waititi and Marvel executives reunited on a greenlit fourth Thor movie. Many of the cast were interested in returning including star Chris Hemsworth who credited Waititi with revitalizing the character after initially growing exhausted with the role. From a business standpoint it just makes sense to give Waititi another go at Thor given that Ragnarok was the highest grossing and best reviewed film in the series, but while Ragnarok struck the balance between its humor and taking its story reasonably seriously, Love and Thunder stumbles hard with its tone often feeling at odds with its thematic material.If there's one thing I think many people will agree on, it's in Christian Bale's performance as Gorr The God Butcher in that it's probably the best villain we've seen for a standalone Thor movie yet (keep in mind Loki didn't go full force until the first Avengers film). The opening sequence where we're introduced to Gorr traversing a desolate wasteland with his daughter who dies of starvation and thirst in his arms only for Gorr himself to find the God he worshipped is indifferent to his suffering makes him a sympathetic villain and his transformation through the usage of the Necrosword makes him an intimidating villain with a lot of depth. In many ways it reminded me of a better version of villains like Ronan the Accuser or Malekith who had very similar motivations but were paper thin in comparison to Gorr.Unfortunately, that's where we have to transition to the weak points of the movie, of which there are many. Right out of the gate the movie has an abrupt tonal shift from the ending of the scene where we see Gorr's corruption to a montage sequence where Taika Waititi's Korg narrates a heavily abridged version of Thor's life glibly discussing character deaths in a rather offhanded way which transitions to Thor still with the Guardians of the Galaxy who are really only an extended cameo. Despite the lingering threat of Gorr the movie overplays its comedy to an obnoxious degree with Korg now having warn out his goodwill from his restrained usage in Ragnarok to terribly running gags about a pair of screaming goats Thor uses as transport who aren't funny and just annoying. Jane Foster is given a richer role than previous incarnations as she's not only taken on a separate mantle as Thor but is battling cancer but rather than explore Jane and Thor's relationship regarding either of those two points, the movie thinks it'd be more interesting to see yet another terrible running gag of Thor's weapons acting like his ex-girlfriend and currently girlfriend with Stormbreak now jealous of Thor's hangups with Mjolnir now loyal to Jane in what's less a running gag and more a limping gag. The sad thing is, if you look at the nuts and bolts of the story it's pretty solid. The main problem that takes the movie down is in the fact is afraid to let our characters have any stretch of pathos that isn't interrupted by a stupid joke. But there are at least a few scenes that hit emotional resonance such as the ending.Thor: Love and Thunder has all the right elements and a really good villain and performance from Christian Bale, but the overly jokey tone makes Love and Thunder very much the Yin to Ragnarok's Yang. With that said: I don't think this is a worse movie than Thor: The Dark World because I will remember Love and Thunder (both good points and bad) but I still struggle to remember The Dark World. It has some issues that weigh it down to being the weakest Thor movie alongside The Dark World but both movies aren't great just for different reasons.

ipc-title__text: Thor's latest outing is an easy if forgettable watch
ipc-html-content-inner-div: In 2017 Kiwi writer/director Taika Waititi changed the direction of the up until then po-faced Thor in surprising and commercially beneficial ways with the wild and inventive Thor: Ragnarok but proving once more that you can't always capture lightning (thunder?) in a bottle, Waititi's return to the solo Thor universe with Love and Thunder provides a carelessly fun few hours while also continuing Marvel's recent trend of feeling like a brand that is at present slightly aimless.With no surprise that Waititi and his main man Chris Hemsworth bring the same manic and off-kilter vibes to Love and Thunder that they delivered with Ragnarok, fans of the pairs first wild collaboration are sure to find much to enjoy this second time around with an abundance of insane characters (literally one that is a Bao Bun), colorful action and quirky humor but there's something a little off here that holds their newest venture back with tonal imbalances, a so-so story and a feeling of pointlessness all apparent in a relatively quickfire venture that at least never tries to outstay its welcome.Following the exploits of everyone's favourite Asgardian god as he gets back in shape and venture's around the known and unknown universe with The Guardians of the Galaxy, only to find his life upturned by the arrival of Christian Bale's Gorr the God Butcher and the return of Natalie Portman's Jane Foster, Love and Thunder has a lot of ground to cover through its runtime and Waititi never allows anything to linger too long in the memory and while there are some nice highlights with a trip to a city of the gods run by a fairly hilarious Russell Crowe as Zeus one such moment, there's also a feeling a lot of good material happens off screen with both Jane and Gorr's arcs in the film feeling they could've done with some screen-time and fleshing out.Portman's much-hyped return to the Thor world has some nice moments but her transformation into a weapon wielding god happens with fairly little build-up or time in the spotlight feeling like a missed opportunity while as good as he is (give this man a monologue to chew on any day of the week) there's a feeling like Bale could've had more too do as Gorr, a villain that could rival Thanos given the time to shine, Bale is having a blast going all out in his first foray into the Marvel universe after crossing over from the DC space but much like Foster's arc in the film there's a lot of Gorr's experiences and exploits that happen off-screen here, holding Gorr's first cinematic outing back from becoming an all-timer.At days end Love and Thunder is a film that many are going to love, while some will dislike it even more than Ragnarok's new directional take on the chiseled god but there's no denying there's an aimlessness happening here that even the most dedicated of Marvel fans couldn't deny with a sense Marvel needs to unveil its overall plans fairly quickly and Waititi to keep pushing himself as a director ensuring his style and mannerisms don't continue to dwindle.Final Say -A mindlessly enjoyable film with sporadic moments of brilliance that coasts by on its easy-going charm and charisma, Thor: Love and Thunder marks an intriguing period for its titular character and its brand name company as begin to wonder more than ever what the point of everything happening really is?3 rock babies out of 5For more reviews check out Jordan and Eddie (The Movie Guys)

ipc-title__text: I liked his new outfit, but this film hurt me.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Thor: Love And Thunder (2022) -Hello? Yes, I'd like this film to be remade please, without all of the nonsense and with Chris Hemsworth's real bottom. I mean who tuned in to see a CGI version? Surely it's a thing of beauty in its own right?Lose the stupid goat noises and the odd "quirky" jokes that were just for the sake of it and really focus on the fantastic story that this could have been.It even started daft.
