They took his recklessness too far and it certainly didn't seem like the comic book version of Thor that I was used to from his appearances in the X-Men collection.I liked the use of Korg narrating things throughout, but that was enough humour.The jokes in 'Thor: Ragnarok' (2017) worked because they weren't every two seconds and were appropriate to the storyline, but they seemed to have saturated this script or probably ad-libbed the dialogue in some sort of attempt to outdo the laughs of that previous instalment, which has ultimately ruined the whole thing and put me right off of Thor as a character. I realised recently that actually Liam Hemsworth is probably the better of the brothers having seen him in 'The Dressmaker' (2015), but watching this film definitely put me off his brother Chris, because he obviously agreed to take his greatest character in this ridiculous direction.I think that Chris and Taika Waititi need to part ways now before they ruin the franchise completely. The 'Guardians Of The Galaxy' (2014) part at the beginning was quite clearly to explain away the fact that the "Asgardians Of The Galaxy' film was never made and they had to show how Thor had moved on since leaving with them in 'Avengers: Endgame' (2019).Unfortunately it got too stupid and was far too busy with new and existing characters.And I am really very angry about this, because, as I've said, the story was such a great concept. Bringing back the gorgeous and talented Natalie Portman as Jane Foster+ and facing them off against 'Gorr The God Butcher', played superbly by Christian Bale, were class ideas.If this had been produced and directed in the same way that the other Marvel films had been, then I believe that it could have been one of the best stories in the series, but what they actually achieved (If you can call it an achievement) was a conglomeration of a kids adventure film, a bittersweet romance and a comedic farce all rolled into one. It really lost its way.I feel as I did with 'The Eternals' (2021) and 'Shang Chi' (2021), that this film was rushed out to keep the Marvel momentum going, but didn't have the thought or consideration put in to ensure it was worthy of the franchise. It was missing that final proof read and edit and it showed.I'm actually glad that my mother fell over and I had to take her to hospital on the night that I was supposed to see this film, because I'd be furious if I'd paid to see it.460.72/1000.

ipc-title__text: Typical Summer Superhero Action with a Nice Emotional Punch
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Reviewing this movie is made difficult with the subjective bias against the comedic formula that the screenplay uses incorporating The Guardians of the Galaxy characters for the first half of the movie. The plot unfolds with a slow opening of a tragic survival story and the introduction of a new menace threatening the universe. Then the story uses a juvenile-level narrative flashbacks and adds a romantic dimension along with the threatening menace which by the end of the movie becomes like Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness a strong redeeming climax that helps to greatly lift the overall assessment of the movie. For those unfamiliar with these characters, a number of well-known actors offer up some surprising, disguised performances, perhaps credit to their acting abilities and make-up, except for surprise appearance of Matt Damon (uncredited) whose presence is almost always impossible to disguise. In sum, Thor is an enjoyable, summer romp that does not break any new ground, but Chris Hemsworth makes great use of his light, comedic lines. Mostly tame, off-beat almost overly cute humor along with the typical fantasy action sequences describe this movie, but it is the relational moments that shine.

I sometimes feel like Taika Waititi is wasting his talents making MCU movies when he could be making great original content. But then he does make pretty good MCU movies, so maybe it would be a shame to miss out on those. 'Thor: Love and Thunder' wasn't quite as good as 'Thor: Ragnarok' for me, but it was still a decent watch.The film is once again very light-hearted. It is certainly going for laughs more than anything else. Consequently the tone is very safe and no one ever feels like they are in much genuine danger. Which is a shame because Christian Bale plays a particularly menacing (at least visually) villain.There are some fun cameos along the way as usual. The film is pretty well paced too. It doesn't really have a period which I would say dragged. If you enjoyed 'Ragnarok' then you are almost certainly going to have a good time with this one. 7/10.

ipc-title__text: First a joke, then futility, and finally some serious battle
How could you possibly waste Christian Bale?
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Yes, It is visually stunning, the screenplay is fast-paced, and it's good to see Thor and his compatriots back in action, but what it lacks is profundity or substance so to speak. Despite having one of the fiercest villains i.e. Gorr (The God Butcher) at your disposal, how could you possibly ruin it?I mean, you had a performer like Christian Bale to play this character yet still you decided to not give him sufficient screen space? And for what? To make him look like nothing but a trivial expansion in your cinematic universe? Why? What were you thinking? Look, I do appreciate what you guys have done with Thor or Dr. Jane Foster, or even with Valkyrie, but what you have done to Gorr is inexcusable, I will not forgive.Moreover, I saw many others had conveyed their disapproval regarding the tonality of the film which did lean more towards a lighter, less gritty route and I too happen to have the same complaint. Just try to imagine this being darker and more serious; things could have turned out a whole lot better, I guess.

ipc-title__text: Another Fun Popcorn Movie from the MCU
ipc-html-content-inner-div: The Thor series of movies were ones that I wasn't fully interested originally but have become my favorite of the original group of Avengers. This one also pulled my interest with the villain being Gorr and played by Christian Bale. This one I watched with Jaime as there are certain superhero films she will still watch.For this movie here, we are first introduced to Gorr as he is given the Necro Sword that allows him to kill gods. He goes about this hunt after dedicating his life to one that turned his back on him.Thor (Chris Hemsworth) is still hanging out with the Guardians of the Galaxy. They split ways here as Thor learns of Gorr, who is known as 'The God Butcher'. This pulls Thor to Earth. He goes to New Asgard where King Valkyrie (Tessa Thompson) is in power still. Korg (Taika Waititi) joins him.There is a wrinkle here that I picked up on from the subtitle, Love and Thunder. Jane Foster (Natalie Portman) has cancer. She is slowly dying and it feels like she is giving up the fight. Darcy (Kat Dennings) wants her to reach out to Thor, but things didn't end well and there is unresolved feelings.The two of them run into each other when Mjöllnir calls out to Jane. Thor has a big surprise from this as well. He might be a bit jealous. Thor enlists the aid of those that will join him to defeat this new threat that is killing gods and there are none that can escape his wrath.Now that I've recapped this movie, I did want to say that this another solid installment. What I noticed here is that this one is another dark take while also being whimsical. Jaime wasn't even entirely sure if she liked this one as it seems to be more comedy than others. I was looking for the best way to put this since The Dark World and Ragnarök also have dark elements too. This seems to be a thing with Thor movies. I should say that I like the comedy aspects as it made me laugh.Then back to the darker elements. Gorr is a great villain. I'm not familiar with the comics so I don't know about him as a villain. It is interesting since he uses a weapon called the Necro Sword that would be right out of video games I've played like Final Fantasy. I like that aspect. It also brings interesting powers. Gorr also kidnaps children. I never feel like they're truly in peril. I still like it.I'll then go over to the acting. Hemsworth is great as Thor. I like that this movie makes him a bit more human which is good. Bringing back Portman is good too. There is good heart and emotion there. I like Bale as the villain. He fits that role well. Thompson and Waititi are solid in their supporting roles. They're both great with the comedy. We also have cameos by Russell Crowe, Jaimie Alexander, Idris Elba, Chris Pratt, Dave Bautista, Karen Gillan, Sean Gunn, Dennings, Stellan Skarsgård, Luke Hemsworth, Matt Damon, Sam Neill, Melissa McCarthy and Ben Falcone. We also get the voices of Vin Diesel and Bradley Cooper as well.All that is left to go into would be with the filmmaking. This has good cinematography. There is good contrast between the place of the gods to the desert we first see Gorr and then even going to the shadow realm. There is a lot of CGI, but I come to expect that. This has Disney money so it looks good. We also get a heavy dose of Guns-n-Roses which I wasn't expecting with the soundtrack. This is worth a watch and one of the better movies during the Marvel Cinematic Universe for Phase 4.My Rating: 7 out of 10.

ipc-title__text: Funny as hell, but not as good as the first 3 Thor Films
ipc-html-content-inner-div: 'Thor: Love and Thunder" is, like most of the Marvel films since Iron Man died, only intermittently amusing, a bit wobbly in its storytelling, thin in its emotional impact and more geared toward spectacle than coherence. Thor's latest planet-skipping adventures are built around the party-rock atmosphere of several Guns N' Roses tracks, notably "Sweet Child o' Mine," but, alas, the song's refrain "Where do we go? Where do we go now? Where do we go?" is all too apt for the movie's directionless, make-it up as we go along style. Here are a lot of things I love about Waititi's approach to Thor, but my favorite is that they are now comedies. While "Ragnarok" was packed with jokes, I think "Love and Thunder" embraces the comedy aspect even more. The trailers let us know there would be plenty of laughs, but it also felt like it may try to be a bit more serious. Well, thankfully, that was the trailer, not the movie. "Love and Thunder" is listed as an action, adventure and comedy. What it actually is, is a comedy with some action and adventure. I laughed out loud so many times and just when you start feeling like things are getting serious, you get a perfectly timed gag and the tension is released. Often times when a movie is trying to be funny or full of action, the filmmakers tend to sacrifice story and emotion for spectacle. This is not the case with "Love and Thunder." Waititi understands in order to make the jokes land and the action hit, you have to care about what is happening. I don't want to give anything away, so I'll be vague here, but there is a rich story filled with love, wanting, loneliness, heartache and sorrow. These heavier elements create a story we're invested in as an audience, but it's balanced expertly with humor, adventure and plenty of spectacle. I cared about Thor, Jane and even Christian Bale's Gorr. Waititi and his team created relatable characters, strong storylines and plenty of drama. We've had a few opportunities to see this, but Hemsworth is a brilliant comedic actor. His timing and delivery are pitch-perfect and make for an egocentric Thor with a heart of gold, and you can't help but love him. Hemsworth was the perfect choice for this role and it's ever more evidenced in "Love and Thunder." We all know Natalie Portman is a fine actress, but her chemistry with Hemsworth is palpable and she brings a certain sense of humanity to the film that is essential to its success.

I just got out of Thor Love & ThunderSPOILER-FREE**** SPOILER-FREE**** SPOILER-FREE****Not as good as it could have been, but I liked it a lot more than Doctor Strange & The Multiverse of Madness. I think it has more comedy than Ragnarok, so if you didn't like Ragnarok, you probably really won't like this. But it got some huge laughs (see it with a packed crowd) and I did laugh out loud a few times. There is also some great use of Guns n Roses songs.Of the cast Hemsworth is great, I love this version of Thor, as opposed to one from the first two movies. Bale was superb, he was very creepy when he was onscreen!! Natalie Portman works in a way I didn't expect. I LOVE Natalie Portman, but I never cared about the Thor and Jane relatiinship. I was surprised at how much I got into it and their relationship in this one. Russell Crowe is clearly having fun, but he won't be for everyone. Tessa Thompson is no fun, but that's how her character is written, so it's not her fault. Where was the bad ass from Ragnarok?It's tone is a bit all over, the comedy is so front and centre it kind of takes away from the seriousness of what is happening and it is serious at times.The Jane/Mighty Thor storyline seemed a bit rushed and I'd have liked more Bale, but overall, I really liked it a lot and will be seeing it again.

As usual for the MCU, 'Thor: Love and Thunder' is a good watch. I did want more from it, though.Chris Hemsworth remains the star of the show, I'm adding nothing new by saying he is just perfect for the role. Tessa Thompson, Taika Waititi and Natalie Portman all make for good support. Christian Bale is also someone I enjoyed, I like the look of his character but kinda felt that I wanted to see more of him - it's like we see a beginning and an end, but part of me feels like we coulda had something in-between.The special effects are solid, as is the music; even if the track choices aren't the most creative. I probably would've shortened the run time a little, though that isn't anything all that noteworthy to be honest. There are some funny moments in there, which is always something I expect from a Taika Waititi flick.As for me and my own personal Thor ranking, this - like the 2011 original (also 7/10) - isn't one of my favourites (fwiw, I enjoy 'Thor: The Dark World' and 'Thor: Ragnarok' (both 9/10) way more) but it's still a fun enough time that I'd recommend it.I simply cannot (cannot, I tell you!) believe they didn't just call this 'Thor Four' btw... 💔

Thor: Love and Thunder does attempt to explore themes of love and loss whilst introducing the Mighty Thor and putting Thor on a journey of self discovery. However, it sadly doesn't work as well as it should due to a rushed pace and way too many jokes that are almost never funny.Chris Hemsworth is still going strong as Thor but the extreme goofiness is getting a little stale. Natalie Portman has never been better as this character and Tessa Thompson is still great as Valkyrie, even though she doesn't really get much to do.Taika Waititi massively overstays his welcome as Korg this time, who becomes very annoying really fast. Christian Bale is one of the better MCU villains with a good motivation and an unsettling presence but is let down by limited screen time.Takia's direction on the other hand is stronger, there's some nice visual imagery and the colour palette is pretty vibrant but the MCU grey is still present throughout sadly. The CG is consistently inconsistent from start to finish.The music by Michael Giacchino is fine, there's one new theme that's pretty memorable but the lack of Thor's theme is annoying. The soundtrack is really good, all the songs are classics that fit the tone and style well but some could have been used better.

ipc-title__text: Christian Is Very Good In The Role
I loved it! Not as good as Ragnarok, but I loved it!I
ipc-html-content-inner-div: T's a bit nick picky, but it is not as good as the last Thor movie. I always expect these marvel movies to get better and better to the point that they put the movie before it to shame. Still, this sequel to the Thor branch of the Marvel cinematic universe franchise did not exceed expectations. It had action, adventure, and humor, which I was expecting from Taika Waititi, who also directed Ragnarok, and that was great. Still, in Love and Thunder, the humor outshined the action-adventure. Not necessarily entirely a bad thing because the humor was so on point. Never did I feel a joke was dropped that did not deliver the laughs it expected, but I do feel these laughs came at the price of the action-adventure, which was lacking. The visuals in the movie were epic. Waititi knows how to film a sci-fi Fantasy, especially one that pays homage to the 1980s (although the constant use of Gun and Roses songs was not as spectacular as using Immrgant song by Led Zepplin twice in Ragnarok). As the movie progressed, the visuals got better and better to the point where a complete introduction of a marvel comics character making his first full appearance in the cinematic universe was breathtaking. Waititi was working that camera. The performances from the whole cast were good. I could go on about how great Chris Hemsworth is as Thor and his fantastic chemistry with Tessa Thompson as Valkyrie but what impressed me was Natalie Portman's return as Jane Foster (AKA Thor). I was not expecting much from the actress who seemed bitterly glad to end her ties with the franchise, but from the moment she appeared on the screen, she was dynamite in my book. I love every minute of her. Also, Russel Crowe's run as Zeus was enjoyable. It solidified everything this movie was about, and you can tell he enjoyed his role. Well done! Overall, Thor: love & Thunder was laid out like a comic book. As easily as I sat in the theatre watching, was easy as if I had sat in my living room reading it. I don't think any of these movies ever did a comic book story arch as great as Love and Thunder did, and that's what it got going for it! Worth taking a look at!--

ipc-title__text: And is it too much to ask that Thor have just ONE unqualified happy ending???
ipc-html-content-inner-div: "Love & Thunder" is like a fun but forgettable filler comic - silly, short, bright, diverting, feigning import, & largely lacking substance. The biggest problem is the incessant humor fighting against the uber-serious themes. I miss Branagh's Shakespearean self-seriousness that used to ground this character. Don't get me wrong; it's often quite funny, but when there are ten overly self-aware jokes every minute, some are bound to work.

Thor: Love and Thunder: Another fun epic with some dark bits, but Thor (Chris Helmsworth) is so vain and conceited you'll always laugh. We even get an Assembly of the Gods (a bit like the SW Galactic Senate) in Omnipotence City where Zeus (Russell Crowe) rules the roost, The dark stuff come from Gor (Christian Bale) The God Butcher who is determined to off as many Gods as possible, he has some justification though. Also on the gloomy side is Jane Foster (Natalie Portman), she has terminal cancer but then is attracted by Mjolni which reconstructs itself and transforms her into a female Mighty Thor. We also get the Guardians of the Galaxy who help Thor (Helmswoth) deal with some fall out from Gor's activities. Great battles and skirmishes, Thor even gets a pair of giant goats to help him along with Korg (Taika Waititi) as his sidekick. A wonderfully imagined New Asgard on Earth (which has become a visitor attraction) comes under attack from Gor and his Shadow Realm monsters. This film is a fun epic adventure and doesn't over stay it's welcome with a 119 minute running time. Directed by Taika Waititi, who co-wrote the script with Jennifer Kaytin Robinson. 8/10.

ipc-title__text: Has a fun 80's vibe to it.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Seems that the Thor movies keep getting better with each sequel. Seems like the cast and crew where having a blast making this, pretty much comes through on camera.Nice to see Jane Foster(Natalie Portman) return and become her own superhero. Chris Hemsworth always knows how to balance it out has Thor, the superhero part, the comedic, and the emotional part, and he and Portman still have beautiful chemistry. Tessa Thompson is also great, Russell Crowe really hams it up has Zeus. Let's not forget Christian Bale has the villain Gorr, he gives a enjoyable creepy over the top appeal performance. The effects are always fun also. I hope there will be Thor movies to come.

ipc-title__text: As someone who didn't like Ragnarok at all, considering one of the worst Marvels because I felt that none of the jokes landed, all being cringe
Dreadful movie, so disappointing, I wouldn't know where to begin with it. I just think they turned up and made stuff up on the day,. Don't believe there was a script, made it

ipc-html-content-inner-div: The franchise remains in Waititi's assured hands as he becomes the first director to helm more than one film in the series, unfortunately it seems like he's trying to use much of what worked in Ragnarok while at the same time trying not to totally repeat himself. Thor is still without a clear path or plan, but must take action to thwart the machinations of a madman (Bale, who deserves a lot more screentime) out to butcher all Gods. Thor also gets a blast from the past when he reunites with old flame Jane Foster--now bonded with his old companion Mjolnir. Even after three previous entries there's still a lot to work with here, but so many of the key characters are mishandled, the bulk of the comedic bits fall flat, and the ex-lovers chatter gets tired oh so quickly. After a promising opening the movie stumbles into tonal uncertainty as it veers between silliness and seriousness but never convincingly establishes what's at stake or manages to feel consequential. It's redeemed somewhat by the fantastic visuals and a third act that's pretty good, but the unevenness of the finished product and the limited use of so many great characters makes it curious as to what was left on the cutting room floor. **½

ipc-title__text: Where Ragnarok Came Easily, Love and Thunder Tries Way Too Hard
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Fresh off saving the universe in the climax of that last Avengers movie (doesn't it seem like three lifetimes ago?), our mighty Thor is stricken by a heavy case of ennui. Granted, he's spent the past however-long running around the cosmos with his new friends in the Guardians of the Galaxy, righting wrongs and soaking up the adulation, so it's not like he's completely listless. He just wonders if, maybe, there mightn't be more to life as a living thunder god than cheap thrills and easy wins. That's where the villainous "God Butcher" Gorr comes into play. Having violently ended a great number of minor deities already, his vengeful blade now points squarely at New Asgard. Where, coincidentally, Thor's old flame Jane Foster has just taken up a form of godhood.Following hot on the heels of 2017's Ragnarok, the '22 model brings the whole band back together again with a few additional boons. Stunning visual effects, epic fantasy landscapes, belly-quaking rock'n'roll tracks, an irreverent sense of humor (trademark of returning writer/director Taika Waititi) and a decidedly loose connection to the greater MCU... yeah, this wants to be a successor to Ragnarok, all right. Shame, then, that it's just a high-profile case study for the law of diminishing returns.Without exception, every single component that so felt effortless and precise in the previous film is weaker and broader in Love and Thunder. Where the last entry was delightfully quirky and witty, this one feels forced and excessive. Where I was ready to stand up and cheer at the opening chords of Led Zeppelin's "Immigrant Song," the similarly climactic placement of "November Rain," either the third or fourth Guns n' Roses tune on the soundtrack, made my eyes roll. The ambitious visuals have taken a step down, the cast has lost its edge, and the story, though excessively simple, still under-delivers. Christian Bale is completely wasted as Gorr, acting his heart out in portrayal of yet another villainous afterthought whose sporadic barks are far worse than his bite. Natalie Portman is awkward and flavorless as an ex-lover turned rival; Thor seems more upset about being ditched by his semi-sentient war hammer. Even MCU heavyweights Chris Pratt and Chris Hemsworth have had far better showings, mutually saddled by a bland script.Love and Thunder has bits and pieces that work - a handful of laughs, a few visual nods to the source material - but those are light and fleeting enough to have fit into an ambitious short film. Everything else is either a well-intentioned whiff or a confirmed misfire. What in the world happened here?

This was a pretty good sequal, and for the first marvel character to have four movies, this thor outing was entertaining but at the same time a few things felt off. The guardians of the galaxys scenes felt they didnt fit as if the actors were not even on set filming it. Always nice to see them though, especially mantis. Jane foster comes back after last seeing her in thor the dark world and I loved her lady thor outfit. It was good seeing her scenes and how she communicated with thor. Crowe as zeus was a nice touch too and as always korg provided the comic relife. It was still a good thor film and I liked the music aswell. There was some good action and a good cast and overall a decent enough marvel film, better than strange anyway.

One of the most enjoyable MCU romps in a while. I had a good time throughout the film. There is a lot of fun stuff. Waititi is a great directorial and comedy force. But would it make any real difference to the future of the MCU if this film didn't exist? No. Not really.

ipc-title__text: I went to see this movie for Natalie Portman. She looks amazing !!!
ipc-html-content-inner-div:
Thor:
Love and Thunder
IMAX opening day ,
I missed the 3D showing so IMAX it was !!!I went to see this movie for Natalie Portman.Thor: Love and Thunder on IMAX will feature almost 35 minutes of expanded aspect ratio exclusive in IMAX. The film was shot with IMAX-certified digital cameras and audiences will experience the 1.90:1 aspect ratio, providing up to 26% more picture compared to the regular screen.I went to see this movie for Natalie Portman
She looks amazing !!!Natalie Portman Enjoyed the Challenge of Getting Buff for 'Thor: Love and Thunder'
Her workouts consisted of boxing, skipping around, core work, and weightlifting. And because she was working out so rigorously, Portman, who is a vegan, had to switch up her diet so she could ensure enough protein intake to gain muscle as opposed to losing weight. She trained for 10 months !! And it shows .Thor: Love and Thunder is a very fun film. Taika Waititi delivers tons of good, gregarious fun. 8/10.

ipc-title__text: Thor clocked out and traded in.
ipc-html-content-inner-div:
Thor must stop Gorr the God Butcher from eliminating all gods and save the children of Asgard.Where as Thor: Ragnarok was a colourful cosmic adventure, director Taika Waititi's Thor: Love and Thunder delivers a fun outing, packed with one liners, quips and puns; but it's tonally off making Chris Hemsworth's Thor a buffoon, even more so than in previous films. Unreined Waititi and
Jennifer Kaytin Robinson's high-stakes plot and drama is overshadowed by comedy and far removed from the feel of the Marvel Comics.There's a handfuls of humorous cameos including Matt Damon, Sam Neil, Melissa McCarthy, Luke Hemsworth and Russell Crowe along with the cast of Guardians of the Galaxy to name a few. Despite a great effects, soundtrack and score even with Christian Bale's solid performance trying to ground it and death themes throughout, Waititi's offering desperately falls short. Love and Thunder becomes almost a parody played for laughs, hints sarcasm, trading in adventure for book of shoehorned jokes.Overall, if you're completely checked out it could be a cheap blast, but it's a sobering reminder that character is everything and even with a solid director and big budget it's possible to still miss the mark.

ipc-title__text: Visually striking; comically and emotionally inconsistent! [+60%]
ipc-html-content-inner-div: The movie is, by all means, a two and ½ stars but an extra ½ goes to Christian Bale who puts his heart, soul, and body into an underwritten character. With confusing character arcs, a good chunk of humor not quite hitting the highs you expect, and the lack of stakes, Taika Waititi's second Thor flick severely lacks the liveliness of Ragnarok. The GOTG cameos don't mean anything, and the entire scene with Russell Crowe's Zeus simply makes for a subpar comedy sketch. Heck, I'm sure Sam Neill, Matt Damon, and the Asgardian performers could've come up with something much better.The MCU continues to struggle with its inability to write off characters even when they're dead, and it's the case with Love and Thunder too. Jane Foster, her sudden cancer, and her mysterious connection to Mjolnir all remain underdeveloped aspects in the film. There is a constant back-and-forth when it comes to tone, and somewhere between humor, drama, and darkness, my interest levels waned. What keeps it engaging, however, is Waititi's visual craft. He creates both a colorful and a colorless world within the same film, and the GnR tracks are perfectly placed.

ipc-title__text: Finally saw this, it's WAY not bad
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Taika is great, especially as the dude made out of rock, if not a very funny and talented Director and actor.I particularly welcomed the return of Jane Foster, and I was a little bit surprised at the way that they brought her back. I distinctly remember Mjollnir being back in the possession of Thor and Captain America after Thor stole it from the Dark World timeline... of course, the Asgardians could have scooped up the pieces left over from Ragnarok, but where is that other hammer from Avengers endgame? Maybe it is not really a plot hole, I don't remember where that other Mjollnir got to. Did Steve Rogers return it?And then it is always great to have the Guardians of the Galaxy involved, this was before Guardians of the Galaxy Vol3 and Nebula's transformation into one of Tony Starks Nanotech projects. I honestly liked her before when she was still partly RadioShack shelf rejects.And compared to Ragnarok, although there is a lot of humor in this film, it does have some serious drama.But there are a number of absurd complaints I've read in several dupe "reviews". Let's go over these, shall we?1) It's FUNNY.To not like a movie because it is FUNNY? That is the main complaint that I am reading, oh, this is no good because it is FUNNY. Wait, what?There are some new gimmicks in this film, nothing was wasted. And so Thor assembles a new means of transportation through by Bifrost. Out of... Watch the movie to find out what it is made out of. But it's funny!2) NepotismI also read a number of complaints regarding "nepotism", wait, what! That's a big so what! I don't care who plays what or who, or if they are the son or daughter of some cast or crew member. Yawn. And honestly, I did not know when I was watching the film.Christian Bale almost reprises his role as the American Psycho. - at first, we believe that this person is irredeemable. But in a major, unexpected twist, well, you will have to watch the film in order to see what I'm talking about.The film starts getting very serious toward the middle, of course it kind of slightly bothers me that Thor is still a little bit goofy after the events of avengers endgame. But then again, this is also within his character. He was handed a major loss in endgame, and this was his reaction. So, as far as I'm concerned, he is dealing with that loss, which changed him irrevocably.This is a much different Thor than the person that we met in the first film. And The Avengers. That serious person... Which is totally expected after all the character has gone through.And these changes were just for films, the comic book numbered in the hundreds, and the character was always ever-changing, even then.Remember when Thor resided within a geek that had to yell "ODIN" at a hammer which would then turn him into Thor? The character has changed a lot over the course of maybe 40 or 50 years. And then some of his power was siphoned off into another character named Bloodaxe, which was a spinoff title that only lasted a couple of dozen issues- it was related to West Coast Avengers, which then became Force Works.It's kind of like how the Hulk was always dumb and residing within Bruce Banner. And hulk has gone through a lot of changes. There was a time he was dumb when he was human, but smart when he was "The Gray Hulk"- but back then he went by "Mr. Fixit", he accompanied Wolverine in a few issues. Anybody remember The Hulk versus Thor? It is now called "the return of the Incredible Hulk"- at the time when it was originally broadcast, it was called the Hulk versus Thor, or probably simply Hulk vs Thor. And some of the dialogue from that TV movie found its way into the first Thor film.3) CGI?Another complaint was with the amount of CGI, which you can barely tell these days. And this complaint is made by people who don't realize that there are still a lot of practical effects and real, physical locations and objects, even in this film. I'm getting really tired of that old complaint. If we have the ability to make realistic, digital set extensions, then we should use them always. But even with a lot of digital set extensions, a lot of the detail is real physical props, and other real artwork.I like that this movie focuses a lot on the Asgardian children, and it shows their true potential- including the son of Heimdall.I like that this film pulls back from the inanity of Ragnarok, although this film includes some of that silliness.I thought Ragnarok was way over the top, but I did enjoy it. But this film has that same over the top feel at least at the beginning, but it also is balanced with some heartbreaking things.The final complaint and I see this a lot is about "the writing"I want to ask the people who wrote those reviews, have you ever written for television? Have you ever written for Broadway or the theater?You can't just sit down and spew unplanned stream of conscious, everything has to be planned out and mapped out, especially with television.And it's even more difficult with a film.And so the question I finally have is: are these reviews taking an extremely long time to post? Because I don't believe I have put anything into these reviews that are anything near as bad as what I have read recently.

In Taika Waititi's most recent adaptation of "Thor: Love and Thunder," there are both serious stakes and humor. The humor, especially the mocking man-mountain, really makes it. The way the tone alternates between profound seriousness and deathly seriousness won't be to everyone's taste. Taika Waititi, the filmmaker of "Thor: Ragnarok," deserves praise for treating everything as lighthearted entertainment. The "great bits" are Turn-the-Tide brawls set to Guns'n'Roses' Greatest Hits, and they only occur once in each of the film's three acts.

ipc-title__text: I knew the Marvel kiddies wouldn't like it but us GROWNUPS did!! super fun film !!
ipc-html-content-inner-div: I knew the Marvel little tykes wouldn't like this film cause it had 2 much humor and feeling rather than mindless action and macho crap. Bale was his usual BRILLIANT self he cant do a character and not steal every scene he is in and in every movie only time he was out done was Dark Knight and the villain ALWAYS out shines the hero. Loved the humor you cant get better than mixing comedy with any genre action/comedy horror/comedy THE BEST!! Hopefully we get a part 5 heck even Russell Crowe was hilarious. The whole theater was laughing and we all left after having a GREAT time and with the years weve had we NEEDED it !! Thank you to the WHOLE CAST AND CREW!!

ipc-title__text: Unlike Anything That MCU Has Shown Us Before; Matched With A Rocking Soundtrack
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Marvel Studio's Thor: Love and Thunder officially redefines the definition of film and on-screen art. Taika Waititi's background as a painter can be seen throughout the film, through the use of a vibrant color scheme and specific tint isolation. This is incredibly aesthetically pleasing and, quite frankly, nothing that the Marvel Cinematic Universe has shown us before. Matched with a rocking soundtrack -- Appetite for Destruction from Guns N' Roses, Thor: Love and Thunder is quite literally an "appetite for destruction."Thor: Love and Thunder picks up after the events of Avengers: Endgame. Thor (Chris Hemsworth) is still tagging along as one of the Guardians of the Galaxy. After all his paths have been severed from his battles with Thanos, he finds himself without a pathway. In all of his thousands of years of living, this has never been a concept that Thor has had to tackle. This puts him on a journey of self-exploration. Although, obviously in the Marvel Universe, that can only last so long when the new villain Gorr the God Butcher (Christian Bale) comes to town. Gorr vows that "all gods will die." Thor recruits the help of his ex-girlfriend Jane Foster (Natalie Portman) who seemingly became a Thor herself. These two learn to work together to defeat Gorr and how to navigate the world while rekindling their old relationship.Thor: Love and Thunder emphasizes the idea of "love" in the title because that's how audiences will feel about the film's color variations and banging soundtrack. Christian Bale completely steals the entire show as Gorr the God Butcher. In every scene he is in, your eyes are glued to his worldly-like presence on the screen. Although he is terrifying, the audience will not be able to get enough of him. Christian Bale finds a way to make this a Christian Bale film and not a Chris Hemsworth film. As much as Gorr the God Butcher's storyline is golden, which is ironic given his black and white color scheme, other branches of the film feel unnecessary. During the film, certain plot points are used that feel somewhat like a cheap excuse to move the story forward. The characters spend a solid 30 minutes exploring something new, yet later we learn that it has no overall impact or relevance to the story. Part of the film is wasted on the focus of Zeus. It may be comedic and light-hearted in the moment, yet it almost feels like it is only introduced to help set up future Marvel projects, rather than focus on the film we are currently watching.If the title doesn't make it obvious, the film deals with the theme of love persevering and expresses the concept that relationships aren't forever, but the love behind them is eternal. Following previous Marvel content Thor: Love and Thunder continues the trend of pushing PG-13 boundaries and getting darker. When I say that Christian Bale is incredibly terrifying, that is really true. Marvel does not hold back on his character, especially when a large part of his role is about abducting children. Given that, plus the barrel of intense action throughout the film, this film is not to be taken lightly.I give Thor: Love and Thunder 4 out of 5 stars and recommend it for ages 12 to 18, plus adults. You can find Thor: Love and Thunder raining its way into theatres on July 8, 2022. So make sure to check it out!By Jude A., KIDS FIRST!
Okay, an overall pleasant movie! Did not reach my high expectations in the least, but I love Thor & I love Marvel, so it's a 7/10! Christian Bale deserves an Oscar for this!

Why is Thor so hard to get right? Thor 1, so average. Thor 2... We try to not talk about. Thor 3 was great and now... Yikes. I have to believe Waititi was being pressured by studio execs. I refuse to believe that he would've created something like this on his own. He's too good. This thing was a mess, it was awful. It really felt like big MCU trying to recreate Ragnarok but stripping it of its soul. Hemsworth is trying, Portman is amazing and even she can't save this from being a mess. Oh, and Bale... Bale is doing the best he can with what he's being given. That's just it though, I don't feel like it's on the actors, they each feel like they're trying but you can only do so much with so little. It's really hard to watch these Post-Endgame movies and not think Marvel is starting to circle the drain. Had a good run, but wow does it feel like we're grasping at straws now.

ipc-title__text: A very funny and enjoyable parody
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Really enjoy this movie, it is quite enjoyable in colorful visual aspect and there is never a lack of good action scenes and amazing special effects. The catch here is that the movie is very comedy oriented, giving it a cartoonish tone and it feels like a parody of Thor. Russell Crowe's Zeus character is too cartoonish and ends up contributing very little. Chris Hemsworth is still the best as Thor and Natalie Portman now has more participation. The relationship between Thor and Jane Foster brings this movie to life more than the first 2 installments and there is more chemistry between them. Christian Bale in the role of Gorr is an extraordinary villain, quite dark and with a good story that justifies his actions. Another exciting thing about the movie is the soundtrack, which includes Guns N' Roses songs that offer a really exciting moment. As much as this movie ends up being a parody, it manages to fulfill its objective of entertaining like any Marvel movie. My final rating for this movie is a 9/10.

Having not seen "Thor" since the first installment, I wasn't prepared for how director Taika Waititi had restylized the franchise to become more of a joke-infested comedy as well as a CGI-saturated epic adventure. It was funny at random moments with a few unexpected celebrity cameo appearances, but the constantly comic approach was maintained at the expense of the convoluted Asgardian adventure storyline. It also meant sacrificing the heart that would have us empathize with the fate of the principal characters. Chris Hemsworth still plays the title role in the manner born - though the rest of the cast felt somewhat less committed to their roles, even Christian Bale as the malevolent evildoer and Natalie Portman returning in superhero form as Thor's love interest. The souped-up climax was such a textbook MCU exercise in eye-rolling excess that the ending was robbed of its innate poignance.

Love and Thunder was not as strong as Ragnarok but I found it entertaining. The film had a somewhat good dose of humour. I loved the funny awkwardness created with Thor and Stormbreaker and the screaming goats were funny. Chris Hemsworth was born to play Thor and does well in carrying this film. It was great to see Jane Foster (Natalie Portman) play a hero figure who was equal to Thor but with a sad twist. It was the most serious film in the Thor film series with Jane having cancer and the death of the villain's daughter at the start of the film. I felt they could added a bit more humour, used the Guardians of the Galaxy more and perhaps Zeus and the gods could have teamed up to fight Gorr. I was not impressed with the black and white fight scene on the planet that looked like the Moon. This was far better than Doctor Strange which was disappointing and it had a great soundtrack. Overall not all bad.

ipc-title__text: It's fun but too much stupid attempts at comedy big it down and stop it from really hitting its stride!
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Yeah too much of everything kind of, like for example the screaming giant space goats, it would have been funny as a one-off joke but it's something that pops up throughout the whole movie! And this movie really assumes you must love Korg a whole lot because he has not one but three patronising narrations that open and close the movie and bring you up to date with what happened between here and Endgame, and I didn't like those scenes very much as they just didn't do it for me and felt like a lazy attempt to condense the story and get it moving faster, one would have worked at the beginning of the movie but it's overdone, and so is Korg grossly, I thought he worked much better in Ragnarok because he and the schtick approach was new and was done much better and just enough for it to not be to obnoxious in that movie, but here I felt sick of him within moments and he way overstayed his welcome and was just annoying as fk!! Urg it's like the movie was made for severely attention deficit people who can't sit still and take in a movie for like two minutes, it was terrified of slowing down even just a little and just letting the story breathe for a while, the rapid fire jokes were for me having a bad effect on the more serious aspects and the pathos, I thought it clashed horribly when it would go from her as the lady Thor to sick and dying in the hospital, you simply cannot plonk something as deadly serious as freaking cancer in a movie like this and expect it to work, it's like having Billy get a brain tumour in Gremlins 2! It felt like there was a really good movie in there somewhere, just between Thor Jane and Gorr but it didn't focus on that enough, I really didn't think Natalie Portman and Chris Hemsworth has any chemistry at all in the original movie but here I thought the opposite, they're a little older and things have changed a lot since that picture and she seemed more relaxed than before and I liked her as a warrior woman I thought it was cool, I was surprised by how she ended up at the end I thought it was surprisingly sad, don't worry about her coming back in any sequels folks! Christian Bale was surprisingly awesome and very creepy as the villain, I thought he came off as genuinely insane and lethal, I wanted more of him, he was probably the most threatening villain in a marvel movie yet. I also loved how his story ended as well, never expected to see one of the biggest cosmic entities of the Marvel universe in one of the movies, kudos to Taika for not having Eternity crack some goofy joke, although I'm sure it was severely tempting! There was definitely some awesome things in it, I loved the visuals and some of the huge locations, and the hall of the gods and the silly Zeus was where I thought the comedy did work really well and I liked that scene a lot with Thor declaring the gods cowardly and ticking off the most lazy Zeus ever, look forward to see where that leads in the future. I was overall slightly disappointed with this, it took what worked for Ragnarok and cranks it up to eleven and for some that might work but for me the comedy was mostly just annoying and obnoxious, frequently stopped the movie dead and prevented it from really ever taking off in a big way, this overstuffed cosmic mess of a film proves that Mr Waititi is capable of overestimating his strengths as a director and also that he could really do with learning a little restraint! X.

ipc-title__text: Sadly the worst of the Thor series
You might Love the Comedy And Action This Thunder Brings
ipc-html-content-inner-div:
LIKES:The Pacing At Times: Thor Love and Thunder once more puts us back into the fast paced seat of Marvel and keeps the foot on the pedal the entire time. Like Ragnarök before it, the fourth installment has the same energy and pizazz that Waititi brought us in the past and that makes for an energetic pace. It does not take long to get into the adventure element and he keeps things moving as fast as he can to keep you the viewer into the madness this particular film has to bring. He has brought other elements into the mix to help bring others in, but the pace is certain to be perfect for those with flash in the pan likes of the cinematic world.The Balance of Characters: Marvel has become accustomed to putting a lot into their phase 4 movies, with the last three films juggling a lot of characters and fan service into one installment. Thor's fourth installment has a lot of characters to play with and keep on the screen at one time and it does it surprisingly well, and perhaps the second best of the Phase 4 stuff to date in terms of this element. The Guardians have their fair share of time without being too stuck on the movie, while Thor's merry band of godly misfits each get their own time to shine on the screen and feel significant in some way. Our leading bad guy Gorr has meaningful moments in this film and feels like a well-developed character, while the other plot elements of the film get their own time and good use. It's a fantastic surprise to see how many people had their shining moments and a nod to Waititi for finding a way to juggle it.The Sound Track: Like Guardians, this movie may have one of my favorite track lists to watch a movie too. All the classic songs and epic energy is waiting to swallow you whole with the crazy vibes and perfect timing for inclusion in this movie. Odd love ballads are there during the calmer and more intimate moments, while the action packed moments once more pull from the legendary decades of rock and roll. It feels just like Ragnarök's execution on many levels, and for me was better at times with dropping the right song at the right time and kicking major butt with it. Even the orchestral work finds a place to shine, and the unique tracks for it, and unique spins, show that Waititi is just as ridiculously fun as he always has been.The Visual Direction/Sound Editing: With the budge and resources of Disney, big visuals are the expected norm at this point. While I can't say this is the most mind blowing use of their technology, I do have to clap my hands and nod at the worlds they created for this film. Thor's adventure takes a lot of new styles to heart in their quest, starting technicolor and trippy from the get go that we have seen in Guardians and then moving into something much deeper. The group managed to do so much with the use of lighting in this film, most of the time using it perfectly to really give the aura of the worlds they were trying to create. As seen in the trailer, there is an homage to the black and white film technique that I loved, and heading to the divine city of the Gods really felt like something out of a Percy Jackson chapter in the books. It's beautiful and the sound editing that goes with most of these scenes fully brings that extra emotional punch with it, be it robbing the scene of sound, or adding the sheen and heavenly shine of the kingdom of the gods.The Emotional Moments Of The Movie: Many of the Marvel movies have not really hit me with the emotional punch like other fans have. Spiderman has come the closest, and there are a scant few times of a few other things to get me to nearly form tears. This one though has the most emotional moments for me in a very, very long time. I can't say much, but the character development of Thor is really good in this film, and addresses a few things that movies like this tend to shy away from for the fantasy elements. You'll find yourself potentially in a relevant case for Gorr, Thor, Jane, and Valkyrie's trials and really feel the connection they were going for in their representation on screen. Again, I want to say more, but I can't for spoilers so let's keep going.The Comedy at times: Waititi proved you can have a lot of comedic fun with Thor and still have the Marvel element. For this film, he did that very well on many levels again, bringing with it some brilliant dialogue and timing that I absolutely laughed at in the film. As Korg, his delivery is just spot on and well narrated, sort of like the Barney Fife of Thor's band, that provides that kick you need to relieve the tension. Thor himself feels like the Asgardian we have known and loved for so long, and it really flows well in this movie to not be a drastic twist.DISLIKES:The Rushed Pace In The Opening: Like Rogue One, Thor's fourth installment has an opening that seems a bit rushed, choppy, and a montage more than anything else. It does the job and gives you enough of the story foundation to enjoy, but yet still seems a bit choppy and montage like that I did not quite enjoy. Much of it had to do with the Guardians inclusion and the Gorr's opening moves, alongside jane's story for why she is coming back to the universe. It's not the worst thing given the amazing acts to follow, but you can't help but wonder how good this film could have been with a little more time in the opening.A Story Element: I can't say much about this element without ruining the story, but another small quip, is why the solution to the problem could not have been used again for the final number. Probably to help out with the emotional punch mentioned earlier, probably another rule that I missed or don't know from the comic book. Regardless, the last part seemed to have a fix we could have used, but again I'll let it mostly slide.The Emotional Moments Can Be Tough: If you have a nightmare or sensitivity to some deeper story elements found in Dramatic movies, this film can be tough for you to watch. A warning more than anything, Thor's fourth tale hits some hard topics that do hit the emotional scale, but may be too realistic or hard to watch in the way they present it. It's realistic and makes sense, but it's also a grounding element that you may not want to see in a super hero movie.Some of The Political Push: Yep, we should not be surprised that Disney is still doing the checkbox checking in their Phase 4 installments. The Love and Thunder has a few moments of showing the political agenda off, some of which are naturally baked in, and others a little more of a push than needed for me. It's not the content more so the timing and placement, and though Waititi accomplishes the taste balance better than others, sometimes it gets away and seems to be a diversion not needed.The Visuals Sometimes Get In the Way Of the Action: If you are a fan like me, you like to get the full scope of the action playing out, like in Avengers or Winter Soldier. Waititi and his crew do this decently well, but there are times where the visual style or camera work gets in the way and feels like a cost saving step. The dark tones, how they are zoomed in and the CGI cramming sometimes don't come out as well as they had hoped for me, as they block the people doing the action. Again, it seems trivial, but with a little more post editing and lighting, I think the action scenes in some parts of the movie would have been awesome.A Little More Action: Yep, the action junkie wants more action, surprised right? It's a trivial moment given the other movies I've seen, but Thor's fight scenes in the middle and the end could have used about five to ten minutes more for me to finish those moments strong. The pillar is again the middle moment on the platform, all I can say again, which felt like it held almost the right amount of involvement and finish. The end scenes came close and still end well, but just a little more time with the music, the style, and the twist involvement would have really made this element perfect for me.The Comedy Gets A Little Excessive: By far my biggest dislike of the movie, was the excessive comedy that this part of the Marvel franchise goes too far for me in. If you want your comedy stuffed into every line, with running gags that keep going, Waititi made this movie for you. For others, there are times where the comedy is in your face, forced, and excessive to the point of losing the funny and going to the annoying part that you hope the element will stop. Sometimes it's the banter and the dialogue trying to shoehorn in, and other times it's some political comedy that just does not need to be in there when there seemed to be other options. My biggest irk of the comedy though was the famous goat yell, and just how excessive it became, only making me laugh a few times when he timed it well. Overall, this was the part that seemed a little too much for me, but for those who like comedy, you'll love it.The VERDICT
Thor's mighty adventure turned out to be better on many levels than I thought and really was the fun adventure the trailers promised. It's a movie with style, pizazz, and that Waititi magic many have fallen in love with, balancing a lot of elements to fantastic amounts in who they recruited for the ordeal. With a great soundtrack, awesome visuals, action that feels early Marvel, and character development, this film really has a lot for the fanbase to revel in and enjoy in the shorter runtime than you would expect. Though it does still have some elements I did not enjoy like a rushed paced story element, a little political moments that could have been tapered down, and excessive comedy at times, the movie really is a fun and good installment for me. This is a film worth the investment to going to the theaters and may be worth the full blown theater experience (Imax etc.) if you got the resources or access to it. Overall, this movie for me gets:Action/Adventure/Comedy: 8.5
Movie Overall: 7.5.

ipc-title__text: Not as good as it should be..
ipc-html-content-inner-div: While there were parts of this movie i liked, there were also parts i didn't! The jokes was a little too much and i wanted the movie to get a little more dark and serious! I also expected The Guardians to be in the movie a little more! Christian Bale was great as Gorr but underused! Not enough screentime.The romantic plot was mixed. I would say that the movie has a clear directorial style and vision, like Doctor Strange 2. Unfortuanally, like that One, it feels messy. Great soundtrack and it is visiually stunning, but without an engaging plot and characters, it feels hollow.Overalt another Phase 4 movie that you might enjoy, but also forget soon after.

Thor - Love and ThunderIt was a self-indulgent disaster, with a tissue thin story packed out with unnecessary CGI, stuff this stars who were given little or no direction and were just there for the pay check.This movie seemed intent on ticking every woke box and current trend and my feel it was written for a prepubescent audience. For "real" Marvel fans this was a disaster wrapped in a fiasco and they would have wasted their ticket price.Rarely am I so offended by a movie written by a committee of morons who create movie reflecting current trends and then directed by an idiot. We cannot pretend this was good and I have yet to find anyone that enjoyed it on any level.My advice stay away from this tripe, sack the writers and arrest the director.

ipc-title__text: Fun. But why did Zeus sound Italian?
ipc-html-content-inner-div: A fun movie with a decent cast. After the last few, where I feel that phase 4 is mostly a failure, this one was a little too comedic. It was still more enjoyable than the recent Doctor Strange, and most of Marvel's TV efforts (Ms. Marvel is the best). But it wasn't a bad movie.

I liked Thor (2011), I did not like Thor: The Dark World (2013), and I liked Thor: Ragnarok (2017) because it was good new direction for the character. Thor: Love and Thunder (2022) was the same as Thor: Ragnarok (2017).Chris Hemsworth as Thor is still great, but Thor in the movie can act stupid and can be cringey at times even though he does have good moments and cool action scenes.Natalie Portman as Jane Foster/Mighty Thor was good. I liked how she became Mighty Thor because it was like how she becomes Mighty Thor in the comics. She was cool in action scenes, and she has good scenes so you can feel what she is going through.I did like Christian Bale as Gorr the God Butcher because you do get a backstory that helps you understand him, he can also be creepy and intimidating. The problem is I would have liked to see more of him because he is not in most of the movie.The relationship between Thor and Jane Foster/Mighty Thor was still good and they work well together. The problem with the movie is that it can get too cheesy with its jokes, and it can get cringey, but there are jokes and dialogue that are funny.The movie has an 80's feels to it, the Guardians of the Galaxy are only in some small scenes, and the action scenes are fun to watch. The 3rd act can get stupid, but it is entertaining.Thor: Love and Thunder (2022) is like Thor: Ragnarok (2017) in many ways, but I liked Thor Ragnarok (2017) more than this. Thor: Love and Thunder (2022) is fun and entertaining to watch, but you might not like this if you did not like Thor: Ragnarok (2017).

That's the third MARVEL movie in a row i have watched the last days, i mean, of the latest phases. There is a slight but constant, drop in quality. Judging from the other new movies' reputation, it's safe to say that they failed hard to keep up with Phase 2 and 3.It's better than BLACK WIDOW and ETERNALS. If you lower your expectations, you will enjoy it. Yes, jokes are forced and THOR: RAGNAROK seems like comedy gold, a G. O. A. T in comparison. There is a lot of mediocrity here. Maybe this movie targets very young audiences, i mean, if i was 10 years old, i would probably love it. It's too naive and silly.However, there are some positives. As many people have mentioned, Bale is great. Portman is a very good actress too, and she doesn't disappoint. Russel Crow was funnier than i expected. I found these goats very funny too and Korg was a likeable character. Hemsworth is always a charismatic presence. Furthermore, i got used to this movie naiveness and i liked a lot the final "battle". Guns n roses were a perfect choice, as a 90's kid, their music always brings me joy. Finally, there were some lines that made me laugh. (Jarnbjorn vs mjolnir, etc).So, lower your expectations, forget previous phases' existence, and you will probably enjoy it. Still, this Phase failed.

ipc-title__text: A Mixed Bag of Fun and Confusion
ipc-html-content-inner-div:
"Thor: Love and Thunder" (2022), directed by Taika Waititi, is the fourth installment in the Thor franchise and the first to break the solo trilogy barrier. The film stars Chris Hemsworth as Thor, alongside Natalie Portman, Tessa Thompson, and Christian Bale.Plot
Thor, now a wanderer after the events of "Avengers: Endgame," reunites with the Guardians of the Galaxy. However, their journey is interrupted when Gorr the God Butcher (Bale) begins his quest to kill all gods. Thor is forced to return to Earth and Asgard to confront this new threat, reuniting with old allies and facing new challenges.Characters
Chris Hemsworth continues to deliver a strong performance as Thor, showcasing his heroic nature and emotional depth. Natalie Portman's return as Jane Foster adds a human element to the story, while Tessa Thompson's Valkyrie brings a sense of strength and leadership. Christian Bale's Gorr is a memorable villain, bringing a dark and menacing presence to the film.Atmosphere and Visuals
The film maintains the 80s-inspired aesthetic and humor of "Thor: Ragnarok," with Waititi's signature style shining through. The action sequences are well-choreographed, with a mix of slapstick comedy and epic battles. The visual effects are stunning, creating a visually appealing experience.Conclusion
"Thor: Love and Thunder" is a fun and entertaining addition to the MCU, despite its weak plot and confusing side quests. The film benefits from strong performances, engaging action sequences, and Waititi's distinctive direction. While it may not be the strongest entry in the franchise, it offers plenty of laughs and heartwarming moments for fans of the series.Rating: 6/10.

ipc-title__text: Woke and blunder is a more appropriate title

ipc-html-content-inner-div: Love and Thunder really is an absolute hoot. It is unapologetically tongue in cheek while still packing in some solid emotional heft.It boasts a plot that crams in a lot yet never feels congested. The foundations and structure of the plot do follow the typical Marvel formula, but Taika's script and direction make this film feel nice and refreshing.Speaking of Taika's script it is very sharp and funny. Mix this with Hemsworth's comedic timing and delivery and you get a match made in heaven, so this is definitely the most I've laughed at a Marvel movie.Hemsworth really looked like he was having the time of his life playing Thor in this film which was so fun to watch. Natalie Portman back in the MCU and with such a badass role was brilliant to see.Bale played a pretty good villain, nothing outstanding but there was some decent development there and he brought a sufficient level of unhinged menace to the role.I will say the action was never particularly inspiring and I would have liked to seen more of Bale and have that role fleshed out a bit, but these criticisms are relatively minor and don't detract too much from the quality of the film, which for the most part is top notch.If you throw yourself into this film with reckless abandon and are happy to surrender to Taika Waititi's quirky and goofy humour then you will have a blast.

ipc-title__text: All about the fun! Not a total disappointment!
ipc-html-content-inner-div: This movie is a lot like Star Wars the Phantom Menace for me. Some might get annoyed that I compare this movie with that one but hear me out.Sure there are some outrageously silly and over the top things that can be annoying, a bit ridiculous, and out of left field, but it's all about the fun that the movie took me through with the action/fight scenes, the visuals/art that went into the movie, and also the villain (Christian Bale was GREAT and I really bought into his character!). This movie was very creative and I liked many of the decisions that the production team and the screenwriters made beyond the negative stuff (which I could mostly look past). I always like the character of Thor and while I wish I saw more of them, it was good seeing the Guardians of the Galaxy again too! I liked what they did with Thor and Jane and while not all of the humor landed some select things were funny! (The vending machine joke)

ipc-title__text: Thor: Love And Thunder Is For Me MCU Worst Film To Date
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Thor: Love And Thunder is simply my biggest disappointment of the year, so far?, i think it will stay until the end of the year, but who knows, anyway despite the usual great MCU movie trailer, for the first time i'm leaving the theater so disappoint on an MCU movie, Thor: Love And Thunder is basically an awful romance movie where the main couples of the film have a superpower, Thor is mostly just a full unfunny comedian here, Jane Foster (Natalie Portman) and Thor chemistry is awful and their dialogue is just so cheesy, their chemistry is also not click for me in the first Thor but it's not terrible, and their chemistry is good in The Dark World but i guess that because Jane Foster did not appear much on that movie and only have a few scene with Thor and i don't mind it, and so i can safely give a conclusion that Natalie Portman as Jane Foster is just not good, Christian Bale as a villain surprisingly awful, Gorr is just a lame unbadass villain, he's not scary for me and he's not menacing, it is possibly MCU worst villain, from Ragnarok to Love And Thunder this movie is a super downer, if it's directed by different person it's still make sense but no it's still the same guy, Taika Waititi, in Ragnarok you got this version of Thor who are mostly still a badass just with a little bit of comedy and it works perfectly, a badass female villain Hela played incredibly well by Cate Blanchett, you got Loki which is one of the best thing in Ragnarok, you also got bruce banner, and the fight and the battle was fantastic, in this one only the first battle and the battle in Zeus place that i enjoyed, the rest is mostly a meh battle, i also wanna say that Lady Sif played greatly by Jaimie Alexander is probably MCU most underused and underappreciated great characters they've ever have, and she only have a very very small role in this one, much smaller role than she have in Thor: The Dark World, i love Lady Sif in the first Thor and Thor: The Dark World and not only i want her having a way longer screen time in here, and i also way much prefer her than Jane Foster, i think she deserve on the main team alongside Thor, Valkyrie, and Korg, and they did not do that, MCU really use her character so terribly, now let's talk the pros of Thor: Love And Thunder, the movie still have a few pretty good moments and the whole Guns N' Roses soundtrack that i like, i think the visual and special effects was great, Valkyrie and Korg was not awful in this one, they were ok, the last battle was also just ok, and that's about it, the rest i just can't stand it, so overall Thor: Love And Thunder is for me MCU worst film to date.

ipc-title__text: It really is not that bad.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Wow critics are pretty harsh on this one. Yes, it is definitely a much weaker movie than Ragnarok and I understand how disappointed you can be if your expectations were pretty high; I happen to be in the same boat. But not taking its predecessor into account, this is still a fairly fun and entertaining MCU flick. Is the overall tone a little too lighthearted especially considering the supposedly seriousness of the villain? Probably. But I think it is still in line with what we can expect from a Taika Waititi Thor movie. All in all, I would still recommend it; just know what you're getting into and you will have a good time.

Thor (since Endgame) has been teamed
up with the Guardians of the Galaxy and contemplated who he's going to be/what he's going to do with himself now. While this is happening, Thor hears stories about gods being killed and people everywhere suffering in the aftermath. The GotG decide go to help who they can while Thor & Korg return to New Asgard (Gorr's next target). When they arrive to a battle happening, Thor sees a familiar sight,, Mjolnir!!! He gleefully extends his hand to receive his old weapon/friend, but Mjolnir flies right past him,, to be recieved by the Mighty Thor (regular Thor's old flame), Jane Foster!!!!Thor (the first movie) was great / Thor the Dark World was pretty good / Thor Ragnarok was out of this world!!! This one (Thor Love & Thunder) was pretty good too,, not quite as good as the Dark World (imo),, but still pretty good. Glad to see Portman back in the mix, and how she & Hemsworth get to bring the story of Thor and Jane Foster the closure it deserved. Christian Bale was incredible and I wanted to see more of him as Gorr!!!Not great by any means, but still enjoyable and worth plenty of lols. 6.8 rating.

ipc-title__text: Bit too much of a... good thing? I don't know.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Thor: Love and Thunder does its best being a true sequel to Ragnarok but the key elements are missing this time around: and that's Thor's buddy-relationship with his brother Loki. Christian Bale's character is like a stand-in for God of War's Kratos in terms of archetype, make-up and also fees like a 'campy-go-grumpy' stand-in for Tom Hiddleston's iconic trickster.There's stuff that works here, and stuff that doesn't. It's like a birthday cake that's got too many flavours in it all at once instead of being squarely triple-choc or vanilla; instead it tries overdoing the sweetness without distinction of flavour or craft. That's Thor: Love and Thunder, a film that tries being more by doing the exact same thing pretty much. It's feel-good without ample risk, but at least the typical MARVEL sense of fun is still there. It may not be inviting for anything particularly inspired, but this Thor film is determined to reinforce the character as a mainstay from here onward.This film has spark, but no real sense of awe beyond the action spectacle. Thor may not be as tried-and-true as other more established superheroes out there, but there's clearly room for improvement in the future.Thor: Love and Thunder gets 3/5 stars. It's the standard MARVEL-fare that's become a to-be-expected box office hit.Clearly MARVEL's formula is being called out by some; it works for others, but some see through the innately formulaic structures starting to get in the way of these adventures feeling fresh and inspiring. It's not a bad film at all, but long-standing characters deserve (and don't have any real right to be denied of) character development and expanding the creative horizons of their respective world.Even satisfying candies refine their formula to make themselves feel less 'complicit' with ordinariness from time to time.

ipc-title__text: Worst MCU yet, things keep getting worse...

ipc-html-content-inner-div: Movie was a full comedy package. The blend of comedy and action was too good. My belly was hurting while laughing at each and every comic scene. The story and the climax was little bit weak but overall a good entertainer.

ipc-title__text: "I Choose Love" - "Whatever Happens, Never Stop Fighting"

ipc-html-content-inner-div: The story doesn't make sense, but there are some scenes (Zeus, black and white, final battle) that are pretty good and the comedic bits work for the most part.I admit that the first act didn't work that well for me (except the great intro) and I would have loved to see more from Bale's character (always great when in scene) and to feel more on the emotional scenes. However, yeah, if you don't think too much about this film, you can enjoy and have a fun. Not Ragnarok though. But enjoyed it more than Strange 2...

ipc-title__text: My favourite among the four Thor movies
ipc-html-content-inner-div: I never understood the love for Ragnarok and don't understand why people are getting underwhelmed by this one. Ragnarok had a better story than this one but the style undermined that story even though it was still better than the two Thor films that came before, both of which were also good imo. Here the style and the story meshes so well together. The ending felt genuine and touching, something that I felt missing in Ragnarok. Chris Hemsworth and Natalie Portman were a treat to watch in this action rom-com.

ipc-title__text: Marvel done Waititi style (again) - pumped with unadulterated fun & silly feel-good factor. Hammer time!
ipc-html-content-inner-div: After the superb "Jojo Rabbit" terrific director / writer / co-star Taika Waititi smashes his second 'Thor' blockbuster: "Thor: Love & Thunder" which he pumps unadulterated fun into alongside Marvel's usual stellar cast (with too many A-List cameos to mention) & spectacular effects. Chris Hemsworth hams it up brilliantly as the loveably dumb titular warrior god who here must do battle with 'god butcher' Christian Bale, helped by the likes of Tessa Thompson, ex-gf Natalie Portman & a beast voiced by Waititi (but not by Russell Crowe (funny)). "Guardians Of The Galaxy Vol.2" is still the BEST Marvel flick, but this is up there, on silly feel-good factor alone. Hammer time!

All camp and a whole lot of fun. Lots of cameos from the Marvel Universe. Thor is charming. Thor is beautiful. Thors are mighty. Thor collides with a quest for love. My exit interviews, of approximate 20-25 people, yielded scores from 8 to 10 (with two 11s). I had a blast! I give this movie a 9 (total campy fun) out of 10. {Marvel Superheroes}

ipc-title__text: Not much serious villain spoils the fun ...
ipc-html-content-inner-div:
RATED 7/10
Language: EnglishOne time watchable action drama. Went with so much expectation and movie is not upto the expectation...The Thor comedies are looks like more silly and lot of flashback sequences irritates the first half.... The second half was too good and somewhat fulfills the action and GFX expectations....
Most of the actions are in dark and the 3D glasses reduces some more contrast... totally it looks like so dull for the first half. Second half was bit more colourful and my high recommendation is to watch it in 2D.I like Zeus more than the God butcher. May be because this butcher kills the unknown gods only, all the known gods are just wounded and survived. It reduces the seriousness of Christian character very much...Wasted.Go with low expectations, you will like it.

This film is all tongue and cheek. It never takes itself seriously. That was an attribute that I appreciated most of all in the film. There is a central theme to the film too, it is about the toxic nature of hatred & holding on to grudges. It offers embracing love and forgiveness before it is too late.It did pain me to see Russell Crowe as an over-the-hill Zeus. I guess I will always picture him as Claudius Maximus from Gladiator.Christian Bale was phenomenal as Gorr. He really had the best transformation. I didn't recognize him until much later in the film.Chris Pratt looked a little scruffier than I last remembered him.I usually am not a big fan of CGI. However, in this film, they really did an amazing job with both the CGI, lighting and color grading.The humor is a hit and miss endeavor. Sometimes it hits the mark, other times it can be cringy. The story really isn't that great but since this is a comic book film, I wasn't expecting great writing. It's rare to see any good writing in a comic book film.It's a fun watch. It exceeded my already low expectations. It was better than the impression I gotten from the trailer.

...yet nonetheless highly entertaining. The jokes are never-ending as is the action. Christian Bale outdoes himself, and do all the cameos. I'm not a Thor fan and past films have stayed on the stupid side, but this one crosses the line into parody and immense fun.

Thor: Love and Thunder is easily the best Thor movie of all time and it's one of the best superhero projects of the whole year, I love Thor as a character and I had high expectations for this film, but it was even better than I expected it to be.For one thing, this film is visually stunning, it's easily the best looking Thor movie, the cinematography is brilliant and the colors are absolutely beautiful, this film has a banger of a soundtrack and it's hilarious, Taiki Waititi's fingerprints are all over this film and it is so much funnier than Ragnarok, with bombastic action scenes and one of the best MCU villains.The entire cast is fantastic, Chris Hemsworth is as always amazing as Thor and I loved Jane Foster's character development, Natalie Portman is also phenomenal in the film, but the real standout was Christian Bale.Christian Bale is absolutely terrific in this film as the terrifying Gorr, he is exquisitely creepy, the film has an amazing and also hilarious ending that really brought fruition to Thor's character and I think was the perfect return to the beloved character.I'm gonna give Thor: Love and Thunder an A.

Disney+ IMAX Enhanced Version1. Second time watching it and the quality dipped even more. In Disney+ release they improved and fixed a lot of unfinished and wonky CGIs presented in the theatrical release.The film destined to be a mediocre entry since the beginning. I didn't like how Taika Waititi made Thor unserious most of the time and that made some emotional moments felt bland. Waititi overdid some jokes and it was cheesy and cringey. Christian Bale delivered probably the only standout performance; not his best or decent work to-date. The ending was not satisfying at all.2. Second time watching it and the quality dipped even more. In Disney+ release they improved and fixed a lot of unfinished and wonky CGIs presented in the theatrical release.The film destined to be a mediocre entry since the beginning. I didn't like how Taika Waititi made Thor unserious most of the time and that made some emotional moments felt bland. Waititi overdid some jokes and it was cheesy and cringey. Christian Bale delivered probably the only standout performance; not his best or decent work to-date. The ending was not satisfying at all.
