"Thor: Love and Thunder" is a high-budget production that doesn't know how to take advantage of it. The script is bland and full of easy jokes that manage to entertain without more than highlighting. The cinematography is successful in much of the footage but there are a couple of scenes where it looks overly amateurish. The performances are decent, Natalie Portman stands out as usual and Christian Bale puts in a good performance without obviously being the best of his career. A movie to see and only remember one scene or another.

ipc-title__text: The worst Thor movie so far
ipc-html-content-inner-div: It's not terrible like Wonder Woman 1984 or a complete mess like Black Widow. It does have some good gags and the budget is high enough so that it largely looks big and flashy. I did laugh a few times and no scene was lazily made. But this is a waste of time.I think the scene where they put in 2 gay relationships via the dialogue kinda says it all. It's where I knew the movie wasn't going anywhere. You can usually spot a bad movie by what it tries to be. Modern Marvel movies can be great if they focus on the comic universe and a clear story. But today most of them are just given to a director or producer. So you may get someone who wants to recreate a proper and great old story in the universe like Thor: Ragnarok that was a remake of a great cartoon. The first Thor movie was a start of the story overall. A small story set among real people. This instead if a mess. The director of Thor: Ragnarok now tried to make it into a full on progressive comedy so a lot of the powerful relationships and deep story turn into gags. Some gags do work, but it's just scene after scene being a gag. A ton of flashbacks and small scenes. With the story itself becoming a gag. It reminds me of the Ghostbusters reboot where they took the universe and made it into a giant joke focused on progressive values and feminism. I didn't hate the reboot, but I can see why fans of that universe hated it. So as I'm a fan of the Marvel universe I really dislike what they are doing to it here. This movie focused on female Thor and overall progressive values instead of trying to expand the Thor universe. It's catering to the ignorant masses who buy movie tickets because the movie is progressive. The female Thor even calls herself Thor for some reason. What a mess. At least give her another uniform and another name. Thor is the name of a male god in the Norse mythology. There are PLENTY of female names you could use here. Just have the same character with another name. They do next to nothing with her anyhow so what's the point? It's like the last James Bond movie where they made agent 007 into a Black woman. Why? Call her 008 and that's just fine. Don't lazily reuse an old character to score some cheap points.The movie also fails as much here is created from ground up. There are new gods, a new significant secret key, even the old characters are now comedic so their old personalities are gone. A lot of the story is now gags and progressive scenes with the old universe taking a backseat. Thor: The Dark World (2013) being much better than this movie says it all as it was universally disliked. Even though I didn't hate everything about this movie there are so many pointless cringe scenes that it definitely takes away from the universe. I have no need to watch more Thor movies and I regret watching this one.By the way. Some of the kid actors are horrible. There is a Black kid who is given a female name for some gag reason. He was horrible. Absolutely a mess in every scene. Which is weird as the director made the fairly fun Hunt for the Wilderpeople (2016) with a kid actor and has many other movies with boy actors. So what went wrong? I think everyone was just being lazy here.

Thor: Love and Thunder continues with the adventures of Thor(Chris Hemsworth), after the events of Avengers: Endgame(2019). Thor joins forces with Valkyrie(Tessa Thompson), Korg(Taika Waititi) & old flame Jane Foster(Natalie Portman), to fight Gorr the God Butcher(Christian Bale), who plans to eradicate all gods.Thor: Love and Thunder is a mind-blowing film. Director Taika Waititi has knocked it out of the park yet again, after Thor: Ragnarok(2017). The action set pieces are awe-inspiring. The visual effects are fantastic. The 3D is eye-popping, especially in IMAX. The humor in the movie is guffaw worthy. There are also emotional moments, that differentiates this film from its 2017 predecessor. My favorite movie in Phase 4 of the Marvel Cinematic Universe, after Spider-Man: No Way Home(2021). Chris Hemsworth is outstanding as Thor. Hemsworth goes from strength to strength each time he plays the God of Thunder. Natalie Portman is spectacular as Jane Foster/The Mighty Thor. Portman's triumphant return to the Marvel Cinematic Universe surpassed my already sky high expectations. Chris Hemsworth & Natalie Portman share effortless camaraderie together. Christian Bale is unforgettable as Gorr. Bale's performance makes his character one of the best villains in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Tessa Thompson is excellent as King Valkyrie. Taika Waititi is hilarious as Korg. Russell Crowe is superb as Zeus. The supporting cast is great. The cameos are memorable. Thor: Love and Thunder is a must watch for Marvel Cinematic Universe fans. Go, have a whale of a time watching it on the big screen. Can't wait for the next Thor film!

..and yet, this is all so very familiar.Love and Thunder is too much of a joke to take seriously.Overly silly tone (the goats get old really fast), an average villain plot (and a WASTED great actor), and a lack of real stakes. Add the fact that some beings die (cheaply) and some just don't.. or that "powerful Gods" become inconsistently useless for the sake of plot.I'm tired of mediocrity. No amount of colorful scenes will make this work, waititi. The worst part is that it uses stories that were written with buildup, intent and merit for a Comic.. and it feels like they were mushed and summarized onto an average script for the sake of much needed substance. That is not to say Chris and Natalie didn't deliver on the emotional tones at times! These great actors delivered on something I actually enjoyed.. but it feels ultimately hollow and unimportant. It's a decent watch, in the same vein as the first Ant-Man was. The masses might like it (although the theater I went to was mostly silent).You can see naked Thor in the trailer.. so, just wait for the Disney+ release.

ipc-title__text: MORE OF A FART THAN THUNDER
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Really puerile humour and weak boring story. Confused as to what it was all about. Cancer, feminism, schoolboy humour. A real mess.Loved early Thor but not this. Love Hemsworth but now he really is just taking the piss.Waititi should stick to his TV comedies, which I love, and leave superhero movies alone. He has literally lost the plot. 🙄

ipc-title__text: Enjoyable if you have to see something at the cinema
ipc-html-content-inner-div: My sister wanted to go to a movie with me. Ok let's see Thor I said. It was a little short at 2 hours or so for the money we paid. We've all seen Marvel films by now so it's a movie you know what to expect going into so it's not a gamble. Nothing to write home about but enjoyable. Interesting choice of soundtrack which will either be loved or hated by many I would say. It needed a good half hour more to flesh out the story. It was really quite short for a Marvel film. I'd watch it again when it comes on TV but wouldn't really recommend it to non-Marvel fans as I don't think it's very appealing overall.

ipc-title__text: Too Much Love, Not Enough Thunder
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Marvel did not quite amp up their action and story arcs in "Thor: Love and Thunder". However, there were only a few dull moments. The movie was fun, funny, and curious, especially with its new character redesigns and plot twists.Taika Waititi did a good job directing this latest film in the "Thor" franchise. He also wrote a neat script with Jennifer Kaytin Robinson. As a fictional character, Thor was originally created for Marvel comics by Stan Lee and Jason Aaron.Barry Baz Idoine, the cinematographer, was the biggest winner in this film. Both Michael Giacchino and Nami Melumad's musical scoring was great. Nigel Phelps' production design was amazing. Good work also by the art direction and set decoration teams. Mayes C. Rubeo did superb work on costume design. The hair-makeup, VFX, CGI, sound, and stunts crews also brought their A-game.Thor, played by Chris Hemsworth, was amazing - his comedic timing was also on point. Jane Foster, aka Mighty Thor, played by Natalie Portman, was a revelation. Gorr, played by Christian Bale, was mindblowing. King Valkyrie, played by Tessa Thompson, was great. Korg, voiced by Taika Waititi, was memorable. Zeus, played by Russell Crowe, was brilliant - his every scene was masterful.Memorable cameos by Sam Neill (as stage-actor Odin, rather interesting), Matt Damon (as stage-actor Loki, rather funny), Luke Hemsworth (as stage-actor Thor, rather fitting), and Melissa McCarthy (as stage-actress Hela, rather hilarious).All other cast and crew did amazing work in "Thor: Love and Thunder" now streaming on Disney+ Hotstar.I loved how Waititi implemented and then balanced several captivating and entertaining angles and elements. As a result, an almost-2-hour movie felt half as short. That said, "Thor: Love and Thunder" did not live up to the standards set by previous "Thor" titles.Making a superhero out of Jane Foster was the best decision for this movie. Portman hit it out of the ballpark. This was in keeping with the comic books, including "WHAT IF? #10" (published in 1977), which saw a mortal Jane Foster transform into Thordis, the Goddess of Thunder. Goes to show how progressive that small slice of Marvel comic history was to have made such an empowered character all those years ago.In the movie, Thor's love for the dying Jane was strong enough to ensure that Mjölnir (whose shattered pieces were still on Earth) found her worthy to wield the deific hammer, thus saving her life for the time being and granting her fresh purpose. They covered plenty of key relationship elements between Thor and Jane, and it was fun to watch. But aside from Thor and his love, Mjölnir itself saw something in Jane, and therein was the real gift of all.As a villain, Gorr the God Butcher was an excellent addition to the cast. Christian Bale was stupendous in the role. He's going to be a hit among atheists. In truth, Bale was the best thing in "Love and Thunder". His character brought great meaning to the story.The movie contained a few fan-crazy moments, and two more-than-interesting post-credits scenes. I particularly loved the rock-n-roll elements. Somehow, despite having more than a few corny and clichéd elements, "Thor: Love and Thunder" did not fail to use them all to regale and entertain. It was good fun, though it wasn't as great as some of the "Thor" movies that preceded it.

ipc-title__text: A fun movie that lacked focus.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: As someone who has not read the comics these superhero movies are based on, it's interesting how I picked up plot points from some of the recent comic arcs prior to their cinematic debut. Case in point, I knew for a while that Jane Foster (Natalie Portman) became Thor for a while for medical reasons. In Thor: Love and Thunder (2022), this somewhat recent plot line from the comics combines with the modus operandi of Phase 4 of the MCU: wrapping up the loose ends from Phase 3 of the MCU.Doing a victory lap after his well-received Thor: Ragnarok (2017), Taika Waititi still brought his trademark comedic sensibilities to this movie but seemed to falter a bit with the much heavier themes of the God Killer (Christian Bale). In fact, I was expecting a bit more out of Bale, considering how dedicated he is to his roles. Don't get me wrong-there were still a bunch of really great action sequences in this movie, and the revelation of a council of gods is a profound theological can of worms that I'm sure will come into play in future films.The real problem with this movie was its lack of focus. Sure, it tied up the Jane Foster storyline from the first two Thor movies, but the only thing it really set up was a potential addition to the "Young Avengers" that Marvel keeps hinting at but not confirming is coming. Without knowing what this enormous Phase 4 of the MCU is headed toward, it's difficult to justify movies like this. Still, Love and Thunder was a fun action comedy to turn your brain off to for a few hours.A fun movie that lacked focus, I give Thor: Love and Thunder 3.5 stars out of 5.

ipc-title__text: Lower your expectations and it will come out alright.
ipc-html-content-inner-div:
Here's The 4K Lowedown on "Thor: Love and Thunder" (PG-13 - 2022 - Theater)
Genre: Fantasy/ComicMy Score: 7.7
Cast=10 Acting=5 Plot=7 Ending=9 Story=7
Imagine=9 Pace=7 CGI=10 Comic=7 Funny=6Thor's retirement is interrupted by Gorr the God Butcher, who seeks the extinction of the gods. To combat the threat, Thor enlists the help of King Valkyrie, Korg and ex-girlfriend Jane Foster, who to Thor's surprise wields Mjolnir."Technically, you have to actually die in the battle itself to get to Valhalla." I lowered my expectations on this and it came out alright in my book. There were some groaner moments for sure with the humor and acting of the film, but there was a surprise belly laugh that came out of nowhere which made me put a point back on. As far as the Thor films go, only The Dark World got a lower score. As an MCU fan it was a must watch for me and it will be a must buy. I would be hard pressed to tell anyone they have to see this in the theater or buy it on 4K when it comes out.

ipc-title__text: Not bad at all, could've been great though
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Since the beginning of the fourth stage in MCU until now, this film has contains the most accurate quotation from the comics.A comedy vibes similar to what appeared in Thor Ragnarok which i personally considered it one of the best works Thor movies, but here the comedy was relatively more visible, Not always in a good way.Marvel succeeded in presenting a high-ranking villain with this work, carrying a purpose, a cause, a tragedy, and a painful past that was perfected by the actor Christian Bale, as expected. The element of drama was effective in the story, as the film revolves around the character of Thor completely this time, Thor is the most person who has loved people taken from him in MCU so far, starting with his mother, then Auden, then his homeland, Asgard, then Loki several times, and with this film it took more from him than before, all of this and still takes from him more at the end of the successive tragedies until the All Father character is formed and enters the MCU.With that being said, now come to the negative points of the movie. Some of the comedy scenes were inappropriate within the context of the scene and had no meaning. Taika Watiti tried to create a second Ragnarok inside the movie, but the importance of the story and its depth are not commensurate with this amount of irony, especially beside the presence of gods. The last fight had a few bugs and although it was fun, at one point I felt like Christian Bale's presence was just a way to attract viewers with his debut. After all, Love and Thunder isn't much better than Marvel's first-class work, but it's an enjoyable and worth watching movie experience, that's for sure.

ipc-title__text: Good Character Arcs for Thor and Jane
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Under the Writing and Direction of Taika Waititi, the THOR franchise portion of the Marvel Cinematic Universe has gone in a more comedic, rather than Shakespearean, direction and THOR: LOVE AND THUNDER proves that this direction is a smart one both for THOR and for the overall health and diversity of the Marvel Cinematic Universe as well.Starring Chris Hemsworth, of course, as the titular THOR, Love and Thunder shows our demi-god hero at a crossroads in his life and career. Into this world walks his ex-girlfriend, Jane Foster (Natalie Portman) and chaos ensues as both are chasing the god-killer, Gorr (Christian Bale).This sort of premise set-up (and the fact that Hemsworth is playing THOR for the 8th time), could have fallen victim to banality and dullness, but under the watchful eye of Waititi (Writer/Director of the severely under-rated JOJO RABBIT), this THOR soars with the best of them and develops the overall arc and (eventual) pay-off of both Thor's and Jane's arcs precisely and (upon retrospection) in the only satisfying way that they could have ended. So, kudos needs to be given to Waititi for walking this tightrope and sticking the landing.Hemsworth, of course, is charming and buff as Thor and balances the action, romantic drama and comedic portions of this story well. Waititi brings more than just comic relief (though he has plenty of that as well) as the voice of Thor's buddy KORG, while Christian Bale is more than just one-dimensional (how can this actor be anything but interesting) as the main villain of this piece..What surprised me the most in this film is the portrayal of Jane Foster by Portman and how her character becomes the "female Thor" (that's not a spoiler, it's in the trailers) and does NOT become just "Thor's girlfriend". Portman has made no secret of her distaste of how her character became the femme fatale in THOR: THE DARK WORLD and refused to return to this character previously. Obviously, Waititi has been able to come up with a storyline - and an arc - that would interest an actress like Portman to return and Natalie nails it. She looked bright-eyed and energized by this part and by where her character goes in this film.And then there is Tessa Thompson's Valkyrie. This character is a strong part of Thor's story - and the story of the survivors of Asgaard (their destroyed homeworld). Thompson owns this part and is engaging and interesting to watch on-screen. Out of necessity, her character and story play a supporting role to the main Thor/Jane story, so her character didn't get quite enough to do for my tastes. But it did whet my appetite for a stand-alone Valkyrie film (make that happen Marvel).There are cameos and extended-cameos galore in this film - as well as TWO end credits scenes - so to mention them would be to spoil them, except to say that the GUARDIANS OF THE GALAXY play a pivotal role, but for those who came to see a GUARDIANS film, you'll have to wait for GUARDIANS 3 to come out next year - this is a THOR film.A very satisfying entry in the Marvel Cinematic Universe and while not a perfect film (it does try too hard, at times, to mine the same, surprise comic gold of THOR: RAGNAROK), THOR: LOVE AND THUNDER delivers a stand-alone Thor story that drives both the characters of Thor and Jane forward in a smart, intelligent way...and when is the last time the words "smart and intelligent" were used with a comic book film)?Letter Grade: A-8 stars (out of 10) and can take that to the Bank(ofMarquis)

Being a huge fan of the Marvel Cinematic Universe, I must say that the first two instalments of the Thor franchise haven't been anywhere near my favourites. When Taiki Waititi was brought in to direct Thor: Ragnarok, he injected some much-needed life. Since then, Thor has been a much more enjoyable character to follow and I now look forward to seeing him every time. Hearing that Waititi would once again be back for the fourth film excited me a great deal, but I also knew it would be a very hard task to top the third film. Thor: Ragnarok is one of my favourite Marvel films, and while there are more than a few moments in Thor: Love and Thunder that harken back to what made Ragnarok great, it's not quite on the same level for me. Still, Thor: Love and Thunder is a genuine blast at the movies and here's why I recommend checking it out.Picking up after the events of Avengers: Endgame, while still being a sequel to the Thor films, the premise here is that Gorr (Christian Bale) who now wields a sword known as the "Necrosword", has a mission to murder every God in existence. After having killed many already, Thor (Chris Hemsworth) is next in line. With the addition of a very well-done story that brings back Jane Foster (Natalie Portman), this film has a lot going for it. The villain storyline and Jane's storyline are both serious elements of the film, but otherwise, this is just a straight-up comedy, through and through. I liked the tonal shifts throughout the film because Taiki Waititi knows how to tread that line, even though a few moments tread a little too closely.If you were a fan of the silliness in Thor: Ragnarok, you'd probably love watching this film, but I will say that Thor: Love and Thunder dials it up to a hundred here. From giant screaming goats to a love triangle between his axe (Stormbreaker) and his "ex-hammer" (Mjolnir), I was laughing throughout. This will absolutely be a deterrent for some viewers though. Marvel is known to have a lot of comedy sprinkled throughout their films, but this one probably takes the cake for the amount of humour. The humour landed for me about 90% of the time though, so I had an absolute blast.Christian Bale is a fantastic addition here and is completely committed to this role, even though I wish he had a little more screen time. Where his storyline goes by the end may also leave viewers dissatisfied, but I kind of love how it concluded and I can't wait to see where those last few story beats lead. On top of that, I will say that Natalie Portman brings her A-Game here. I wasn't a huge fan of her in the first two Thor films, but her reason for being in this film was easily the best aspect of the movie for me. Again, like Gorr, I just wish a little more time was dedicated to her storyline. This is a film that clocks in at under two hours, but I believe an added 20 minutes or so could've fleshed everything out just a little more.In the end, this is the most fun I've had with a Marvel film in a while. Taiki Waititi's kinetic energy is on full display here, more than I've ever seen before (What We Do in the Shadows included) and Chris Hemsworth commands the screen with his portrayal of Thor, as always. The jokes fly a mile a minute, but I enjoyed that about this film, even though I was worried it would ruin my enjoyment. I do feel that it suffers a little from having multiple storylines and not quite enough time to explore them all, but I was ultimately satisfied with how everything played out. For being such a big story, I will also say that the scale of this one felt a little smaller than the rest of the Thor films. It almost felt episodic at times. Overall, Thor: Love and Thunder is absolutely a must-see if you enjoyed the silliness of Thor: Ragnarok, but some may be turned off. I personally give it a big recommendation because I had a lot of fun.

Watched this with one of my sons who wanted to check it out in spite of the spate of negative reviews he had heard about in whatever multisocial mediaverses he treks through. Perhaps even here it seems.We watched it on a Friday night. The popcorn was implied, it's a Marvel movie, so yeah all of life is at stake, or is it all of afterlife. But Taika is the man behind the curtain and the green screen pajamas, you know he's going to be clever but in a good-hearted way. There's a contrast of mortality, for mere humans as well as for the powerful beings.And no, I'm not talking about those powerful beings here flexing their reviewing might with "1" reviews (or the begrudging "2s" whose Mothers used to sing them Guns and Roses lullabies. I know you wanted this movie to be more of a crossover between Agnes Varda and Abbas Kiarostami, maybe next time.Not to digress, but how has this actual world become all about the outrage? Even Spinal Tap did a few unplugged gigs.Speaking of outrage, I did catch a few minutes of the alternate version where Sonic Youth's early music was used as opposed Axl/Slash - and man that scene where Lady Thor takes out a certain son of a carpenter. Not sure I understood the whole pro-life is actually tied to ur-death motif. /sBack in the actual film, I did find an interesting contrast of superheroes and deities, granted deities that are pretty much no longer worshiped by anyone. Christian Bale was captivating on screen, and Taika does bring in some pretty big stars (and their kids per the credits).I get that it's not just incels who struggle with their impotence, and that while we may want heroes (or even hope against hope for honest politicans), life ends up being more complicated and disappointing than that.Love may feel like a treacly antidote. But like this film if you approach it more eager to appreciate than annihilate, and you toss in a few laughs, even some at your own expense, you can worry later about What the Thunder Said.

The first two Thor films were dark, one note and a little dull. All that changed when Taika Waititi took over the director's chair for "Thor: Ragnarok". Full of bright colors, poignant humor, and a complete reinvention of the character, "Thor: Ragnarok" is one of the most beloved stories in the MCU. Similarly, this film is bright, cheerful and flashy. It falls more in the comedy genre than action, which is both positive and distracting at times.The villain in this movie, Gorr the God Butcher, is one of the most fascinating antagonists in the MCU. His story is compelling and just looking at him will run chills down your spine. Christian Bale ("The Dark Knight") nails his portrayal of the character and is one of the highlights of this movie.The film does a great job of recapping Thor's experience over the last decade and sets the stage without having to hop on Disney+ to watch the predecessors. The supporting characters are likable (especially Korg), the humor is exactly what you would expect from a Taika project and the runtime is well balanced.This is the first installment in the Thor franchise without his brother, Loki, and the absence is felt. Apart from Gorr, some of the new characters introduced were overly comedic and took away from the heart of the film. The second act was weak and focused more on setting up future installments than staying in the present.If you have seen the trailer, you know that the Guardians of the Galaxy are in this movie. Unfortunately, we will have to wait until "Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3" in 2023 to see them in action, because their screen time is extremely limited.There are moments with real character development and complex emotions, but those scenes are undermined by an onslaught of jokes. Personally, I love Taika Waititi's style and humor, but it might be too much for some viewers."Thor: Love and Thunder" is a popcorn flick. It is upbeat, visually impressive and transports you to another universe. The humor might be a bit excessive, but it's a break from the traditional MCU mold. In my personal rankings, I have this movie just below "Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2" and above "Ant-Man and the Wasp". It's a solid entry in the Marvel Cinematic Universe and a lighthearted theater experience.

A late review, but better then never. Thor, well an Asgardian god, after all the battles and fights, coming with a twisted humor and different from previous editions.Thor coming up with jokes and liners in this edition, the seriousness is not there and with all this attempted humor, you may find, this beautifully made experience a bit hollow.Regardless, it is a must see movie, long way from Thor I through avengers till here, so it is not suppose to be missed.Yes, there at some points in the movie that you really wanna just get over the movie, but the end is worth it.Guns N Roses songs did put up a different flavour and taste into the movie. Just that didn't like the way Zeus was presented.Furthermore, there can never be a better Thor then Chris HemsworthPeriod.

This is another hollycrap-ic time-waster with loads of VFX that could admire kids a lot with sorts of plots that easily covers the kids but for adults, it is just a piece of crap and nothing else.Your money, time & energy could be saved if you would save yourself from watching this piece.One thing to note is that I read the cast only after finished watching the movie and I realised that it was Christian Bale in the villain role and yeah that's the only role you probably might like watching in this whole film, the hero, the Thor has become boring.I'm wondering how come the makers don't even review before letting these kinda films out for the public to have, let alone the public, don't they have the responsibility of seeing how their invested resources have turned into, this is one of Marvel's poorly made.

Watched Thor Love And Thunder with Chris Hemsworth(Extraction) as Thor, Taika Watiti(The Mandalorian) as Korg, Tessa Thompson(Creed II) as Brumhilde/Valkyrie, Chris Pratt(Jurassic World Franchise) as Peter Quill/Star-Lord, Bradley Cooper(Nightmare Ally) as Rocket, Pom Klementieff(Guardians Of The Galaxy Vol.2) as Mantis, Karen Gillan(Gunpowder Milkshake) as Nebula, Vin Diesel(Fast 9) as Groot, Oscar Winner Christian Bale(The Fighter) as Gorr With Oscar Winner Russell Crowe(Gladiator ) as Zeus, and Oscar winner Natalie Portman(Black Swan) as Jane Foster/Mighty Thor.I watched was great Hemsworth,Thompson Portman, Crowe and Bale did phenomenal very Fun as well poignant but Hopeful Like Better also a great Opening scene with Thor as well "Eat My Hammer" also I thinkTaika Waiti's upcoming Star Wars Movie will be good he can hit Serious and funny at the same time that is his next project.Great Music By Michael Giacchino(Spider-Man:No Way Home), Cinematography By
Barry Idoine (Rogue One), and Direction By Oscar Winning Taika Waititi(Jojo Rabbit) Eat My Hammer 8/10.

Taika went overboard with goofy Thor. It was an absolute perfect balance with 'Ragnarok'. It could be argued even that one was a bit much, but for the most part it was thoroughly enjoyed by everyone and is regarded as one of Marvel's best outings. The same cannot be said for 'Love and Thunder'.It was nice to see Portman back, and her story line was well done. Christian Bale who is one of the best actors of this generation just didn't have a lot to work with.It's still entertaining, it just loses its way in trying to make a joke every fifteen seconds. The serious moments are so few and far between that the viewer forgets they even exist within the film.

ipc-title__text: A solid adventure that both satisfies and saddens
ipc-html-content-inner-div: "Thor: Love and Thunder" is the 29th film in the Marvel Cinematic Universe and the fourth solo film to focus around the Marvel superhero Thor. Directed and co-written by Taika Waititi ("Thor: Ragnarok", "Jojo Rabbit") and again starring Chris Hemsworth in the lead role, it continues the God of Thunder's journey throughout the universe in a solid adventure that both satisfies and saddens.After the events of "Avengers: Endgame", Thor (Chris Hemsworth) has been in outer space with the Guardians of the Galaxy, visiting distant planets to help out their inhabitants with any problems they are facing. Some time later, Thor is forced to part way with the Guardians after he receives an emergency signal from New Asgard back on Earth. Upon arriving home, Thor is informed that a being known as Gorr the God Butcher (Christian Bale) has come into possession of the god-murdering Necrosword and intends to wipe out all gods from existence, with the citizens of New Asgard next on his hit list. With this new danger looming, Thor hurriedly recruits his associates Valkyrie (Tessa Thompson), Korg (Taika Waititi), and his old flame Jane Foster (Natalie Portman), the latter of whom has taken up the mantle of "Mighty Thor", to stop Gorr from his deicidal killing spree.Since he was first introduced into the MCU back in 2011, Thor's solo films have been, to put it mildly, a mixed bag. The first two struggled to find a harmonious tone, with an inconsistent blend of out-of-place comedy and unnecessarily dark moments preventing them from becoming memorable additions to the ever-expanding Marvel Cinematic Universe. In fact, if it weren't for the amusing antics of Loki (Tom Hiddleston), I assume most people would skip these two films without a second thought. All of this was rectified in 2017 with "Thor: Ragnarok" finally striking the right balance between humorous and serious themes, all of which can be traced back to the involvement of Taika Waititi. All of that remains here in "Thor: Love and Thunder", as it thankfully continues everything that made its predecessor such a great inclusion to the MCU.Though it doesn't deviate too much from the previous film in terms of tone, this one still retains the same amount of fun and energy that all the MCU fans crave. Here, we get to see Thor as a more upbeat character, who has worked through many of his personal insecurities that were holding him back following his fight with Thanos years ago. He is more optimistic and sure of himself, and despite causing the occasional collateral damage like most superheroes, he always finds ways to make up for it (or at the very least TRIES to).I like how over the course of three prior solo outings and four "Avengers" films, Thor has since developed some of the most relatable humanistic traits in the whole MCU, which is interesting considering the character is supposed to be a perfect god. We've seen him go through a wide range of personality changes, from self-important deity, humbled defender of Earth, depressed wreck haunted by his mistakes, and now a man contemplating what his future might bring. But it is in the latter example we see Thor delve deep into what is arguably the most important emotion of all: Love.Considering the film has the word "Love" in its title, it stands to reason that it will be the overarching theme its main character will grapple with. Long time MCU fans will remember Thor's original love interest Jane Foster, the astrophysicist from the first two movies whose belief in a scientific explanation for everything is shattered when she meets the God of Thunder for the first time. Though the two seemed to hit it off at first, certain factors prevented the pair from going any further, leading to their break-up and, in turn, her not appearing in the third film.Foster returns here with a vengeance as she makes up for her absence with her new identity as "Mighty Thor". Watching as Thor tries to comprehend the sight of his ex-girlfriend donning not only similar attire to him but also using a repaired version of his old hammer Mjolnir provided some amusing comic relief upon their reunion and the way he handles this situation shows how far he has come as a character. He now truly feels a love for someone unlike anything he has felt previously, allowing the story to take their relationship to levels not seen before.In addition to implementing all of these new romantic elements, director Taika Waititi also uses his eye for visual detail to the film's advantage. He shows us brightly coloured locations such as the Omnipotent City, a sprawling metropolis populated by various other gods, including Zeus himself (played by Russell Crowe). Waititi uses this place in particular to show how these gods all have different attitudes to what their titles may suggest. For instance, some of these gods actually care about the well-being of the less fortunate while others just find their positions nothing more than a burden. These moments allow for some quirky universe-building that only a film set in the MCU could properly pull off.But it's not all vibrant environments we get to see. There's also the Shadow Realm, a sinister place lit only by the colours of black and white. When our heroes arrive at this menacing location, the film starts to resemble those classic colourless feature films, tapping into that old school feeling of people exploring somewhere frightening. The movie's antagonist Gorr appropriately considers this place home and his dark intentions suit it to a tee. The way in which Waititi is able to balance these two polar opposite locations alongside one another is testament to his talent as a filmmaker and goes to show that his presence among the MCU staff is a welcome one.Returning to the role after a three-year absence, Chris Hemsworth demonstrates how much he has evolved alongside Thor as a character, going from a stoic overpowered god to a fun-loving hero not afraid to show his sensitive side. Hemsworth uses his signature Aussie larrikin likeability to bring out the amusement factor that makes what I call the "Waititi-era" Thor a more endearing hero than when he was first introduced. His scenes with Natalie Portman as Jane Foster had a believable warmth to them, which is surprising since I always thought they lacked chemistry with one another in the first two films. I guess it was simply poor writing in those movies because with the way the pair interact here you'd swear their relationship always had this much of a spark to it. With that in mind, Portman is clearly enjoying herself more this time, considering she has a more physical role in the story than before. It's nice to see her occasionally one-up her co-star during the film's action scenes as she manages to hold her own when the going gets tough.I also think Christian Bale did a good job as the film's main villain Gorr, a man hell-bent on causing the extinction of all gods. Knowing how talented an actor Bale is, it was nice to see him provide the character with more dimension than your typical MCU antagonist. Without venturing into spoiler territory, Gorr's backstory is shown to be quite tragic, immediately clueing the audience into why he is on this genocidal crusade in the first place. The best types of villains are the ones who think they are doing everything for the greater good (like a certain purple Titan wielding a gauntlet), and I did feel sorry for Gorr once I understood his motivations, although this of course doesn't justify him wanting to murder the innocent.Now four solo movies in, it's great to see how a hero like Thor has finally found the appropriate balance between a powerful god and a regular person. Though I think there is little else that can be done in future films to develop the character beyond what we have right now, we can still appreciate him for what he is already - a genuine person with relatable flaws. And that is what I believe to be one of the reasons why the MCU has been successful for so long - it shows that heroes, even literal gods, are capable of going through legitimate growth and changes to become better people. That and the casual humour of course. Either way, it has proven to be a winning combination.I rate it 8/10.

ipc-title__text: The comedy in this fourth Thor film often unnecessarily overshadows the story and drama sides.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Thor: Love and Thunder is the fourth Thor film in the film series. Like the third Thor film, this film is directed and this time also partly written by Taika Waititi.In the film, after all his adventures, Thor (Chris Hemsworth) is somewhat lost in his life and decides to go back to New Asgard. Before returning here, he learns that a dark creature called Gorr the God Butcher (Christian Bale) is on a mission to kill all the gods.When he arrives in New Asgard he wants to ask Valkyrie (Tessa Thompson) for help, but here he sees that his old hammer Mjolnir has been restored, but has found another owner. This owner is his ex-girlfriend Jane Foster (Natalie Portman), who has magically taken over his hammer and powers. Along with Valkyrie and Korg (voice of Taika Waititi), both try to stop Thors Gorr before he manages to kill more gods.With this film, Tor is the first superhero from the Marvel film series to have four films of his own. Taika Waititi managed to get the Thor series moving again with the third Thor movie and is trying to do the same again with this fourth movie. Together with other script and story writers from other Marvel projects, he managed to turn the third Thor film into a more appropriate comedy action Sci-Fi film. In this fourth Thor film, the writing comes only from Taika Waititi herself and the more aspiring writer Jennifer Kaytin Robinson. The fact that the writing now comes from fewer people is reflected in the film. This fourth Thor film contains too many comedy elements, which often unnecessarily overshadow the drama moments and other elements. The comedy also comes at the cost of some of the different storylines, making some of these seem a bit rushed and if not clear which can sometimes lead to a more long-winded feel.Fortunately, Taika Waititi knows how to provide beautiful and believable visual effects in the film and thus brings out different worlds of the gods in creative ways. For example, he brings out the divine sides of the Marvel film universe more clearly and more playfully than they tried to do in the Marvel film Eternals, for example. In this film he also manages to use rock music from the 80s as a soundtrack in a fun and appropriate way.The returning cast members once again reprise their roles in this film. Despite the lesser sides of the script, Taika Waititi managed to persuade Natalie Portman to return to the Thor film series. Portman gets more drama sides with this film, but also super power sides to work with. In addition to Natalie Portman, Taika Waititi also managed to get Christian Bale back to act in a superhero movie with the script and request of his children. After his time as Batman in The Dark Knight trilogy, he no longer wanted to act in superhero movies. Bale brings a darker serious side to this film, adding more darkness and some light tension.

ipc-title__text: Better than I thought but still one of the worst superhero movies of all time
ipc-html-content-inner-div: I had very low exceptions. Seeing how they dumbed down Thor and made him into a slapstick joke I did not even want to see this movie. So when I say this was better than I thought I mean I thought this would be a -10/10 movie and be so horrible I would not be able to finish it without falling into a radioactive vodka-chamber. So the good news is that this is not THAT bad... The bad news is that this is still absolutely terrible.The good with this movie is that it expand the Marvel Universe somewhat, we get to see some new things, some new worlds, some new characters. The cinematography is pretty great and the CGi hold pretty good. I also think the Jane story was a lot better than anticipated and I almost did not hate her.The bad is everything else. The dialogue is atrocious, the attempt at humour is for children who has never seen a movie before, and the story is beyond contempt. This movie is also very short and it feels very rushed, very cut off like they wanted to make 40min more but did not have the budget or the studio hated it so they sliced of 5min here and there. And the acting... sorry but this is probably the worst acting I have seen in any Marvel movie. Every scene feels forced, and every actor look like they do to not want to be in this movie.Almost all the negatives I mention above I would blame on the director which leads me to my main complaint; the directing is absolutely horrible. This is badly put together, badly edited, too short, badly told and if actors that we know can put in a good performance do not that has to be blamed on the director.Everything else I mainly blame on the script. OMG this is so badly written, absolutely horrible. This movie is written by a 12yo blind and deaf fan of bad humour and then it has been added to by Darth Kennedy who was brought in to polish the script. Then directed by a childish man-baby lacking anything resembling an intellect.I give this 2/10. I do not think Superhero movies can get worse than this. This is on par with the worst of the genre and I cannot phantom who can honestly like this.

ipc-title__text: Christian Bale !!!!!!!!!! Christian Bales great performance wasted in a joke of a film.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Christian Bales great performance wasted in a joke of a film.Every million Thor: Love and Thunder makes, is a million Marvel Studios and Disney has stolen, in the true meaning of the word, from fans. And believe me when I say that this farce of a movie is so vacant, that there really is nothing to spoil.

ipc-title__text: Thor: Love and Thunder boasts a bittersweet story about finding peace and love in suffering and pain, but it fails to reach its full potential.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: If you enjoy reading my Spoiler-Free thoughts, please follow my blog to read my full review :)"Thor: Love and Thunder boasts a bittersweet story about finding peace and love in suffering and pain, without forgetting the necessary thunderous action that reaches its best level in a long sequence surrounded by a breathtaking black-and-white color palette.Christian Bale stands out with a terrifying performance as one of MCU's best villains in recent years, while Chris Hemsworth and Natalie Portman share excellent chemistry. Visually distinct and with a unique soundtrack, the formulaic screenplay benefits immensely when focusing on the complex arcs of each character.Still, the continuous comedy bits - far from the hilarious creativity of the past - deny further exploration, removing emotional value from the third act. The action featuring generic CGI shadow monsters holds predictable issues, and an irrelevant plot deviation only serves as a teaser for future content.Overall, Taika Waititi succeeds yet again, but this time, he fails to reach the full potential of the premise."Rating: B+

Thor's fourth feature film increasingly blurs the line between fun and farce, although it mostly succeeds in what it sets out to do. Taika gets a little too much free reign as there are many unnecessary jokes. I really hope you like screaming goats. In addition, it's often hard to take the dramatic moments seriously when you think there's about to be a joke inserted to undercut it.Natalie is a nice addition as she brings some gravitas, however her character is saddled with some occasional poor dialogue. Hemsworth is game as always with his stellar comedic chops. His interactions with his various weapons are some of the best scenes in the film. The colors and vibrancy Waititi brings continues to be a highlight and one particular scene on a moon is stunning to watch. I have to say I also loved the GNR needle drops.It's not too often that I wish a film was longer, but this is one of those cases. I feel like we miss a lot of Thor-Jane moments we need to really feel the payoff here. Gorr is also shockingly underutilized and we barely see him butcher any gods. Bale goes all out with a phenomenal performance as one of the MCU's best villains, but I just wanted more.Love and Thunder is pretty standard Marvel fare that we're all accustomed to, which is fine, however I wouldn't mind a more consequential story in Thor's next cosmic outing.

ipc-title__text: Marvel Dead and Buried well done Disney
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Since Marvel Studios was taken over by Disney and the sad loss of Stan Lee the decline has now reached a Rot!Disney has completely Destroyed Marvel the days of Daredevil the Punisher Ironman Jade Jones to name but a few are long long gone Marvel used to be imo the Number 1 in comic book fantasy series DC could never compete with! Now Marvel has turned so bad that they make even DC look great!This latest offering is pathetic as are the tongue in cheek attempt at humour which fails so badly rendering this movie to neither be a comedy or an action movie I wonder for how long Chris Hemsworth can carry on as Thor without dying of embarrassment at the scripts he is given!Hard to get excited anymore about any New Marvel offerings as time after time the writers fail and produce blandness and badly scripted blandness like this!

ipc-title__text: This Movie Lives and Dies By Taika Waititi
ipc-html-content-inner-div: The Good: Christian Bale as Gorr the God Butcher is probably the best thing about this movie. He hams it up a lot, but it feels purposeful. It's also fun to see him play the role of megalomaniacal villain and his motivations are very understandable, even if sorta under baked. Even the segment that takes place in Gorr's homeworld (dimension?) is easily the most visually interesting aspect of the film.Hemsworth is always good as Thor. He has great leading man charisma, but the way the character is treated as a joke for a large portion of the movie feels very strange and quite the departure even from Ragnarok, where "goofy Thor" made his debut. It's as if between that film and the two Avengers, he went down a couple of IQ points. Russell Crowe as Zeus was pretty fun, and I like how he was the sort of antagonist we don't typically see in these movies: a self indulgent, lazy narcissist.I also like the general comedic tone - to an extent - for the sole reason that it represents a change for the MCU. Just like Multiverse of Madness, this movie is really the product of an auteur, mixed with the MCU's requisite standards. While that might not sound good, it does mean the film feels refreshing and tonally distinct from other instalments, even if not always for the best.The Bad: As you're probably aware, Love and Thunder is basically a comedy. It's a funny movie, but it's almost trying so hard to be funny that it comes off as somewhat exhausting. Humour is obviously subjective, so what's funny to me isn't funny to you. I get it. But I think the humour here actively impacts the narrative.Bale's Gorr the God Butcher isn't a very threatening villain and despite some heavy stuff happening, Waititi seems intent on undercutting EVERYTHING with a joke. Jane has cancer? Gorr kidnaps children? The Gods are selfish jerks and maybe should get comeuppance? Difficult ideas are just watered down to the point where you can't take the movie very seriously.It's also hard to explain, but the type of jokes this movie engages in just...feels stale even by the end of the movie. I know in the depths of my soul that this movie will not stand the test of time. There are some jokes that are already dated that confusingly made it into this movie.As for the story, it's very basic and straightforward. Thor needs to stop Gorr and Jane is helping him. That's essentially it. Whereas Ragnarok was pretty clearly a commentary on colonialism and how societies will always, inevitably, have to reckon with it, Love and Thunder doesn't really go anywhere. It doesn't even have a premise; it's trying to be a romantic comedy, but has to also be a generic comic book action film as well. So what we get are both genres messily mashed together and the film never excels in either genre. I do have to say Portman and Hemsworth have pretty natural chemistry, but it's just not enough to carry the film.Tessa Thompson as Valkryie is just really bad. She seems completely checked out of the movie and her character has nothing to do. Watiti as Korg REALLY overstays his welcome and oh my god, those screaming goats. When I say that this movie has some jokes that are just run into the ground, it's these - three? - characters who are the worst culprits.I was shocked by how bad the visual effects were as well. Rumours about the toxic environment that Disney fosters for VFX artists are vindicate with this one. The movie has some very uneven CG, with several moments - some of which have already become infamous on the internet - when my jaw dropped at how bad certain characters and set pieces looked. It's not a good look for such an effects heavy movie.The Ugly: Waititi's distinctive style and sense of humour is all over this thing, and generally, if you find him and his stuff funny, I think you'll like this movie. But, whereas Ragnarok felt like a refreshing and necessary direction for the character to take, Love and Thunder feels like going in the direction for a bit too long and missing the destination. It's not a bad movie, but it's not a particularly memorable one and I can't imagine it gets better with repeat viewings.

ipc-title__text: An Above Average Mess Of A Film
ipc-html-content-inner-div:
One of the most hyped films, Thor: Love and Thunder is out and I have now finally had a chance to watch it and here is my review for the film. The premise of the film sees Thor attempting to work himself out when he must team up with his ex Jane Foster in order to stop a new enemy.Main Character
Chris Hemsworth has now played Thor for 11 Years and he could play the role in his sleep. He is great in this film and he is just so good as the character and has made him into a really fun lead character. Thor had a great story arc in Avengers Endgame and it kind of continues here with his character getting an interesting deep dive with a continued progression which is good to see.Supporting Characters
Natalie Portman as Jane Foster was a pretty dull part of the previous Thor films but I actually liked her here and I definitely feel like this is the best she has done. Seeing her take up the role of Mighty Thor is really entertaining and seeing the two Thor's in action adds something fresh to the film. The story between the two of them is well handled and I thought this was the most chemistry that Portman and Hemsworth have had. Tessa Thompson is back as Valkyrie and she is pretty fun once again, her character doesn't get much development but she is always entertaining and Thompson is clearly having a lot of fun in the role. But there are some falters here, Christian Bale plays Gorr The God Butcher and it just didn't work for me. He was a dull villain who wasn't given enough time for you to really care and Bale switches from intense to goofy too often for me and it just makes his character feel inconsistent. Korg is one of my favourite characters in the MCU but he is in this film way too much and his overuse of comedy is too forced and takes away from the overall product. I think it shows that he is best in smaller doses and they shouldn't have him as front and centre as he is here.Story
The story is at its best when it focuses on the relationship between Thor and Jane. There is some real drama here mixed with some nice humour, in interviews it was claimed it would be the biggest part of that film and it succeed here. But the story just feels incredibly rushed and a bit all over the place, it tries to balance really serious moments with comedy and it really doesn't work at all with an ending that also didn't quite work for me.Script
The script is actually quite funny, its not as funny as Ragnarok but there are some chuckle worthy moments. There is some good drama here that is actually quite dark which I don't think people would be expecting to see here. But the film goes way too hard on the comedy and it just doesn't work, the two things clash and create this mess of a script.Style
The film looks really good, the action is pretty exciting and in this day of age the CGI looks really good. Seeing the two Thor's in action is really fun and made the action scenes a bit more fun then it would have been if it had just been Thor. But the film isn't paced very well, it clocks in at around 1 hour 45 and it feels rushed. Also as good as it is, there wasn't one action set piece that really stood out for me.Overall
Overall, Thor: Love and Thunder is an above average film that has its moments but it falls way short of expectations and I think only big MCU fans will appreciate it as much as me.Rating - 6/10.

An underwhelming film which should have been awesome, especially with the soundtrack during the iconic battle scenes, but it all felt a bit flat. The special effects were colorful but blurry, the humour rarely landed, the silly moments were too silly, the battle scenes too dark and the emotionally moving and horror moments didn't fit with the light hearted bumbling superhero vibe. The plot was good with a well-rounded villain and the acting performances were good, but overall, it was nothing special and I was bored by the third act.

ipc-title__text: The script is thin, too familiar, and excessively campy, which causes the film to suffer before getting to anything of substance.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Thor: Love And Thunder was easily the biggest disappointment of the summer for me. I do like the trailers that got made for the film. The people that make trailers for films by Marvel Studios do a good job. The film itself, however, turned out to be easily the worst Marvel film so far. I didn't expect Marvel to release a film this bad, but it happened. This is the first Marvel film that I don't want to see again. I'd rather be apprehended by Elon Musk's private right-wing militia than to see Thor: Love And Thunder again. Well, fine, the film is not that bad. But I definitely don't look forward to seeing it again. What makes it bad is the fact that almost everything in it is played for laughs. Nothing can be taken seriously. There are too many jokes and too much silly stuff. I'd say that about a third, or at most half, of the comedy in the film is effective, but the rest is mostly cringeworthy. Christian Bale, as usual, attempted to deliver a good performance, but his performance got wasted on a film where it doesn't belong. Since this is a Marvel film, the costumes and the special effects that got made for it are good as usual. But, again, they're wasted on a misguided film. I don't know if it was Taika Waititi's intention to make the film this bad. It probably wasn't. He was probably given too much freedom to do whatever he wanted and this has resulted in something farcical. I like every Thor film by Marvel that came before this one. Thor: Love And Thunder has a 64% fresh rating on Rotten Tomatoes. It doesn't deserve this rating. The rating should be rotten, quite rotten. I've never trusted Rotten Tomatoes because of one simple reason. Most professional film critics in the West are not reliable. They are bought and paid for, they are politically motivated, or they simply don't know what they're talking about. Hollywood films have been getting worse for several decades already, but the professional film critics either don't realize this or they don't want to talk about this issue. Therefore, they award high scores to films that don't deserve praise, they clobber films that don't deserve to be clobbered, and they go about their jobs as if nothing has changed. This is why I almost never check what they have to say on Rotten Tomatoes. If Thor: Love And Thunder hadn't had some propaganda in it, I think that its rating on Rotten Tomatoes would have been much lower. Unfortunately, many people simply repeat what they read on a website like Rotten Tomatoes. If a film is certified rotten on this website, they think that it's a bad film. This is not how I think. But, anyway, since Thor: Love And Thunder is a film by Marvel Studios, I still went to see it in a theater. Not everything about it is bad. Some of the comedy works, especially at the beginning. The direction is misguided but fine. The performances by the actors are fine. But, overall, the film is a disaster because nothing in it can be taken seriously. In addition, the action is disappointing and almost non-existent. Of course, there is one thing that could have saved Thor: Love And Thunder in its present state, or at least partially redeemed it. This would have been an inclusion of Zeus's planned orgy in the end credits scene. Or we could have at least been shown how Rich Evans defeats Thanos singlehandedly in an alternate universe. But instead what we got was Zeus talking to his son Hercules about killing Thor. How disappointing.

I thoroughly enjoyed Thor: Ragnarok. I enjoyed this one...much less thoroughly. This movie tried even harder to be funny than its predecessor, but trying is not the same as succeeding. It felt like a movie made mostly of tongue in cheek montages that occasionally remembered to add plot and stakes. Very occasionally. Why were the Guardians of the Galaxy necessary? Why did we need whole sub-plots about Asgard theatre troops? Why did Russell Crowe have to go THAT far with his whole schtick? Almost everyone other than Thor, Jane, and Gorr seemed like ironic cardboard cutout scenery. I appreciate the sense of humor, but it's not enough on its own. If the story (and really nobody other than Bale) doesn't take things seriously, why should we?

ipc-title__text: Too Short and Fast-Paced and Too Much Komdi
ipc-html-content-inner-div: I haven't felt this much disappointment in years regarding MCU movies, and I didn't even expect much after the mediocre reviews. I was really excited back when I first heard the news of Christian Bale joining the movie, but just as I expected, he had little screen time and the script focused more on the comedy and throwing jokes at us every second than give us a good story.Like I'm sorry, but did I miss something, or did Gorr only have 3 or 4 brief scenes before his first actual encounter and conversation with Thor? Like it felt like he had even less screen time than Hela. He had only 3 minutes of "origin story" and "characterization" in the beginning and that's it, he doesn't come back until nearly 40 or 50 minutes into the film. Really really hate it and am disappointed in how they did not give the minimum characterization to this villain, or even to Jane for that matter. It felt like they deleted at least 10 minutes of Gorr origin from the beginning. The whole movie felt like it was a recap of a 3 hour or at least a 2:30-hour movie. Like it doesn't feel like a movie at all, and it's all because of the mediocre script.It's the same with the Jane situation; we're just thrown into her story and it doesn't get the development it deserves because of the short runtime and there's just a tiny little bit of emotional attachment to this character and not the amount of attachment the movie wants you to have. And it's because of the mediocrely written scrip, it's because of the short runtime that has lots of times for Thor goofing around with the Guardians and joking, and not establishing its villain and giving him proper screen time and giving him and Jane good characterization.The whole script is written so weirdly that it feels like it's only included the plot points but not the establishing scenes and the essential "let the scene breathe" scenes. The whole events of the movie happen so fast and they are joined together in a way that doesn't feel natural or like an actual movie, it doesn't feel like this movie has 3 acts, it feels like 1 or maybe 2 acts. And I keep saying "feel" because it's my opinion after all and I don't want to present them as objective facts.I guess some of the scenes and jokes are funny, but it's so overdone that looks like the movie was written by a teenager for 5-year-olds. Of course, I knew that the movie was gonna have lots of comedy because Ragnarok made Thor popular again and they found their golden formula with Thor, but I didn't expect them to turn Thor into a goofball. What is it with their obsession to turn every character into a Star-Lord and a Guardians of the Galaxy character? Thor was perfect in Infinity War, the Russo brothers knew what they were doing and they knew how to balance comedy and serious, and that's why all of their movies are 8/10 or more for me and that's the reason their movies are the top fan favorites among all the MCU movies.When you think about it, the story and plot structure of this movie is not too dissimilar from Ragnarok, but for some reason, that movie that was also 2 hours, felt like an actual movie, but this one doesn't. So maybe they should've kept the writers?It's funny that Taika said they have the best villain in the MCU, while I feel like even Malekith that I don't remember anything about, had better characterization and origin?! Like after watching the movie, all I can say about the character of Gorr, is that "he had a daughter and now he doesn't" and that's it. And this was supposed to be "the best villain ever"?! Even the most forgettable villain from MCU, Ghost from Ant-Man 2 had better characterization time and origin. Like I actually don't understand how they thought showing Gorr for 2 minutes at the beginning, without even showing what actually happened to him and his daughter and giving us a proper characterization, and then making him show up again after 40 minutes is good writing and good characterization and is gonna make the audience care. Baffling. I don't understand why they are deleting so much from the movies and making them only 2 hours that feel rushed and that they need more time for characterization and developing the plots and the characters, when they literally made the best-selling movie of all time with Endgame that was 3 hours? Even Spider-Man No Way Home had more than 2 hours of run time. So why not give Doctor Strange and Thor more time so they don't feel rushed!? At least Doctor Strange 2 still felt like an actual movie with a three-act structure and knew not everything has to be a joke. (Although arguably some of the most cringiest jokes of MCU were from that movie)Another thing I'm disappointed in is Michael Giacchino's music for this movie. I may have not expected much from this movie, but I had really high hopes for the music. And don't get me wrong, the piece is an absolute banger of a theme, but I expected at least 2 or 3 more themes? They uploaded the theme before the movie came out and I thought it was good and that there was also gonna be more in the movie, but it wasn't? It's just 2 or 3 other variations of the same theme? Really? That's it? Just one theme for the whole movie which occasionally is played as a sad and somber variation? I know that Doctor Strange 2016's themes were also mostly variations of the main theme, but they sounded different enough and had more themes. But this one only has one theme and that's disappointing to me. I wasn't really a fan of his Batman theme too, felt too repetitive and nothing iconic or memorable. Even his No Way Home had like some good different themes. I still wish he composed for every one of these movies (not Black Panther of course) andSo pretty much every aspect of this movie is a disappointment.What these movies need is more time spent in pre-production and I'm talking about pre-vis for the action scenes, I'm talking about more time spent in the writing room improving the scripts. How can this multi-billion dollar company not find good writers? Maybe bring back Christopher Markus and Stephen McFeely? Because they seem to actually know how to write competent scripts that might have cringey jokes in them too, but have serious moments too and don't turn everything into a joke and rush things by cramming everything into 2 hours.Also, have we not gotten tired of villains summoning minions and demon creatures to fight for them and they just sit far behind and watch?! Even Hela had a decent fight scene with the Asgardian army in Ragnarok and that me feel like at least they will do a good fight scene with Gorr, but they didn't?! Like do they not realize how boring it is to introduce an already underdeveloped villain with bad characterization and laughably bad origin scene, only to have him sit somewhere and just summon demons to fight for him? Like imagine if instead of Captain America jumping into the battle with his shield and fighting the bad guys, he just stood there and sent some random guys to fight for him. Or instead of Thor going around with his hammer and defeating enemies, he just summoned some kids to fight for him... oh! That was actually one of the coolest scenes though, but you get what I mean.My disappointment with Gorr is immeasurable and my day is ruined.In conclusion, Gorr had a horrible origin story (his origin is ok, but not presented well. Might as well just write his origin on a black screen and not show anything) and worse characterization. He made decisions so quickly and changed his motivation and his mind so quickly and so many times like a teenager who doesn't know what he wants. Jane had a bad characterization too because the short run time didn't allow her story to become more developed and they could've presented her story in a better way. The action scenes are nice but what is action good for when you have a really bad script? Thor is turned into a more goofball and an idiot than he was before. The music is nice but only has one theme. Gorr has really awful screen time. The movie doesn't feel like an actual film. There are not 3 acts here, it feels like one act. Too short and rushed and nothing gets developed in this short run time. They have time for jokes but not actual character and plot development and decent characterization.Thoroughly disappointed in the villain and everything else, and I would've ignored some of the other problems if Gorr was actually well-written, had a good origin story of more than 5 minutes, actual good characterization and development, and much, much more screen time than this.

IN A NUTSHELL:
Welcome back to the exciting world of the Marvel Cinematic Universe! In this new addition, Thor enlists the help of Valkyrie, Korg, and ex-girlfriend Jane Foster to fight Gorr the God Butcher, who intends to make the gods extinct.This hilarious and fun movie was directed by the creative and playful Taika Waititi, as well as written by him with writing help by Jennifer Kaytin Robinson. Stan Lee gets writing credits for his visionary Marvel comics. Man, I miss seeing his cameos in Marvel movies.THINGS I LIKED:
Chris Hemsworth was made for this role. He's bigger and badder than ever. His trainer, Luke Zocchi stated, "He is in phenomenal nick. He's the biggest he has ever been. He's the heaviest he's ever been. This extent of musculature required Hemsworth to eat at least 8 times a day during the entire duration of filming just to maintain all the muscle mass he had acquired." There's a scene when we see Hemsworth completely naked from behind and shirtless from the front. Speaking about his physique, admiring Chris Pratt called Hemsworth a man-God. Ha ha Chris Hemsworth's son Tristan is seen in the movie as the young Thor.Who doesn't love Thor? He has more stand-alone films than any other MCU character.The cast features five Oscar winners - Christian Bale, Matt Damon, Natalie Portman, Taika Waititi, and Russell Crowe - and two Oscar nominees - Bradley Cooper and Melissa McCarthy.To catch everyone up to speed, an entertaining summary features video clips from Thor's past movies, plus a few new ones to fill in the blanks.Wow, I didn't even recognize Christian Bale until he started to speak! Initially, he turned down the role but his kids begged him to do it. His performance is exceptional and what takes the parody style of the movie into an Avenger battle.It's so great to see the beautiful and talented Natalie Portman again. She looks amazing.I adore the Guardians of the Galaxy, so I loved their inclusion in this story.So much humor, both visual and spoken.Fun, rocking soundtrack.So many fun cameos like Matt Damon, Melissa McCarthy, and...no more spoilers.Lots of flashbacks and fun Easter Eggs for true MCU fans.As with all MCU films, keep watching during the final rolling credits for another scene and sneak peek at what's to come.THINGS I DIDN'T LIKE:
Not all of the humor lands. In fact, some of the cheap and quirky jokes get in the way of developing a powerful movie. Overall, the movie feels like a goof-fest and even a little embarrassing.What the heck was that accent supposed to be for Zeus? Russell Crowe's portrayal was way too silly and even disrespectful for the all-powerful Zeus.Christian Bale's character was interesting and completely underutilized. Korg had more screen time and lines than the villain in the film. Bad move.TIPS FOR PARENTS:
Some profanity
Lesbian references
Superhero violence.Various kinds of weapons were used.People die.THEMES:
Love and loss
Purpose in life
Self-discovery
Friendship
Loyalty

ipc-title__text: Not every god has a plan
Don't get the hate - this was excellent!
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Thor: Love and Thunder is an excellent film. It's hilarious, has a great villain, and Chris Hemsworth delivers, as usual, as Thor. The movie once again deals with Thor looking to belong to a family that cares about him, and in doing so he has to rescue a bunch of missing children and reconnect with the old love of his life who now wields his Hammer and has become a new version of Thor. Thor evolves in this film to a father figure, and it's beautiful and funny and heartfelt.

ipc-title__text: Boring villain makes this movie below average
Missed Potential Due To Odd Tone
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Despite great potential and some brilliant performances, Waititi's second direction of Thor is wide of the mark. It seems unable to find the genre it wants to fit in, keeping the same humour from Ragnarok, but mixing it with horror in Bale's Gorr. Neither genre is able to build momentum, meaning typically funny scenes, which would have landed in the previous film, have far less impact, yet the comedy is too constant to allow any other tone for the film.For the most part, the performances of the cast are brilliant. Hemsworth is in phenomenal shape and perfectly encapsulates the Thor character that has come to be the norm, funny and zainy but able to pull the emotional parts off easily. Portman makes an excellent return, displaying the contrast of frailty and power superbly. Bale is outstanding, its a shame Gorr isn't allowed to flourish in a darker context given Bale's performance.Crowe, for me, had a very dodgy 'Greek' accent, and was used as comic relief in a time when it wasn't needed. Zeus was wasted as a whole. Axl/Astrid was also particularly rigid playing Heimdall's son.There is a period around the halfway mark in the Shadow Realm where everything becomes infinitely better, and Bale is able to shine. The use of colour (or lack thereof) is powerful and is the only time where a clear period of terror/darkness is created. They are great scenes, and everything appears to improve, even the CGI.The CGI largely looks pretty good, but particularly during the early stages of the film does appear less crisp, as is frequently becoming the case in MCU films released in this period. However, screen ratio is used very well, often switching, but without much rhyme or reason. Taking up the full screen does make those scenes look particularly good though.The story is from great source material and holds up, but often isn't executed the correct way, and characters feel a little twisted to fit the comedic tone. That's the issue with Love & Thunder, it does not replicate the fun success of Ragnarok, and doesn't have a lot else to fall back on.

ipc-title__text: An action comedy with tragic ending
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Every complain about the movie does not make sense. There are lots of comedy moments some of them really good. There some (not all) very good action scenes and by end the story ends tragically with the death of one of the main characters.Taika Waititi is an adult comedy director (not so much about sex) and it seems Disney forced him to tune down certain things and add some kids adventures to the mess.In any case the movie is entertaining, very well acted by almost everybody (Portman did not seem too secure for the part) and with mostly with good action scenes.What other thing could you want ?

The last Thor movie was great. But this one tried to do the same recipe but jumped the shark.The cheese factor was too much. And a lot felt near cartoony.It picked up near the middle and faltered here and there. But if it wasn't for Christmas Bales performance , and Chris hemsworths name in the credits, O don't think I would have stuck it out.As of late, I think the last marvel thing that was good was the tv show Loki. But a lot if misses in the very thing else. Maybe marvel has run its course.Add for 600 characters
The last Thor movie was great. But this one tried to do the same recipe but jumped the shark.The cheese factor was too much. And a lot felt near cartoony.It picked up near the middle and faltered here and there. But if it wasn't for Christmas Bales performance , and Chris hemsworths name in the credits, O don't think I would have stuck it out.As of late, I think the last marvel thing that was good was the tv show Loki. But a lot if misses in the very thing else. Maybe marvel has run its course.

This movie fits perfectly into the mold that Marvel had given us some years ago, being the highlight of this movie.When you go to see a Marvel movie you don't expect anything extravagant or artistic, you expect a movie to turn off your brain, watch the action and laugh a little, something this movie does perfectly, it doesn't try to be something it's not. The story is entertaining, with some exciting moments, but the tone is what makes it not so good, it's very childish, the jokes and the way it approaches some interesting topics like love is very silly, it seems that children wrote those parts, there is no maturity in the story or in the characters, that is the most counterproductive thing about this film. But the rest is everything that we would expect from a Marvel movie, good special effects, entertaining fight scenes, a predictable but enjoyable story, new characters, some cameos and very childish jokes.It's definitely not trying to be something it's not, the director knows what franchise the movie is in and does a good job with the narrative, but the very childish and silly tone of the movie makes it not the best or the most remarkable among the movies of this character.

I actually enjoyed "Thor: Love and Thunder." While there were a few odd scenes and the opening caught me off guard, it was overall a well made movie that entertained me for two hours, thus I am rating it a 6/10 like the previous Thor sequels. I liked the music and the sense of humor, I know not everyone does, but I did. In fact, Hemsworth is a great comedic actor whose manner has really defined this modern Thor character. I enjoy the slight silliness; I don't need overly dark and serious superhero films as some people do. I also liked him in "Men in Black: International." And even playing a real bad guy in "Bad times at the el royale" he still can't help showing off that odd sense of humor and his fit body of course. Obviously not everyone likes these Thor movies and that is ok, but I do, and I'm not a big superhero genre fan. Though I don't like some of the flashing lights and stuff, but that was really only an issue in the first film of the series, which is why I rated "Thor" only a 5/10.

ipc-title__text: The sad fall from grace of Marvel continues
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Fairly funny in parts for the first half of the movie, then when the plot needs to happen, it becomes a cringe inducing borefest.You can have humour, you can have drama and have poignancy but you cannot have it all in a superhero movie whilst trying to push 'the message' down everyone's throat.I felt no sense of dread or trepidation during any of it and in the end it just became the same as all the phase four Marvel movies....just a bunch of stuff going on. None of it made any sense, none of it made me care.I am done with Marvel. The awful writing from their TV shows has now seeped into the once great movies.

"Thor: Love and Thunder" hammers its way into theaters with a 6/10 rating, and I must say, it was just okay.
