Chris Hemsworth and Tessa Thompson deliver charismatic performances, injecting humor and heart into their characters. The film editing keeps the pace lively, balancing action with quirky moments. Its strength lies in its exploration of themes like identity and legacy, and the film certainly doesn't shy away from the over-the-top comic book fun. However, it falters with a somewhat convoluted plot and a sense of déjà vu from previous Thor installments. The music adds a bombastic flair, and the cinematography captures the fantastical landscapes with vividness. "Thor: Love and Thunder" may not be the most thunderous entry in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, but it delivers a decent dose of cosmic superhero antics for those seeking a fun, if somewhat familiar, adventure.

ipc-title__text: A Passable but Underwhelming Adventure in Thor: Love and Thunder
ipc-html-content-inner-div: I was let down a little by this movie but I try to start with what I liked. Love and Thunder still looks good, it has the same kind of visual sensibility that helped Ragnarok stand out from the pack. The fight in the shadow realm has some nice cinematography and choreography with the action. Jane's return is also intriguing from moment one, I can't go far into spoiler territory but they do find a new angle on it to make Jane as Thor unstoppable yet vulnerable at the same time. The rest of the plot isn't as unique or fresh but the creative team handled her character's return with a lot of tact.Writer/Director Taika Waititi brought the Thor movies back into the limelight with Ragnarok and a lot of the legwork was done through putting the focus on the comedy. It kept things breezy and Hemsworth can pull it off so Ragnarok avoided getting bogged down in the drama like The Dark World did. That mindset is present here, but it's regrettable that most of the comedic bits in Love and Thunder just aren't funny. Do you remember the screaming goat video? Hope you found that funny and get ready for that joke 10-20 times. Think Thor getting jealous over Mjolnir being reformed and ignoring Stormbreaker isn't awkward? It's actually hilarious....right? Humour is subjective but I can't remember the last time I saw a comedy in theatres where there was such a low hit rate with the jokes. Love and Thunder feels like it's trying too hard to replicate the spontaneity and surprise that Ragnarok had up its sleeve to diminishing returns.The MCU has larger names but I'm of the mindset that Chris Hemsworth is one of the more underrated actors in their stable. He's got all the physicality, he's capable of running the emotional gauntlet and he's really funny when given the opportunity. Love and Thunder gives him the chance to reunite with Portman and he's absolutely game, he smashes the bad guys and tells the jokes as required. It was nice to see Natalie back too, her departure from the franchise was very unceremonious and she's given more to do in Love and Thunder. She's a good addition to Thor 4 and her character felt like the most original part of the movie. Tessa Thompson is still doing her thing as Valkyrie, she's still got great chemistry with Hemsworth and while she's given less to do than you realize, she holds up her end of the bargain. Ditto for Christian Bale who gets a chance to be more hammy here and there but other than the opening couple of scenes, he's left playing the same couple of notes on the piano for the rest of the movie. He's a great actor and I thought he deserved more to do just like Thompson did. The Guardians are in and out of this movie so quickly, they're respectively fine in their bit. Casting Russell Crowe as Zeus was a nice twist and while he's clearly having fun, I thought the bit went on too long.As much as Waititi re-energized the franchise with Ragnarok, the end result with Love and Thunder just isn't at the same level. I had heard going in that the critics were nitpicking and that Waititi was making such weird and refreshing choices with the material. When the credits rolled I was just confused. What was so daring or different in this movie? There are macro plot beats (Jane's return, the city of the gods maybe?) that go a different way but the movie recycles a similar aesthetic, presents us with a largely two dimensional villain and it's the same old search for the Macguffin. To my surprise and while I think Taika is capable of incredible work (Jojo Rabbit was a huge surprise for me), this is just a lacklustre script and the film presents itself as more quirky and edgy than it actually is.If you had told me at the start of the summer that I was going to like Madness of the Multiverse better than Love and Thunder, I don't know if I would have believed you. Maybe expectations were too high but I feel like Waititi and his team just couldn't capture the same magic twice and what we were left with here was a decent looking and passable effort that was underwhelming overall. Most of the comedy falls flat and the story failed to keep me interested. As much as I enjoy Hemsworth as this character, unless we're partying with the rest of the Avengers, I'm not sure if we need another Thor solo adventure. Maybe we've had our fill of Thor beating people up with G&R playing in the background?

I can't be bothered typing an essay so I'll sum up:Thor is reduced to a bumbling idiot to elevate Jane and Valkyrie.Horrible CGI.Jokes that don't land.A plot not worth caring about.Forgettable set pieces.Overuse of Guns N Roses.

This was amazing! Sure, it was very very silly at times but it really tickled my funny bone. The story played out as you would expect with a god killing MacGuffin, but it was still fun to see the Greek gods in their selfish ways. The trio of Thor, Valkyrie and the Mighty Thor worked really well together and I would watch them all day.

ipc-title__text: Where oh where has Marvel gone...long time passing...
Was this supposed to be comedy relief after more serious flicks like "...Multiverse of Madness"?

ipc-html-content-inner-div: Hilarious, sad, & tons of fun. Insanely well-crafted villain. The humor blends with the story & emotion. Great colors & lack of color. The mythological additions are awesome with beautiful set design.

Disappointment is the first word that comes to mind when this movie is mentioned.A great soundtrack can't make up for everything else. The movie looks more like some kind of parody, but it's just not funny. The jokes get tiresome and the movie is too childish, just disappointing.Christian Bale tried his best, but even he can't save this movie from mediocrity. I've skipped a few Marvel movies, because they kept getting worse and worse, and this movie convinced me to skip a few more.The film bores the viewer with unnecessary things instead of giving him good entertainment. The jokes in the movie are just not funny, they're boring, and the script could have been better.Unfortunately, the film turned out to be a complete waste of time. The cast is solid, the soundtrack is great, but that's about it.It's a shame, this could have been really great, and it turned out like this, just another disappointment.

There's not much to say about the Norse god of Thunder's third solo film. At least, not much positive to say.In 'Thor: Love and Thunder,' Taika Waititi once again tries to push the envelope on how silly a movie he can make at the expense of Chris Hemsworth's once-beloved Avenger. Despite the addition of an extra-creepy villain (Christian Bale), the tone of this film is woefully dull.The combination of a nonsensical script, lack of even an ounce of originality and tired tropes results in what is perhaps the weakest entry from the MCU to date. And it's hard to see any other film giving it a run for this title anytime soon.

ipc-title__text: Chris Hemsworth and Natalie Portman's Chemistry Saves You Throughout the Movie !!!
ipc-html-content-inner-div: A lot is happening in Thor: Love and Thunder. The premise is two-fold, with Thor (Chris Hemsworth) waging a war with the Gods to save a bunch of kids from the hands of a butcher named Gorr (Christian Bale). At the same time, he is also navigating his rocky love story with Dr. Jane Foster aka The Mighty Thor (Natalie Portman). Along the way, Thor encounters some old friends, makes some new ones and goes from flexing his big guns to doing a full Monty in a matter of minutes.Director Taika Waititi's personal take on pop culture, music, fashion and humour is pretty evident throughout the 120-odd minutes. Mind you, the film has some genuinely funny moments, but most of them don't actually involve Thor. You will see a lot of familiar faces from Thor's universe and multiple references to previous films and some cross-over moments. In fact, one of the best scenes in the film is a long show-reel that introduces Thor to the audience.What the film excels at is giving the audience a bang for their buck. The VFX, the sets and action scenes are top-notch. In fact, the fight scenes that involve The Might Thor and Gorr are some of the best choreographed moments in recent MCU history. Russel Crowe's Zeus act is hilarious and looking at him you can't help but wonder if this was the guy who once played a Gladiator.Christian Bale is rock solid as Gorr and menacing in most parts. Natalie Portman and Chris Hemsworth have great chemistry and their comic timing is on point as well. The soundtrack, especially the late 80's rock tracks, adds flavour to the big scenes.If you don't compare it to Thor: Ragnarok, then Thor: Love and Thunder is enjoyable. There are classic goofy Thor moments and then the larger-than-life action scenes. Here's hoping the next Thor movie feels more organic and wholesome than just a pit-stop to making a quick buck for the bosses at Marvel.

Thor: Love and Thunder is the fourth installment in the Thor franchise and the 29th in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. While it is an entertaining movie, it may not be the best Thor movie or the best Marvel movie overall.The film has a more lighthearted and comedic tone compared to previous Thor movies. Some viewers may find it a bit childish and not as action-packed as they would like. Additionally, there are some cringe-worthy moments in the film that may be off-putting for some viewers.However, the movie does have its strengths. The performances from Chris Hemsworth, Tessa Thompson, and Natalie Portman are all excellent. The chemistry between the characters is palpable, and the humor hits the mark more often than not.Ultimately, while Thor: Love and Thunder may not be the best Marvel movie, it is still an enjoyable and entertaining film. Fans of the Marvel Cinematic Universe should definitely check it out at least once to see how it all unfolds.

Thor Love & Thunder was an entertaining movie as far as Thor movies are expected to be, although I felt this movie focused and relied more on the comedic side of things rather than diving deeper into the characters origin. Gorr The God Butcherer (Christian Bale) was magnificent, truly a standout performance. Chris Hemsworth is great at playing Thor, he invests alot into the role as we've seen over the years and hopefully more to come.I'll admit I was skeptical at first in the decision of bringing Jane Foster/Lady Thor back into the mix as her character has had no relevant screen time to the story for many years but I was wrong, she was brilliant. I couldn't help but ponder where Loki was, I was expecting a reunion/ a confirmation of Lokis possible survival for Thor but nothing. I know its all a plan and I have faith it will be incredible! I can't wait to see Thor return on the big screen, I'd highly recommend this one, not the best ever but still very entertaining!

I can't believe how this turned out to be such a mess of a movie with so much talent in it. Great director, top proven actors and we still get this as the final product. The only thing I liked about the movie was Bale as the villain, and everything else was bad or mediocre at best. That's interesting because usually most Marvel movies like this have everything good except for the villain, as a rule. The film looks like it was made by a 12-year-old child, a lot (too many) of bad and forced jokes, I was embarrassed and cringed at some scenes that are supposedly funny, and I haven't heard this much Guns and Roses since I was probably twelve year. Hmmm, what a coincidence!Basically, a very bad movie, made in haste, without much logic and plan, which surprised me. Definitely the worst Thor movie and one of the worst Marvel movies.

ipc-title__text: Bland and not heroic at all
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Love and Thunder was chaotic, all over the place, messy, filed with lots of weird dialogues and punchline with a not so strong storyline.The film is particularly disappointing given that it's directed by Taika Waititi, the nimbly funny New Zealander who made Thor's previous installment, Ragnarok, a smash hit and generally has a strong track record of mixing tones, swerving from silly to sentimental with practiced ease.The return of a major actor such as Portman should feel compelling, but she's simply part of some busy wallpaper. Bale and Crowe are instead the film's biggest standouts, because they dare to supersize their performances.To summarise, Love and Thunder offers the usual lightning-streaked action and tossed-off gags, but this time, there's not enough heft behind the flashiness.My Rating: 4.5/10.

ipc-title__text: It's just okay which isn't good enough
ipc-html-content-inner-div: The start of this movie was flat out stupid, the design, the story it just looked awful and whilst the villain did end up doing alright it set a tone that this wasn't going to be a film you'd assume loving would be a guarantee.The guardians cameo felt pointless, teenage groot is the worst out the 3, it just felt like a waste. I love the humour Thor has but it used to be occasional, this film tries it every step of the way, endless jokes, the weird goats that literally lost it's comedic value by the second scream. Jorg was funny but also when you realise he made the movie he has a surprisingly big part.The story was just ok, chemistry was a bit off, you just didn't particularly care about the extras. The mayor of his homeland was meh, fights were just deja vu and the rest was just a bit aimless and pointless.Did I laugh? Yeah! Did I enjoy it? I'm unsure, I was mainly disappointed/confused. The end credits with the guy from Ted lasso and Valhalla were probably the least interesting I've seen.Truthfully that should be it for Thor stand alone films, as good as he is, his worlds just dull especially without Loki, I assume maybe there will be some cross over with Valhalla? Either way I can't say I'm bothered and most people I heard seemed deflated. He should just be part of the big films and leave the solo ones.Sense Stan sadly passed I've found marvel films to have dropped off hard, this was a full on comedy and nothing like the original 3 where comedy was there it bits. Stan wouldn't have liked this, but from passable like Spider-Man to middle of the road like ten rings to the awful eternals and venom and whatever dr dull was. Marvel had a run of unbelievable films which no longer seems a guarantee. DC have black Adam which looks fun, be nice to have some competition as the Batman and morbius films were dull as hell.Is this the begging of the end for them being guarenteeed hits? After 5/6 mediocre at best films, I'd say yeah.

ipc-title__text: This is The Worst SuperHero Movie Ever Made 😞
ipc-html-content-inner-div: This is the Worst SuperHero Movie Ever Made. I thought it was not Possible to Actually Do That, I thought it was Bad, I thought it was Absolute Rubbish.This is the Worst SuperHero Movie Ever Made. I thought it was not Possible to Actually Do That, I thought it was Bad, I thought it was Absolute Rubbish.This is the Worst SuperHero Movie Ever Made. I thought it was not Possible to Actually Do That, I thought it was Bad, I thought it was Absolute Rubbish.This is the Worst SuperHero Movie Ever Made. I thought it was not Possible to Actually Do That, I thought it was Bad, I thought it was Absolute Rubbish.Q: Just How Bad Was It?A: I thought it Was Absolute Rubbish.That's How Bad It Really Was.

What can you say after seeing the dumbest version of Thor? This movie understands absolutely nothing about the character or his world. Taika Waititi wants to do something different, something entertaining, something that breaks with the schemes and fails miserably in everything he sets out to do. The final product is somewhat sloppy, there is mistreatment of many characters, such as the Guardians of the Galaxy, and there are even ridiculous technical flaws, such as glaring continuity errors. The soundtrack is repetitive, the script is absolutely poor, simple, empty, full of inconsistencies, conveniences and jokes that don't land well. It's a disaster.Perhaps it's a lucky movie to be part of the MCU, because at least it's guaranteed high-quality visual effects, and it can afford to have a good cast that saves certain situations, but other than that, it's an irritating movie.I hope Feige never calls Waititi again.

ipc-title__text: Should be Renamed as Thor: The Fault In our Stars
ipc-html-content-inner-div: As the first MCU film to feature a successful marriage of real comedy, visually striking action, energetic soundtrack and seriousness through its wicked antagonist, Ragnarok deserves the praise & reverence it has received over the years. The attempt to re-hash the same elements in Love & Thunder however, backfired as the film has been deemed a disastrous blunder.Taika Waititi's brand of comedy blew out of proportion in Thor 4, with jokes coming up dry and REALLY overused. Multiple scenes were delegated to Thor's love triangle with Mjollnir and Stormbreaker, which failed to sell in the hundred times it was pushed down the audience's throats. Thor also, has been unfortunately relegated as the film's annoying clown, throwing more cringy punchlines than actual punches. His love story with Jane Foster was non appealing as well, due to the absence of chemistry and on screen fatigue. Between the uninspired comedy and cloying romance, airtime was wasted, airtime that could've been spent to further the limited positives the film had, such as more of Christian Bale's Gorr or Tessa Thompson's King Valkyrie. Shameful!Apart from the glaring mistake to turn Thor into the next The Fault In Our Stars, there remains a long list of mishaps. There is Russell Crowe's sheepish portrayal of Zeus, those UGLY costumes and a clichéd storyline to bring the film in deeper depths. The soundtrack, which put to good use some Guns N Roses songs, were good but feels EXACTLY like Ragnarok, diminishing the actual experience.Overall, Love and Thunder feels like its own parody. The film ultimately massacred Thor, its franchise's characters and the goodwill garnered by Ragnarok, by letting silliness take over to the point of annoyance. It wastes a terrific performance by Christian Bale and its relevance in the MCU is a serious question mark. This is easily Taika's worst film to date, and could be a mark that the MCU, is nearing its expiration date. 5/10.

Love and Thunder's lightheartedness is it's main feature. Sillness of it's somewhat cringey moments are cute and adds an easygoing tone. The plot's shapeless form makes it unpredictable and exciting. Maybe this is the best way forward for certain MCU stories, to make the plot more light-hearted, silly from which the plot has more qualities of a comic book adaptation than a separated entity from it's roots. Visuals are heavenly and that was the golden ticket for this movie. Plot's metaphorical outlook on society is admirable too , there's no genre limitation to remind of reality. Great performances by the cast making the experience a joyous one. Well done.

ipc-title__text: A disappointing follow up to Ragnarok.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Thor: Love and Thunder (2022) follows Thor as he goes up against a new villain who aims to kill all gods. He enlists the help of his friends, and a new unexpected hero. Unfortunately I really wasn't a fan of this film, and I just ended up getting really bored while watching it!Firstly, the cinematography was fairly decent but there wasn't much to talk about. I really enjoyed the black-and-white that was used in the film, it was tasteful and set an interesting tone. My main issue in terms of visuals comes with the CGI, which I thought was poor and some of the worst we've seen in the MCU so far. I'd expect more, as they obviously had the budget needed.The acting was good, and the characters continue to be as loveable as they always were. Chris Hemsworth is charismatic as Thor, and Natalie Portman really put her all into her performance, however I feel her character was rushed and wasted. Christian Bale was intriguing as the new villain but once again, I feel his backstory was rushed and felt incredibly basic.The humour for this film felt forced, and I much preferred Taika's approach in the previous film, Thor: Ragnarok (2017). This was a shame as I really enjoyed Waititi's previous works. A few of the jokes made me cringe, which most definitely wasn't what I expected.The music was fitting, but Guns N Roses seemed to be almost the only music used, therefore it got old quite quickly and had less of an effect as the film went on. I can't really remember the score, so I feel unable to comment on that.Lastly, the pacing was messy, and the tone was confusing. The film was both fast and slow, but It didn't balance it very well, and the film completely lost tension for me because of this. My biggest problem was that I couldn't tell what tone the film was going for, and the tonal shifts were too often and abrupt.
Funny with great music. Solid storyline. Like all Thor movies .. outstanding. Best Superhero flick this year. A must see. Check it out for sure. Saw it in a packed theater on opening night.

ipc-title__text: Good performances don't make a good script
Those who expected too much might end up disappointing themselves
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Story isn't complicated and kind of simple .But, I would love to watch more Gorr aka Christian Bale. For me, MCU did injustice to his character, he should have some more scenes. Most surprising thing for me was, I never think of watching Dr. Jane playing as Mighty Thor however,it's amazing to see her playing and carrying on this role so perfectly. And, Thor is usual best to do some actions or comedic scenes whatever he gets.But, sadly, the story wasn't good. So,the artists haven't much to offer though they played the roles so gracefully.

ipc-title__text: It's fun but it's not great
ipc-html-content-inner-div: At times this film is good and at times it's really good but then at other times it's just meh. It's definitely better then the 2nd film in the series but it's not as good as the last film. Where the film lacks is the villain they could have done it better and executed it better. At times the film is stop flashy and so much going on. The story is the main down fall what I loved is Natalie Portman but eve that could of been done better. It's a good fun film but it's nothing better.

A lot of people expected the fourth and supposedly final Thor movie to be a passing of the hammer, and I don't blame them for detecting a pattern within the latest Marvel Universe titles -- at least the ones that concern the original Avengers:So far, Steve Rogers has handed his shield over to Sam "The Falcon" Wilson, we've seen a new Black Widow in the form of Yelena, and I'm pretty sure we got a new, younger Hawkeye in the Hawkeye TV show (I'm not gonna watch that), which is to say nothing of She-Hulk. And yes, the trailers for Taika Waititi's Thor: Love and Thunder made it seem as if Thor Odinson (Chris Hemsworth), who now seems kind of a joke, was going to surrender Mjölnir to Jane Foster (Natalie Portman), his bland love interest from the first two movies. Why her? Because it was in the comics, shush.Hell, pretty much all of these changes mirror the comic books. Passing a superhero mantle from one character to the next -- sometimes of a different race or gender -- is one of the medium's oldest traditions, so I could certainly see why people expected us to get a "new" Thor with this film (because apparently, first names are now mantles to be passed forth once a magical hammer abruptly repairs itself).However, after the latest Doctor Strange movie ventured into the Multiverse and changed very little in the process (despite adding such supposed game-changers as America Chavez and other stuff that likely won't be mentioned outside of the Doctor Strange or Scarlet Witch properties), I was genuinely thinking that the trailers were showing us an alternate reality; one that will only feature in this flick as a throwaway adventure and then never be acknowledged again. I won't reveal whether Mighty Thor is a permanent mainstay, but will report that I'm nevertheless troubled by the general directionlessness of Phase Four. What's this all for? What's the next Endgame? And why is the plot point "Jane was snapped by Thanos and, due to a side effect of it, she now has cancer" not an Onion headline?As the film begins, Thor is out adventuring with the Guardians of the Galaxy but is forced to reunite with Foster, Korg (Waititi's character from Ragnarok), and other older friends when Gorr the God Butcher (Christian Bale, who gets the best scenes of the film) starts exacting revenge on all "gods". That is, of course, the aliens that inspired the gods and goddesses of Earth mythologies (now including the likes of Zeus, as portrayed by Russell Crowe, who has the power to flick away Original Thor's robes and give us a good look at that regained "god bod" of his). He's not going around slaughtering deities willy-nilly.But in terms of more truly god-like (omnipotent) figures, the film also follows in the footsteps of Eternals by bringing in some more of Marvel Comics' more "cosmic" characters, specifically Eternity, who is a personification of the entire Universe and the source of Gorr's power -- so there's a decent explanation for why he would become something so impressive as a "god" butcher. Whether Eternity is still at the mercy of the Time Variance Authority or an angry witch who can "destroy the Multiverse" is anyone's guess. Could Konshu and Moon Knight rearrange the stars that comprise him at their own leisure? Who knows? It's useless to think too hard about Phase Four media.We also reunite with Valkyrie (Tessa Thompson), who is the "king" of New Asgard while Thor is off with the Guardians. Much fuss has been made about the fact that the film calls a female ruler a king, to which more smart-alecky viewers will explain that Asgard is a made-up fantasy world and so it's not our place to question how the word "king" is used in their pretend space-Viking culture. Funny that "king" is apparently the only Anglic linguistic unit that's used differently whereas the rest of their language mirrors ours pretty straightforwardly, but whatever. Go off, kween. I mean, qing!Another notable "character", I guess, is Mjölnir itself -- which, like I said, makes a very sudden return and seems more interested in Jane than Thor. Its relationship with Thor supplies many supposed laughs. Is it an old ex? Old roommate? Estranged kid? Pet? Simple: It's whatever joke Waititi felt for at the time.Thor: Love and Thunder is very much another Marvel movie. Like many of the post-Phase Three additions, however, it does mostly allow the director to keep his voice. Waititi isn't as unrestrained as Rami was with Multiverse of Madness -- which strayed a little too far from the MCU mold for some fanboys -- but he's possibly even wackier here than with Ragnarok, and we're treated to some wild, interesting-looking worlds (particularly the nightmarish pocket realm of Gorr).The film has enough zaniness to go around and I do like Bale's "Come to Daddy"-inspired performance, but the VFX will often look incomplete, the dreaded Marvel comedy is worse than ever (capping many nice scenes with a cheeky wisecrack or silly character moment and so deflating them -- when it doesn't outright take older dramatic moments and treat them with all the dignity of a Seltzerberg parody), and some scenes are shot like some McDonald's tie-in commercial that managed to get the actors from the real movie involved. Much like fast food, however, you're not wrong for liking it; I'm not here to stop you. Having just seen the Tollywood epic RRR (which was both crazier and yet treated its characters with more dignity than this), my own patience with Hollywood is the lowest it's ever been, though I guess there's little to be done (even as the spread of RRR does re-ignite my faith).I just hope that you're watching this because you feel it genuinely enriches your incomprehensibly short time on this cosmic spec we so briefly inhabit -- the fact of which bolsters just how astronomically lucky you are to be alive to experience this age of art -- and not because you're too lazy and complacent to seek out whatever isn't Hollywood-approved product. And yes, that includes if you're watching it just for Buff Mommy Portman; I'm all for that.

ipc-title__text: Nowhere near as bad as people say

ipc-html-content-inner-div: Because everything from serious scenes to emotional ones were made to look funny or is it the actors making the script feel like a spoof or is it the script itself. Every character especially Zeus played by ABC is a joke. I haven't read the comics so I am the last person to judge the story so I won't. But the film in its entirety is a very badly made one while the VFX is as good as any other Marvel film except for the Thor as a baby scene that looked pathetic. The shots including the VFX are beautiful and fun. But characters aren't strong. A film that has a confrontation or a fight between two or more people/ teams must have strong characters/ sides. Here the villain looks menacing in terms of make-up and/or prosthetics but in terms of acting like a villain, the character is a joke.

ipc-title__text: Gotta bring all the Love and Thunder!
ipc-html-content-inner-div: I finally watched Thor: Love and Thunder. It was not bad, but still a pretty good Thor movie. Not gonna lie. Chris Hemsworth was great as he usually is, and Natalie Portman did great and she looked very beautiful in the film. Christian Bale did such an amazing job playing the best super villain Gorr the God Butcher, he's performance was on fire!Taika Waititi did a pretty good job making this movie so rock and rolling with load of action and comedy, and with incredible classic music and his best voice character: Korg.Best Thor movie in the world! But no spoilers for this movie. So... yeah.

Marvel continues its downward spiral with another Thor movie that could off worked. But tries too hard to be up there with the last one.It's another messy, CGI filled mess that tries too be funny In its first half, before getting into the decent dark stuff it should have done from the beginning.It tries to repeat "Ragnorok" with its cartoony style. But it looks horrible, and goes overboard with the modern stuff, and setting up characters no one cares about. While the reliable guardians of the galaxy take a back seat.The movies saving grace is Christian Bale. Who's always the best thing in average movies these days. Overall though, it's unfortunate that it's just another chapter in a story that's already finished.

ipc-title__text: Not as bad as thor 2 but not as good as thor 3 ragnarok

ipc-html-content-inner-div:
Rating: 5.0
Overall, a movie that is poorly executed and cannot be saved with Thor's charm as it tries too hard to be funny with its meta jokes and constant volume of jokes (even when it mostly does not work) as this takes away from actually building a storyline that should really be developed, the relationship between Thor and Jane and how Thor comes to terms with being at the end of his character arc.Bad Direction (Really tries too hard to be funny and really is chaotic with trying to progress the story forward), Acting (Very Good from Chris Hemsworth (Really shows the experience he has with the character and effortlessly is able to command every scene he is in), Very Good from Christian Bale (Really shows the level of dedication he goes through as an actor as he is very captivating even in this villainous role), Pretty Good from Tessa Thompson (A good comedic relief that is menacing this time around and picks up where she left off from the previous film), Decent to Pretty Good from Taika Waititi (Plays the comedic relief character and has his ups and down given the script he wrote), Pretty bad from Russell Crowe (Really was not that convincing as Zeus as his acting was not there and his accent really did not sit right (which is surprising because this role was really written for him)), Decent to Pretty Good from Natalie Portman (Tries a bit too hard in this performance and really falters when it comes to the emotional side of the character (something that is surprising to me given her experience)), Very Good from Matt Damon (It was really funny how he is able to carry on his cameo from the previous movie and have such a small role even though how big he is), Pretty Bad to Decent from the rest of the cast (though Good from the Guardians of the Galaxy (really just stayed on brand for their characters given how short of screen time they had))), Pretty Bad Story (The overarching story was not that bad as it deals with Thor post Avengers as he is trying to come to terms with unfinished love, it is just not that well structured and the ending really is not that good; plus the general breaks from the narrative were really sloppy and not well executed (given that it was amateur style and it really was not that funny); also, for a movie that is meant to be about Thor and Jane's relationship it does a real bad job in helping develop it (we are kinda just thrown into what happens)), Pretty Bad Screenplay (The movie tries way too hard to be funny and because of it only 1/3 jokes really hit in the movie, plus most of the lines are really predictable and bland), Pretty Good Score/Soundtrack (though it is really annoying how much they play Sweet Child o' Mine throughout the movie), Good Cinematography, Decent Sound, Pretty Good Editing, Very Bad Visual Effects (Given the budget for the movie it is really alarming how unfinished and cartoonish it looks, it looks like they did not spend any effort to change this up before the release), Good Costumes (Did a good job in the Asgardian armor), Plot Structure was a real mess as the movie tries to follow a simplistic Marvel structure but tries to be quirky with it with different breaks and changes that it really hurts with the execution; also the rising action in the character arcs was really poorly done and the resolution really is thrown at the audience and the ending really takes away at what it was trying to build, Pacing was incredibly fast (and this is from the short runtime; the movie could have really benefited from 20-30 minutes added to help with developing and building character relationships), Build to climax was fine and pretty typical of Marvel; climax was incredible formulaic and predictable to any Marvel movie, Tone was pretty 80s and i think he did a good job in helping build this (but is too meta at times with how it is like this)

Shame on Disney and their lack of any mora compass. Looking around during the movie while Russell Crow tells Thor "stay with us and drink wine, eat grapes and have orgies with us. Lots of orgies" was disgusting. I almost walked out the movie. That's not the only dumb sexual piece Disney forces on your children but it alone is enough to give this 2 stars. What a piece of crap.

Thor Love and Thunder is the fourth entry in the Thor franchise and it is a step down from the previous. I feel like Ragnarok did a better job at the comedy. I find comedy in Love and Thunder just didn't land properly. As well, I feel like Gorr the God Butcher was underutilized in the film. I feel like he wasn't used enough in the film and it doesn't make him feel like enough of a threat. He's the GOD BUTCHER and he doesn't seem to fit the role. I do find Christain Bale does a good job as always but it doesn't help the flawed script.I find the CGI in Love and Thunder is a little more spotty than Quantumania. I'm more likely to pick out a worst CGI moment from this movie than Quantumania.Out of the Thor films, my favorite ones are the first and Ragnarok. I find Love and Thunder is a little more watchable than the Dark World. It's definitely more memorable. I do find the post credits scenes in Love and Thunder is good enough setup for the future and would like to see the continuation. I hope that a possible Thor 5 does better than this one and possibly be on bar with Ragnarok. Taika Waititi seems to kinda overstayed his welcome as director, so probably best to get a new director in for Thor 5. I'm alright with him staying as Korg but not as director or writer.

Pedestrian sequel which didn't add much to MCU altogether. Taika Waititi purposely offered interesting choice of 'colors'. While some of running jokes felt aimlessly, Thor & Jane brought heartfelt moments together. Bale gave a hammer-blow performance.

ipc-title__text: Leans into comic book fun and silliness, but does it well
ipc-html-content-inner-div: This worked for me more so than Ragnarok. It's a bit more silly, but also far more serious in many ways. The comedic beats worked and they're better balanced with other emotions. It's also just gorgeous in 4K HDR. Each new movie seems to out do the previous, making it an absolute feast for the eyes and ears. I had a blast watching it and I think it's more enjoyable than the previous Thor movies. None of them are particularly exploring anything deep. What thematics are present are done well, though. Just enough awkward ex stuff, screaming goats. The ending felt a lot more interesting than most of these flicks, that's for sure.

ipc-title__text: Christian Bale Is 2022's Best Supporting Actor in a Good but not Great (Probably The Worst!) Thor Film
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Bale should be nominated for his work in this film and he should win. He is that good here. Now if only the rest of this movie could've followed his lead. That's a movie worth watching. It's almost as if, by tone, there are two separate films going on here. There is the dark and tragic storyline of Bale's character, and there's the rest of the goings on of this movie which is silly. Almost too silly. The differences are jarring.The movie is also too long. Not long for a Marvel movie but could still stand to shave of 15-30 minutes. That's how much time is spent on wasteful things.I wasn't crazy about the last Doctor Strange and I'm not crazy about this film. It seems the MCU is going down but what can we expect? It can't go on forever. Sooner or later there will be some stinkers in the stable.This movie gets a 7 because it's a Marvel movie and Marvel movies still look great.How much longer can the MCU get by on just its looks?Probably not much longer.

I found the movie acceptable, Thor Ragnarok had set the bar very high, unfortunately this movie is not nearly as good. I think it has good comedy and good fight scenes, and the plot of the movie was bad as well as the ending.
Thor Love and Thunder was absolutely fantastic. The comedy and action was top notch. The acting was great as always with MCU movies. Will definitely watch again.

I can't think of a worse superhero film. Reminded me of The Fantastic Four. It is supremely boring, with not a single action sequence worthy of being discussed and with characters that are as shallow as a puddle. It is hard to believe that a director as creative as Watiti has cone up with such tripe. He gave a thrilling new direction to Thor series with Ragnarok. Here, the film is so jaded. I have my sympathies with those who saw this in theatre. But spare a thought for those like me, who saw it or would be seeing at home. It is torturous for all of us. Easily the nadir of Marvel cinematic universe.

The opening scene raises quite a heartfelt moment and very quickly establishes the villains motive which I particularly like here. It also raises serious theological questions to ponder , but the goofiness and lightheartedness of the majority of the movie allows you to avoid a dreaded car ride home debating the merits of religious beliefs.Perhaps some of the comedic relief is a little over the top, but in my opinion still preferable to overly dragged out battle scenes that make some of the MCU films 2.5-3 hours. There are also some nice Easter eggs and references to past films if you've kept up with everything.Most important of all Bale really excels in the villain role as Gorr and displays his malleability as an actor that few possess. For me, the villains are what truly drive superhero movies and here Bale by no means "butchers" the role; certainly one of the MCU's better villains. Only knock might be that it would have been nice having a little more screen time with him considering how effective he was in the part.Lastly the soundtrack was fantastic, highly recommend viewing in a theatre with upgraded speakers.Admittedly , Taika Waititi is a bit of an acquired taste as a director and took me a while to come around to, but I've arrived and am now quite a fan.

I would say honestly cuz Thor just found another love his usual mjonir finally after all these years of absence, finally love breeds love, but i noticed that all the scenes were more comedic than d intended action, that's why i won't be seeing the movie again cuz it's not worth my second time once is enough, but what the hell if was fun seeing Thor again in action i hope the sequel would be a hundred times better than this one, just hoping that marvel will bring back that spark that made it sour like it did before, keeping my fingers crossed.Still looking forward to more reviews like this so there's more where that can't from.

"Thor: Love and Thunder" is a film that constantly seeks to combine action and humor, and it misses both, the jokes are shallow, poorly executed, there is no punch and at a certain moment it seems that we are seeing "everyone in panic" but Thor doesn't have the same wisdom as the classic comedy anthology, because it still tries to take itself seriously and still tries to preach a totally infantilized humor, even the development of the characters is null, the construction of Thor as Natalie Portman is non-existent, the construction of the villain is done in three minutes - it's serious - we don't feel attached to any character, nothing works in terms of script here and to complete the action scenes are with a terrible CGI, we have a constant use of dark scenes to disguise the mediocre effects, with a weak choreography and poorly rendered movements, bringing in great actors like Natalie Portman, Christian Bale and Russell Crowe does not save the work, on the contrary, it makes everything just a little more embarrassing, as they all do their part. Cartoonish and poorly written soundings, not even the direction of Taika Waititi saves, the good director has some glimpses of originality, especially at the beginning of the third act, otherwise it seems that the feature was made in 30 days. The soundtrack is very good, but its sound design in the use of scenes is also poorly used. Grade 5/10.

ipc-title__text: not good,this is what is wrong with the movie industry.

ipc-html-content-inner-div: Back in 2019 comic-con, when kevin feige announced thor love and thunder with taika watiti returning as its director, i got very excited because i loved thor ragnarok very much. My excitement got doubled when Christian bale was announced as the antagonist marking his comeback in comic book genre after a decade.Coming to positives, the biggest plus point was Christian bale as gorr the god butcher but he got very less screentime. Natalie portman who was absent in ragnarok returns in love and thunder as jane foster and her comeback was meaningful. Some visuals were good.Now the biggest issue i have is that despite having so many jokes and gags none of them made me laugh. Ragnarok had several laugh out loud moments but i didn't even chuckle once at the jokes. Thor character is being made a joke film by film underestimating his might. Taika watiti fails to balance comedy and emotions, hence the final product turns into a mockery instead of parody.

'Thor: Love and Thunder' (or Thor 4) is a bridge between 'Avengers: Endgame' and 'Guardians of the Galaxy Vol 3' and is not really linked to any of the other recent MCU films/TV shows, but it does a really good job of building on 'Thor: Ragnarok' and the spirit of that film, including making Valkyrie (Thompson) and Korg (Waititi) the two main sidekicks of Thor (Hemsworth, who both ground him and add humour.The plot is based around Gorr (Bale) having a sword that can kill gods, set-up well in the first 10min, and at the same time, Jane (Portman) being back as "The Mighty Thor" and being able to wield Mjolnir. A lot of this is explained in nice quirky montages, courtesy of Korg. There's plenty of great cameos - from a lot of Aussies too, since it was filmed here - but the biggest (not a spoiler) is Russell Crowe as Zeus, who has a semi-important role, and is great.Love & Thunder is very fast-paced, using the soundtrack excellently - especially four Guns N Roses songs - and it's amazing the difference of "the vibe" during/after 'Thor: The Dark World' and 9 years later compared to this film. The black and white scene is excellent, there's plenty of battles and whenever it starts to get too serious, there's some well-placed jokes. The ending seems fitting and leaves you happy to see where Thor's journey takes him.

The reviews of this have been mixed and its obvious why. This movie doesn't really sit well within the MCU and it doesn't work well as a movie.The first problem with this is is that the tone of the movie is simply off. While a few MCU movies have humour as part of the overall story this is almost 90% humour, but its not really that funny.The music doesn't hit well either, there is an overuse of Guns n Roses which don't really fit well with the scenes they are used. Unlike Led Zeppelin tracks in the other Thor Movies.Even the look of the movie is off, while most of the CGI is ok what is striking is just how bad the other Guardians of the Galaxy look. I would go so far as to say they look unkempt and out of shape.There is a narrator throughout in a New Zealand accent, which was a novelty in the past but now feels tired and its quite an annoying voice.However the biggest disappointment is the emotional payoff at the end. The whole movie is set up for this and I really didn't care. This is the fatal flaw of the movie, particularly since Endgame etc handled this aspect so well. The ending is simply meh and you don't really care.The strangest part about this movie is that it looks like its had a huge budget but some of it looks really bad and it has to be one of the least satisfying movies out there. Antman did a much better job of being an engaging and satisfying movie without half of the effects and flashes this throws at the screen. I am beginning to think this director is getting worse and he is basically over hyped at this point.Even the post credit scene is a severe case of the who actually cares...

*Thor: Love and Thunder* is a significant misstep in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. While it attempts to balance humor, action, and emotional depth, the film ultimately falls short in delivering a satisfying narrative.Taika Waititi's signature comedic style, which was successful in *Ragnarok*, feels overused and forced in this installment. The film's tone is inconsistent, veering between slapstick humor and serious drama without finding a cohesive balance. The introduction of Jane Foster as Mighty Thor is a promising concept, but it is underutilized and feels rushed.Christian Bale's portrayal of Gorr the God Butcher is wasted potential. The character is introduced as a formidable villain but is quickly reduced to a one-dimensional antagonist. The film's exploration of grief and loss is superficial, lacking the emotional depth necessary to resonate with the audience.The action sequences, while visually impressive, lack the impact of previous Thor films. The plot is predictable, with several plot holes and inconsistencies. The film's overall message is unclear, leaving the audience feeling unsatisfied.*Thor: Love and Thunder* is a disappointing entry in the MCU, squandering the potential of its premise and characters. It's a film that prioritizes humor over substance, resulting in a shallow and forgettable experience.

ipc-title__text: A FUN WATCH BUT DON'T EXPECT TOO MUCH..
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Well 1st time in Marvel a 4th Movie for any character that's a big achievement and a joy moment for all THOR fans. Well talking about the movie if you know the movie director than you should probably get the idea of his movie making. As I being completely honest I was expecting more but still I like it what the director has deliver us. Chris Hemsworth is far More better than in the endgame. Natalie & Tessa simply nailed it with rest of the cast. Story could've been more better because you have such a powerful villain but I don't know what the director thought and movies runtime could be long rather than it's Christian Bale just nailed it. Yeah he has less screentime but whenever he comes at screen he'll just made your day. Director should've given a lot more time to Gorr but still nonetheless. Anyway It's a fun movie if you are a THOR fan you'll definitely like it but don't expect too much because it's a standalone film as it should be....

ipc-title__text: A sparkling visual spectacle to be experience in theatres!
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Oscar-winning film-maker Taika Waititi's approach to superhero movies is directly in contrast with the edgier, darker turn most franchises have taken off late. While Robert Pattinson's smash hit "Batman (2022)" showcased a grittier, more ground-level caped crusader, "Spiderman: No Way Home (2021)" and "Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness (2022)" ventured into the multiverse, opening up psychological thriller and horror elements for the MCU. Taika's unique blend of colorful storytelling and quirky comedy had single-handedly revived the Thor franchise which was down in the doldrums after the disastrous "Thor: The Dark World (2013), infusing fresh new life and zest into the character with his quite fabulous "Thor: Ragnarok (2017)".While continuing in the same vein, leveraging his star man Chris Hemsworth's natural gift for sarcasm and comedy, Taika adds new elements to the arc in this edition, calling in not one, not two but three Oscar-winning performers in Natalie Portman, Christian Bale and Russel Crowe. The story follows Thor after the events of "Avengers: Endgame (2019)" with the God of Thunder seemingly reduced to a shadow of his former self, tired of his superhero adventures and suffering from a lack of purpose and meaning. He is, however, forced to take a break from this existential angst after Christian Bale's "Gorr the God Butcher" unleashes fresh hell on the universe, seemingly on a rampage to hunt down every God he can get his hands on.Armed with a mystical superweapon known as the Necrosword and the intensity and screen presence only an actor of Bale's caliber can bring in, "Gorr" is a fresh new interpretation of antagonists in the MCU and a fine adaptation of the classic character from the iconic "Thor: God of Thunder (2013)" comic. Waititi's storytelling brilliance doesn't stop there, as he warps in another fan-favorite comic book arc, that of "The Mighty Thor (2016)" where Thor's lady love Jane Foster becomes a female version of the God of Thunder and blends it neatly with the Gorr mythology.The writing, by Jennifer Kaytin Robinson and the director himself, is continuously engaging and is peppered with unexpected surprises to keep you on the edge of your seat. While the core story arc is painstakingly told, Taika pays close attention to expanding the universe as well, throwing up some juicy easter eggs that will be cannon fodder to the fans for months on end as well as teasing some universe-shattering extensions to the MCU in the mid and post-credits scene. That an upcoming story arc might feature one of my favorite comic actors in recent times was an absolute joy!Despite this apparent plethora of characters he has to work with, Waititi manages to keep his script tight and engaging and most importantly, short with a barely 2-hour-long runtime. With scenes involving Jeff Goldblum's "Grandmaster" and Peter Dinklage's "Eitri" cut at the editing table to accommodate this, there will be a significant section of the fandom that will wait with bated breath for the full directors cut version of this fine film. "Thor: Love and Thunder" may not rise to the groundbreaking levels of Ragnarok, but backed by solid performances, delivers wholesome entertainment and a visually grandiose theatre experience. Recommended!

ipc-title__text: Just trying a bit too hard.
Thor...What have they done to you?
ipc-html-content-inner-div: I don't want to hear anymore about The Dark World being the worst Thor movie. Love & Thunder clearly takes that position. This really makes me sad because I've always loved Thor as a character and all three of his previous films. This fourth one is a mess though. It tried so hard to be funny, but ended up just being silly. It honestly felt like a parody of itself at times. I couldn't take anything seriously because it didn't take itself seriously. The whole Zeus scene is just dumb. I miss the Thor we got in the first two films, and while Ragnarok was a big shift away from those, at least it was successfully funny.This film just went the wrong direction. Korg was not only unfunny this time around, he was completely unnecessary. I kept wondering why he was even there. He added nothing to the film. Valkyrie is fine, though also not super important. Thor, Jane, and Gorr seem to be the only characters that matter in this story. These three are easily the best parts of the film. While I wasn't a fan of Gorr as a villain for this film, Christian Bale gives one heck of performance. This is also the first Thor movie where I liked Jane Foster. I never felt like the romance between her and Thor had any chemistry, but at least her storyline is interesting this time.And it's almost impossible not to love Chris Hemsworth as Thor, even when he's starring in a bad movie. But I am ready, and it sounds like Chris Hemsworth is ready, for a serious, darker Thor experience. A Thor who is more viking warrior than goofball. Story wise, Thor 4 should have ditched this weak storyline and instead kept the Guardians of the Galaxy as part of the story throughout the movie. The tone of the film would have worked much better with this team than with the team we ended up with. Also, Thor needs Loki. The two of them together create magic. Sadly, Love and Thunder is a rare MCU film that has almost no rewatch factor. Hopefully a lot of important lessons were learned here and we'll get another Thor film that's done right.

Thor: Love and ThunderThe fourth film dedicated to Thor reunites the director of Thor: Ragnarok with the cast, and features the return of Natalie Portman as Jane Foster, who had been missing from the story since 2014's Thor: The Dark World.Here's what's fun about the movie: It's so silly you can't help but laugh throughout almost the entire thing. While the plot is serious, and helps move along the MCU's overall plot, there are so many parts that are so ridiculous you can't help but enjoy the ride. Screaming goats anyone?The film picks up a few years after Thor left with the Guardians of the Galaxy at the end of Avengers Endgame. He spent those years regaining his physique, but set adrift mentally as he tries to process all the loss he had gone through over the last decade (or more when you count the blip that always confuses me regarding the Sacred Timeline).New Asgard seems to be doing well under the leadership of King Valkyrie. It has become a tourist attraction even showing a multitude of cruise ships docked at their port.After a few years, Thor finally parts ways with the Guardians to deal with his "midlife crisis". It was fun to see that team cameo in the first 20 or so minutes of battles and backstory, but Gamora was missing with no explanation. Chris Pratt and Chris Hemsworth are so silly together as they totally try to out masculine each other.Now the sad part: Jane Foster is dying of cancer. She looks into the shattered hammer of Thor, which pieces are in New Asgard after Hela destroyed it in Thor: Ragnarok. She transforms into a fierce warrior that calls herself the Mighty Thor. Jane gets to do combat scenes, instead of being sidelined as the scientist. Together with Valkyrie, it was a lot of fun to see two strong female leads stand toe to toe with Thor, and then against Gorr (Christian Bale).I know this film didn't get as much praise as previous MCU entries, but I loved it. Russell Crowe as Zeus, Thor's unexpected but welcome nudity, those screaming goats, watching Jane and Thor's history from before the Infinity War, and the final battle involving the New Asgardian children makes for a lot fun. The making of documentary stated that they tried for a 1980s space adventure, and they pulled it off.Of course, Marvel fans must watch it because we watch everything, but the film does well for people who watch this as a stand alone.

I'm not sure why everyone hates on this movie. There are so many terrible mediocre or less marvel movies out there. Thor movies have consistently been better than most of the other marvel movies and have only gotten better each time. The actors are all at the top of their game in this. A couple jokes are weird and there wasn't enough Kat but otherwise to witness such emotion given in such a short time is wonderful. The use of color is excellent too. After watching all the recent marvel movies to catch up i saved this one for last and was so glad i did. It was like a breath of fresh air on a sunny day. This isn't just a marvel movie it's a great film.

ipc-title__text: Not as great as Thor Ragnarok
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Who would've thought that the only MCU character (so far) to get 4 solo films would be Thor? The first Thor movie was an okay introduction and the second one was quite bland. In came Taika Waititi with Thor Ragnarok (2017), who made Thor a charismatic and fun character. Thor Ragnarok was no doubt one of the funniest and most enjoyable movies in the Thor franchise so far. It was no wonder that I was looking forward to Thor Love and Thunder when it was revealed Taika was returning as director. So did Thor: Love and Thunder deliver more fun or was this a big thundering step backwards?Firstly, Christian Bale was phenomenal as Gorr, the antagonist, in this film. He delivered an amazingly unsettling performance that made him incredibly creepy. He also delivers on the sorrowful moments as well that make him very sympathetic. Amazingly, he can be both frightening and yet kind of root for him. Natalie Portman finally returns to the Thor franchise as Jane Foster after being absent in Ragnarok. Her return is very "mighty" as she isn't just a doctor that is around but now a hero in her own right. It was great seeing her return and it's great to see that the chemistry between her and Thor (Chris) is still there. She has her struggles to deal with it and Natalie does an outstanding job of conveying the pain that she is going through. Chris and Tessa return as Thor and Valkyrie respectively and they are still great. Taika is still fun as the rock person Korg. Russell Crowe is pretty enjoyable to watch as Zeus as well. The whole cast did a great job in their performance.I also like the themes that are explored in the film. The exploration of love is a running arc for Thor throughout and I liked seeing him try to find "himself". There is also the theme of death in both Gorr and Jane's arc. It is handled wonderfully in both and I liked the resolution to it all as well. Legendary composer, Michael Giacchino, gives a colourful and bombastic score that works well for the movie. He also incorporates some great use of songs, similar to Guardians of the Galaxy, such as "Sweet Child o' Mine" by Guns N' Roses that just mesh well in the film. There are some pretty enjoyable action sequences but the most memorable is in the second act. There is a fight scene in the shadow realm that is just visually oozing with style.Unfortunately, the comedy in this movie does not work. I just found the comedy in this movie to not be that funny. Ragnarok had some laugh-out-loud moments but Love and Thunder just never get those types of moments. Additionally, a lot of the humour comes from Thor being an idiot. In Ragnarok, he was a lot more comedic but he had an arc and an important decision near the end. Here he is just a comedic idiot throughout and he never gets that sort of big decision as he did in Ragnarok. He does have an arc but it's very weak. It's genuinely a shame that the titular character has been reduced to a joke in his film. On that note, the comedy isn't as prevalent as it was in Ragnarok. Ragnarok was a comedy throughout with some strong serious moments sprinkled in. Love and Thunder mesh half a comedy and half serious and this tonal clash hurt the movie. The serious moments are when the movie is at its best but then a dumb gag happens and damages the moment.Christian Bale is the standout in this film but his character Gorr is barely even in the film. There is a whole middle act where he just isn't even there. He is also called the God butcherer but we don't even see him on screen actually butchering a god which is such a shame. Gorr needed more screen time to flesh out his character and show why he is a threat to the gods. They also don't show why Gorr killing gods is bad. There is one scene implying negative consequences but we don't see it either. This creates a problem where it feels like there isn't much at stake in the film even though there is supposed to be. The film just doesn't have much weight to it. In Ragnarok, Odin's death was meaningful, the brother's conversation was meaningful, Valkyrie's decision to help was meaningful, Thor embracing the God of Thunder was meaningful, and Thor letting Asgard blow up was meaningful. Love and Thunder just lacks a lot of these apart from one thing at the end that isn't even Thor.Overall, Love and Thunder is pretty disappointing. I expected something that was like Ragnarok but instead got something that felt like an attempt at Ragnarok. The comedy wasn't as funny this time and there are a lot more serious moments this time that is great but makes the comedy feel more jarring as it interrupts the moment. However, it is not downright terrible as there is enjoyment to be had here. It's just not a great Thor movie and definitely not as good as its predecessor. It's just okay and after over 20 MCU movies, okay just isn't good enough.

ipc-title__text: Definitely worth seeing but doesn't quite reach the height of its predecessor.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: This is a tough movie to explain. I can't say there was a part of Thor: Love & Thunder I didn't enjoy, but I also left the theater feeling unsatisfied. There were great parts! The space goats and Thor's jealous battle ax were highlights. There was a big fight scene with some of the best special effects in a Marvel movie to date. But the ending felt sudden and disappointed me, while the movie overall lacked something that made me connect and care about the plot.

ipc-title__text: Not bad but tries too hard to be ironically funny
ipc-html-content-inner-div: This is an ok film but not your standard marvel movie. Most have some quite good humour but this one seems to just want to be a full super hero comedy. Sadly it just comes across as though it's trying too hard.It's worth a watch but it's by no means a classic.

ipc-title__text: Very much a self parody.....But better on 2nd viewing.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: 5 years ago when Thor: Ragnarok came out it was received very well. It was a more comedic but very sharp Thor film. Director Taika Waititi brought his very peculiar sense of humor to the MCU and it was refreshing. With Love and Thunder Waititi goes even further into comedy. So much so that the film feels like a self parody. I am all for silliness in superhero films but if you want an audience to be emotionally invested in a story you have to take it at least a little seriously. The film starts off as a full on comedy and the 3rd act gets serious but again, the shift in tone is jarring. Chris Hemsworth I'd good again as Thor and Natalie Portman is back as Jane Foster Thor's love interest. They have a good chemistry but again it's all so silly that when the film gets serious we should care more. Christian Bale plays Gorr, the God Butcher. He is the villain and is the best part of the film. A really good performance that is taken seriously but the rest of the characters are so busy being funny that it seems he belongs in a different film. Bale's great villain is sort of wasted. Is it entertaining? Yes. There are some really cool visually touches and yes some of the comedy works but I wish that the film would have been more of an adventure and less self parody....Grade: B-

"Thor: Love and Thunder" was definitely a step down from "Ragnorak" in terms of being a fun and goofy Marvel movie. This one tried to be a little more sentimental. Gorr the God Butcher (Christian Bale) could have been a lot stronger of a villain. There's a lot of "could haves" with this movie; it could have been funnier, could have been more sentimental, could have done with more spectacle. This is just another run-of-the-mill Marvel movie.Chris Hemsworth, Natalie Portman, and Christian Bale are all good here. Korg (Taika Waititi) is again the standout character, I love the comedic relief he brings. The movie starts off strong and ends strong but it's very messy throughout.Side note (and I'm not sure if this was just the theater I went to), but there were some weird audio issues like the sound mixing was off. The volume was very low at points like I couldn't hear a thing, and there were points where the music or the sound effects drowned out the dialogue and it was hard for me to hear what the characters were saying.Overall, not bad but no where near the level we've seen Marvel produce at. It's just very average and gets a couple extra points merely for the Marvel polish but there's nothing here, really, that is redeemable or warrants any sort of in-depth discussion or analysis.

ipc-title__text: Marvel has stepped up its villain game lately.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Taika Waititi amps up the zany craziness of Ragnarok to unbelievable levels in this film, both for better and for worse. The movie is often hilarious due to how unpredictably absurd it is, but sometimes suffers due to the overbearing need it seems to feel to always have jokes in every scene, regardless of whether they fit in with what's happening in the movie.But, this is nothing new for Marvel. I only bring it up because it happens far more often in this film than in any other Marvel outing.What is new in this film (and quite fresh) is the villain. Christian Bale gives a surprisingly both creepy and heartfelt performances as the God Butcher. Right from the opening we have a deep compassionate understanding for why he does what he does, and the conclusion of the story gives him a very satisfying conclusion for his journey as well.I just wish there was more of him. He gets a great introduction and a great ending in which compelling parallels are drawn between him and Thor, but throughout the rest of the movie he's just "evil possessed guy." The motivations are still there, but I wanted to see more of what he was doing and how his possession was affecting his mind or personality.I was worried about how Jane would be as "Lady-Thor," and thankfully her presence in the movie is warranted. She's written into the story in a way that both makes sense and actually amplifies the emotional stakes, which are sadly nonexistent in a lot of these Marvel films.The action is mostly pretty good, but kind of a mixed bag. The camerawork and selective use of colors is fun and frenetic, but the overuse of CGI is sometimes far too noticeable and makes the movie look...cheap. Cheaper than any other Thor movie. Cheap is not a word I like to use when describing $200 million movies, but there isn't a better one to use for this.Endings are hard to write, and the ending of this film (no spoilers) both works and doesn't work. There's a satisfying payoff to the themes of love and loss, but at the very end the story asks us to care about Thor's relationship to a character who we have not seen and know nothing about.It's a sweet and charming ending, but it left me feeling...colder than I think the filmmakers wanted me to feel. And that's because they didn't put in any work throughout the movie to make me feel as satisfied as the characters in the movie are by the ending's outcome.I do recommend this film, for Christian Bale's performance and for Taika Waititi's very distinct (if flawed) absurd method of telling stories with a lot of humor and heart and ambition. A lot of ambition.

This film is completely the definition of writer clash. You have Taika's comedy and quirks that make his films stand out while the other writer has a serious sense. The God Butcher seems like such a serious bad guy and they don't treat him like that. Russell Crowe was weird in that film. But the comedy was funny, the characters all likeable, and the action was decent. Overall its a film with a writers clash very visibly and has its issues. But it sill has fun.

It has two-hours of jokes and Guns and Roses! Saw it opening night with 5 friends and we loved it! Lost two stars for Disney's silly alphabet soup, so silly it got laughs for 5 attempts. Ladies were there to see Helmsworth strip down. He was his most buff ever. Jane got buff for this one too. Unlike Gal in Wonder Woman or Bree as Captain Marvel -- you could tell she put on 20 pounds of muscle. Great flick. Like the others, I will see it again!

ipc-title__text: Great Film manifesting Peace in the World.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Another great super-powerful film - with the profound message that if we all work together, we can manifest World Peace super-fast :)This of course also applies to healing the world on a physical level - as indicated in this fine story of heroism and love - such as finding a cure to cancer, which I'm sure we will, if resources and scientific research are channeled properly and all of us billions of people work with solidarity, empathy and love.NB: As the new leader of the Russian Federation, I will do everything in my power to finally end this dreadful war, by restoring diplomacy and dialogue with our neighbors in Ukraine - so that we can commence with the withdrawal of our troops from Ukrainian territory and start Peace Talks.Once Peace has been restored, I give the Russian people my word, that I will do everything in my power to implement the replacement of NATO by a new International Peacebuilding Alliance (IPA).In the IPA, the top priority will be Peace and Nuclear Disarmament, where both Russia and the US will be instrumental to manifest the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR) and the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child (UNCRC) in the International Community.We would like to emphasize that we are expecting the United Kingdom, Russia and the United States to fall in line with this new International Peacebuilding Policy :)

ipc-title__text: There's a good movie hidden in here
ipc-html-content-inner-div: I liked what Taika Waititi did with Thor Ragnarok. The lighthearted attitude worked fine with the serious attitude Thor has to the world and to himself. I said it a few times before - humor is probably the best cure for pompousness. But humor works best with set boundaries, most of these seem to be forgotten in this movie. And as far as I'm concerned it's plain shame since the serious part of the movie is one of the best I've seen in a long while. With Natalie Portman and Christian Bale both giving two of the best performances I've seen in superhero movies ever. And the rest of the leading roles didn't fall too far behind.But some of the jokes were so pathetic and pointless I felt like Taika Waititi got carried away by the idea of making Thor funny and pushed so far it almost ruined the movie. I get the point - most of the gods as depicted in our own myths are petty and even ridiculous, that would have been better pointed out in my humble opinion if they didn't play their roles as cartoons. Cartoons that look ridiculous and petty are almost commonplace. So - what's the point here did they feel the viewers wouldn't understand how pathetic the gods were if the roles were played straightforwardly? That means they wrote these roles all wrong. Did they feel there were too few jokes there - I don't know but if they did they were mistaken. There were already enough jokes as is, and still they kept piling more and more jokes - maybe they felt like the other part of the movie was too morbid so they wanted to counter it with an extra dose of jokes. That's the most likely explanation but in my book they were wrong to think so and that's mainly on Taika who lost a lot of points in my personal book for his poor sense of balance. I had to make a big conscience effort to ignore parts of this movie that practically made me cringe because the other parts were so good I didn't want anything to spoil them.Once again kudos to Natalie Portman and Christian Bale - they created real depth of character where only hints were written.

Snooze fest. Very few moments which were kinda good. Silly one liners ruining the flow. Some visuals were wonderful in bits and pieces but most of it bland. And they dont even know what to show and what not to show in the trailers. Literally spoiled one of the main moments in the film. The marvel universe is getting bigger but I kinda feel they are losing the plot. No content. Nothing. I camt believe it is the same director who directed ragnarok. Huge disappointment. Would have loved to see more of meik. Lady Sif is a joke in thor universe. Gods are weaker and out of context. Everything is out at the mercy of Gor. He is better than all of you. Huge let down.

The multiverse plotlines and the insane success of Marvel these days, has made their content become empty, shallow and a mere eye candy experience.The best word to describe this movie is soulless; a fast-paced story that doesn't allow for the plot to evolve organically, a goof fest of characters that are simple comedic versions of their own selves, terrible jokes, ridiculous scenes (the kids in the final act...) all of it wrapped in decent CGI to make it easily digestible.Taika Waititi did the hardest thing which was to recover a character with a boring couple of movies and making the third one the best adaptation for the character itself and for its place in the cinematic universe, but this second time around he simply over did it, I felt nothing for this film, it's an empty experience with good imagery.If you stay for the credit scenes you will see how pointless the final part of the film is, and it had the potential to do some sort of redemption but it's again an empty gesture... Also, the reason I don't score this lower, is the fantastic performance by Christian Bale (nothing surprising here) and makes me sad that they wasted such a great villain in a movie like this, a great achievement not from the acting department made possible by Bale and Portman but also for the villain's background story, one of the richest I can recall from the MCU.Wasted potential, Marvel and Disney are sitting on their pile of money making this Phase 4 which has been overall very underwhelming, I know this won't happen, but they should either give audiences a break from Marvel or just reinvent the Universe and explore other characters and directions.

Just like how Ragnarok was sort of a transition movie for infinity war(albeit a good one), this one feels similar, a prequel perhaps, for the next Thor movie. It touches ever so slightly into the emotional themes of love and romance, but ultimately falling short of what the title asks suggests. Furthermore for an action film, it just doesn't seem enough. It's trying to be both an action and a romance, but failing on both aspects. Still, while I'm not really a fan of the ending, it's a decent and enjoyable film with a few witty moments here and there.

What I liked about "Thor: Love and Thunder"...it's killer big hair soundtrack.What I didn't like...the daggy dad jokes that just were too try hard and so corny i swear I could see a corn cob hanging out of the mouth of whoever uttered those unfunny lines.You will laugh in this movie because the Kiwi director & writer, Taika Waititi is at it again after the success of "Thor: Ragnarok".They've given him cart blanche and he sold his soul.Chirs Hemsworth goes from Dad bod to Dad jokes in one training session in which he's amassed the most muscle ever for Thor.So much so his co-star Chris Pratt from "Guardians of the Galaxy" is ashamed to stand too close in scenes because he looked puny in comparison to the Aussie All-Star.In a nutshell: Thor enlists the help of "King Valkyrie" (Tessa Thompson), "Korg" (Voice of Taika Waititi ) and ex-girlfriend Jane Foster (Natalie Portman) who becomes "Mighty Thor" ( no spoiler alert it's in the trailers) to fight Gorr the God Butcher, who intends to make the gods extinct with his mighty Necrosword.Christian Bale as "Gorr" is one of the best horror elements of this stand alone Thor movie that doesn't really propel the MCU along anywhere.Frankly though I'm finding the fight scenes in Marvel a bit of a snore fest after 29 of these movies...time to shake it up as Tay Tay would advise.Watch out for: Russell Crowe as "Zeuss" in the naked Thor scene.Why is it not cultural misappropriation when a Kiwi can bung on a terrible character Italian accent (sounds more like the Mario Brothers)?I'm confused.The whole Guardians bunch drop in on this flick not just "Peter Quill" and wait for a special appearance from 2 other actors in the end credits Easter Eggs.I just wonder what Stan Lee would think if he were alive today to see whats happening to his creations.Maybe he'd just laugh all the way to the bank like everyone else involved in this project.It's already made its ridiculous $250 million budget back in just over one week at the worldwide box office.Which is great for the Australian film industry because a lot of it was filmed here in Oz at Fox Studios in Sydney.A part of me thinks Thor should have stayed in retirement in the New Asgard.

ipc-title__text: From an Action series to a comedy...
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Thor: Love and Thunder is the fourth installment in the Thor series. I have only watched the fourth one and I think this was a great action comedy! Marvel tried definitely to make something else and they did. I have never seen a movie like that in Marvel. Great humor, great script and dialogues and the story is catchy and interesting, with good sudden changes and fine romance.
