After what I have heard and read, Thor was an action series which wasn't mean to be a comedy. But this movie, it was a lot of it! A lot of ironic quotes, slapstick and much more! I think this movie is a great starter for you if you are new to this universe. You do not have to watch it chronologically, because they explain everything in the beginning and I think you will have a great first impression! Why do I give it 9/10 instead of 10/10? Because it was a post credit scene, that is a sneak peak for the next installment, but I think this movie ended so well that continuing it will be bad. That's the only little problem. But without that, it is great!

ipc-title__text: Thor cannot catch a break, he has some of the worst movies in the MCU
The night Jane and thor have finally strike the box office
I'd give it a 10 if Disney wasn't involved
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Not a bad movie. And rather entertaining with all the action, creatures and effects. But because Disney has gone full satanic crazy woke, I will only reward the marvel workers on this but shame the Disney people. Sell ALL your Disney stock, do not support them. I got this movie free, so I didn't even spend a dime to Disney to see it. Walt would be turning in his grave over what Disney has become! But enjoy the movie, don't expect endgame or prior to Disney takeover quality. But it still is the MCU what's left of it anyway. So sad to see all the good stuff get ruined by woke idiots these days. I hope daily wire and other good sources get with it and start taking it all back for us. Pray they do. 😊

ipc-title__text: Religious zealots may not approve but an awesome look at Gods and Myths!
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Another entry into the Superhero films' hall of fame by the same director as the other entry: Ragnarok. This time laughs and love in equal measure as action and universal travels, through Korg's unique style of storytelling.We find Thor where he was last seen, in the company of the Guardians, but a number of fatal occurences around the galaxy force a separation: the Guardians on one ship, Thor, Korg and Taylor Swift's goats through Stormbreaker's Bifrost portal to the New Asgard. Here, Thor, Valkyrie, and a new and improved Jane must confront a new evil: a powerful force intent on ridding the universe of Gods because of his heartbreaking circumstances. As always, Thor alone cannot conquer this evil so he must travel great distances to find an army.And here the religious zealots have a hissy fit, as the gods depicted are depraved, self-loving idiots led by an indulgent Zeus, played brilliantly by Russell Crowe (I'll have to wait until it is released on DVD to pause the line up of fabled gods to see if the more well-known ones are there, but I expect they are!). Without support, they take what they need from the gold-bleeding heathans and try to confront the evil head-on, themselves.Taika Waititi's self-deprecating humour and spectacle on show once again, knocking Hollywood's heavyweights onto their knees! A superior storyteller in all aspects: design, stylings and music beyond anything that has come before!! A true masterpiece in the individual Superhero spectrum- Avengers in his hands would be a comedic Dirty Dozen: worthy of awards! He has broken all molds of what sequels should look like: this is not dark and dreary like Star Wars: The Empire Strikes Back, nor fun and happy-endingly as Return of the Jedi, maybe a pinch of both. Having a Star Wars film in his hands in the future is very promising!The returning list of characters, actors and story arcs is impossible to detail from just one viewing and would spoil the surprise and fun for first-time viewers, but suffice to say it is superb! The whole experience is shockingly, breathtakingly fun to the nth degree! A must-watch for Marvel fans of all ages!

ipc-title__text: Very disappointing and tried too hard to be funny
ipc-html-content-inner-div: I'm just going to be honest... I went into this movie knowing that people found it disappointing and sort of underwhelming for a MCU movie just because i'm a completionist and I have to watch EVERY MCU movie, else I don't feel complete. I mean for Christ's sake, I endured Morbius (which was bloody atrocious. The only half-decent thing about that movie was the damned after-credits). Anyways, this was everything that the people said. Disappointing, trying too hard at comedy which just didn't hit with me (Ragnarok was much much funnier), just didn't live up to any standards. Very sad, and hope that they'll save this mess with their next Thor movie (or series). It just kind of seemed like the director gave up on this from the start.

Thor: Love and Thunder.Thor ,Jane Foster his ex girlfriend and Korg the Valkyrie are fighting Gorr the God Butcher ,who's seeking for the extinction of the Gods.Thor : Love and Thunder is a ridiculously fun space viking movie and I have to admit that it was a very unique and unusual experience .The story isn't that interesting to be honest , a big threat again but this time the villain had some really convincing motives and I really appreciated it .However , it felt forced to be funny while they could made it more serious and it would have been more impressive .There were so many jokes ,more than a Thor movie usually contains, but what was bad about is that I barely laughed once.The idea of making such a horrifying villain in a ridiculous atmosphere is unusual to see of course but unusual wasn't enough .The poor Christian Bale took it too serious while everyone else was having fun. Especially Chris Hemsworth because Thor was far from being the usual charismatic Thor .Finally ,I must say that it had its moments and wasn't that bad , Marvel has to do something about its next projects and hopefully we'll receive what we deserve and what Marvel used to offer .

The first part of this sequel is full of jokes, is zainy, wacky and has a light tone. And that works. The second half of it is more serious, with extra stakes, action sequences added and a few emotional moments. And that works too.What doesn't work is that the filmmakers haven't figured out a way to match these dark and funny bits together in a way that fits. There are numerous false sacrifices that don't raise the stakes. Weirdly enough they did this in the Amazon series The Boys as well - and that's a problem.The actors do look like they are still enjoying playing the characters. There were a few, such as the Guardians of The Galaxy, that should have stayed longer. And a few others, such as Korg and the Asguardian kids, that overstayed their welcome. (Waititi plays Korg, so for some reason in this film he gets most of the dialogue)
Valkerie was sadly underused and Jane's feelings towards her illness should have had more screen time.Thor is back and he's here to stay, which is a good thing since I do love his character. But overall this follow up to Ragnarok could have been much better since it had all the ingredients to be. They just weren't used right.

ipc-title__text: A film that will cause further division of fans of the MCU
ipc-html-content-inner-div: This is a very different movie compared to the last one that's been released, i've seen a lot of reviews talking about the contrast between letting the directors make their movie and continuing to telling the "MCU" story. Think the last 2 movies including Dr Strange MOM has the same issue. These are movies that are created by their director to be completely 100% stand alone. Phase 4 of the MCU doesnt feel like the start of something new like phase 1 did.Will say that Hemsworth and Bale are still and always be the standout actors for the film. Its still so surprising that he has such perfect comedic timing, downside is that the script went 1 step to far in making Thor an Idiot. His whole arc from Thor 1 to Endgame that he went from the arrogant god to caring about everything and everyone, not letting collateral damage come to the forefront but within minutes of movie starting this has just been reverted. Bale as Gorr was great but earning the title of the God Butcher was a step to far, seems as though this was a Mordo set up from Doctor Strange level threat than actually the epic level threat. Only seeing the first god actually killed on screen was a disappointment. Thinking that Russel Crowe being signed on for 1 movie i hoped he might have been the shock that earnt him the title. Side note Russel Crowe as the campest version of Zeus ever was a great edition to the movie.Thinking this is where the movie falls down, the comedy in Thor: Ragnarok was perfection and trying to capture lighting twice doesnt always work out. There were some standout laugh out loud moment... Korg but there was a lot of jokes that didnt land. Either cringe or taking away from the story. This could have been a 2 part story which would have been even better. So much of the story was rushed, Janes redemption but also demise was so quick for such a poignant story line from the comics. Then the Goats, it was funny for the first 3 times then they needed to shut up!Im not going to say that i didnt enjoy the movie but i think i've fallen into the trap of overthinking what could be shown in the movie and ultimately being slightly disappointed. I'd love for the team to return to do the next movie and just hit the heights that Ragnarok did.

ipc-title__text: Best Thor movie of the series
ipc-html-content-inner-div: I was pretty shocked by this movie. I went in thinking it was going to be horrible. I had a free ticket and absolutely nothing better to do. It's probably one of the better movies in the MCU. Natalie Portman shockingly pulled her weight in this film and did a great job. The last film she did a great job acting in was The Professional, which is a shame. She's coasted off that film ever since and it was cringe-worthy.There were some parts where they tried to overdo it at the beginning with the Guardians, but thankfully, someone did damage control and the movie got less cringe-worthy as time went on. The cameos are pretty great as well.Highly recommended.

The visuals in the film is really good to watch and the effects in 3D are amazing. The performance from Chris Hemsworth sir is amazing and the amount of hardwork he put in this film can be realised while seeing him on screen.

ipc-title__text: You are not the Thor we're looking for!
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Thor Love and Thunder feels more like a comedy then a superhero film under Taika Waititi's direction. While Ragnarok made it work this just didn't feel like a Thor film. I miss the feeling one got from watching Thor or Thor The Dark World.Being a marvel film the movie has a massive budget and it looks and sounds amazing. The cast is really great and it's an enjoyable movie all told. However it just doesn't feel like something I want to go back and rewatch multiple times.I will give the film a decent 6/10 rating. The acting is fine, the VFX and SFX are great. The story is not terrible but could definitely have been done in a much more enjoyable manner. The comedy was overdone and gave me a headache after a while.Thor fans will still enjoy it and seeing Jane Foster wielding Mjolnir is interesting to say the least. All in all, worth a watch but be prepared for what you're going to get.P. S. It feels very rushed, like a rollercoaster ride without time to actually enjoy any of it or give enough time to it's characters.

ipc-title__text: Few strong moments, buried under a funny mess
ipc-html-content-inner-div: After Guardians of the Galaxy, Marvel went into a comedic direction with GOTG2 and Thor 3. Now Thor 4 takes it a step further and pushes it over the edge with non-stop misplaced jokes.Thor 4's only redeeming qualities are a very impressive Christian Bale and Nathalie Portman, who put some soul and motivation in this movie. Thor has become a funny sidekick and some of the cameo's, for example Korgg and Zeus, are downgraded to clowns who add little to the story.The same joke can only be funny for a few times and Marvel/Waikiki/Thor obviously didn't get that memo, and so they ruined a movie that had the potential to be dark and compelling. Who knew gods could be so unintreresting and annoying.......

ipc-title__text: A Bit Of A Letdown From Waititi

ipc-html-content-inner-div: Nitpicking MCU Fans, I despise them! Thor was finding his place. Gorr was upset with false Gods that killed his daughter. Personally I love how they created Love and Thunder.I can totally understand how Thor was going through a relationship with his weapons and yes it was silly. The seriousness with Jane, shouldn't be a joke. Gorr had a creepy presents. He was played by Christian Bale, which I thought he did a terrific job!However it was not as terrible as Captain Marvel. Above average I say.

ipc-title__text: It's Fun, and that's about it
ipc-html-content-inner-div: The ongoing adventure of Thor after Endgame.It fun, I'll give it that. The characters are all generally enjoyable, I think Gorr is a better Marvel villain. However, like most other reviewers say, it's not the most deep or introspective piece. It's simply a fun action adventure movie.It's probably still worth a watch, and it may gain more attention over time, but for now, really only die-hard Marvel fans need to watch it.

ipc-title__text: Was this supposed to be a joke ?
ipc-html-content-inner-div: I was very confused, as I thought a, watching a marvel movie full of drama and action, instead I was watching a comedy, I mean it was fun and entertaining, but the whole movie was a joke. Taiki did a fine job with the pervious Thor movie, but for this was, he must have been drunk, and Disney needed to release the movie to meet a deadline and make some extra $$$. All characters were funny except for Christian Bale' character of course. I think all those big actors they either were desperate for a role, or must have owed Taiki a favor, else they wouldn't have been in this film. The movie was funny and entertaining all the way, that you would expect a funny happy ending, instead, you get a rather sad and dark ending.

ipc-title__text: Entertaining and vivid. But it can't quite decide what it wants to be.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: The first Thor (2011) is one of the best superhero films ever made. It had a clear storyline, great special effects, a great cast all around with a fine pick for the lead role (Chris Hemsworth), a stirring musical score, and a director (Kenneth Branagh) who knew how to lean right in to the mythical grandeur of the Norse gods. Yes, those were the days. Now in this fourth Thor film where are we? Norse god? No, a 'space Viking'. Serious warrior? More of a lovable doofus with muscles and a magical axe. It's all very entertaining and easy to watch -- things never drag, and visually, Love and Thunder is as striking as almost any thing Marvel has come up with. The Shadow Worls, the Hall of the Omnipotents, and the mysterious Eternity are terrifically well done things to look at. Also, for a cast that includes Natalie Portman and Christian Bale (and an over-the-top Russell Crowe cameo) how can you go wrong?So I enjoyed it. Go see it, you'll have a good time. But I also came away thinking that underneath the hood, this movie is fighting with itself, and for that I look right at director Taika Waititi. This thing can't decide what it wants to be. There's a lot of straight-on situational and romantic light comedy, which is fine, but the deep problem with that is that when things suddenly NEED to get serious (as they almost always should in superhero films; after all, the word 'super' is there for a reason, and saving the world/universe goes with the territory), it's hard to be convincing about the necessary shift in tone.Look at the other 'best' superhero films of recent years: the first Iron Man (2008). X-Men 2 (2003) and Days of Future Past (2014). Spider-Man 2 (2004) and Spider-Man No Way Home (2021). Wonder Woman (2017). The first Avengers (2012) and of course the big Infinity War/Endgame pair. What do these have in common? Yes, they have great characters and production values, but the ultimate key is that all of these films take themselves seriously, and that's how to make a fantasy world work. They lay out a storyline where the stakes are high, and then go at it straight on. If the movie can't even suspend its own disbelief while it's rolling then how can the audience do it? Waititi seems to want to have it both ways, or all ways, at once. Are we watching a sendup of superhero films or the real thing? I had the same issues with his Jojo Rabbit (2019), which was brilliant in certain ways but a chaotic mishmash of tone. It was less than the sum of its parts.Just to get the rest of my complaints out of the way, the first half-hour felt quite odd; the actors were delivering their lines in a quippy, offhand way as if they were in an episode of Seinfeld or Friends or whatever the recent equivalents are. And I was looking forward to seeing more of the lovable Korg and his off-center dialog that was such a fun part of Ragnarok, but it just fell flat this time. Tessa Thompson as Valkyrie was sadly underused and it looked almost as if she wished she was somewhere else.By this point, the Marvel film universe has almost completely disconnected from its original comics source material. (Case in point: it was very cool to see Eternity introduced as one of the Ultimate Powers of the universe -- he's rendered extremely well, just like the first appearance in the Doctor Strange comics. But he seems to be used as something like a wishing well, which is pretty trivial. Really, guys?) Right now it feels as if they are making up stuff as they go along, and interestingly, they are starting to run into the same storytelling complexity problems that the superhero comics have had for decades: continuity and retconning. If there's a Grand Plan for Phase 4 and 5 it's sure hard to see what it is.

ipc-title__text: Fun to watch, even more fun if you watch it as a standalone film
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Better, much better than Dr. Strange 2. I laughed quite often. As a standalone film, it is very entertaining, but it does not add much to MCU.And I really appreciate that it is not a simple bait-and-switch. There are many cringe moments, though.Maybe less time with the goats and more time with the gods and Christian Bale?

Thor: Love and Thunder (2022)This is quite possibly the worst marvel movie that I have had the displeasure of experiencing. According to Chris Hemsworth, this movie was written by a 7 year old child but I had no idea that 7 year old children were allowed to be under the influence while writing scripts. Phase 4 has definitely been a stinking pile and this movie is the equivalent of throwing a thunder bomb to explode that pile and cover the audience with "fun", "humor" and "entertainment".The film is about... well its literaly just a bunch of excessive CGI mess, unbearable toddler humor and a plot that makes you want to scream like those goats. The only good part is the prologue with Christian Bale and after the MCU title begins to roll, everything feels like an incoherent parody where literally everything is poorly made whether its effects, choreography, dialogue, editing or pacing. Thor has definitely hit a new low as he has been degraded to a clown at a kids birthday party who is there to dress up in a cheap costume, talk to hammers, act like a bambling fool and get paid at the end of it all.You were excited for Guardians? How about 5 minutes. You wanted to see God Butcher in action? Forget about it. Instead, enjoy 2 hours of a talking rock. How did Mjolnir get restored? Who cares. How did Jane all of a sudden become a Woman Thor? Doesn't matter. Just stick your head inside a meat grinder and have fun because this is "Entertainment" from the comedic genius Taika. The plot actually invents new gimmicks that contradict themselves and the previous movies. I was hoping that at least the climax would pay off but instead, its kids fighting the villain with shiny plastic weapons and in the end, love is the answer.What's bewildering is how actors like Christian Bale, Matt Damon and Russel Crowe agreed to be in this garbagio; I guess the writing and CGI budgets were spent on their paychecks. People who watched this in the cinema should have been reimbursed and given money to see a therapist after experiencing this abomination. Next day after watching, I sat and wondered if this film had any redeeming qualities and unfortunately, I couldn't find any.Movies.shmovies on Instagram for honest movie and TV Show reviews.

ipc-title__text: The funniest entry in the MCU
This MCU thing is getting really old
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Thor will be back. I can't say that I'm excited. I also can't say that this will be in another Thor movie, because in the MCU universe it doesn't matter who's name carries the movie, as long as they appeared in any marvel comic everyone's welcome whether it makes sense or not. This leads to a messy storyline and many stars standing in front of a green key. I have to admit, the Omnipotence City looked absolutely stunning, but I would have been much happier watching a good scenario. Every recent MCU movie seems alike. Lots of stars, heroes, CGI, yet another apocalyptic threat, a more interesting mid part before the final fight, credits, a teaser for a future marvel spoof, more credits and a final scene. This has become a total drag. On the plus side : 3 funny scenes and a good villain.

ipc-title__text: Disney is Ruining the Marvel Universe
ipc-html-content-inner-div:
Whats going on here? Usually when I see a marvel superhero flick its a real treat, exciting, thrilling ,intense at times and even dark in some cases...Since Disney has gotten its gooey fingers on marvells movies, they have been Utterly destroyed and turned into Hallmark movies, comedic parodies and the heros completely emasculated...Look at Hawkeye, Hulk, and now Thor...whats next? Ruin Daredevil as well? This movie, I sat down to watch with my gf and 20 mins in we were both rolling our eyes and shocked at how shallow, stupid and childish it had become... we honestly couldnt even finish watching it,though i may try later myself...It was Painfully bad and thats really sad considering the high regard and respect marvel films had back in the days of infinity war and falcon and winter soldier...The decimation of an incredible franchise...the destruction of the marvel universe, more so than anything done by Thanos...so sad...
at least DC has kept it legit and Uncompromised.... Hard Pass on this mess of a film...Im shocked that christian Bale even wanted to be associated with it.

I think I get it, it's feel like stand alone movie. Taika really expand his own universe, try a lot of stuff. Which for some pov, it's great. Become something totally fresh.But on the other hand people follow this franchise for a reason. It's stay for this long for a reason, people loved the formulaTo be fair, the scenery have some beautiful scene ever on marvel, loved the music too, brave writing also.But I feel like it's being hold to secure something, if it meant to be all out just don't hold anything. With that the movie will either totally loved or hated. But I think that situation worth to try.

A fun as hell ride that consistently puts a smile on your face and makes you laugh and while it isn't as good as Ragnarok it's definitely another great movie by Taika Waititi. This movie clearly isn't meant to be taken too seriously as many of Waititi and Marvel's movies but some of the serious moments work. Gorr is a good villain to an extent, he is definitely just a construct of the plot but Christian Bale's performance is enjoyable and at least he has an arc and isn't just bad marvel dude 32. The movie did jump around a lot and wasn't as focused and I think that's why Ragnarok was a better movie than Love and Thunder (and part of me really missed Loki being in these movies).

ipc-title__text: Thor: Nepotism and Narcissism. The Family Vanity Venture.

ipc-html-content-inner-div: Entirely non-innovative. Attempts to be constantly funny at the expense of tension but falls flat, with maybe one or two jokes landing. I was holding out hope that the MCU would pull together some large scale event in the future but I think it is safe to say the infinity saga was the last great era we had from them.

ipc-title__text: A lot of heart, a lot of fun - sometimes too silly
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Overall I really liked the message of choosing love. And there was a lot of heart and soul in this movie. But it also was a little undercut by the jokes sometimes. And I liked most of the humour but there was some jokes that were really corny and unnecessary. I actually really loved Natalie Portman as Mighty Thor. She was a great addition. I didn't particularly care for Christian Bale as Gorr though. He was borderline camp for me. I was a little disappointed with the after credits scene. First one reminded me of the GOTG 2 scene with Adam Warlock. And the second one was unnecessary. Overall though I had fun with the film and enjoyed myself.

The movie sucks to be honest, bad plot.... infact the only thing I loved about this movie is Christian Bale as Gorr. His performance and look were so rich and incredible. That's all! The rest of the movie is Soo that I tried my possible best to sit through. I mean why would Marvel do something like this? Also what happened to the special effects team? The VFX was so poor in this movie; looked cartoonish and cheap, with un-laughable humor... Only humor I did enjoy aside Bale was the bleating and screaming from the Goats. This is a very forgettable movie and will definitely not add this to my library cuz I feel so ashamed of it. Production and directing were too poor and won't recommend this to anyone.

Yes, it flirts with being cheesy and some of the jokes get recycled a bit too often, but this is a solid chunk of cinema entertainment.Thor has changed so much from his early Marvel appearances - this is mostly silly fun, with a couple of battles, some excellent guest appearances, creative visual and musical references, and a light pulling of the heartstrings.Well worth the £4.99 ticket.

Taika is the type of guy who keeps Rita for fun & plays smooth romantic jazz for his baboons. He prefers solitude
I heard he goes out to war areas with green drapes so that war could continue in peace & he gets to do a romcom movie right there. What a honest man. This guy right here should be considered as a legendary movie maker.Scorsese doesn't know anything man
Come on.

6.4/10. There were a lot of good moments and the movie is nice, but I felt it was geared too much towards 7-10 year olds. I felt like I am watching a Disney movie about a prince saving princess and the Worlds. There was not enough umph for adults. Some funny moments, a few cool cheesy fights, but felt lacking a bit in all of those. Don't get me wrong, it wasn't BAD, but wasn't as good as all previous ones.A side note would be about the 3D version which is what I watched. It was so "bland". If you are releasing a 3D movie and you know colors will not be as vibrant, why not crank it up a few notches for the 3d version, so that when you wear glasses it would show up at least somewhat colorful?!? Just common sense, no?As another side note, and this is just a personal opinion, the screaming goats maybe was not the brightest idea. AVX Dolby in theaters it was noise piercingly loud, I saw A LOT of people covering their ears. It was not a pleasant sound at all, and while it was sort of the idea, it was just TOO LOUD.

After the last few appearances of Chris Hemsworth (Thor) in the MCU, I could not wait to see where his epic tale would take him next. I could not be more disappointed to find out that it took him here. With so much trauma, growth, and development being thrown out the window, this film turns our hero into a simplistic fool that cannot possibly have stood toe-to-toe with the Mad Titan and lived to tell the story. With a great director and great actors, you have to wonder how no one stopped the ridiculously childish humor, the unnatural pacing, and the story that goes from drama to comedy and repeats faster than you can blink. There are some redeeming features, such as some of the visuals and the little we see of Christian Bale (Gorr), but they are wasted underneath the burned memory of screaming goats. Everybody makes mistakes, unfortunately, Taika made this one.

Seen more than many negative reviews, I thought it was enjoyable, screaming goats cracked me up!At points it felt the pace was a little slow, a tad more action would of made it even better! But definitely worth a watch!

ipc-title__text: Well...Thor has objectophilia. Who would know?
ipc-html-content-inner-div: For those unaware of this perfectly "normal" mental condition, Thor is in love with his axe, and are afraid his axe is jealous of Mjølner, his ex. To complicate matters, Mjølner is no swinging by our old BRILLIANT scientist Jane Foster (Nat Portman with big abs), who NOW is The Might Thor. Why, you say? Well, sadly she has 4th stage termal cancer, but visiting Tønsberg, were Åsgård now is run by King (WHY not Queen??) Valkyrie, she spots the pieces of ol' Mjølner, and gets to be Thor. We will never know why. And Thor still loves the NEW Mighty Thor. So this is a love...triangle? Or something.Over to storytime? It's about a godkiller, cause a guy was upset with his God for destroying his family, so he found a sword called Kronos (That's actually the name of the God of War, which is pretty ironic), and starts killing Gods. All soon to the jam of several old hits from Guns N'Roses.In my "review" of Thor I mocked the story, talking about how stupid it would be if they got Greek mythology into MCU. BUT look no forther, cause, Thor, Mighty Thor Jane Foster, Korg AND Valkyrie travells to...someplace, and meets the mighty Zeus (fat Russell Crowe)....who is kind of a dick. But that part I liked, cause it's pure comedy. Specially the nice ladies around Zeus fainting when they see Thor's mighty....penis. That's F-U-N. Zeus lightning thingy looked btw incredible stupid, but hey, it's a cartoon movie.So, what did I think of Thor: Blood and Thunder? Oh, not Blood, but Love. It was ok'ish. Compared to the multiverse mess in other movies in stage 5 or whatever, it's a little funride, although director Taika Waititi really has to be hold in strains to keep from comedy which isnt so funny. Oh, we are going for a Guns N'Roses theme, so Heimdall's son wants to be called Axl, the biggest idiot of all vocalists.The movie doesnt do anything really to push the so-called MCU envelope any further. It's action in space, with comedy. I didn't shed a tear when someone "important" died, just whatever. BUT the most stupid thing comes in the end credits, when we get exposed to a new "villain". Yes, Thor will get hunted by Hercules, Zeus son. And he looked redicilous.

ipc-title__text: Almost too silly for its own good, yet Taika Waititi pulls it off
ipc-html-content-inner-div: I like Taika Waititi's work (the What We Do In The Shadows *FILM* is a great example). He really pushes the silly humor aspect here, but for purposes of watching something fun on TV, it's quite good -- better than I was expecting actually. There are a number of running gags, and for my taste they all worked just fine. Christian Bale does fine work as villain-of-the-week Gorr. As endings go, this one is a bit unexpected, and it's pleasantly thoughtful (not just "Kill the bad guy!").If you look beneath the surface, there are actually some serious philosophical questions posed, not that they need to be considered (or even recognized) to enjoy the film -- they'll fly over the heads of many.1) If God (or gods) are "good", why are innocents allowed to suffer?2) Should one expect a "reward" in an afterlife?3) How should one make their life (and perhaps their death) meaningful?4) How does one come to terms with an inability to protect those you love?To be clear, I'm not saying this film is as good as Ragnarok, nor do I think it's a tearjerker in its serious moments. But such moments DO exist, and they're fairly well done. A longer (Director's) Cut might add to some characters, but we'd risk losing the carefully-controlled pacing. So it's fine as-is IMHO.Anyhow, I hope you understand that this film can be enjoyed on multiple levels. I give it seven (7) stars, which is currently above par. Thanks for reading.

Thor: Ragnarok is a truly great movie that perfectly balances action, comedy and emotion through an interesting story. This movie was a fun mess. The main focus was on the comedy and action throughout a decent story that went downhill in the final act. It's decent, and Christian Pale (sorry, terrible joke) gives a great performance as Gorr The God Butcher - an interesting antagonist with a great motive. Like I say, the movie had a pretty great start with a solid first two acts. It just goes way downhill after that with a bad ending. Giving it a 7/10 is me being generous.

Massive disappointment from both the MCU and Taika Waititi. Feels more like a parody of Thor: Ragnarok more than a continuation to that movie. Waititi's style works incredibly well for his other films but here it's just too much. The comedy undercuts almost every emotional moment and deflates almost any tension in every scene. The character development here for anyone who isn't Thor is underwhelming. Natalie Portman returns as Jane Foster and she feels more like a mandate from Disney to include her rather than Taika wanted to. I also don't think Portman is doing a great job here but the script she is given doesn't help her at all. Chris Hemsworth is good as Thor. It's clear Hemsworth is having a blast and his charisma kept me somewhat invested. Christian Bale's Gorr is a very mixed bag. On one hand you have a really fun, engaging, and great performance from Bale but that character of Gorr just isn't great. His origin is rushed and confusing before the film bizarrely chooses not to show him kill any gods besides one. A character called The God Killer only gets to kill one god on screen. Great job Marvel! The other actors like Tessa Thompson and Russell Crowe are doing a good job but their characters feel like an afterthought. The filmmaking here in general honestly feels a little bland. Taika's style is there but it feels awkward this time. The visual effects don't look great most of the time either however with the recent news about how Marvel treats it's VFX workers and how little time they have then it's understandable why they look incomplete. The film wasn't completely devoid of anything fun though. There were some fun sequences and fun jokes though. The black and white fight is very creative and fun to watch and The Rock at the end was pretty great. The rest of the jokes in this film really aren't that funny though. The screaming goats weren't funny the first time and they weren't funny the 15th time they made the joke. With the lackluster output that Phase 4 has given us, Marvel is in trouble right now if they don't course correct soon. If you enjoy Ragnarok then maybe you'll enjoy this but at the end of the day you can skip it.

Marvel Cinemas have lost their magic. The studio has become so greedy and it has flooded the superhero movie market with garbage not worth watching. Each movie has been worse than it's predecessor and the quality has been lacking.There are no more Iron Man or Captain America quality movies anymore.I did not know if there would be a movie worse than Captain Marvel, but Morbius proved me wrong. I did not think you could get worse, but this Thor was the bottom of the Marvel universe.Natalie Portman is so bad in this movie - even more wooden than she was in Star Wars. It also did not help that the dialogue felt childish.

ipc-title__text: It's a largely okay movie pumped out by the MCU conveyor belt.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: This is a great example of the MCU fatigue.This one feels like Taika Waititi wanted to inject more fun into his film but for me just came off as gimmicky and I got bored with the humor after a few minutes. The story is kind of just meh and the visuals are really bland but that is a staple of the MCU these days.Passable film but I was expecting more from Waititi.

Okay, I can totally understand peoples criticisms with this movie, on the other hand I found many parts of the movie very fun and entertaining.I'll start with what I liked, Jane was way more enjoyable than I anticipated and so were the goats. AHHHHHHHH. The action in the movie was really good, the visuals and score were also quite good. People say they just made Thor stupid but I think he's just hiding how he feels, he beats around the bush but even a god can be scared to open themselves to people, my highlight was Gorr, REALLY good performance, I wanted more !!!! I think Les's can be betterMy gripes. For a god butcher, I would have liked to see more than one god get slaughtered because Gorrs presence was frightening, the comedy, I like marvel comedy and have never complained, this movie has too much, it was like the Big Bang theory laugh track, a bit too much, the ending fell a little flat and just seemed to be shoved at you very quickly.An enjoyable movie but I wouldn't be rushing to see this one again any time soon, 7/10.

I am not sure that I can continue having hopes of expectations for Marvel films to come together into something cohesive. The franchise is clearly just churning out one-off films that don't amount to an overarching story with purpose the way that they used to.With that said, Thor Love and Thunder was fine. There were some funny moments, some good action (though not really enough in my opinion), the cast did well, and the cinematography matched the caliber of Ragnarok.Small spoiler, but I did expect the Guardians to play a bigger role in this movie. They were hardly in it at all. I felt the movie would have been strong individually as well as to the MCU if they were a bigger part of the story. It seemed like that's what was coming between Thor and the Guardians after Infinity War/Endgame but it totally fizzled out.Bottom line, you can watch this or skip it. It really doesn't matter, unfortunately.

As someone who has see all 4 thor film I can honestly tell you that this one is by far my favorite it is the best one yet. This is a romantic comedy adventure and it is funny if you are a fan of Thor or marvel you enjoy this film.

Let's begin with what seems to be the biggest criticism of this film, the comedy. Having seen Taika Waititi's other films I felt fairly prepared for there to be a joke every 5 seconds, not every joke landed and there were moments when jokes didn't fit the tone but overall, I wasn't too distracted by it. I think this film failed in a lot of other ways but for me at least the overabundance of humour was passable.What I wasn't such a huge fan of was how rushed everything felt. Alright, maybe rushed is the wrong word, we spent ages watching the stuff that I was less interested in and then just skipped over the stuff I was there to see, namely Gorr. Gorr is the villain, played excellently by Christian Bale. Bale is one of the most talented actors alive so you would imagine he would be given time to show off, for some bizarre reason though, we never see Gorr the God Butcher, Butcher any gods. He kills one early on and then is relegated to off screen evil doing, while we instead follow Thor and his gang on their merry adventures. Whenever Gorr was on screen I was excited, but they only gave him like 20 minutes of screentime. Chris Hemsworth as Thor, Natalie Portman as Thor 2 and Tessa Thompson as Valkyrie were all good, but come on. None of them come near to the charisma that Bale brings to the table. So not only did the film just skip over all the most interesting parts, which reportedly were filmed but just not used in the final cut, but then the rest of the film is just a mildly entertaining comedy? I was disappointed.The best scene, that single handedly dragged this film up from a 5 to a 6 for me, was when Thor fights Gorr on a planet with no colour. The way this was shot was so different from the usual MCU fodder and actually seeing Gorr in his element was great. If the film as a whole had been as inventive and interesting as this one scene then I might have had a brilliant time. It wasn't and I didn't so before I finish I'll just throw in a few nitpicks just to kick this film while it's down.When Thor and friends seek help from other gods, the majority of the gods feel like really boring designs, they could have had so much crazy stuff here but instead just had a couple weird designs and played the rest safe. There are two goats, they annoy me and aren't funny. Thor's outfit is actually painful to look at. Just a terrible design. Korg is treated as a main character, he was better in the first when we just got small bursts of him, here it starts feeling like too much at points.This film isn't terrible but it just lacks in a lot of places, the ending was nice enough and certainly tried to get you more emotional than anything else in the film but it was difficult to feel for the characters after an hour thirty of them just quipping. Also all emotional value was ruined by the post credits scene.

ipc-title__text: And another franchise destroyed. Disney strikes again.

ipc-html-content-inner-div:
Don't go expecting endgame the film dosent take itself seriously the why should we take it seriously.I had a great time watching this. The film is more crazier than ragnork but i think that's not a great thing
Nevertheless a good watch.

It's awful. I kinda enjoyed the first 15 minutes, because it does not take itself seriously and is a bit meta, but then it lost me, I got bored and I didn't care. It also looks cheap. Poorly written and poorly directed. Basically this movie is a boring mess. Very disappointing.

ipc-title__text: What lifted this movie, in my opinion, was the humour and the music.
Typical badly made and directed MCU film
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Another forgettable, laughably bad MCU film Marvel Studios and Disney keep churning out to reap a sad profit. The only salvageable element of this film would be Chris Hemsworth and Natalie Portman's chemistry as Thor and Jane. The action scenes, jokes, and plot are so poorly written and designed, it gets boring FAST. I definitely preferred the first two Thor films over Love and Thunder. The direction was much more cohesive and the runtime didn't drag on versus this film which is a tedious slog to finish watching even on a first viewing. Not recommended even for MCU fans, which I can happily say I'm not one.

ipc-title__text: A Watchable Movie with Christiane Bale stellar Performance
ipc-html-content-inner-div: "Thor : Love and Thunder " starring Chris Hemsworth in lead role...One word : Marvellous....Thor the God of Thunder ⚡ is on his mission after the split from Avengers...He joined with Guardian of Galaxy and was on a journey in saving various universes from evil goons....Then comes the God of Butcher on one hand, who is on a mission to slay all the gods & on the other hand Thor comes across his life his lady love James Foster...How Thor balance his love & his God of Butcher elimination mission forms the rest part of the movie...Marvel Studios always comes up with new forms of their story telling & in no way it fails its marvel lovers.....Talking about the performance, Christian Bale whom I loved as Bruce Wayne here he totally surprised me...He just lived to that character as God of Butcher..Lastly, end credits which couldn't be missed and was worthy enough to wait...

I love Chris Hemsworth as Thor, I can't imagine anyone else playing the part but the comedy is ruining the franchise, it's getting more and more slapstick.It is entertaining in parts and I thought Christian Bale and Russell Crowe were both very good, but I was disappointed to only see the Guardians of the Galaxy for a few minutes, I am not a fan of Tessa Thompson at all, she is way over rated in my opinion, And didn't Natalie Portman once complain and say she didn't want to be in these movies? So they decide to make her female Thor? Terrible idea, she's another overrated actor.Oh and I hated the screaming goats.

ipc-title__text: Less godly to Ragnarok but still great
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Much messier in execution compared to Thor: Ragnarok, but the humour and style of Taika Watiti keeps it going strong and Russell Crowe was a highlight. Also good uses of music too.7.5/10.

ipc-title__text: Still better Ragnarok than Love and Thunder
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Thor finds himself the target and target of Gorr the God Bucther who wants to destroy the gods. However, he did not expect that his ex-girlfriend Jane Foster had become Mighty Thor with his Mjolnir. Together with Valkyrie and Korg, they go on a cosmic journey to confront Gorr.Thor: Love and Thunder is the 4th film of Thor's journey in the MCU and is a large solo film series in the MCU. This film still seems to use the same formula from Ragnarok, starting in terms of comedy, colorful visuals and flexible acting. The film is set after the events of Endgame. However, it is really unfortunate. Despite thepost-Endgame story, there are many changes from Thor's character development in this film which is much looser and has a great sense of humor. This is a bit of a weakness of this film even though this film is quite entertaining. Too much comedy is brought and the humorous impression of Thor has an impact on the limited character development in this film. Starting from Gorr the God Butcher who should get a large portion as the main villain. Gorr's appearance here is quite extraordinary, but the lack of performance in the film does not give a scary impression in the movie and even sympathy for his motivation is not felt. Then Jane Foster's transformation into Mighty Thor is also a pity. Supposedly, we can see Jane's problem here which can be explored more deeply. Likewise with the presence of Zeus who actually makesadi boast in this film.Overall, the film performs entertainingly . It has a story premise that is less convincing even though it has brought Thor's biggest enemy. The conflict of the story is less deep. There are many conflicts that should be able to be explored far away. Many plot holes occur with the impression that everyone has understood the world of Thor. Both stories and conflicts are less capable of being densely constructed and fused. Love and Thunder became a rock n roll film for me with a memorable rendition of GnR's skirt music. A little disturbing part of the film, visuals from Axl or Astrid and annoying goat sounds.

It's a case of bate and switch. We wanted to see more of Thor but instead we've got OP Jane and Valkyre.I'm going to go right ahead and say it, We don't want known superheroes in female form. It's not good. It's not interesting. It's bad.Christian Bale delivers amazing performance as always, but unfortunately it's not enough to save this mess. Hope he'll reappear in another movie in some way.I'm tired of this "woke" politics being shoved down our throat. Listen to the audience and give us what we want, and we wil repay handsomly.

Thor: Love & Thunder is the next installation in the Thor franchise, once again with Taika Whatiti behind the camera. This can be seen because his style is characterized by a lot of humor and many colors. There is a counterweight to this humor, namely Christian Bale's Gorr the God Butcher. A good enemy whose motivation one can understand.Thor has never really been anything to me, but I can easily see the qualities in the film. The humor also got me a few times, it should have.Marvel has so far not released the best movies this year - so it's exciting to see which direction the development.

It's no secret that I loved what Taika Waititi did with "Thor: Ragnarok"; he made me fall in love with Thor again after really getting bored of the character in "Thor: The Dark World". And I am so happy to report that he has done it again with "Thor: Love and Thunder"! I still love his comedic take on Thor so much, it still works so well for me, and I was thrilled to see that he finally was able to make the Jane Foster character, as well as her relationship to Thor, work so well and come off as so likable! I finally cared about the relationship between Thor and Jane as well (for the first time in the MCU); I was so happy to see that the elements that didn't work for me in the past were able to become something so much more in this film, and I fully attribute that to Taika's skills at writing great characters and great relationships! He is especially skilled at blending his signature style of silly comedy with some heartfelt emotion, and that is on full display here! There are moments where the film had me laughing so hard, and then in the next scene feeling like I was on the verge of tears... and it didn't feel forced at all!This movie just made me feel good! Throughout the whole film I was smiling, and by the end even despite the few flaws it has, I left the theatre feeling happy and much better than I did when I went in. It has such lighthearted fun, while also dealing with dark subject material, but the playful way Waititi tells his stories with so much heart and humour just makes you feel so good while watching... it truly is such a blast! I love this film to death, it feels like an 80s action sci-fi space opera crossed with a rom-com, with a little bit of rock ballad mixed in! And it felt like such a perfect tone for Thor! The movie is a beautifully told love story about finding meaning and living in the moment with a lot of emotion and catharsis focusing on themes of change, spirituality and religion, and as I mentioned, finding meaning in one's self. I thought Taika wrote a wonderful story, brimming with so much great humour (if you liked the comedy style in Ragnarok.... you'll love this!) and lots of awesome action and emotion. I just can't get over how well it all worked together, I fell head over heels for it!Like I continue to say, I love how Waititi blends comedy and emotion. Despite how silly the movie can be (and I love that), it never sacrifices the story for a joke. In fact, the jokes and silliness seem to have an underlying thematic exploration beneath them; we start to see Thor as someone who uses humour to hide behind his problems and insecurities. The film really did a good job at articulating Thor's inner pain through the humour, it was brilliant. We see characters express themselves in deeper ways through comedy than they could normally. Plus, I just really like Waititi's comedic style and tone, and find it's unlike anything else we are used to seeing in comedy currently. It works so well for me... every joke and gag here had me laughing out loud. And the emotion of the film is so poignant too, from the incredible opening scene with Gorr, to small dialogue scenes between Thor and Jane (I loved those moments, they were quite well written). It hits so well and with so much impact, and doesn't feel forced or tonally off in any way... Taika just has a gift for blending these tones!It shouldn't be a stretch to say that I felt this film was written so cleverly and with so much heart! I thought it told a great story with some impactful meaning and some awesome comedy. It could be cheesy at times, but I loved that, it felt like it matched that 80s rock ballad style perfectly! There were also so many storytelling decisions that I found to be quite bold for Marvel. Heck, the film opens with a scene discussing religion, faith, and the notion of gods in such an intelligent way, questioning whether gods are worth worshiping, while also establishing our fantastic villain, Gorr the God Butcher. I truly found him to be quite sympathetic, thanks to some great writing, especially in that first scene, as well as Christian Bale's incredible performance. It's not an understatement to say he delivered one of the best performances we have seen in the MCU, and he has become one of my favourite villains among Thanos, Killmonger, Loki and Wanda! Bale commands the screen, he was menacing and terrifying, and yet still had moments where he was really funny, on top of showing an emotional/sympathetic side! He had this Pennywise-like sort of cheesy, creepy vibe to him which I loved; I just couldn't get enough of Gorr and Bale's performance. He also looked phenomenal too! But I think that leads to my biggest complaint for the film... we only get a few Gorr scenes, and while Bale kills it every time, I could've used a little more! And that brings me to my next slight issue... structurally the movie does feel a little messy at times, and scenes feel very rushed at the beginning. You can tell it was really cut down, so much like with Gorr, I would've loved to see a few more scenes added in, the movie felt like it needed an extra 15 minutes at least. It still works quite well as a final product, but I found myself longing for more and feeling like we were missing scenes here or there at many times throughout the film. An extended cut honestly wouldn't hurt the film, and because I loved literally every scene we got in the movie, I'd be so happy to see even more!The soundtrack in this movie was phenomenal. I loved Giacchino's score, and the heavy metal version of the Marvel fanfare was also really cool! But my absolute favourite element of it was the Guns 'n Roses focus! Waititi made great use of classic songs such as "Sweet Child O' Mine", "Welcome to the Jungle" and "Paradise City". I thought it was really cool to have to focus on one band, as it made the movie sound more cohesive rather than jumping around to different sounding music. It did however use a few other songs, and I love the use of Enya's "Only Time" and ABBA's "Our Last Summer" over some really fun montages, the latter of which is what really made me care about Thor and Jane's relationship. I love how we got to look back at a time when they were in love, and see all the mundane activities they got up to instead of just the superhero conflict stuff we saw in the last movies. The stripped down approach helped to make me finally understand why the relationship was so important to Thor, and seeing him reconnect with and come to terms with his current relationship status with Jane was quite perfect. I also loved how they compared this relationship to Thor's relationships with his ex-hammer, Mjolnir, and his current axe, Stormbreaker, and the way they personified the weapons was so funny to me! Chris Hemsworth really sold those scenes so well too! In fact, he sold everything Thor did in this movie perfectly, from the great action to the hilarious comedic moments. I really felt Thor's pain as he was looking for purpose in the universe. And did he ever look the part here... his muscles are HUGE. He is just perfect in this role and I love how he has evolved the character over the years! His chemistry with Natalie Portman here was phenomenal too, again, this is the best they've ever been together. I loved Jane's story, and while it was so cool to see her wield Mjolnir and take up the Mighty Thor mantle, it was the underlying emotional elements that worked best for me!Now, putting aside everything else, I truly enjoyed this film purely for how it made me feel. Because it made me feel good! I went in expecting a good time, and not only did I get that, but it actually improved how I was feeling as I watched the movie; I left feeling better than I did before I saw it! It just made me happy, it made me smile and laugh so much, and even the emotion found a way to touch me in really profound ways. So yes, I may be more forgiving of this movie than some, but for me it just worked so well and really made me feel good! So if you want a fun time at the movies that makes you feel good, I'd highly recommend "Thor: Love and Thunder". I love it to death, and honestly I have no specific reason why, I just felt so good after watching it and find it so unashamedly loveable! It may not be for everyone as it does use a niche style of comedy, but it sure worked so well for me! I just loved how happy it made me. It's unlike anything else in the MCU and really treads some new ground, so thank you, Taika Waititi, for this movie that brought a little extra light into my life! And genuinely, can we get Thor 5 like right now? I need to see it so badly! Loved every second of this and laughed so.

Powerful themes, strong performances, & robust laughs do the heavy lifting in yet another (barely) above average Phase 4 MCU entry, brought down by the too-common uninspired fight sequences & weak post-credit scenes. #nitrosMovieChallenge.

Seen more than many negative reviews, I thought it was enjoyable, screaming goats cracked me up!At points it felt the pace was a little slow, a tad more action would of made it even better! But definitely worth a watch!

ipc-title__text: Well...Thor has objectophilia. Who would know?
ipc-html-content-inner-div: For those unaware of this perfectly "normal" mental condition, Thor is in love with his axe, and are afraid his axe is jealous of Mjølner, his ex. To complicate matters, Mjølner is no swinging by our old BRILLIANT scientist Jane Foster (Nat Portman with big abs), who NOW is The Might Thor. Why, you say? Well, sadly she has 4th stage termal cancer, but visiting Tønsberg, were Åsgård now is run by King (WHY not Queen??) Valkyrie, she spots the pieces of ol' Mjølner, and gets to be Thor. We will never know why. And Thor still loves the NEW Mighty Thor. So this is a love...triangle? Or something.Over to storytime? It's about a godkiller, cause a guy was upset with his God for destroying his family, so he found a sword called Kronos (That's actually the name of the God of War, which is pretty ironic), and starts killing Gods. All soon to the jam of several old hits from Guns N'Roses.In my "review" of Thor I mocked the story, talking about how stupid it would be if they got Greek mythology into MCU. BUT look no forther, cause, Thor, Mighty Thor Jane Foster, Korg AND Valkyrie travells to...someplace, and meets the mighty Zeus (fat Russell Crowe)....who is kind of a dick. But that part I liked, cause it's pure comedy. Specially the nice ladies around Zeus fainting when they see Thor's mighty....penis. That's F-U-N. Zeus lightning thingy looked btw incredible stupid, but hey, it's a cartoon movie.So, what did I think of Thor: Blood and Thunder? Oh, not Blood, but Love. It was ok'ish. Compared to the multiverse mess in other movies in stage 5 or whatever, it's a little funride, although director Taika Waititi really has to be hold in strains to keep from comedy which isnt so funny. Oh, we are going for a Guns N'Roses theme, so Heimdall's son wants to be called Axl, the biggest idiot of all vocalists.The movie doesnt do anything really to push the so-called MCU envelope any further. It's action in space, with comedy. I didn't shed a tear when someone "important" died, just whatever. BUT the most stupid thing comes in the end credits, when we get exposed to a new "villain". Yes, Thor will get hunted by Hercules, Zeus son. And he looked redicilous.

ipc-title__text: Almost too silly for its own good, yet Taika Waititi pulls it off
ipc-html-content-inner-div: I like Taika Waititi's work (the What We Do In The Shadows *FILM* is a great example). He really pushes the silly humor aspect here, but for purposes of watching something fun on TV, it's quite good -- better than I was expecting actually. There are a number of running gags, and for my taste they all worked just fine. Christian Bale does fine work as villain-of-the-week Gorr. As endings go, this one is a bit unexpected, and it's pleasantly thoughtful (not just "Kill the bad guy!").If you look beneath the surface, there are actually some serious philosophical questions posed, not that they need to be considered (or even recognized) to enjoy the film -- they'll fly over the heads of many.1) If God (or gods) are "good", why are innocents allowed to suffer?2) Should one expect a "reward" in an afterlife?3) How should one make their life (and perhaps their death) meaningful?4) How does one come to terms with an inability to protect those you love?To be clear, I'm not saying this film is as good as Ragnarok, nor do I think it's a tearjerker in its serious moments. But such moments DO exist, and they're fairly well done. A longer (Director's) Cut might add to some characters, but we'd risk losing the carefully-controlled pacing. So it's fine as-is IMHO.Anyhow, I hope you understand that this film can be enjoyed on multiple levels. I give it seven (7) stars, which is currently above par. Thanks for reading.

Thor: Ragnarok is a truly great movie that perfectly balances action, comedy and emotion through an interesting story. This movie was a fun mess. The main focus was on the comedy and action throughout a decent story that went downhill in the final act. It's decent, and Christian Pale (sorry, terrible joke) gives a great performance as Gorr The God Butcher - an interesting antagonist with a great motive. Like I say, the movie had a pretty great start with a solid first two acts. It just goes way downhill after that with a bad ending. Giving it a 7/10 is me being generous.

Massive disappointment from both the MCU and Taika Waititi. Feels more like a parody of Thor: Ragnarok more than a continuation to that movie. Waititi's style works incredibly well for his other films but here it's just too much. The comedy undercuts almost every emotional moment and deflates almost any tension in every scene. The character development here for anyone who isn't Thor is underwhelming. Natalie Portman returns as Jane Foster and she feels more like a mandate from Disney to include her rather than Taika wanted to. I also don't think Portman is doing a great job here but the script she is given doesn't help her at all. Chris Hemsworth is good as Thor. It's clear Hemsworth is having a blast and his charisma kept me somewhat invested. Christian Bale's Gorr is a very mixed bag. On one hand you have a really fun, engaging, and great performance from Bale but that character of Gorr just isn't great. His origin is rushed and confusing before the film bizarrely chooses not to show him kill any gods besides one. A character called The God Killer only gets to kill one god on screen. Great job Marvel! The other actors like Tessa Thompson and Russell Crowe are doing a good job but their characters feel like an afterthought. The filmmaking here in general honestly feels a little bland. Taika's style is there but it feels awkward this time. The visual effects don't look great most of the time either however with the recent news about how Marvel treats it's VFX workers and how little time they have then it's understandable why they look incomplete. The film wasn't completely devoid of anything fun though. There were some fun sequences and fun jokes though. The black and white fight is very creative and fun to watch and The Rock at the end was pretty great. The rest of the jokes in this film really aren't that funny though. The screaming goats weren't funny the first time and they weren't funny the 15th time they made the joke. With the lackluster output that Phase 4 has given us, Marvel is in trouble right now if they don't course correct soon. If you enjoy Ragnarok then maybe you'll enjoy this but at the end of the day you can skip it.

Marvel Cinemas have lost their magic. The studio has become so greedy and it has flooded the superhero movie market with garbage not worth watching. Each movie has been worse than it's predecessor and the quality has been lacking.There are no more Iron Man or Captain America quality movies anymore.I did not know if there would be a movie worse than Captain Marvel, but Morbius proved me wrong. I did not think you could get worse, but this Thor was the bottom of the Marvel universe.Natalie Portman is so bad in this movie - even more wooden than she was in Star Wars. It also did not help that the dialogue felt childish.

ipc-title__text: It's a largely okay movie pumped out by the MCU conveyor belt.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: This is a great example of the MCU fatigue.This one feels like Taika Waititi wanted to inject more fun into his film but for me just came off as gimmicky and I got bored with the humor after a few minutes. The story is kind of just meh and the visuals are really bland but that is a staple of the MCU these days.Passable film but I was expecting more from Waititi.

Okay, I can totally understand peoples criticisms with this movie, on the other hand I found many parts of the movie very fun and entertaining.I'll start with what I liked, Jane was way more enjoyable than I anticipated and so were the goats. AHHHHHHHH. The action in the movie was really good, the visuals and score were also quite good. People say they just made Thor stupid but I think he's just hiding how he feels, he beats around the bush but even a god can be scared to open themselves to people, my highlight was Gorr, REALLY good performance, I wanted more !!!! I think Les's can be betterMy gripes. For a god butcher, I would have liked to see more than one god get slaughtered because Gorrs presence was frightening, the comedy, I like marvel comedy and have never complained, this movie has too much, it was like the Big Bang theory laugh track, a bit too much, the ending fell a little flat and just seemed to be shoved at you very quickly.An enjoyable movie but I wouldn't be rushing to see this one again any time soon, 7/10.

I am not sure that I can continue having hopes of expectations for Marvel films to come together into something cohesive. The franchise is clearly just churning out one-off films that don't amount to an overarching story with purpose the way that they used to.With that said, Thor Love and Thunder was fine. There were some funny moments, some good action (though not really enough in my opinion), the cast did well, and the cinematography matched the caliber of Ragnarok.Small spoiler, but I did expect the Guardians to play a bigger role in this movie. They were hardly in it at all. I felt the movie would have been strong individually as well as to the MCU if they were a bigger part of the story. It seemed like that's what was coming between Thor and the Guardians after Infinity War/Endgame but it totally fizzled out.Bottom line, you can watch this or skip it. It really doesn't matter, unfortunately.

As someone who has see all 4 thor film I can honestly tell you that this one is by far my favorite it is the best one yet. This is a romantic comedy adventure and it is funny if you are a fan of Thor or marvel you enjoy this film.

Let's begin with what seems to be the biggest criticism of this film, the comedy. Having seen Taika Waititi's other films I felt fairly prepared for there to be a joke every 5 seconds, not every joke landed and there were moments when jokes didn't fit the tone but overall, I wasn't too distracted by it. I think this film failed in a lot of other ways but for me at least the overabundance of humour was passable.What I wasn't such a huge fan of was how rushed everything felt. Alright, maybe rushed is the wrong word, we spent ages watching the stuff that I was less interested in and then just skipped over the stuff I was there to see, namely Gorr. Gorr is the villain, played excellently by Christian Bale. Bale is one of the most talented actors alive so you would imagine he would be given time to show off, for some bizarre reason though, we never see Gorr the God Butcher, Butcher any gods. He kills one early on and then is relegated to off screen evil doing, while we instead follow Thor and his gang on their merry adventures. Whenever Gorr was on screen I was excited, but they only gave him like 20 minutes of screentime. Chris Hemsworth as Thor, Natalie Portman as Thor 2 and Tessa Thompson as Valkyrie were all good, but come on. None of them come near to the charisma that Bale brings to the table. So not only did the film just skip over all the most interesting parts, which reportedly were filmed but just not used in the final cut, but then the rest of the film is just a mildly entertaining comedy? I was disappointed.The best scene, that single handedly dragged this film up from a 5 to a 6 for me, was when Thor fights Gorr on a planet with no colour. The way this was shot was so different from the usual MCU fodder and actually seeing Gorr in his element was great. If the film as a whole had been as inventive and interesting as this one scene then I might have had a brilliant time. It wasn't and I didn't so before I finish I'll just throw in a few nitpicks just to kick this film while it's down.When Thor and friends seek help from other gods, the majority of the gods feel like really boring designs, they could have had so much crazy stuff here but instead just had a couple weird designs and played the rest safe. There are two goats, they annoy me and aren't funny. Thor's outfit is actually painful to look at. Just a terrible design. Korg is treated as a main character, he was better in the first when we just got small bursts of him, here it starts feeling like too much at points.This film isn't terrible but it just lacks in a lot of places, the ending was nice enough and certainly tried to get you more emotional than anything else in the film but it was difficult to feel for the characters after an hour thirty of them just quipping. Also all emotional value was ruined by the post credits scene.

ipc-title__text: And another franchise destroyed. Disney strikes again.

ipc-html-content-inner-div:
Don't go expecting endgame the film dosent take itself seriously the why should we take it seriously.I had a great time watching this. The film is more crazier than ragnork but i think that's not a great thing
Nevertheless a good watch.

It's awful. I kinda enjoyed the first 15 minutes, because it does not take itself seriously and is a bit meta, but then it lost me, I got bored and I didn't care. It also looks cheap. Poorly written and poorly directed. Basically this movie is a boring mess. Very disappointing.

ipc-title__text: What lifted this movie, in my opinion, was the humour and the music.
Typical badly made and directed MCU film
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Another forgettable, laughably bad MCU film Marvel Studios and Disney keep churning out to reap a sad profit. The only salvageable element of this film would be Chris Hemsworth and Natalie Portman's chemistry as Thor and Jane. The action scenes, jokes, and plot are so poorly written and designed, it gets boring FAST. I definitely preferred the first two Thor films over Love and Thunder. The direction was much more cohesive and the runtime didn't drag on versus this film which is a tedious slog to finish watching even on a first viewing. Not recommended even for MCU fans, which I can happily say I'm not one.

ipc-title__text: A Watchable Movie with Christiane Bale stellar Performance
ipc-html-content-inner-div: "Thor : Love and Thunder " starring Chris Hemsworth in lead role...One word : Marvellous....Thor the God of Thunder ⚡ is on his mission after the split from Avengers...He joined with Guardian of Galaxy and was on a journey in saving various universes from evil goons....Then comes the God of Butcher on one hand, who is on a mission to slay all the gods & on the other hand Thor comes across his life his lady love James Foster...How Thor balance his love & his God of Butcher elimination mission forms the rest part of the movie...Marvel Studios always comes up with new forms of their story telling & in no way it fails its marvel lovers.....Talking about the performance, Christian Bale whom I loved as Bruce Wayne here he totally surprised me...He just lived to that character as God of Butcher..Lastly, end credits which couldn't be missed and was worthy enough to wait...

I love Chris Hemsworth as Thor, I can't imagine anyone else playing the part but the comedy is ruining the franchise, it's getting more and more slapstick.It is entertaining in parts and I thought Christian Bale and Russell Crowe were both very good, but I was disappointed to only see the Guardians of the Galaxy for a few minutes, I am not a fan of Tessa Thompson at all, she is way over rated in my opinion, And didn't Natalie Portman once complain and say she didn't want to be in these movies? So they decide to make her female Thor? Terrible idea, she's another overrated actor.Oh and I hated the screaming goats.

ipc-title__text: Less godly to Ragnarok but still great
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Much messier in execution compared to Thor: Ragnarok, but the humour and style of Taika Watiti keeps it going strong and Russell Crowe was a highlight. Also good uses of music too.7.5/10.

ipc-title__text: Still better Ragnarok than Love and Thunder
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Thor finds himself the target and target of Gorr the God Bucther who wants to destroy the gods. However, he did not expect that his ex-girlfriend Jane Foster had become Mighty Thor with his Mjolnir. Together with Valkyrie and Korg, they go on a cosmic journey to confront Gorr.Thor: Love and Thunder is the 4th film of Thor's journey in the MCU and is a large solo film series in the MCU. This film still seems to use the same formula from Ragnarok, starting in terms of comedy, colorful visuals and flexible acting. The film is set after the events of Endgame. However, it is really unfortunate. Despite thepost-Endgame story, there are many changes from Thor's character development in this film which is much looser and has a great sense of humor. This is a bit of a weakness of this film even though this film is quite entertaining. Too much comedy is brought and the humorous impression of Thor has an impact on the limited character development in this film. Starting from Gorr the God Butcher who should get a large portion as the main villain. Gorr's appearance here is quite extraordinary, but the lack of performance in the film does not give a scary impression in the movie and even sympathy for his motivation is not felt. Then Jane Foster's transformation into Mighty Thor is also a pity. Supposedly, we can see Jane's problem here which can be explored more deeply. Likewise with the presence of Zeus who actually makesadi boast in this film.Overall, the film performs entertainingly . It has a story premise that is less convincing even though it has brought Thor's biggest enemy. The conflict of the story is less deep. There are many conflicts that should be able to be explored far away. Many plot holes occur with the impression that everyone has understood the world of Thor. Both stories and conflicts are less capable of being densely constructed and fused. Love and Thunder became a rock n roll film for me with a memorable rendition of GnR's skirt music. A little disturbing part of the film, visuals from Axl or Astrid and annoying goat sounds.

It's a case of bate and switch. We wanted to see more of Thor but instead we've got OP Jane and Valkyre.I'm going to go right ahead and say it, We don't want known superheroes in female form. It's not good. It's not interesting. It's bad.Christian Bale delivers amazing performance as always, but unfortunately it's not enough to save this mess. Hope he'll reappear in another movie in some way.I'm tired of this "woke" politics being shoved down our throat. Listen to the audience and give us what we want, and we wil repay handsomly.

Thor: Love & Thunder is the next installation in the Thor franchise, once again with Taika Whatiti behind the camera. This can be seen because his style is characterized by a lot of humor and many colors. There is a counterweight to this humor, namely Christian Bale's Gorr the God Butcher. A good enemy whose motivation one can understand.Thor has never really been anything to me, but I can easily see the qualities in the film. The humor also got me a few times, it should have.Marvel has so far not released the best movies this year - so it's exciting to see which direction the development.

It's no secret that I loved what Taika Waititi did with "Thor: Ragnarok"; he made me fall in love with Thor again after really getting bored of the character in "Thor: The Dark World". And I am so happy to report that he has done it again with "Thor: Love and Thunder"! I still love his comedic take on Thor so much, it still works so well for me, and I was thrilled to see that he finally was able to make the Jane Foster character, as well as her relationship to Thor, work so well and come off as so likable! I finally cared about the relationship between Thor and Jane as well (for the first time in the MCU); I was so happy to see that the elements that didn't work for me in the past were able to become something so much more in this film, and I fully attribute that to Taika's skills at writing great characters and great relationships! He is especially skilled at blending his signature style of silly comedy with some heartfelt emotion, and that is on full display here! There are moments where the film had me laughing so hard, and then in the next scene feeling like I was on the verge of tears... and it didn't feel forced at all!This movie just made me feel good! Throughout the whole film I was smiling, and by the end even despite the few flaws it has, I left the theatre feeling happy and much better than I did when I went in. It has such lighthearted fun, while also dealing with dark subject material, but the playful way Waititi tells his stories with so much heart and humour just makes you feel so good while watching... it truly is such a blast! I love this film to death, it feels like an 80s action sci-fi space opera crossed with a rom-com, with a little bit of rock ballad mixed in! And it felt like such a perfect tone for Thor! The movie is a beautifully told love story about finding meaning and living in the moment with a lot of emotion and catharsis focusing on themes of change, spirituality and religion, and as I mentioned, finding meaning in one's self. I thought Taika wrote a wonderful story, brimming with so much great humour (if you liked the comedy style in Ragnarok.... you'll love this!) and lots of awesome action and emotion. I just can't get over how well it all worked together, I fell head over heels for it!Like I continue to say, I love how Waititi blends comedy and emotion. Despite how silly the movie can be (and I love that), it never sacrifices the story for a joke. In fact, the jokes and silliness seem to have an underlying thematic exploration beneath them; we start to see Thor as someone who uses humour to hide behind his problems and insecurities. The film really did a good job at articulating Thor's inner pain through the humour, it was brilliant. We see characters express themselves in deeper ways through comedy than they could normally. Plus, I just really like Waititi's comedic style and tone, and find it's unlike anything else we are used to seeing in comedy currently. It works so well for me... every joke and gag here had me laughing out loud. And the emotion of the film is so poignant too, from the incredible opening scene with Gorr, to small dialogue scenes between Thor and Jane (I loved those moments, they were quite well written). It hits so well and with so much impact, and doesn't feel forced or tonally off in any way... Taika just has a gift for blending these tones!It shouldn't be a stretch to say that I felt this film was written so cleverly and with so much heart!
