I thought it told a great story with some impactful meaning and some awesome comedy. It could be cheesy at times, but I loved that, it felt like it matched that 80s rock ballad style perfectly! There were also so many storytelling decisions that I found to be quite bold for Marvel. Heck, the film opens with a scene discussing religion, faith, and the notion of gods in such an intelligent way, questioning whether gods are worth worshiping, while also establishing our fantastic villain, Gorr the God Butcher. I truly found him to be quite sympathetic, thanks to some great writing, especially in that first scene, as well as Christian Bale's incredible performance. It's not an understatement to say he delivered one of the best performances we have seen in the MCU, and he has become one of my favourite villains among Thanos, Killmonger, Loki and Wanda! Bale commands the screen, he was menacing and terrifying, and yet still had moments where he was really funny, on top of showing an emotional/sympathetic side! He had this Pennywise-like sort of cheesy, creepy vibe to him which I loved; I just couldn't get enough of Gorr and Bale's performance. He also looked phenomenal too! But I think that leads to my biggest complaint for the film... we only get a few Gorr scenes, and while Bale kills it every time, I could've used a little more! And that brings me to my next slight issue... structurally the movie does feel a little messy at times, and scenes feel very rushed at the beginning. You can tell it was really cut down, so much like with Gorr, I would've loved to see a few more scenes added in, the movie felt like it needed an extra 15 minutes at least. It still works quite well as a final product, but I found myself longing for more and feeling like we were missing scenes here or there at many times throughout the film. An extended cut honestly wouldn't hurt the film, and because I loved literally every scene we got in the movie, I'd be so happy to see even more!The soundtrack in this movie was phenomenal. I loved Giacchino's score, and the heavy metal version of the Marvel fanfare was also really cool! But my absolute favourite element of it was the Guns 'n Roses focus! Waititi made great use of classic songs such as "Sweet Child O' Mine", "Welcome to the Jungle" and "Paradise City". I thought it was really cool to have to focus on one band, as it made the movie sound more cohesive rather than jumping around to different sounding music. It did however use a few other songs, and I love the use of Enya's "Only Time" and ABBA's "Our Last Summer" over some really fun montages, the latter of which is what really made me care about Thor and Jane's relationship. I love how we got to look back at a time when they were in love, and see all the mundane activities they got up to instead of just the superhero conflict stuff we saw in the last movies. The stripped down approach helped to make me finally understand why the relationship was so important to Thor, and seeing him reconnect with and come to terms with his current relationship status with Jane was quite perfect. I also loved how they compared this relationship to Thor's relationships with his ex-hammer, Mjolnir, and his current axe, Stormbreaker, and the way they personified the weapons was so funny to me! Chris Hemsworth really sold those scenes so well too! In fact, he sold everything Thor did in this movie perfectly, from the great action to the hilarious comedic moments. I really felt Thor's pain as he was looking for purpose in the universe. And did he ever look the part here... his muscles are HUGE. He is just perfect in this role and I love how he has evolved the character over the years! His chemistry with Natalie Portman here was phenomenal too, again, this is the best they've ever been together. I loved Jane's story, and while it was so cool to see her wield Mjolnir and take up the Mighty Thor mantle, it was the underlying emotional elements that worked best for me!Now, putting aside everything else, I truly enjoyed this film purely for how it made me feel. Because it made me feel good! I went in expecting a good time, and not only did I get that, but it actually improved how I was feeling as I watched the movie; I left feeling better than I did before I saw it! It just made me happy, it made me smile and laugh so much, and even the emotion found a way to touch me in really profound ways. So yes, I may be more forgiving of this movie than some, but for me it just worked so well and really made me feel good! So if you want a fun time at the movies that makes you feel good, I'd highly recommend "Thor: Love and Thunder". I love it to death, and honestly I have no specific reason why, I just felt so good after watching it and find it so unashamedly loveable! It may not be for everyone as it does use a niche style of comedy, but it sure worked so well for me! I just loved how happy it made me. It's unlike anything else in the MCU and really treads some new ground, so thank you, Taika Waititi, for this movie that brought a little extra light into my life! And genuinely, can we get Thor 5 like right now? I need to see it so badly! Loved every second of this and laughed so.

Powerful themes, strong performances, & robust laughs do the heavy lifting in yet another (barely) above average Phase 4 MCU entry, brought down by the too-common uninspired fight sequences & weak post-credit scenes. #nitrosMovieChallenge.

ipc-title__text: This is not the Thor we knew in The Avengers.
Thor: Love and Thunder: Lots of Flash and Fun, But the Film Doesn't Soar

ipc-html-content-inner-div: I recently watched "Thor: Love and Thunder," and it surprisingly exceeded my low expectations. Taika Waititi's humor, although not consistently hitting the mark, brought a light and entertaining tone to the MCU. The characters, especially Thor, the Guardians of the Galaxy, Jane Foster, and Korg, showcased undeniable charisma, contributing to the film's appeal. Skillful editing kept the pace smooth, allowing me to lose track of time, and the narrative arc around Jane Foster added a compelling emotional dimension.On the flip side, the plot felt somewhat formulaic, lacking the innovation of "Thor: Ragnarok" and unfolding predictably. There was a noticeable missed opportunity in exploring more depth in the main storyline and secondary characters like Almighty Thor. While Christian Bale's performance as Gorr was commendable, the character's writing fell short, preventing Gorr from becoming the formidable Marvel villain he could have been.

ipc-title__text: Serviceable "fourquel" has Waititi's style but lacks purpose
ipc-html-content-inner-div: I've always found Thor to be one of the weaker A-list MCU characters, but I appreciated Taika Waititi's vision for "Thor: Ragnarok." His quirky humor, great soundtracks, and attention to deft pacing and comedic timing made that film, while far from perfect, a unique standout that helped create a fresher vision of Thor as a character that not only would ultimately set him up for "Infinity War" and "Endgame," but provide a blueprint for how directors could still put at least a somewhat unique stamp of their own on the Marvel formula. I'm not necessarily a hardcore fan of Waititi ("Jojo Rabbit" was not for me,) but still appreciate his idiosyncrasies and interests in using humor and irony to pepper stories in unexpected and distinct ways. With that said, given that I enjoyed "Ragnarok" and also love Christian Bale (who plays Gorr, the film's villain,) I was hoping this sequel would deliver. While it's not terrible by any means and a fine way to kill two hours on a hot summer day, it's much more forgettable than its predecessor and adds vanishingly little to the MCU as a whole.The film deals with Thor's post-"Endgame" whereabouts, including his partnership with Jane Foster (the "Mighty Thor.) Its primary plot line, however, centers around him and Jane having to rescue a group of kidnapped local children from the wrath of Gorr, a vengeful father who wants to kill all the gods. As anyone who saw "Ragnarok" and remembers its light, breezy, irreverent tone can imagine, the tone is emblematic of that film. Yet while the film can sometimes be entertaining, it just doesn't work anywhere near as well as "Ragnarok." The humor doesn't feel fresh and instead feels rather forced, the character development is surprisingly rather weak, and the stakes never feel convincing. There are plenty of ways to do comparatively lower-stakes MCU movies in a more interesting way (like "Shang-Chi,") but instead this feels more like a Disney+ miniseries concept than a theatrical movie in terms of plot depth and relative impact to the greater MCU. Even its themes of romance and the impact of interpersonal relations on the psyche feel blandly explored, and the emotional core there is in the story feels rather weak compared to "Ragnarok." To Waititi's credit, the film is deftly paced at a notch under 2 hours managing to never feel too long nor too short, he does serve up a good soundtrack (highlights include classic Guns and Roses songs,) and a few scenes have CGI visuals that are a cut above your average Marvel movie. Yet these stronger elements unfortunately don't match up against the film's relative sense of purpose or even a strong, original plot. Christian Bale is very good, unrecognizable, and menacing as Gorr, but he's almost criminally underused in the story, to the detriment of the broader narrative as a whole. Recommended for theatrical viewing only to devoted Marvel fans; everyone else can wait to stream it or skip it entirely. 6/10.

Welcome to the Marvel Universe Thor: Love and Thunder and it's great to have you aboard. I love how they keep the comedy aspect of Thor going. Waititi takes you on a journey, from feeling somewhat awkard in the beginning, to laughter, and than sadness. In addition to Hemsworth's amazing awesomeness (my wife was in heaven for one particular scene), Portman and Bale were great in their roles. Waititi also brings great visual colours and a perfect soundtrack that makes you want to raise your fist in the air.

Nothing is. It becomes boring. I found nothing of value that was added to marvel or thor w this film. Was it cool that the universe was expanded w new characters w different twists, yes... was it good? No. Jeremy Johns and Chris gore said it best - it's a tv episode and it's forgettable. This was made for Disney+ content. What does red letter media say - 'consume new content'? Pft- pathetic attempt. I expected more from this director. Dr. Strange was a mess and this was a missed opportunity. Disney needs to stop w the divisive marketing and maybe hire better writers. The Batman and Robin of Marvel.The more I think about this "film" the more I despise it.

Its vibrant and so colorfull with it the silly jokes it sometimes made me think its a kids movie but with too many adult punchlines. The story was decent but the execution felt little rush, The old characters return jane and her friend and sif with it thor's journey with guradians was nice, The CGI was too brilliant specially the golden temple and some gorr's scenes they were eye-pleasing,The gorr was awesome but it felt underused just like other marvel movies villians, The zeus and other gods portrayal was little amature-ish and with gorr's arc it could be awesome but the whole terror was missed with the fun vibe of movie and with the jane's arc although it was good on paper it needed more runtime to proper cover all the plotlines without that it felt kept going just like that although The Love and thunder reveal at last and the final act was amazing, the mid credit was awesome and end credit was decent. Overall it was a missed opportunity but a decent movie!

ipc-title__text: Fun at times - I'm sick of "The Message", maybe an attempt to hide the decline of Marvel and Taiki Waititi?
I did NOT love this Movie
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Thor has his fourth entry in the wonderful and colourful world of Asgaard. Unfortunately, this installment of the franchise is not very good, and simply lacks in areas the other Thor Films didn't. So Let's review "Thor:Love and Thunder".The problem with this film is it becomes too jokey, there's too many silly things that happen that it feels more like a Parody then a film itself, it doesn't have to take itself seriously, but when the film is too silly it just doesn't work. Much like the screaming sheep, and Thor doing the splits inbetween two trucks. It's funny because it's ludicrous, it's not funny because it's clever.Another thing is the Villain. He has a nice portrayal at the start but it then goes SiDeWaYs. He is made out to be a strong force to be reckoned with, but in reality he's a stale character with not much to do. And it becomes disappointing for the viewer.There are positives to take from the villain, was his daughter's death, it's a nice moment to sympathise with him, and it works well into the story. It shows her importance to him, and when she's gone it shows the effects and how he's feeling without her. It creates for this vengeful mission that went downhill in about 5 Minutes.Jane was also wasted. And her being like Thor really doesn't work. She was the love interest, and it takes away any potential tension the film has because it's played off for laughs rather then an exciting and impactful sequence. Also, Jane disappeared out of Nowhere so that's more so why it doesn't work.The other good thing about the film is it's effects, they look nice and colourful and give the film a well and grandish look, whilst also being well polished and nice to look at. So there is a positive there, and it is the BEST Looking Marvel film. Now its time for the Verdict.Would I recommend this film?No, But Non-Marvel fans may enjoy it.

Eventhough I wasn't much hyped for Thor : Love and Thunder , yet I was disappointed . Major drawback of this movie was trying to keep everything funny and hilarious , even Thor loses throughout MCU journey was potrayed as joke and at end it felt like some spoof , but TBH most of the places comedy worked well , so i guarantee movie never fails to entertain you . Plot was weak and seems like it was exclusive made for children's watch . Huge cast in single movie and runtime is around 2hrs , so everything was jus rushed and felt incomplete . Overall just watch it for fun , don't expect something like Thor Ragnarok .( suma suma ovoru scene comedy , sarcasm , mock panren soli nala scene kuda keduthu vachurukingha le da )

Don't even bring up prevous films. First films of characters tended to be good, then fine, now they don't even try. The collapse of MCU started with Spiderman trashing the set timeline, but whatever, I thought, well, take individual movies, sometimes.Still, however bad Endgame was, it at least carried an overarching narrative. What is the thing holding all these movies together anymore?But ok, whatever, individual movies.Well, ALL of the P4 films were simply: bad. Patheticaly bad waste of money. But what do I know, right? Profit is profit, even if the planet will burn down because of it, right?Then somehow this Genderswapped Thor sparkled my interrest. I looked at the poriginal story, and it looked magnificient. Ethan Hawk's character looked excellent in the promo. I didn't mind Cartoon Thor. I was ok with Natalie Thor (Nhor?).But Nhor joking all through the film, even in hooman form, not even a shadow of cancer, and suffering, and everything this story is about? I remember Jessica Alba from F4: "And then the director said: could you cry nice?"So I don't even anymore. #MCUisDead.

ipc-title__text: Brings the thunder, but not so much the love.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: I liked Taika Waititi's last installment of the Thor series, Ragnarok felt like a fresh and exciting direction for the character in the Marvel Cinematic Universe with a good balance of humor, heart, and presenting the best replication of Jack Kirby's visual style in live action. However, even as I walked out of the theater after seeing that film, I didn't think it should be established as the standard for any and all Thor stories going forward, but it looks like many in Hollywood and its own writer/director Taika Waititi thought very differently, and as a result lightning doesn't strike twice.Firstly, there are many other epic stories from Thor's comic history that would make excellent blockbuster cinema and work fine in the continuity of the established Marvel Cinematic Universe, yet they decided to use more recent runs as the basis for its story - not that that is a bad thing per se, but it's still disappointing.I did like Natalie Portman quite a bit as Jane Foster in the first two Thor films and found her chemistry with Chris Hemsworth to be very good, so I was fine with Portman returning. Gorr the God Butcher being brought in felt like an interesting idea for the screen and Christian Bale playing them raised expectation, and then you have the introduction of other Gods with Russell Crowe as Zeus and that just excited the Marvel Zombie in me, but unfortunately Taika Waititi seems to be in-love too much with his brand of filmmaking and tries to recreate Ragnarok all over again and does anything but succeed in their attempt at doing so. The movie has too much humor to the point where any stakes and drama lack impact, and it will echo memories of the superhero movie duds of the late 1990's and early 00's with its desperation to entertain the viewer.I personally think there is still a lot you can do with Thor and his lore for the Marvel Cinematic Universe, but Taika Waititi should hand the directing duties to someone else - personally, I wish Sir Kenneth Branagh would return and reclaim this franchise. Branagh's 2011 introductory film was a solid representation of the Thor character and his cast of characters, it's operatic and Shakespearean drama coupled with genre filmmaking worked fantastically.As it stands, I would rate this as the worst Thor entry to date, even worse than The Dark World - because even that had more going for it and didn't treat nearly everything as a joke.

ipc-title__text: Horrible stupid silly script - pathetic Thor
ipc-html-content-inner-div:
I'm a big fan of Thor and love the prior films but this disaster of a script by Taika is simply pathetic.I went in with an open mind but the sophomoric childish humor and lack of a real story makes it feel like a parody of itself. Poor Thor becomes this silly caricature of the hero and the only person that feels like a real character is Christian Bale who luckily actually acts like a true villain.Imagine a nightmare cross of Guardians of the Galaxy and Dumb and Dumber with a Soap Opera Thor
behaving like a silly fool - and throw in fatty Russell Crowe as a silly Zeus with a hilarious pathetic Greek accent and the topping is 2 large goats with annoying screams.A total train wreck that I had to turn off in the middle because it was intolerable and Taika selection of music gets old fast. And I grew up in the 80s
Eat my hammer Guns n RosesWatch it for the cgi and Christian bale - and for the Children ( yes that is the main crux is saving the children of fantasy Disneyland Askard ha ha ).It makes one wonder what Taika and Disney are smoking these days and what kind of disaster will be created by Taika with Star Wars.1 star because Zero not available.

ipc-title__text: The beginning of the fall of the MCU ?
I cant believe so many bad press on this film
ipc-html-content-inner-div: This film was not as bad as critics all complain it was, I feel this was not an amazing film but it certainly was good enough to enjoy.Maybe some people are too uptight? Too serious?I found this a fun and entertaining film that also carried heartbreak and it also dealt with his personal feelings although quite short but the intent is fully visible as he has to rebuild himself and the loss he suffers just made it a more powerful movie.Not to mention their were some very outrageous moments n scenes but they were so fun filled & its nice for a change as it clearly had a very big Guardians of Galaxy type of vibe too it.Also the ending credits like holy bleep! I knew it!! I totally kept thinking during the film like what if this happens in this film and introduces this new hero from the comics??? I was so excited to see it happen.Overall it kind of felt like the movie was to short for his story length but they did their best to wrap up the film and theirs many subtle positive messages in this film that u can pickup on.

Ok the first thing I have to address is the goats, every single time they screamed all I could hear is "WHAA I FEEL GOOD". And that by itself cracked me up to no end. Now as for the movie, it was ok, it was the same 30% corny 70% hero thing most Thor movies are. I think the dialog could have used a good once over, and the story wasn't really as engaging as the other ones. It just didn't seem on par with the other ones in terms of hero value, but I mean this is a long going franchise, it was inevitable that it would fall off eventually. The acting was good as usual. I give it a modest 7/10, it did what it was suppose to do. I really like that they made kids be part of it, it's a new twist and good to introduce kids into the marvel universe and let them feel godly.

ipc-title__text: Entertaining but could have been better
Drama ruined for the sake of comedy
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Love and Thunder, in my opinion, was very underwhelming. Ragnarok was a great movie, one of the best MCU movies, it balanced comedy and drama very well, this movie, does not. It's all over the place.The editing is choppy and scenes feel very rushed. The story is bland and uninteresting. It isn't bad, there are some good moments here and there, like some of the Jane stuff is pretty good and the flashbacks with her and Thor add much needed layers to their relationship. But that is all this movie has going for it. There was potential for an emotional movie here, with scenes that could have been real tear jerkers, but each of these scenes were ruined by some stupid, non funny joke. Taika is a pretty funny writer, but here his jokes fall flat 80% of the time. Chris is good with his line delivery, as always, but everyone else? Nope.Then there is the CGI... What has happened to the MCU movies after endgame? Aside from No way Home, every Marvel movie has had awful CGI, but the effects here are about the same as the recent MS Marvel show. Yes, they look that bad at times.The good thing about this entry in the Thor series, is Christian Bale. He is really good here, and he looks like he is having the time of his life. But his scenes are far few in-between. He doesn't show up much, but when he does his scenes are good. The villain itself is bad, maybe slightly better than that pathetic excuse for a villain in Dark World, but Gorr, is a disappointing villain.Overall, I think this movie is boring, it tries to hard to be funny, and in the process, ruins scenes that could have been great. It feels rushed, and the editing is choppy, poor visuals and an underwhelming villain. It's the weakest entry in the Thor movies, even worse than Dark World - don't hate me for that lol.

ipc-title__text: Really? The longer you watch it, the worse it gets
ipc-html-content-inner-div: It is hard to understand how they can so thoroughly mess up a proven franchise, but apparently it is easy to do. The Matrix franchise has done it, and this one has done it. It is sad really.The acting is decent, and actors deliver as much as possible, but it lacks continuity, a rational story and so much more. The atrocity that is Russell Crowe's character and performance is just absurd. Christian Bale is as angst ridden as ever and delivers it well, but what a wasted performance on a nonsensical script.The story is bad, the directing is pretty bad, everything including the music is over the top and absurd.I understand how the screaming goats felt in this film and wanted to scream with them!

ipc-title__text: Not nearly as bad as the cry babies say
ipc-html-content-inner-div: It wasn't the best MCU movie and it wasn't the worst. It did feel a little empty and kind of rushed but still enjoyable and funny. MCU fanboys are becoming more unbearable than Star wars fanboys.

After rewatching it J still think this is a misunderstood movie. Taika himself is misunderstood genius. Although he's got a great sense of humor his creation like this and Jo Jo Rabbit, recently Our flag means death are not comedies. Everyone expected this movie to be something like Ragnarok. This is a great drama with some action and comedy. I think he did a great job as always. Don't understand the hate at all. I really enjoyed in the cinema and now owning it on digital as part of my collection. I took one star off because I cannot stand Melissa M, annoying, untalented not funny.PS the worst MCU movie is still Dark world to me I could only finish watching it once and never could finish rewatch it.

I've never been a fan of the Thor movies, abd this did nothing to change my mind. It starts in what feels like the middle of a different movie. Turn it's just one CGI scene after another with little exposition or development. It's one stupid joke after another as well, as any drama it tries to build it defuses by trying to get you to laugh at it.There are screaming goats which are annoying to no end. That's a sentence I never thought I'd write.The plot is ridiculous. My favorite is a doctor breaking bad news in a hospital...to Thor next to a vending machine! And that's supposed to be a serious scene!Convoluted, jumbled mess. Had to stop to look up on the net whether I had missed anything because things were so scattered.

ipc-title__text: Well it seems like a bad movie,
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Which was cheesy and ridiculous, bloated with bad cgi actions and dialogues right from start, but it actually isn't. The rating obviously a reflection of people that were overwhelmingly seeing those problems and yet failed to grab the true meaning of the movie. This is actually a good mockery of the people in power or authority, and those who follows them blindly without questioning, well as the people who worship false idols. The other great message of this movie is the choice and struggle between love and hatred, and the consequences it would cause. Of course the movie is full of bad actions, silly conversations and costumes with cgi quality of commercials with bad composing, which was quite the result of changing endlessly by marvels directions which has ridiculously little time for the artists to execute, but actually by the meaning of it this movie deserves a better review and credit, which was way better than soulless and empty ones like shangchi and black panther.

Standard Thor film from the MCU, with plenty of humour and CGI to spare. Hemsworth is genuinely amusing as usual and Crowe gets a laugh or two, but Portman largely struggles with the comedy. Natalie is quite believable as the Mighty Thor however, and has some OK moments. Bale delivers the best villain since Thanos and the GNR soundtrack rocks. Fairy typical silliness overall. 6/10.

Neat visuals and a few chuckles aside, love and thunder is burdened by a boring story. Gorr is underutilized despite Bales performance and the comedy is extremely cheesy at times. The screaming goats....wow did that get old fast. Love and Thunder never takes itself seriously. Every scene is a setup for a punchline. A dramatic moment will play out and 5 seconds later que a joke. Because of this I couldn't take anything seriously and I found myself bored. Despite a visually striking fight scene in the shadow realm none of the action stood out. A disappointment.

Thor: Love and Thunder is an empty movie, so much so that I almost forgot the movie shortly after leaving the theatre. This is because the movie feels like a collection of scenes glued in some way one with each other, without a proper structure behind and so the plot is non-existent. Indeed when the halftime break occurred I controlled the time because very few events happened and I couldn't believe it was already half of the movie. Also the jokes are bad and the entire audience had like 8-10 laugh over the whole duration. Indeed the peak of the entertainment of the night was one guy who fell asleep snorling. Also the character development, which was a big part of Ragnarok, is nowhere to be found here. Thor: Love and Thunder is not a putrid movie at all and someone will surely enjoy it, but to me it felt like throwing two hours of life in the vacuum because of how empty it feels.

This was the most paint-by-numbers films I've ever partly watched.It gets 1 star only and solely because I didn't watch all of it. I came back later to try and finish and gave up a second time out of boredom, and DNF gets an automatic 1 star.The film itself deserved maybe 2 or 3 from what I saw.Thor is finding himself for the third time in 3 movies. He's millennia old and has to 'find himself' 3 times in 8 years. What a loser.Then boredom happens, the screaming goats are funny for 2 minutes but it drags on for ages and is so repetitive the gag gets really old really fast.It has no time to breathe, the themes are love and loss and death and terminal cancer and inevitable loss, but there is a cheap gag every 30 seconds so we're not supposed to care at all about any of that.This is a film which seems to be aimed at, and written by, a 7 year old with ADHD.

ipc-title__text: Such a waste of talent for cheap laughs
ipc-html-content-inner-div:
Why oh why did the makers of this film miss such a glorious chance to use the talents of The Guardians of the Galaxy cast but more terrible they've blown probably the best Big Bad in Marvel films to fill the movie with cheap laughs rather than be a big hitting extravaganza
Love & Thunder bumbles along on the same path as the previous film but it could have been much much more.

ipc-title__text: A Silly Mess of a Film
ipc-html-content-inner-div: After the refreshingly funny & heartfelt Ragnarok, this one is a massive letdown. Unfunny Jokes took center stage and every Character Development & emotionally deep moments were ruined by stupid comedy. Great characters like Korg & Valkyrie, even Guardians were utterly wasted. Christian Bale plays a really intriguing Antagonist but he is hardly seen doing anything in the film. Chris & Natalie have never had any meaningful chemistry, so the whole plotline falls flat. CGI is shockingly awful. The only time you feel something is in the climax but thats just too late. A rushed, unfunny mess of a film.

ipc-title__text: Tries to hard, still fell asleep
ipc-html-content-inner-div: I have absolutely no idea what the intention of this movie was, but I am glad that I skipped it in the cinema and waited for the VOD release. This is not good. The plot is weak, the humor is forced and the visuals are awfull.So far the marvel movies looked OK for the most part and I sort of tolerated the greenscreen third act. This movie is greenscreen pretty much 80% of the time and I couldn´t care about anything that was happening because none of it felt remotely realistic.Some of the jokes were fun, but there were simply too many with not a lot of breathing time. In market mechanism if you have an abundand supply of something while the demand remains similar, the price of said item goes down. That model works very well here because the more jokes you have, the cheaper they seem and hence the laughs are not there.The plot? Basically nonconsequential filler with just a few events that have any kind of meaning. I am bothered a bit that there is a deus ex son of Heimdall out of nowhere with no previous mention whatsoever. I mean, the kid was fine and likeble in the movie but he comes out of nowhere, like pretty much any other plotpoint.There were a couple of things I did like in the movie but that would be getting into spoilers. The main characters work well with each other (except of Corg, get rid of that guy ASAP please) and the Villain was good. Overall I wanted to give 3/10 but bumped it up because of Christian Bale. If you are stuck on a long flight with nothing much else to watch, this is fine but I wouldn´t go out of my way to recomend this movie to anyone.

ipc-title__text: Love and Thunder Makes a Loud Noise In the Theater
ipc-html-content-inner-div: We've been waiting for this, Streamers. Thor: Love and Thunder has finally been released in theaters. The MCU is back before us with more content that we've been clamoring for. This movie follows Thor as he enlists the help of King Valkyrie, Bestie Korg and ex-girlfriend, Jane Foster, to fight Gorr the God Butcher, who intends to make all of the gods extinct.You know with these MCU movies we have to talk about the storyline and the bigger picture. First, a newbie could definitely just watch this movie and not be completely lost about what's going on. As Korg narrates at key points in the movie, he's able to bring us all up to speed. Secondly, I'm no comic book expert but to me this movie doesn't move the universe along that much if at all, which is good. I feel everyone is too wrapped up in how it plays into the phases and multiverse and blah blah blah, which just causes people to not be immersed in and entertained by the product in front of them (*cough cough* alluding to what people did to the Dr. Strange movie but no one asked me, so I'll move on). Lastly, this movie is full of heart. Thor, Jane, and Gorr will pull on your heartstrings throughout in unexpected ways. While some of their plot points weren't fully fleshed out, I recognize that it's hard to make these movies feel important after the emotional depth in Endgame. Nevertheless, Taika's direction and the writing definitely tried their best to fill the movie with heart and humor. Let's move on to the cast.Christian Bale does his thing as Gorr. He's so creepy in this. Bale has a way of slithering across the screen and being menacing even though he's not necessarily physically imposing. Marvel could've taken this to the next level in dastardliness, but it seems like the MCU is building to an overarching Big Bad and don't yet want to give us that Thanos-like figure. Who knows? We may have seen that Big Bad already, but the MCU hasn't truly featured them yet. Anyway! Thor, on the other hand, while goofy and fun, campy, and still beastly, he does come off a bit too corny. And, it's hard to say because some of the exact same moments are definitely going to be moments that people enjoy. The same goes for Korg as well. Taika does a great job voicing Korg, but at times it's a bit much or unnecessary. The fact that he narrates a lot of the movie could be a turn off to viewers. Korg is great in small pebbles but the whole rock mound gets a bit annoying. Our friend, Jane Foster can be annoying too but her bash head Thor-ness is definitely fun to watch. Marvel definitely found a way to make Jane come into her own and not just as a Thor carbon copy, which I enjoyed. I wish I could say the same for Valkyrie. They didn't really let my girl Tessa really shine in this movie. After Ragnarok, I think we wanted that boss chick featured again. Unfortunately, she was more of a bell and whistle than a co-star. Those are the people you come to see but there are a bunch of small characters that either melt your heart, annoy you a bit, make you laugh, or want to see more of. Srangely that mixture, actually gives a movie life. It's just Marvel doing Marvel things making you want more.Long story short, Thor: Love and Thunder while maybe not Ragnarok doesn't fall too far from the tree. Marvel, Taika and Kevin Feige just continue a strong MCU/Thor Franchise. This movie will make you laugh, hold on to your seat, awe at the action, suck back thug tears and more. Thor gets a bit corny but not enough to make me say don't see Bale's creepy Gorr the God Butcher. Love and Thunder will make loud noise in the theaters so grab that big box of fresh popcorn and enjoy.

AMENDMENT: Out of sheer boredom and curiosity, I finally finished watching this. The last 20 minutes or so resonated with what made, again I say MADE, Marvel movies special. However, Marvel is dead. Make no mistake. I still stand by my initial review.INITIAL REVIEW: I'm not sure where to begin. I know where I'll end. Here. For Thor and Marvel Phase Clueless. Perhaps there is some master plan to make a...much like this movie, I cannot finish this sentence.Let's begin again. Taika got drunk on the success of Ragnarok and as happens forgot the moment of the...
If this review seems slapdash and incoherent, unenjoyable, you've already watched this movie.The chemistry between Hemsworth and Portman is non existent. Two boring movies should have proven that. To make matters worse, the script and story are rushed and muddled by the thought of horrible flashbacks that are not flashbacks and gratuitous mugging trying to convince the audience that the first two Thor movies resonated. They didn't. And the forced "humor" is like listening to a great joke that the teller cannot tell.Marvel, Waititi, Feigie...Stop before someone really gets hurt.It really was Ragnarok. You've destroyed Asgard.

ipc-title__text: Tone deaf, Silly in a bad way
ipc-html-content-inner-div: This is a popcorn movie that you're not meant to take seriously, while I'm fine with silliness a lot of it here is in very poor taste.The infinity gauntlet that caused half of humanity to just poof for 5 years? Yeah lets make fun of that tragic event that people are in-world are still recovering from as a one-time gag in an ice cream shop name.Our heroine has stage 4 cancer and dying, because that works so well with none stop silliness and fifth grade level humor. Cancer.... and they keep reminding you of it. Cancer and chemo is supposed to be funny to anyone?Thor is now a parody of himself and all the personal growth he got from the past movies is gone, he is now a clown that happens to have some powers.The screaming goats meme from 10 years ago was funny though. I laughed at that. Also the boat goat vehicle was creative but that's all the credit I can give the movie. All the key moments like Jane realizing her powers, gods dying...etc all of them are off screen, all you get to see is the silly fluff.

ipc-title__text: One of the better recent Marvel films..
ipc-html-content-inner-div: I had a day off today and caught up with the marvel movies I'd not seen.Black Panther Wakanda Forever and Thor Love And ThunderI watched BP earlier, found it a bit dull, a bit ploddy and BP doesn't show up till last 20 minutes and doesn't do much when they do.Thor, on the other hand, is a great entertaining marvel comic book movie.It's silly, it's fun, it's action packed and has tons of 'stuff' for fans to see and pick apart.Christian Bale is also absolutely amazing in this film, he's having so much fun chewing up the scenery that I'm annoyed he died, I'd love to see him back again for more.A great fun and action packed ride.

OK, the film is a mixture of being 50% very good & 50% really truly dreadful.I've watched it once & enjoyed some of it, but the parts I really hated for being so ridiculous & so unbelievably corny & disrespectful, that means now I won't ever watch this film again unless someone was willing to pay me to watch it but it would cost a bit. I love Christian Bale but I hate the terrible Directing & writing, plus the main character arcs make no sense & devalue them all.Disney for some reason give people with really "no proof of the talent required" the power to write & direct a Marvel movie, in this case the power was given to Taika Waititi who ultimately does a dreadful job writing & also directing this film. With the big budget & a great cast of actors this film had real Marvel potential to be a great film but Taika Waititi was a poor choice.If Taika Waititi had wrote for a proper Marvel comic & came up with this exact story Stan Lee would have told him this was simply not good enough for Marvel, as the script does not make sense & in parts becomes too "silly".Now I'm all for a little bit of surprising "humour" in Marvel films as you would get in comics, but at it's core this is still supposed to be a serious universe that has serious consequences if the heroes fail & you have to feel that.By the end of the film the script & directing by Taika Waititi feels more like a parody of real quality Marvel films ( & comics ) which I find disrespectful.Now the film still gets 5 stars from me because parts of the film are really good & this is because of the acting ability of many of the excellent cast, for example Christian Bale is a truly magnificent actor whose overall performance in this film really is top notch ( I really feel sorry for him as a lot of the film script by Taika Waititi really ruined the film ) as Gorr is a great character.Chris Hemsworth as Thor is very good though the script seems to try to make him look more & more of an idiot ( as his character arc is declining here ).Some of the scenes Chris Hemsworth has to do are so poorly conceived & become so ridiculous I really feel sorry for him as we know he is a great Thor.Natalie Portman & Tessa Thompson both do OK however I feel the script they had to work with really did not help them to really show off their acting talent.Russell Crowe was not very good ( seems he does not understand that Super Hero films are meant to be taken serious ) as he acted in it like it was some kind of parody ( like he was supposed to be a parody or in a bad "panto" ).This was a very bad casting choice & when he arrives in the film it really does start to go more & more downhill from there ( Taika Waititi to blame mostly ).By the end of the film it starts to insult everyone's intelligence & becomes unbelievably farcical, as I certainly won't be adding this film to my Marvel collection as the appearance of the guardians of the galaxy at the start of the film actually gave the film a decent start but the script of Taika Waititi killed it.Disney have killed the Marvel movie franchise from being the juggernaut it was as simply they don't respect the Marvel universe enough to ensure it's image is protected instead they give directors with no previous big action super hero movie total control & just sit back as they destroy years of hard work that previous actors & quality writers & directors put in to build the Marvel Universe ( films such as Iron Man, Captain America & yes Thor ).The original film Thor (2011) with Director Kenneth Branagh & Writers
Ashley Miller(screenplay), Zack Stentz(screenplay), Don Payne(screenplay) must all watch this film & say to themselves what has Taika Waititi done & you have to ask what has co-script writer Jennifer Kaytin Robinson done?Jennifer Kaytin Robinson must take at least 30% of the blame though again if you look at her resume clearly she like Taika Waititi ( 70% to blame ) was no way qualified to write the script for this film, however their only defence is that if so,done offered you a boat load of money to do something such as write a film script why would you turn that down as the really idiots here are Disney.The Marvel films could have made billions for many many years but with these dreadful films killing off fans of the Marvel film series how much has Disney cost them themselves long term. Most likely they have lost Billions.So ultimately I can't really blame Taika Waititi & Jennifer Kaytin Robinson for taking Disney's money but if I see either of those 2 names attached to any future film or TV series I most likely will choose to give that film/show a miss.

ipc-title__text: Another Entry on the List of Mediocre Phase 4 Movies
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Thor Love and Thunder is the latest Thor movie, as well as the latest Phase 4 MCU film. As far as the Thor movies are concerned there hasn't been one I flat out dislike. I enjoy the first movie. Dark World is okay. Everyone hates that one, but it had some hype moments for me, and I was never truly bored in it. Ragnarök is one of my favorite MCU movies. So, I was somewhat excited for this as it has the same director attached. Although, my excitement dwindled after seeing Dr. Strange 2 and seeing the reviews for this film. I personally have found Phase 4 quite disappointing. The only entries I think have actually been good are Spiderman No Way Home and Falcon and the Winter Soldier. Everything else has ranged from okay to incredibly subpar. Dr. Strange 2 especially has been one of the most disappointing MCU films for me. This movie, unfortunately kind of follows suit on that trend.I will say that I was never bored in this film. Other films like Dr. Strange 2, Black Widow, and Shang-Chi gat pretty boring in places. This film is fun on a dumb action movie level, so it has that over other Phase 4 entries even though it probably is on par with them on a quality standpoint. There first twenty minutes of this movie in particular were really strong. I was always entertained, though that's more to do with the actors than the writing. Chris Hemsworth is such a charismatic actor that you love to watch even when he's given garbage scripts. I really like the villain here. I love his design, and Christian Bale, as always gives a good performance. I found myself sympathizing with him a bit, which is more than I can say for most MCU villains. The film, like Ragnarök, is beautiful to look at.Many people hate Jane as a new Thor, but I didn't mind too much. Jane as a female Thor did not surprise me, as I know of her from the comics. This is actually the most I've ever like Jane in these movies. In the first two she was just the token love interest character, especially in Dark World. Here she's given much more to do and is given a sympathetic arc of her own. She also didn't outright steal the show away from Thor, which is what I was afraid of happening. I will also say, the film's ending surprised me. I did not think it would end that way, especially since the MCU has been becoming more woke these days.On to the negatives now. The other gods featured here are terrible. Zeus and the Greek gods are a complete joke. I'm a Russel Crowe fan, but he's awful here. This is his worst performance that I've seen from him. You know you screwed up when the Percy Jackson movies did the Greek gods more justice.Also, just like in Dark World, the humor is very hit or miss. Ragnarök had this problem to an extent, but the jokes in that were more hit than miss for me. Plus, you had Loki or the Hulk for Thor to work off of. You don't have that here. You have the Guardians of the Galaxy, but they're not in the movie nearly as much as the trailers led you to believe. Much of the humor fell flat for me here.Overall, Love and Thunder is harmless fun. It will entertain you while you're watching it, but it certainly is not one of the more memorable MCU movies. I'd say it's on par with Dark World. Sadly, much like a lot of Phase 4, this film feels very much like a throwaway entry. The only MCU movies (and show) that has felt impactful in terms of the whole MCU are Falcon and the Winter Soldier, No Way Home, and Eternals. Everything else has felt very much like filler.

ipc-title__text: Not the best and not the worst either but had FuN.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Certainly a movie where everyone in your family kids can enjoy without even seeing previous thor movies . Being a marvel fan of comic books and following movies it would have been a bummer to watch thor dwell too deep in PG era Jolly person. But actually i felt this movie was okay and there is no point in hating it . Did well to give jane foster a role to justify her which was emotional till the end.Expected a nice villain fight or a reveal but ended a forgetful experience. To be frank it's a good movie not the best but enjoyable .

Ever wait for a movie to come out and it's a bitter disappointment? THAT'S what this movie is to me! It came out today on Disney+ and I was so amped to see this one! IT'S MOSTLY STUPID! Sure, it's got a few serious moments, but again mostly stupid and goofy! So far, this is my LEAST favorite Thor movie. The other ones had a few laughs and funny moments, but this one was obviously written by a gag writer! The beginning starts out with Thor on another world with the guardians of the galaxy, minus one member, (I'll let you figure out which one...) and it just gets stupid from there. I'm REALLY glad I didn't go to the theaters to see this. RAGANOK was better than this! And by the way, the ONLY reason I gave this a higher than 4 rating was then ending made me misty. NOT cry...just, misty. Peace.

ipc-title__text: A heavy burden to bear, this thing called continuity.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: In Ragnarok, Waititi, Hemsworth et al had a certain looseness that made for an entertaining hero movie that did not feel like one. Tessa Thompson drinking herself off an entrance? Gold. Thor hijacking Gamesmaster's ship (Don't touch anything")? Another gem. Love and Thunder certainly began with hope when Thor throws his cloak at the beginning of the movie, but by the third song recycled from the Appetite for Destruction album alone (there was no other hard rock band they could use in a hard rock themed movie?), the film was showing its wear and tear. That's not to say Love and Thunder is a bad film, since the cast is all staying true to character, the pace of the movie is on point, the colour, the design, the shade... Love and Thunder is in fact a sharp movie, but the film itself is handcuffed to way too much continuity that has to be answered to.A god worshipping soul loses all faith when unanswered drought claims his daughter. Answering to a cursed sword's call to seek revenge, all gods are put on notice as they are starting to be exterminated. Thor, who returns to shape and spirit after his latest trials, has a target on his back as he holds something of value to this God Butcher.What I do like about Waititi's approach in Love and Thunder is the use of the children. Say what you will about the climax (it's a superhero film, people), Waititi's movies have usually featured kids as the protagonist and Love and Thunder could have used more of their screen time, particularly with Gorr, or have them enjoying New Asgard. What we get instead are some very tiring cliches bogging down an already heavy film. In the face of cancer and abducted children, we didn't need to know Korg's mating rituals. Thor's romance over a former flame (not Jane) was also adding to unnecessary screen time. The key that made Ragnarok feels effortless was the successful banter between characters and parties that made the plot hold. Love and Thunder, though flashy and full of heart, misses that same effortlessness, making for a sometimes tiring watch.

I cannot emphasise enough how disappointing I found this comedy. I call it a comedy but I did not find it at all amusing. It has nothing in common with the original comic book character of Thor that I used to read as a child. I was a great fan of the Marvel comics but the latest Marvel movies are nothing but ridiculous. Why do they keep turning them into bad comedies?I don't think I will bother with any future Marvel movies because they are getting increasingly worse with formulated bad humour jam packed with special effects. The essence of a good superhero story is simplicity and hope. DC comic movies get better and better whilst Marvel movies just get more ridiculous.My advice, don't bother with this one.

For the record I am boycotting Disney because of their insistence of shoving the LGBTQ agenda down children under a certian ages throat.My objection is casting choces. The Norse Gods represented Noweigans and at that time were fair skinned. While Tessa Thompson is a fabulous actor casting her as Valkyrie to show diversity is lame. Now I know there will be protests over this but Iron Fist's girlfriend was African-American if she were portrayed by an Caucasian actor I would be the first to protest. Same for the character Sunspot who was bi-racial. Can you imagine they do a move about "Luke Cage Hero for Hire" and Dolph Lundgren was cast as the lead? Stoopid**Misspelled on purpose.

Thor enlists the help of Valkyrie, Korg and ex-girlfriend Jane Foster to fight Gorr the God Butcher, who intends to make the gods extinct.Thor: Ragnarok is not only the best Thor film but one of the best MCU films in general, so Taika Waititi had his work cut out for him in Thor: Love and Thunder. So did it live up to Ragnarok let's see.The cast is all around great and the chemistry between Chris Hemsworth and Natalie Portman is on full display. They really brought their relationship to life in this one and I feel they handled it much better then the first two Thor films. But I do feel that certain plot points involving their characters were rushed and didn't deliver the emotional punch the writers were looking for. Christian Bale is the standout for me (which is exactly what I expected), his performance as the gritty intimidating Gorr is amazing and why I wish we got more of it. The vast majority of Marvel films have the issue of not focusing on the villain enough and this film is no exception. Every scene involving Gorr is incredibly well done and if they were to have given me more of that it may have been the best MCU film but the constant shift in tone taints the overall quality.Every scene that didn't involve Gorr was very comedic and I felt that the comedy was not handled well for a number of reasons. First when you set up a movie with a villain as dark as Gorr, you need to keep the tone consistent and this film did no such thing. There were a lot of well written jokes but they didn't at all mix with the overall story. Gorr has one goal and that is to kill all the gods and he does some pretty messed up stuff to achieve this goal so to take that premise and intertwine it with a romantic comedy you get what is a very weird feeling movie.The visuals are across the board great and one fight sequence in particular may be one of my favourite from the MCU. The music is very on point throughout the entire film as they pair the awesome action sequences with amazing classic rock hits.Overall Thor: Love and Thunder is a good film. Thor and Jane finally receive their deserved development and Christian Bales Gorr is nothing short of menacing. But the lack of a consistent tone makes for a weird and at times frustrating watch that taints the overall quality of the film.7/10
B+

People need to go buy a sense of humour. It's Thor! Since when has Thor ever been that serious. Yes its daft and a bit silly but that's nothing new and if you have watched previous Thor films this is very apparent. Me and my husband had a good giggle at this in parts whilst other parts were serious and meaningful. The end to me was slightly unexpected but on reflection it makes sense why they would do this. I take it the people who hated this film must also hate guardians of the galaxy as that's a bit silly too.....

As one of the few who didn't like Thor: Ragnarok, I could see the writing on the wall. They would double down on the jokes, never giving the plot or character moments time to breathe and turn it into a tiktok video style clipshow for the ADS generation.What I didn't expect was for them to mess up the plot this badly.The setup of this was actually interesting. This could have been good, if not excellent.Take the opening scene (not a spoiler): Christian Bale's people are left to die by an uncaring god. He watches his daughter waste away and die. When he meets his god, the god is a fat jolly guy laughing and pointing at a fallen guy with the "godkiller" sword. How convenient. He then mocks Christian Bale who promptly kills him. It starts serious, but ends up as a joke.There are several issues with this. One, it is said gods derive their power from people worshipping them. Why then is this god strong and jolly? It would have been far more efficient for him to be a decrepit loser without any power, and Bale to renounce him then as worthless.Similarly, (again not a spoiler, because it's revealed in promotional material and in the comics) Jane Foster is dying of cancer. Expositionary dialogue reveals Mjolnir chose her to protect her. But it's also draining her life when she transforms and kills her faster. Umm, what? Is anyone proofreading this garbage before they film it? This fully contradicts itself.Not only is Mjolnir functioning again after being destroyed before, rendering that entire scene moot, but it's now better because its shards work like a projectile weapon. Nothing in this has consequences.A better setup: Have Thor bring the ruined hammer to Jane so she can study it. Maybe the hammer actually gives her cancer. And then the appearance of the villain sets in motion that she must sacrifice her own life expectancy to save the day and her love. Now suddenly it has gravitas. Self-preservation vs being a hero. Characters that make hard choices are interesting. Characters who just goof around are not.The entire movie is played for laughs. Every potentially serious moment is turned into a joke (except cancer, they don't joke about that). Worse, the jokes are terrible attempts at noisy slapstick. Screaming goats, remember that internet meme from 2005? It's back. Several times.Most newer Marvel movies since GotG tend to be tonally messy, but this is Ghostbusters 2016 level. Constant talking and bickering about nonsense, endless wink wink humor, references to pop culture, and again with an annoying Melissa McCarthy.As usual, the movie suffers from Marvel bloat as well. Too many characters with too little to do. This could have worked nicely as a small, somewhat thoughtful little character drama with Thor and Jane mending their relationship as she makes the ultimate sacrifice and learns to appreciate what it means to be a hero, and why Thor wasn't there for her because he was... saving the universe. But no, we get the Guardians, Valkyrie who does nothing except the director and Lady Sif, who is treated as a joke as well (the one joke that actually made me chuckle).For once, the critics got it right. This movie is a tonal mess, the acting talent is wasted on a subpar slapstick comedy, and the Marvel downtrend continues.Side note: The CGI looks atrocious. Every scene looks like a bad LSD trip with mismatching colors all over the place. My eyes were thankful for a particularly desaturated scene later in the movie during which I found myself rooting for the villain. Christian Bale wastes a good performance and seems to be the only one not in on the joke, that this movie is essentially a Naked Gun style farce. They did him dirty.Now in fairness, it's been said the original cut was 4 hours. Maybe it was more coherent. Maybe they excised some interesting character moments and ruined the pacing. Justice League showed what studio interference can do to a film, and Taika Waiti has proven that he can balance comedy and serious with his fantastic Jojo Rabbit. Or maybe he simply lucked out with that one.

ipc-title__text: Thunderous Thors Action Throughout The Universe!!

ipc-html-content-inner-div: I was very disappointed by this latest entry in the MCU. The movie starts out well with the opening scene starring Christian Bale as the "God Butcher". But then it goes downhill from there. Chris Hemsworth seems to be phoning in his performance, but he is also a victim of a bad script that tries too hard to be funny. I enjoyed the humor in "Thor: Ragnorak" but this one has too many jokes that fall flat and not enough action. The direction and cinematography are adequate but not inspired. Therefore, I can only recommend this one for MCU completists and/or "fanboys". 5/10.

ipc-title__text: It's too loose to be a staple film in the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Thor: Love and Thunder focused a little too much on the comedy aspect leaving much to be desired in the straightforward plot.This movie does a terrific job of introducing us to more of the gods in the marvel cinematic universe leading up to many abrupt emotional teasers.Although the film did have some laugh-out-loud moments showcasing Thors' relationship tension with Stormbreaker and Mjölnir or random screaming goats, it got carried away, which led to the comedy feeling corny. It did have some decent battles showcasing the mighty Thor's hammer.It's too loose to be a staple film in the Marvel Cinematic Universe.Just as the movie Poster suggests, a lot is going on in this film., from the revival of Thor's love interest with Jane to The Guardians of the Galaxy making a non-encapsulating cameo, screaming goats, the gods, and the Gorr( the antagonist). Additionally, I'm still trying to figure out how Jane became "a Thor" I know she may be a chosen one or worth but turning into Thor is pretty wild.Ragnarok is still the best Thor movie in the series.Thor: Love and Thunder feels like a filler episode of your favorite anime. You will gain some pleasant moments from the movie, yet you won't be exclaiming to everyone that this is a must-watch! The first after-credit scene makes me hopeful for a fantastic sequel to this film.With that being said, Entertainmentsparadise rates Thor Love and Thunder a 6/10.

ipc-title__text: Still entertaining, but it's no Ragnarok
ipc-html-content-inner-div: A fun action fueled good time. Chris Hemsworth is great as always so is Natalie Portman and this was definitely my favorite thor movie with her. Christian Bale was fantastic as Gorr & I really liked a lot of the set pieces especially on the climax. I will say though a lot of the humor was pretty excessive and some was just downright dumb. I laughed many times but stuff like the goats constantly screaming got old fast and thor pouring beer on Stormbreaker almost made me facepalm. Despite that though I can't act like I didn't have a great time. Ragnarok was better tho.

Why am I watching Thor Love and Thunder. I'm not watching it because I like Thor, god no! I mean he is a fine character I guess. I don't even remember if I liked the previous movie. I think I did. It was the one with Hulk and Jeff Goldblum, or no wasn't there something in between? Did I ever see the Dark World, or was it called the Dark Elf, I won't look it up, that is how much I care. It's possible I saw that movie. Anyway that is all a blurr. Thor is fine, Chris Hemsworth is ok. Don't love him, don't hate him. Again, can't remember if I've seen him in something else? I do remember the all-female Ghostbusters remake but not much else. He is kinda been only Thor. So yeah, I don't know why I'm watching this film.Does anyone care about the MCU anymore? I mean seriously, is it still sold as the mix of multiple different genres and storyline into one big showdown? That sound awfully like a 2010s thing. For the first Avengers movie it was fun I guess, but by the time they are fighting Thanos the amount of footage you have to consume just get up to speed is too much. Feel like you have to do homework to understand who is who and doing what. And the first thing you feel when you watch any of the latest Marvel films is that you're again watching something set up the back story for another upcoming movie which will set up the stage for another movie and so on. The MCU has become the film equivalent of a requiring reading list at the start of the semester, only it never ends. Like a perpetual wheel of sub-par movies.There, the movie is sub-par. There is nothing else to add. The story is generic, the plot is predictable, and the dialogue is atrocious. The film gives the villain a very valid motivation. He is the gods slayer The "gods" in this film are horrible. And they're not gods mind you, they're not deities, they're just another type of overpowered super-being. In this "universe" a god is not a being that creates life or punishes evil, they're merely beings that seek very basic pleasures. I'm going to stop here; this is already giving it more thought than anybody that worked on this film. That is why this movie is so bad, because it is not interested in what it means (unlike Guardians of the Galaxy vol.2 for instance, although it wasn't Nietsche either). It isn't interested in what anything means, it is only interested in rehashing things over and over. Just to keep the wheel spinning while we're waiting for the next one.

Good fun.Portman & Bale (& Crowe) are able to give the movie gravitas whilst Hemsworth & Co. & the many, many star cameos keep it zipping along.Suffers a little disjointedness from pandemic filmmaking (I suspect) but its heart is in the right place all along.Laughs, tears, & cheers!

ipc-title__text: If you enjoyed Ragnarök you'll enjoy this one
ipc-html-content-inner-div: One thing that shocked me about this movie was the pacing for it. This movie is on the shorter side when you compare it to the other Marvel movies and in my opinion, it works to a certain extent. The pacing goes at just the right speed throughout the entire movie, except at a few spots where the movie does come to a halt, and makes sure to keep the audience entertained from start to finish.Even if the pacing for this movie wasn't the greatest, the story for this movie is still interesting enough to hook you along for this wild ride. From the very opening scene to the last I was hooked wanting to know more and see what happens next. I will say though the story for this movie does feel like it tried to take on too much for this story. Like I said the pacing works to a certain extent and I feel like if this movie was just a tad bit longer some things could've been explored more. With that being said, with the two main story points in this movie, the movie does a good enough job of exploring those points and keeping the audience invested.This can also be attested to the actor's work in this movie which was marvellous. Whether an actor in this movie had five minutes of screen time to being a main character everybody was bringing their everything to this movie. Due to this, the audience grows to care for these characters and wants to see them succeed. The standout performances in this movie for me were Christian Bale and Natalie Portman, who plays Dr. Jane Foster/The Mighty Thor. Christian Bale originally didn't want to play Gorr and I'm so thankful his kids talked him into it because I can't imagine anybody else playing this role. He was able to switch between so many different emotions that made the audience both scared and sympathetic towards this character. The same can be said for Natalie Portman's performance in this movie where she shows how much of a badass Jane Foster is as both a regular human and as the mighty Thor. I do wish though that some characters got some more screen time such as King Valkyrie, played by Tessa Thompson.One thing that Marvel movies are really known for is their hit-or-miss special effects, especially their CGI, and the special effects in this movie definitely were a hit. Sometimes the special effects can start out either way and then slowly get worse or better but here they remain the same throughout the movie. I especially loved the CGI on the screaming goats who stole the movie.The special effects in this movie really do help out with the cinematography which also was great. The cinematography for this movie was gorgeous and helped the audience visually understand where exactly they are by helping create these grand worlds.Now, I know it's become a common thing to hate on the comedy in Marvel movies and I will admit that the comedy in this movie might not work for most, especially this one recurring joke, but for me, it worked. I really enjoyed the comedy in this movie as it still didn't overpower some of the more serious moments and would come at the right time. It also helps that this movie wasn't afraid to actually have serious moments in this movie and let them be just that serious moments.The final thing I want to mention is the soundtrack for this movie and how much of a banger it is. From the musical score, composed by Michael Giacchino and Nami Melumad, to the songs they added into the background everything worked for this movie. Please Marvel do more soundtracks with retro music.In the end, Thor: Love and Thunder isn't going to work for some but if you enjoyed Ragnarok you'll probably enjoy this one as well.

ipc-title__text: Was fine but mcu should do better
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Looks like we have another divisive MCU film yet. Let me start the review with saying Thor: Love and Thunder's first act (or first half,) is indeed not great. The humor falls flat a lot, the CGI is questionable at times( this is actually a problem throughout the movie ) and I just couldn't shrug off the corporate-lifeless feel during those parts. I was patiently waiting for the movie to move onto the more interesting scenes. And luckily, the movie did! (Sort of)When the movie entered the 2nd act and started to focus less on comedy and more on action and emotions, my investment improved quite a bit. (Even though jokes were still there and they were still kinda cringe, but they were better than before) The battle of the Shadow Realm has one of MCU's most visually interesting choices, and I actually had to hold back my tears during the final moments, did not expect the villain to be the heart of a MCU movie. But Gorr definitely would have benefited from more screen time tho. Since he was basically absent during the second act. Even though the movie does have some emotional moments during the final act, I'd say one of the biggest problems of the movie is the lack of tension / urgency. A character supposedly dies or gets injured badly, but turns out it is not a big deal later on. Also, The movie sort of feels like a 'Stepping Stone' type movie. While the movie overall was fun, I don't think there were any meaning ful arc for Thor. After watching the movie I am more interested in directions the Thor character can go after this one.Overall the movie definitely could have been better, and lowering my expectations did help my experience I think. Same thing happened with Eternals last November. But just like that movie, it was overall a decent experience. I don't know about my feelings about the movie after some time passes tho.6.5/10.

ipc-title__text: What to say, what to say...
ipc-html-content-inner-div: My general impression of this movie is that i've just lost 2 hours of my life. It seems like Marvel's conveyor clearly lost and doesn't know which direction and side to go, after they failed everything with multiverse, after they released the worst TV series, that i've ever seenz with the worst dialogues, lore and plot called Loki, and failed amazing sitcom parts of WandaVision mixing it with ungodly MCU lore... Gosh. Latest SM movie was also disgusting. New DS just average. What was the last the can be even called not bad? Black Widow? Eternals? Well, MAY BE! The last good were i'd say Avengers? MCU never had lots of good movies. I'd say Iron Man and Homecoming are the best, solid, last 2 Avengers movies are good(well, i suppose Age of Ultron and Civil War are not that far, but the first Avengers if you look and them now(personally i was in cinema on premiere in 2012, being 13y.o, Avengers entered theatres 1 day before my birthday) have bad dialogues, like they were written by some young schooler and spoils it all) and probably i'd say that i like most of all other Thor 3, though it failed in the end, and couldn't decide either it wants to be an epic action or entertainment. What's about this movie? It just sums it up what we already saw before: whole thing turns into a toothless child cringe "comedy". Remember when we had that epic feeling before, like in Avengers, that something big is happening, that heroes are cool? Forget it! All main cast just turned into clown and "celebrities" of the show. And you could miss it but, it started back at the Iron Man 3, that idiotic direction and vision. I'm tired of all this feigned fun, pathetic wink to the viewer and circus, yeah this movie feels kinda average but this is just over the top. Oh, wait, what do we have here? The most sickening and infantile ending in history of the cinema? Thor does superstupid thing in the most important moment? And then uses his TALKING SKILLS ? Thor? Yeah, this guy is know for his speeches... And how... Just no comments. Movie ends with a note like "next time you'll finally get what you wished for" and you know people, i never dreamed of gachi fight in MCU(sure it will be, after seeing how this movie looks like), it is such a shame. Go to hell, Marvel Studios!P. S. Ah, and be ready, here she is, really bad actress, with creaking voice from Wanda Vision. I gonna ask again, who's daughter she is? Ah, my review to WandaVision, that i tried to publish several times still isn't there? Ok, lets suppose, that i ask about this woman for the first time. Lol, just looked at her page on imdb, she was in Thor 1 and 2, but i noticed her only in WV series. Well, maybe sometimes it is better not to draw attention to oneself...

Let me put it this way. I expected worse. Lately, Marvel movies haven't been reaching the quality they once did, so I wasn't expecting anything special, and that's probably why I'm not disappointed in the finale. It went by pleasantly quickly because there was a lot of action, which I thought was pretty epic in places, but there's just one catch. Story-wise, it's not such a joy anymore. There is a lot of humour. A lot. That's a classic with Marvel movies, but here there's perhaps I would say a little more of it. I generally don't like a lot of jokes in superhero movies. I prefer more serious superhero ventures, like Christopher Nolan's Dark Knight trilogy, but that's beside the point. There were several times in the story where one character was speaking to tell the story and that bothered me. I don't like it much and rarely like it, but sometimes it's cool, but here I didn't like it. Then as I mentioned the humor is really over the top here, which wasn't my cup of tea either. I don't want to spoil, but story-wise it wasn't a total win either. Well it was saved for me by the aforementioned action, which I enjoyed and which Marvel can and probably always will, except for Eternals. That was pretty damn weak in my opinion and Thor: Love Like Thunder is still fine in comparison. So, for me, a good movie that although I would recommend to Thor fans, I might not after all because it gets quite the hate. It's hard to say. My friends were really disappointed with this movie. I'm satisfied though and for me it was fine.

I must say. I was really looking forward to this installment. Was a massive fan of Ragnarok, which combined comedy, fantasy and superhero storytelling perfectly.This film on the other hand- an absolute travesty. It seemed very much like an excuse to get as many A-listers as possible reading a poorly scripted film with some sad attempts at humour. There were few redeeming qualities in this film besides some fancy special effects. It was also quite overacted despite its stellar cast- though that is likely the product of bad direction y Waititi, who I suspect has for some reason taken the franchise in a different direction this time.

ipc-title__text: Its Lucky it Came out AFTER Dark World
ipc-html-content-inner-div: This is a really weak follow-up to the magnificent Ragnarok. After the highs of Ragnarok, this movie is really a letdown. Only Dark World saves it from being the worst Thor movie.Chris Hemsworth is back as in-shape Thor. There is a silly montage showing him getting back in shape. He is bouncing around with the Guardians of the Galaxy before returning to New Asgard when it is in trouble. Tessa Thompson returns as King Valkyrie and quizzically seems incredibly disinterested in the role. Natalie Portman is back after missing the last couple of movies and she is supposed to be taking over the mantel of Thor. Even Jaimie Alexander is back as Sif, but her role is so small and inconsequential, I'm not really sure why she bothered. The new villain is Christian Bale as Gorr, the God Butcher. He is okay in the role, but the character doesn't really elevate the movie the way Kate Blanchet did in Ragnarock. Even Russell Crowe gets dusted off to play Zeus...yea, the Greek god. And its cringe inducing.Oddly, there is almost no chemistry between Hemsworth and Portman in this sequel. Their romantic scenes have no spark and Portman seems so detached. I got no sense that they were in love. The events in the move have almost as little spark as well. There is nothing that hasn't been done in prior movies and it felt so blah. If this was not an established part of the MCU, this movie would have bombed...hard.One highlight is Matt Damon, Liam Hemsworth, Sam Neill and, even Melissa McCarthy, as the Asgard actors doing plays about the events of the previous movie. It was pretty funny, but when the highpoint of your movie is a small callback to the previous film, you might have a problem.

ipc-title__text: Not as good as Ragnarök, but I'm still hoping for more!
A hilarious but tonally odd movie that feels like a parody rather than a canon entry.

ipc-html-content-inner-div: There are movies that strike that great balance between tones and then there are movies like Thor : Love & Thunder.It's actually impressive how many times this movie swings for the fences, misses and falls flat on it's grinning face.Dramatic scenes sandwiched into elementary school humor. Trying so hard to be funny and desperatly pushing for memes and running jokes which are a nuisance even before the repition. And all I could hear in that noise is "Hello fellow kids..."There's a little storytelling device that's called 'Show don't tell', perhaps Disney/Marvel should use it sometimes on one of their villains. It became a cliche even in the phase one that their villains are cartoonishly underdeveloped. That they still haven't figured this out after Thanos is truly baffling.The soundtrack is as try-hard as the comedy, so there's no silver lining here unfortunately.At this point it would be more interesting to list the drugs that has been consumed by the director and producers, because they must have clearly been very satisfied with the salad of a story.m they delivered.It's a shame because the last Marvel movie by Raimi (Doctor Strange 2) had hints of actual good storytelling, if they just didn't have so many cooks in the kitchen to mess it all up.This feels like ten steps backwards compared to their last effort.

ipc-title__text: New Zealand is a country of some great talent
ipc-html-content-inner-div: New Zealand has brilliant music bands, great actors, and some great productions. 7 Periods with Mr Gormsby is one of my favourite TV series: it's intelligent, hilarious, witty, and not afraid to pull punches. You see similar wit in Flight of the Concords.Then you've got anything Taika Waititi. He is the opposite of everything I mentioned. Think of him as New Zealand's lowest common denominator. In the first 30 minutes, I counted one character in Thor: LaT that I liked (Stellan Skarsgard, who appeared for 10 seconds).I say the following in all seriousness. If you are of reasonable intelligence, do not watch this film without some form of mind-altering substance. You will need something to dull the pain.Generally speaking, I don't walk out through a film. I made an exception here. This was dreadful, not funny, and utterly low brow.I scored 3/10 because I saw that the general production was reasonable. The story and acting was dreadful.

ipc-title__text: See something like this happen alot on a TV show
