ipc-html-content-inner-div: AGT! They have an act come out and blow our minds! (Ragnarok) Maybe they even hit the Golden Buzzer! It's fresh, it's exciting, it's all new. Then the next act, or movie comes out! It's not fresh, it's a lot of the same thing! Then you start to compare it to the first example and find it lacks in a lot of areas. Timing, story, villain, jokes. If there wasn't a Ragnarok, this would be considered a fun, but rather quick movie. I also noticed the Ad campaign online actually might be hurting it! It does not live up to the hype! Zeus was funny here and there, he was not Robin Williams! I must have seen 20 paid articles which were really ads trying to convince me it was the best comedy cameo ever. Too much hype, mailed in direction and story.

You got what you deserve, for praising Thor Ragnarok. This movie was already a joke and you gave Taika Waititi carte blanche to butcher the fourth one.I swear the movie can't spend 2mns without cracking a lame joke. Hey Taika, jokes are better when they're actually funny. It's 2022 and I can't believe we're still doing the "Yes you will - No I won't - Yes you will - No I won't" kind of joke, and expecting people to laugh at it.The villain is ok but could have been better if properly developed, and the divinity theme with him.

The entire Thor series is far from homogenous. The original and Ragnarok were pretty outstanding, though being rather different in the ways they presented themselves - one more serious, the other more comedic. Never the less, both delivered an outstanding cinematic experience with depth of storyline and characters. This particular film fails on all fronts. It seems like an excuse to get together an all star cast and milk the franchise with millions of dollars without delivering anything new. The jokes in this film are simply not funny and rather childish to be perfectly honest. I think the Thor series ends here.

ipc-title__text: Fun & Action... but too much pointless humor
ipc-html-content-inner-div: At its heart, and yes, there is a lot of heart here, THOR: LOVE AND THUNDER is a fun, action-filled Marvel movie that is one of the better ones to come in this tiresome post-ENDGAME phase. This is a movie where the hero's journey is is purposeful and resolute, not only for Thor Odinson but Jane Foster as well. To get on that road, though, takes a lot of patience.As fun as LOVE AND THUNDER is, the movie is also childish, idiotic, superficial, and features way too many Guns-n-Roses anthems. The first twenty or so minutes, where Thor goofs off with the equally-juvenile Guardians of the Galaxy, would tax even the strongest of Asgardian gods. Once the threat of Gorr, the god butcher, arrives on New Asgard's steps, the heroes' quest begins - and that is a most satisfactory story.Taika Waititi makes use of Chris Hemsworth's generous smile and biceps in a familiar and comfortable manner. Thor takes on the mantle of leader and proves he is quite sufficient in the role. Smashing and thrashing and joking (maybe a touch too much of the levity this time around, though) leads to a successful, and actually unsuspecting, ending where you are craving more.First and foremost, Thor is a hero. Hopefully future appearances of the Thunder God will focus more on this aspect and keep the over-the-top humor in reserve. Maybe for a rainy day.

While a touch of Taika's farcical "What We Do In The Shadows" humour was splendid in Ragnorak, there's too much of it in this film. It's a non-stop corn-ball comedy hour full of jokes that could have been funny if I wasn't annoyed that they just didn't stop. All the corniness made it really hard for me to get invested in the characters. I just didn't care what happened to anyone in the film, I looked at my watch at least three times and was happy when it was over. Also, stop shoving the WOKE nonsense down our throats. It's so bloody annoying now. Thor was the best, most powerful and most thrilling marvel character and now he's the butt end of a joke, looking stupid so that everyone around him looks much smarter. Sad.

ipc-title__text: Disney continues to lower the standard for Marvel films...
ipc-html-content-inner-div: The first half hour or so has some funny jokes and pop culture references, starting off with a bang similar to the most recent Suicide Squad film, however, unlike the most recent Suicide Squad film, it completely loses momentum, and the rest of this film is utter, hammered garbage. Natalie Portman is fed an awful script, genuinely appearing uninterested in her role, and looks ridiculous as a female Thor - I literally pity her for having to appear in this filth, along with poor Christian Bale. If these producers had any actual brains, which clearly almost nobody working for streaming companies that make feature films does these days (Netflix is equally guilty of producing tripe features), when they read the proposed script and saw the name "Zeus" it would have been very clever for them to think to engage Liam Neeson in reprising his unforgettable performance as Zeus from Clash of the Titans, to the point that I might have given them one more crucial star towards a barely passing grade. Don't tell me Disney doesn't have the cash that this couldn't have been arranged, since Liam Neeson will seemingly work for loose change these days (not to detract from his work, he's excellent, but he appears quite easy to engage, similar to Nick Cage, who I also enjoy). Russell Crowe is utterly miscast as Zeus - his worn-leather face, stringy hair and obesity simply DO NOT CONJURE VISUALS WORTHY OF A GOD OF ZEUS' STATURE, PERIOD, to the GREAT detriment of that entire sequence. I'm surprised to see Christian Bale in such garbage, but none of the fault lies with him. The film has typically strong visuals (LITERALLY THE ONLY THING GOING FOR EITHER NETFLIX OR DISNEY THESE DAYS) but even the visuals are squandered, as mid-way through the film converts to black and white as they enter some sort of "shadow realm" thingy, and honestly, I feel they could have been more inventive making the visuals look good without using color. More routine, boring action sequences and bland storytelling ensue. Whatever, it's garbage, why am I making any effort going any further about it since Disney/Marvel didn't? Basically there isn't a Marvel film since Avengers: End Game, Deadpool 2 and Logan worth anybody's time. Looking forward to another actually GOOD Marvel superhero film ONE day, but at this rate I've accepted that IT'S VERY UNLIKELY...

Worst Marvel movie to date! It's ridiculous and lame. The constant jokes are very cringe worthy. The acting is by far the worst as well. And let's not get started on the CGI!!! Way overused and looks terrible! People complained about The Eternals movie being the worst, but it's spectacular compared to this drivel. Actually, The Eternals should set the bar for cinematography and great story telling. The Thor movies need to stop! And they definitely need to find a different director if they plan to make more movies. We need more movies like Logan and less movies like this. Terrible, terrible!!!!!

ipc-title__text: Worst Thor movie of all time and worse than the trilogy which looks so much better than this!
Another step in the comedy direction
ipc-html-content-inner-div: I loved the original Thor movie, in fact it's my favourite of all the Marvel releases. Kenneth Brannagh did a very good job.I struggled with Dark World; it was considerably weaker. Then the switch to comedy came with Ragnarok, which seemed very popular but I found it hard to get through once again.Love and Thunder goes back to basics with a decent, simple story but unfortunately just has too much super power tennis. Clashes are just bam, bam, bam, bam, win/lose. Then, the other to serve and I can't get into any of that kind action, which is prevalant in most MCU movies and just lacks effort in the writing.The comedy and serious emotional moments don't mix too well either. The light vibe was just lost.Jane Foster as Thor was fun but why she was called Thor I don't get. Why not just be called The Mighty Dr Foster or something? No harm to the plot but these kind of token hand-me-downs are distracting.Overall, not much to write home about. It was OK watch but less good than Captain Marvel, which was already heading in the direction of generic super power movie.I'm not a big MCU fan but I suspect even those that are will find this a bit forgettable.

No that's not a sexual commentary. I mean to say, everyone was funny and that's why it didn't work.Barry Sonnenfeld wrote in his book that he believes the reason he Wild Wild West was such a failure was because Kevin Kline refused to play his character straight, he kept trying to be to funny one when Will Smith's character was written to have all of the jokes. For contrast when he moved on to Men in Black, Will Smith's comedic role against Tommy Lee Jones' deadpan straight-man was a smash hit.In this movie you had 2 obvious characters who should have been the straight-man: Jane Foster and Gor. Instead Waititi had them doing schtick and trying to deliver funny lines. He couldn't resist the urge to wedge his juvenile sense of humor into EVERY POSSIBLE CORNER of this movie.And Jesus Christ I hate Guns 'n Roses, who's terrible idea was that?

ipc-title__text: A different kind of a marvel movie
ipc-html-content-inner-div: To be honest the movie was not what I expected, it was quite different from the normal usual marvel movies that we have all watched so far. I know that a lot of people didn't like it so much but it was not that bad like people are saying in the reviews here. It is more of a parody than an action movie. I found the humour very funny, the movie wasn't taken itself too serious and why not trying something else? I mean it is not like I wanna have all marvel movies made this way, but 1 or 2 marvel movies like this once in a while why not I would find it cool.Christian Bale as a villain pretty much nailed it again, he is so incredible skilled at incorporating characters, I just love watching movies where he is in.The movie is worth watching it, but be prepared to see a different kind of marvel movie than what we used to watch :)

Chris and Natalie did have chemistry in this film. I did see them in the first film and The Dark World. Not Ragnarök. Christian Bale nailed the character of Gorr the God Butcher. With all that makeup on him, his character resembles like Emperor Palpatine, Voldemort and the Nun. Overall, Bale was excellent and scary for the role. There were some parts that became campy but the lines and dialogues were funny. My dad, brother and I laughed along. Of course the action and fight scenes were awesome. There was good music throughout the film as well. Korg definitely stole some of the funny scenes and we laughed at it. The action sequences are great and we were amazed with the special effects. It's still an awesome film and I would watch it again. I wish I would hold Thor's hammer and harness the thunder.

...but still kinda enjoyable, personally. There's no build-up for the event or anything. It's so straight-forward. At least they got the theme of the movie right, Love & Thunder. Not enough exposition to care for anyone. I know people hate it, for instance, Eternals. But I loved it. The humour. Some hits some doesn't. Same ol' MCU jokes but over-the-top, in this case. But it was expected since it's a Taika movie. It was great to see Natalie returning, love her. And so was Hemsworth, Tessa & Bale. The acting was great. Visuals, the usual for an MCU movie.

ipc-title__text: Thor Halfwit-son aka Korg: Love & Blunder
well...i'm glad i'm not alone in thinking that this movie was painful to sit through...
ipc-html-content-inner-div:
I don't know what they producers were thinking, going along with this script. Seems to be made for the 12 and under crowd. Lame...lame...lame.Lots of jokes. Not funny jokes, but lots OF them...
why they thought this guy should direct a Marvel movie is beyond. And it's REALly apparent, from SO many of the reviews, that i'm not even CLOSE to being alone in my disappointment and frustration...
the guy made one overrated, overhyped movie. And i was waiting for something as entertaining as something like an Avenger movie. Look at the cast, for the God's sake...how could they MISS? The answer is, no script worth working with, although the actors really seemed to be giving it their best.I'll be reading reviews first before going and spending my money, in these recession times, on any more Marvel movies.I can't believe they tricked people into making triple the money they sank into the movie...i guess NONE of us read the reviews beforehand, figuring 'how can it be bad? It's THOR!'.

ipc-title__text: I don't normally give 1 star reviews
Top marks for Bale, less for the other
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Taika Waititi has a problem. In the wake of the amazing Thor Ragnarok, where does he take the franchise? Most of the original MCU Avengers have retired, yet the sparkles, the Lord of Thunder, is still putting in the work to change odd bod into god bod. Following all he has lost - parents, brother, friends, planet - he has a lot of issues that he needs to work out. And into this mix comes Gorr, played by an amazing Christian Bale, who challenges Thors strength and other emotions, with his own quest. And in the middle of this epic grudge match of god and god killer, steps Natalie Portmans Jane Foster, reintegrated into the Marvel fold following the falling out over Patty Jenkins, and given a much more beefed up role than just the scientific side kick and love interest. Her transformation is straight out the comics, and not to be questioned, though given all the space magic we've seen in previous films, it's good to see Kat Dennings asking some good questions.But the main conflict comes from the Asgardian weapons; despite throwing Mjolnir to Captain America in End Game, it's obvious he still pines for the only object that properly pull him off and there is a lot made of that, to the point it does get juvenile. In fact, quite a lot of the script reduces the thunder god to a doey eyed hippy, which placed against the sinister Gorr - channelling a combination of Voldermort, Marilyn Manson, Joker and other creepy bad guys - makes the story leap from yelling goats and All Spice adverts, to shadow monsters and dead gods. Russel Crowes Zeus sounds like Borat, and while his scene is one of the better set pieces in the film, it does feel like it could have gone bigger.Marvel have access to a vast array of computer generated content, and there are some amazing set pieces, space ships and battle scenes, though I was left wondering if they'd tried deaging Hemsworth and Portman, that left neither actor looking that great.It was a fun pop corn film, with plenty of comedy and action, though tinged with sadness that Bale didn't get more screen time,.

ipc-title__text: When it's good it's so good but when it's bad it's quite frankly awful
ipc-html-content-inner-div: The comedy here is a mixed bag and at points it feels the team are sacrificing story for comedy to the point where the film feels almost like a parody. Gorr has some awesome sequences in the film but ends up being wasted and falling to the mcus victim curse, Jane is also a waste here. Choosing to adapt two of thors best comic storylines was bold and sadly it fails. The cgi and cinematography are great, there are some hard hitting moments but the movies structure is it's worst enemy. The pacing is all over the place at points you'll feel like you've just missed a whole scene. The action here is great and if you can look past the story issues it is a fun, comedic somewhat emotional ride. But it does make one wonder what is marvel doing?

ipc-title__text: Fun, but felt more like an episode than a film.
Watch the Movie Itself Go Through a Mid-Life Crisis
ipc-html-content-inner-div: THOR: LOVE AND THUNDER (C-) gives us a Thor struggling with an identity crisis (expressed through non-stop jokes) despite the challenges and growth his previous 8 appearances have sold us on. The film itself seems to be struggling with the same thing as it has transitioned to an all-out comedy vehicle with just two dramatic notes - love is good and religion is dumb. Taika Waititi's work here is like religious satire of Voltaire coupled with the schmaltzy humanistic ethic of Oprah filtered through the cinematic comedy lens of Tarantino & Shrek. The film isn't helped by a plot that is as engrossing and ad hoc as the obvious and non-stop CGI locations they travel to. Nor is it helped by action sequences as the film seems completely uninterested in taking the action seriously by giving it stakes or a respite from the non-stop comedy or unique/creative beats. I laughed at some of the jokes, but I found myself growing less and less interested in Thor and the gang that surrounds him. At the rate this universe invents ad hoc items (God killing swords and wish granting altars) that should have been mentioned in the Infinity War, brings back dead people, or retcons the tone/plot of past films - why should anyone care about anything. I hope this is as low as the MCU gets, but I fear it won't be.

ipc-title__text: BEST THOR MOVIE EVER! Don't listen to haters!
ipc-html-content-inner-div: This was the best Thor imo above the rest and one of Marvel's top tiers! Natalie Portman was amazing and all the action, scenery, story and all just superb and Bale was amazing as always. Despite his funny memes when you watch the movie you feel for the guy and his role was one of the best "villains" so far unlike Thanos. 100000/10!!

I did want to like this film because THOR : Ragnarok was i.m.o. The best of all the marvel films , but i was left wanting , this film even tho was amusing in parts the lack of good story let it down and just looked silly .....!!!!!

A nowhere piece of junk - the infantile director and totally amateurish writers can't even decide if its meant for adults or children. In either case, it's just ludicrously bad.Good actors are all the way wasted on caricatured acting and silly dialogue that even a ten year old will yawn at.You should be paid to watch this crap, not the other way round.

ipc-title__text: Everything is a joke, but nothing is funny...
ipc-html-content-inner-div: This movie is a farce and the main character is rendered as a buffoon. I had heard bad things about this but I didn't think it could possibly be this bad.Christian Bale is great and most of the acting is fine. But what they're being asked to do is just complete nonsense. The plot makes almost no sense, and even when it starts to, another stupid or tasteless joke pops up to ruin the mood and flow.About the only redeeming factor could be some of the visuals. But Thor's costume is ridiculous and the CGI for Natalie Portman is weird.I could go on, but just ready yourself for disappointment if you're looking for any sort of depth or intelligent design. Truly a bad film.

ipc-title__text: Love is Eternal Love is Blind but This Film is .....????
ipc-html-content-inner-div:
Making me lose my mind...Meh.Starts off with pickup from Endgame and New Asgard, following Thor's handover and Korg picking up the Thor thread, but......
Not funny, Pedestrian , loads of talent present but wasted in direction and script.over-hyped and Empty....

Despite this film receiving rather a mixed reception, I really enjoyed it! Taika Waititi's style of comedy and directing just fits with me. This film definitely is not perfect, but it is exactly what I wanted.One of my absolute favourite elements was 'Gorr the God Butcher', as the villain. Christian Bale gave such an amazing performance, which shone despite the character's small amount of screen time. There is a particular film sequence that involves his character which is extremely well executed visually. I really liked the direction they took the Jane Foster character in! It genuinely surprised me at points and built upon previous films.The film does seem to move at a rather quick pace. It never really stays in a singular scene for too long. This does somewhat prevent further character development and leaves you wanting a bit more of certain characters. It definitely adds the film's humour, as it does not dwell on jokes that didn't land as well as others. Overall, I would recommend checking it out!

ipc-title__text: Even Godly butts of Thor couldn't save this film
ipc-html-content-inner-div: I did not expect much going into this but hoped for some nice jokes. I loved what Taika did in Jojo Rabbit. Sadly, there were mostly bad jokes this time. Loved Thor doing a Harry Potter and an Ajay Devgn (guess TW sees a lot of memes) - it promised to be funny with these few good moments in the beginning.But it got painfully one-dimensional, so much so that everything was a comedy, which doesn't even make you laugh. Only Bale is able to spur some kind of emotion in the film, and he is rushed through, and Gorr as a character was quite paper-thin. Needed more work on him.Love and Thunder has nothing for which you'll remember it, save for Guns N' Roses.Glad I didn't waste my money watching it at the cinemaAnd was that Matt Damon playing Loki? WHY?

ipc-title__text: My GOD This Movie is Bad.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Didn't like this movie at all. For the first time in however long i actually couldn't finish it. I got about 1hr 13mins into the movie (and this is whilst i skipped a scene or two).The story seemed fine in terms of the God Butcher character that Bale played, but the rest was crap.The comedy was not at all comedic and the acting in general was fine but not enough to save the movie. You know a movie isn't great when even Christian Bale's acting isn't very good in particular.Overall this movie is a perfect example of how Marvel have fallen in terms of movie quality over the past few years. The one and only reason i am not giving it a 1/10 is because the CGI was good and the design of certain characters was fine.Before i end this i must stress how poor the characters are developed in this movie. The Butcher character in his first scene seems slightly interesting but quickly becomes boring. Zeus (a character that should be awesome to see in Marvel) is utterly abysmal. His character is boring and not serious at all. One of the worst (if not the worst) MCU characters to date.I personally believe that Taika Waititi is the most overrated director in all of cinema. None of the movies i have seen from this to Jojo Rabbit have been even average and he gets praised to the high heavens. He was a better actor in Free Guy than director and even in that movie he isn't particularly great. I'm gobsmacked.This movie is poor in 90% of the categories you can rank a movie in, 2/10.

Goats! Thor embarks on a journey unlike anything he's ever faced -- a quest for inner peace. However, his retirement gets interrupted by Gorr the God Butcher, a galactic killer who seeks the extinction of the gods. To combat the threat, Thor enlists the help of King Valkyrie, Korg and ex-girlfriend Jane Foster, who -- to his surprise -- inexplicably wields his magical hammer. Together, they set out on a harrowing cosmic adventure to uncover the mystery of the God Butcher's vengeance.Chris Hemsworth is still great as Thor, but there's too much goofiness now. Although Natalie Portman had a really big role this time and she did really well portraying that role, her acting seemed a bit off in some scenes. Gorr (and with an incredible performance by Christian Bale) is one of the greatest MCU villains, so he definitely needed more screen time. Also, the little cameos were really fun to see.The movie had a fun and promising start, but it got really slow and boring in some scenes towards the middle leading to an underwhelming ending. Despite all that, the post-credit scene was pretty exciting.The movie attempts to be funny with some successful laughs, but it's packed with many jokes that are really foolish to the point where the movie gets quite silly.The CGI (especially the floating head part that everyone is talking about) is very bad compared to "Thor: Ragnarok".Score:7/10.

ipc-title__text: This goes on par with how phase 4's been going for marvel
Great Thor movie, but really suffered from same major issue.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Thor Dark World is still the worst Thor movie. But this one is next. The problem with this movie is:1. It's the same subplot with Thor "finding himself", which is overdone at this point.2. The dark/sad tone and moments of this movie is often overshadowed by the humor. Which just doesn't work well as even in the darkest moments, they follow it up with some cheesy joke that just feels out of place.3. The humor is great as always. But sadly many of the jokes end up feeling less funny and more cringy. The tried to hard.4. The goats..... people either loved them or hated them...strongly. And they really went over board with the goats to the point of the joke lost its charm afterawhile.5. While Bale did an amazing job as Gorr. Again, the serious/dark nature of him was still lost or less effective due tot he constant humor. The contrast really threw things off.6. The story overall sort of felt all over the place and almost rushed. I hate to say it but the best parts were in the trailer.7. Lastly they really pushed the bounds of "out there" ideas from the comics. It had its moments of corniness where many said it was overboard. For example one of the gods we meet is literally a cartoony looking. Boa is the dumpling god. He has a anime look and smile. I laughed, but many thought it was just stupid. Moments like this were to much for most audiences it seemed.In the end, I personally enjoyed the movie. But I can see why so many felt the movie had some issues. I love Thor, I just hope in the future they resolve these issues. I think part of it may also be Taika Waititi's role in the making of the movie. As great as he is, sometimes he needs to have some more restraint.

I have enjoyed all the Thor movies to date, my least favourite would get a 7 out of 10 until this one came along.I've always enjoyed the humour in the Thor movies, but this one simply misses the target in terms of humour and a decent story.It feels like the actors are either laughing at the studio for been paid so well for something so lame, or that they simply aren't interested at all.I knew Russell Crowe could be bad with accents...see Robin Hood, but his turn as Zeus, hamming it up like some old theatre lovey really is painful to watch.I have enjoyed the work of Taika Waititi, but this won't do his CV any favours been the writer.The beginning of the movie was messy, the middle quite boring, and the end felt like the hand of Disney at work.

Watched in 4DX. 3D element was cool.Overall I enjoyed this.Most of the humour hit home.Its action packed and moves at a fast pace. A bit too fast - I lost my way in the middle - too much going on, then it came back together again.The over use of Guns n Roses songs was a bit tiresome - the songs are 35 years old and been used in loads of other films to similar effect.Taika Waititi is very talented but he is at risk of becoming over exposed here - his humour is everywhere, he is the narrator, he voices a main character...The film has a taste of "we can do absolutely anything we want and back it up using some kind of link to ye gods because we are clever" - I like that, but I have seen others dislike it for that reason.Christian Bale is good. Nice to see Russell Crowe and his comedy accent. Natalie Portman is great.Seeing the Guardians of the Galaxy at the beginning kind of reminded me I'd rather be watching a movie about them!I think its a very different Thor movie to the first couple but I enjoyed it.

Proof that after a slew of seriously disappointing (in my opinion- don't kill me!) releases, the MCU can still give us entertaining, emotional, awesome movies. But! If they want to do so, then it's clear that they'll absolutely HAVE to get 100% behind the director's visions, and trust them to make the movie that they want.Also, to talk about the actual film, it's amazing. The acting is great from all the leads, the directing and cinematography is stunningly beautiful. Like, I had to wait weeks and weeks to see this in the cinema after my original trip got ruined, but it was absolutely worth it. The story is everything I wanted it to be, and more honestly. And after seeing the film, I really think that Thor is one of the best characters to have come out of the MCU. Sure he had a bit of a rough start, but as the films have gone on, he's gone through such an amazing arc and character development that he's really become one of the all time great superheroes.Overall, this film pleasantly surprised me and broke my heart in the best way possible. It was emotional, thoroughly entertaining, and totally awesome!

MARVEL's been on a slightly confusing path post endgame. The focus has definitely been on the Disney+ content as mentioned by Kevin Feige in majority of the press conferences. Both Spiderman No Way Home and Dr Strange Multiverse of Madness were about exploring the multiverse concept mixed with nostalgia. While the other TV shows are exploring many new characters and storylines, we wonder how much of them will get integrated into the big screen releases. Amidst all this, Thor Love and Thunder somehow comes off as an unexpected breeze in the midst of a multiverse storm.Thor Love and Thunder definitely lives up to its expectation as to what was shown in the trailer and also manages to surprise you beyond that. The plot is about Thor taking on the new nemesis Gorr The Godbutcher while also exploring more on his life and love. The movie is not so heavy on action but it doesn't necessarily need it as well. Although the humour element feels recycled from most of the previous MARVEL movies, there are some really funny moments. The movie kind of carries the vibes of initial Thor movies and isn't as chaotic as Ragnarok. Michael Giacchino's score is impressive as always and the use of rock music to enhance the action sequence works once again.Thor Love and Thunder is all about characters and their arc. Chris Hemsworth continues his charming ways of playing Thor and at this point of time he's just living it. Natalie Portman's comeback as Jane Foster and also Lady Thor (or should I say Mighty Thor ;-)) is backed by a very strong reason. She may have had some issues with MARVEL in the past but I believe the script has been well adjusted to overcome all those things. Tessa Thomson as Valkyrie probably although a bystander is uniquely funny. It is Taika Waititi as Korg who takes all the cherry on cake with the majority of the humour associated with his character. Christian Bale is without a doubt impressive as Gorr The Godbutcher and also has a great character arc to support his performance. Most of us may feel he may lack a bit of screen time but considering the movie runtime it is just about fine. Along with the above there are multiple funny and interesting guest appearances in the movie including that of Russel Crowe which fit well.Thor Love and Thunder may not be an action adventure extravaganza like some of the recent MARVEL movies, but it is a movie with character and love. Lots and lots of love.

ipc-title__text: Hey, is that the Necrosword? That's cool. I've only ever read about it in stories.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Thor Ragnarok gave Thor's world the shake up it / he needed to keep the character interesting. Undercutting the requisite heroism with sly, at times anarchic, humour, Ragnarok delivered one of the freshest and best movies in the MCU.So how does Love and Thunder get it all so wrong? One word: Comedy. Whereas it's predecessor balanced the story and action almost perfectly with it's humour, here Thor's world is turned into an almost slapstick farce with every actor involved seemingly out to prove they can do 'comedy ' (yes, even Natalie Portman, unbelievably). Unfortunately, most of the humour falls flat as a pancake.Love and Thunder also manages to waste two of the biggest recent storylines in Thor's comic history and squander one of his best villains in Gorr the God Butcher. Thor himself has been reduced to a bumbling man-child, who spends the entire movie staring at Jane Foster like a lovestruck teenager with a hammer fetish.Talking of fetishes, someone involved in the film also has a serious Guns 'n' Roses obsession. The band are plastered all over this movie to a distracting level for some bizarre reason - tunes, posters. T-shirts all feature prominently, with even one character insisting he be called Axl! No doubt it helps Slash's retirement fund, but it's just another strike against the film.Overall, it's a massive disappointment and Thor needs a giant course correction if the character is to stay relevant and have any real heroic purpose within the MCU.

This has to be the most disappointing and least enjoyable Marvel film I've ever seen and I've seen every one at the cinema. First because of what it was and secondly because of what it should have been.I was a huge fan of Thor but I'm done with him now...If I didn't know better I would have said this was a Marvel Parody film. Thor was reduced to a hero without a braincell a far cry from the Thor was saw in Thor 1,2 and Infinity War. 80% of the jokes were cringe and what's worse, they were repeated over and over so you couldn't get away from them. Screaming goats? A love triangle between weapons? Yep!Christian Bale and The Mighty Thor (Lady) were wasted and could have been used much better as were all the other characters who came across as jokes. There is no point going into the story.The slippery slope that led to the demise of Thor started with Thor Ragnarock (The best rated and best selling Thor), it was elevated in Endgame but we could just about deal with it, but now they've come full circle and taken off all the restraints with Thor Love and Thunder.A complete character assassination and another Phase 4 Flop!

I thought Ethernals and Morbuis are bad, bud damn, that was another level here. I don't know what did they smoke but this movie is ridiculous... not in the good way. Total waste of time. Feel bad for people, paying to see this in the TheatersThis movie looks like parody of MCU movies. The whole vibe is a total joke. It started soooo good with decent scene , and that opening scene was the only good thing here. Everything after looks like cheap parody. The Van Dam split (with Kung Pow vibes, tho Kung Pow is quite good for parody!) was so out of place. The movie was filled with ton of references , some of which were not even related to MCU and had no place there.And it's COLORFUL .... if you thought that Ethernals was with depressed colors, come here, here the saturation is +1000. CGI and visuals aren't bad technically, but kinda childish at times.The plot story itself wouldn't be bad, if it wasn't filled with so much random stuff. Dialogues were as stupid as they can be.Bale's performance is good, too bad it was wasted on such movie. The other casts' performance wasn't even good, just typical disney stuff...Sound was good.. but only good. You had decent surround sound and some bass... But nothing impressive. You'd expect amazing surround for such movie but no, not at all. Atmos sound was there just to say there is Atmos, but besides that you wouldn't notice if your height speakers don't work at all. The bass wasn't that low and impressive either.If you like Guns'n'Roses you'd give it 1 point more.. if you ignore the fact that all of the songs troughout the movie doesn't even fit the scenes and they are put there probably because someone on the team loves Guns :D.P. S. Hercules would NEVER obey Zeuss for no reason just because his father is angry and wants revenge :D Greek mythology 101. (2nd post scene)

Thor is one of my favorite characters in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Although not all his films were perfect, the direction that has been decided to take with his character has been an emotional and awesome reinvention of what used to be a character that lacked an interesting personality. This film builds upon the events of the previous films that Thor has appeared in and develops a character study of a man who has lost everything and is now in the midst of an identity crisis. This is brilliantly illustrated through the black comedy approach brought upon by director Taika Waititi who is able to balance the sillier aspects of the story as well as the dramatic undertones that breathes life into this film. The visuals are stunning, injecting the world of the Marvel Universe with color and life that is the equivalent of candy for the eyes. The performances are amazing with Chris Hemsworth owning his role as Thor by injecting an admirable balance of comedy and tragedy. Natalie Portman's return as Jane Foster was perfectly handled with her character arc being an emotional beat and justification for the previous films that she appeared in. However, Christian Bale as the antagonist, Gorr the God Butcher, was undeniably one of the film's greatest strengths. His performance was an artistic approach never fully explored in the MCU, delving into an emotional and sinister angle that makes him easily the best villain Marvel has produced. Although some may argue that the film is too silly for its own good, the comedy is brilliantly balanced with drama that will leave the audience in amazement at what it was able to accomplish throughout. The implications of what can happen next in the story of Thor left me in anticipation of what can come next for this hero, and I cannot wait to be there to see it throughout.

ipc-title__text: As bad as I thought it would be
ipc-html-content-inner-div: I avoided this like the plague, but eventually I caved in and now I saw it. And it was worse than I thought.I wasn't expecting to laugh at all, considering that I never did with Thor Ragnarok, a parody everybody thinks is so much better. But I also wasn't expecting not to chuckle once, not to see even one clever thing in the entire "film".Christian Bale somehow survives this abomination with a proffesionalism that this movie and director doesn't deserve, but serves him and the respect that we should all still have for his career, even after the baffling decision of taking a deal to participate in a Taika Waititi movie.

So confused by the people who are calling this a ten out of ten. It's basically on par with The New Mutants.The black-and-white portions were beautiful, and Christian Bale was perfect for his role. But all in all, the film was style (only occasionally so) and no substance.

This is a really fun 2 hours, plenty of comedy & some really good action! Balance probably leans towards too much comedy but it was a very enjoyable film overall. So many cameos & some brilliant lines! Make sure to stay for 2 credit scenes.

I expected more from this movie. Taika Waititi is a good director at making serious theme matter with comedic acts to it. Even if act plays it off funny, the context is rather sad or depressed, which is why I like Thor: Ragnarok and Jojo Rabbit. However, this movie did not land on its subject matter and takes jokes as the main focus. There are some enjoyable moments of the movie, but it sometimes felt forced and not engaging. Ragnarok, Infinity War, and Endgame was a great switch around for Thor, but this movie dumb down this character and now just embrace him as a joke. I seriously believe this is the movie that's going to hurt the MCU. It's an enjoyable film but nothing to experience again.

Honestly the movie is enjoyable but there was way too much comedy. It was completely overboard the entire time and half the jokes never landed for me. Gorr the God Butcher was easily the best part of the movie though. Christian Bale was amazing and I loved Gorr everytime he was on the screen. Chris Hemsworth does solid too but I don't like how they made thor into a comedian.

ipc-title__text: I miss when Marvel took their movies seriously...
ipc-html-content-inner-div: This film is just one big joke after another. Even a majority of the action scenes had a comedic element to them. It was ridiculous! Any and all intensity that Christian Bale brought to the screen was crushed almost immediately by some unneeded joke or quip of some type and it just grew tiresome within the first 30 minutes and remained cringe for the rest of the film. Sucks because Gorr was probably the best and most interesting part of this film. The return of Natalie Portman would've been more welcome had they given her more to do than just say cheesey one liners and have cancer. It was just silly. Really wanted to like this one, but I feel like this was geared to make children cheer and adults lose brain cells. Just disappointing. 2 jealous weapons out of 5.

ipc-title__text: It's fun, even if it is too silly at times
My wounded heart is in Valhalla, thank you very much for that
ipc-html-content-inner-div: This is the perfect send-off for the God of Awesomeness. For once having an appearance loyal to the mythology, it makes all of the canon, Marvel or otherwise, seem acknowledged in one fell swoop. Mwah! Magnificent. HOLY.

Thor: love and thunder follows Thor as he tries to stop a god killer while also dealing with his ex being Thor now. The movie had a engaging storyline with some great humour and action scenes with some great CGI. I think this Thor had the best character development for everyone and we got introduced to some new characters and saw some old. Thor is still badass as ever.I do have to say that some of the humour was forced.The main villain has a very sad backstory which really makes you connect with him.Chris Hemsworth is still badass as Thor but is also trying to find love now after pushing everyone away. Christian Bale plays the main villain Gorr the god butcher and he is terrifying every scene I saw him in he gave me chills running down my spine. Natalie Portman comes back as Jane Foster and is now Thor and she was surprisingly really likeable in this movie. She also had the best character development as well. Tessa Thompson is still Badass and had some pretty funny scenes but she did not get lot to do and she did not appear a lot in this movie. Taika Waititi is hilarious as Korg. And Russell Crowe as Zeus was the biggest jerk but funny.Overall Thor was good I enjoyed it and I think others will too but I think this movie had way to much Comedy in it.

Doesn't take itself seriously at all. Completely free to do whatever it wants.I had low expectations because I read a few average reviews, but happy to find a very entertaining and spectacular ride. With all the stress and division in the world, it's good to let loose with a movie like this.We've seen so much Thor and Marvel characters, so it makes sense to just open things up and have a jam, so to speak. Play with characters, jump around in the sandpit of the Marvel universe and have some fun.That's what this is about. Fun. Over the top thrills. Escapism from the real world of wars, politics and sinking economies. Thor is great and really holds it together, and a few surprises thrown in.I really can't understand some of the grumpy reviews, this is the good stuff.

Marvel films have never been for a smart audience. But turning a character like Thor and many others into a Clash Of The Titans rom-com really seals the fate of this incarnation of the MCU. There really is nothing new here save for Thors butt, which nobody ever asked for. But serves to show just how low Marvel will go for toilet humor.

It gets better towards the end, but it is a really silly movie and the plotting is ridiculous. It seems like the Marvel Universe is focused on parodying itself at this point. The entire GnR trope was twenty years out of date and the movie was mostly made up of worn out messages with no real creativity. The only reason that Marvel isn't entirely formulaic is that they keep introducing worse plots and poorer humor. Of course, Marvel fans still need to see the movies so that they won't be lost in the next one... or that is what Marvel hopes. Don't spend money to see this one. Borrow it or stream it.

How on earth did anyone allow this movie to be released. Total garbage!Obviously aimed at Wiggles fans, and maybe those with brain-damage. From the opening scene to the end, it possible to believe that the producers have something against Marvel, and might be the first official flop.

A pathetic, 2 very long hours of lame parody...A " how to destroy a fanbase" manual. I will carefully avoid any Marvel movie from now on, and I used to be a fan.The line in the movie : " people need to be entertained" is very true, but don't assume all are idiots...

With 2017's Ragnarock Taika Waititi took an MCU also ran and made one of the franchises few must see movies. He doesn't quite manage to capture lightning in a bottle twice but he does deliver a perfectly acceptable blockbuster.In many ways Love and Thunder is one of the Marveliest of Marvel movies, something in bad guys past (admittedly something pretty terrible in this case) makes him go all genocidal and to complete his evilness he must find the magic macguffin while the heroes try to stop him via some snappy banter and middling action sequences. The film stands tall in that it has funnier humour than most of its stablemates and a villain that leaves their mark. You'd need to look far and wide to find an actor put in more work with so little time than Christian Bale as god shanker Gorr, elevating a character that could easily have been another Malekith the Accursed into one of the franchises most memorable villains.While Love and Thunder has no problem balancing its jovial tone with a menacing villain it is less successful at adding a stage four cancer story to the mix. The physical transformation in Natalie Portman's Jane from wasting away patient to shredded Mjolnir wielder is impressive and Portman looks like she is actually enjoying being in one of these for the first time but the story doesn't half bring an Asgardian size elaphant into the room. It's pretty hard to believe that in all his travels through the cosmos Thor hasn't been to one place he thinks might have a shot at curing cancer.A rather subdued film by Taika Waititi standards and there is no doubt the Marvel formula has been worn so thin its transparent but there is still fun to be had and Thor gets a satisfying end to his story.

Following the wannabe 'Guardians of the Galaxy' movie 'Thor: Ragarok', Taika Waititi goes all out with this over-the-top, try hard, jumping on the 80's revival bandwagon mess of a movie.Of course it's a Marvel Superhero movie, it's supposed to be over-the-top but this movie tries soo hard to be soo many things at once, it just ruins the movie.Thor has been transformed from being ignorant and foolhardy to a clueless, stupid idiot who's purpose in the movie is for comedy relief rather than action. This doesn't work when he is matched against the extremely dark and serious Christian Bale as Gorr (who's performance is too good for this movie).It tries desperately to be on trend with the 80's look and Gn'R soundtrack that feels forced (GotG already did it ...better) and Australian actor Russell Crowe plays the Greek God Zeus as an Italian in what feels like a pointless comedy skit is cringey adding nothing to the story.The Jane storyline is one of the most interesting parts of the film but is shoehorned into an already overfull, cameo heavy plot which is sullied for the constant need for more comedy and one-liners.It is watchable but once is enough.

Marvel/Disney just phoning it in with their latest efforts, in all areas to be honest, not just limited to this movie. This movie however has very little going for it, particularly on account of bad writing, politics aside, though there are some clear efforts to exclaim certain ideologies, which pull you out of the movie, but generally speaking they didn't have very much to work with.Thor, it would seem, doesn't do very well in so far as even numbered sequels are concerned, though this one is sat in the middle of a Disney period of output that isn't doing well at all on all fronts. They're in cash cow mode, and seem to care very little about the quality of their output at this time. This is also evident here with regards the visual effects. In fact this film feels rather like a fan edit, as if taken from a lower budget series.It has a couple of good moments - I particularly liked the goats, and some of it's more sentimental moments were reasonably effective. In fact it had some nice ideas in most areas, however none of them were particularly well executed at all.

ipc-title__text: Risky attempt that didnt work out for Taika
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Now i understand what people meant when they said you either love it or hate it. Unfortunately this route taken by taika fell short. The comedy bits coupled with that intentional soap opera acting was a bit overboard. Maybe it was the slight success of Jojo Rabbit that steered that decision.The script was just horrendous. Jane becoming Thor was absolutely unnecessary and had minimal impact on the story itself. Almost felt like taika said...hey lets just throw that storyline in there with no basis. The ending...wow. What a way to throw your whole script down the drain. Ever feel like you had to use the restroom but turned out to be a fart?Goats were lol tho. Oh and whos bright idea should we credit the post-credit scenes to? #wth?
Thor is becoming the greatest comedian in the Marvel Universe, jokes flies here and there all around. Quite Thor-like Thor movie overall, not fantastic but not disappointing too.Eat my hammer!

The story takes the backseat in this film but the character moments are great. Hemsworth, Portman and Bale shine the brightest in this uneven film. The tone is a bit all over the place, but it is funny and it is dramatic. Sometimes you just want it to commit to one or the other a bit better.

ipc-title__text: Taika Waititi's Second Thor Outing Can't Recapture the Spark of Ragnarok
An Unrefined, but Occasionally Creative Film
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Thor: Love and Thunder didn't seem interested in distinguishing itself as its own movie; instead, it acted as a continuation of the wildly well-received Thor: Ragnarok. I imagine Waititi felt that movie performed so well, critically and financially, that it was an open invitation for him to make the fourth entry in the Thor series even more zany. It's true that he has his own aesthetic, but it's an aesthetic that feels calculated rather than one that has naturally manifested itself as his career has progressed. Love and Thunder was overloaded with hit-or-miss jokes, while the dialogue felt obnoxiously simplistic, as though it had been dumbed down to a level appropriate for a children's book. Still, there were certain scenes that worked to perfection, like the cinematically blissful battle in the shadow realm. And although he didn't have as much screen time as I would have liked, Russell Crowe emanated pure likeability as Waititi's rendition of Zues. There is no doubt it would get my attention should they decide to pursue a Zues spinoff movie. As for another Thor movie, I'm indifferent.

ipc-title__text: Has some value as Friday entertainment, but has child soldiers...? Really bad taste...
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Do you know those days that you're just so tired from work and want to watch something uncomplicated? This might be the film for you!...other than that I think there are few values in it. It had some fun moments but no real depth och character arcs. The worst part of the movie were the child soldiers...I mean, wtf?! I get that it was meant to be inspirering and 'cute' but is was just poor taste tbh and made the whole film to a bottom tier Marvel movie for me.

This installation of Thor is just a fun movie. You enjoy the jokes, the ridiculousness of other worlds and other gods. Thor is no longer the serious honorable viking god who used to be funny cuz he was too serious in casual situations... he is now intentionally goofy (not sure if I like that)There is good use of Guns'n Roses songs which I grew up with. Even my children think it's catchy, good intro to some oldy rock music.Some serious plotlines were wasted, though, unfortunately. The God Butcher (Christian Bale) is a badass villain, and the return of Jane (Natalie Portman) could have been so much more. I feel these two were wasted in what some reviews have already harped on... a silly movie. And so, the dialogue was not such sharp comedy, but mostly goofiness for cheap laughs. Even the remaining Asgardians seem like a bunch of refugees of idiots. That's why this movie is just for fun while waiting for more serious developments in the Marvel Universe.

ipc-title__text: If a zero rating were possible.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: For the sake of rating, let's say I've watched 10,000 movies in my life; Thor Dumb & Dumber would be the worst. Nothing worse than a writer who thinks they're funny. So many little cutesy comments that they obviously thought were funny in Ragnarok that they had to throw in dozens and dozens more. Quite pathetic.I grew up with Marvel Comics. This trash ruined a perfectly good franchise.

ipc-title__text: Too much comedy, not enough peril
ipc-html-content-inner-div: It is possible to put humour into a superhero movie without undermining the gravity of the threat being faced. This film fails to do that.Most of this film feels like a parody of itself. There are way too many jokes, most of which fall flat. Thor himself has become a joke, feeling more like Homer Simpson than the God of Thunder. Christian Bale does a good job as the God Butcher, but his role is almost side-lined by the other characters. And Russell Crowe feels like he is doing a Saturday Night Live sketch.There is a scene in one of the comics whether Captain America has been nominated as leader of all superheroes against a galaxy threatening enemy. Another character objects, on the basis that Cap is one of the least powerful beings present. Thor steps up and says something along the lines of "Captain America is a man whose every action is the embodiment of honour; I would follow him into the jaws of Death." *THAT* is the Thor that I want to see - one who values honour and courage above all else (even physical might), who considers petty mortal concerns beneath him, even though he sometimes finds himself succumbing to them.Sadly, the MCU character is moving further and further away from that character.

Thor's Love and Thunder is a mixed bag at best. There is nothing here to make me want to go back and watch this again.The story really ran out of steam in the second hour. I enjoy the Guardians cameo for what they were but once the movie was done it made me which they'd do a full crossover movie because it probably would have been more entertaining than this.Russell Crowe is entertaining enough and Valkyrie is an understated and captivating highlight. Christian Bale's Gorr is a really great villain, truly scary with some Voldemort vibes (if a little too much at times).As the movie starts you're not sure where Thor's place is and where has the story got to go after everything that has gone before. It has to usual Thor banter (though there's an argument to be made that the goofiness goes on a little too far at times).

ipc-title__text: Not as bad as I was expecting
ipc-html-content-inner-div: So I didn't see this until it came to Disney+, partially because of the negative reviews it has gotten. I was pleasantly surprised and loved the humor. The movie is indeed irreverent and I agree that it is strange to see the irreverent humor laid across the more serious aspects of it. That said, humor is one of the ways we cope with tragedy. That's kind of its main purpose in our psyche.To me, this film kind of sits in the series like Moonraker does in the James Bond series. It doesn't really have a point and is panned almost universally, but if you switch your brain off and watch it for it just for fun, it's enjoyable (at least if you have an open sense of humor I guess). I can see how most MCU diehards will hate it, because it does not really advance any overall plot or develop the characters in a way that is meaningful to the overall universe.One strength of the film is that it continues the overall trend of Thor being the most tragic yet most developed of the major MCU characters. He has had to deal with the most loss and the biggest psychological challenges of the series as a whole. I think what he does here, given the new challenges he faces in that way, is a very good depiction of how we should try to live our lives. Thor has been through a lot, but he just keeps pushing forward, and I think that is a testament to his character and the portrayal, despite all of the other parts of his story and this film. Natalie Portman and Tessa Thompson's roles fit into this perfectly, and they all look like they are having fun.I think the biggest problem here is not the film itself. It is that the MCU set such a high expectation for an overall storyline with the stones/Thanos, and doesn't really know what to do next. It has become a series of episodes that do not clearly link in the storyline. I think a lot of MCU fans are struggling with that, which makes sense given how tightly most of the series fit together previously. So again, you do have to just switch off a bit to really enjoy this, but for most people I think it will be enjoyable to do so, as long as you don't mind the screaming goats (which I found hilarious).

ipc-title__text: A Fun, but Flawed MCU Experience
This movie is the weakest and worst movie of Thor movie series.
ipc-html-content-inner-div: The story of the movie is very simple and the screenplay is very weak. There is nothing much to watch in the movie apart from some action scenes within the movie. The movie has comedy dialogues but they are forced to laugh. The movie lacks a lot of entertaining scenes. This movie is the weakest and worst movie of Thor movie series. I don't know why this movie was made.It would have been better not to make this movie. This movie made money only because of the hype of this movie. The actors in the movie have performed well. The previous movie in this series was also amazing. There is no background score in this movie. The villain of the movie is not that much of a powerful. Family movie. Finally, watching the movie is nothing but a waste of time. So my advice, don't watch this movie.

ipc-title__text: Botched first act and underdeveloped villain
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Marvel Studios' Thor: Love and Thunder finds the God of Thunder (Chris Hemsworth) on a journey unlike anything he's ever faced - a search for self-discovery. But Thor's retirement is interrupted by a galactic killer known as Gorr the God Butcher (Christian Bale), who seeks the extinction of the gods. To combat the threat, Thor enlists the help of King Valkyrie (Tessa Thompson), Korg (Taika Waititi) and ex-girlfriend Jane Foster (Natalie Portman), who - to Thor's surprise - inexplicably wields his magical hammer, Mjolnir, as the Mighty Thor. Together, they embark upon a harrowing cosmic adventure to uncover the mystery of the God Butcher's vengeance and stop him before it's too late.Returning to the franchise after helming 2017's Thor: Ragnarok, Taika Waititi has once again put his unique stamp on the connected universe, creating a film that only he could. With Ragnarok, Waititi debuted a madcap rock-infused adventure romp with a far less serious Thor, creating a break from the previous two films that while, with moments of brilliance, didn't quite live up to the character's potential. Here in Love and Thunder, Waititi brings the same manic energy but slightly tempered, choosing instead to deepen the relationship between Thor and Jane Foster. The result is a film that is true to its name: love and thunder, bringing plenty of humor, action scenes, and a generous helping of character development.While there's plenty to like in Love and Thunder, the film is not without its problems, namely in its villain and its pacing. The first act is a jumbled mess of scenes, hopping all around the galaxy without giving the audience time to settle and orient themselves. The opening scenes lack the emotional gut punch of the original Guardians of the Galaxy; where James Gunn made us immediately care about young Peter Quill and his relationship with his mother, here in Love and Thunder, Waititi doesn't take the effort to fully develop the relationship between Gorr and his daughter. That, plus the subsequent scene after as Gorr meets his god, make for a rocky start to the film that takes a while to recover from. Speaking of The Guardians of the Galaxy, the team appears more as a reminder that they exist and a nice treat to hold us over for Volume Three than for any real plot specific reason, outside of them receiving the initial distress call. Each member, with the exception of Star Lord, gets one or two lines before they take off, making their inclusion for the most part unnecessary. Once the film settles, which unfortunately isn't well into the second act, the ride becomes smoother and more enjoyable.Thor: Love and Thunder doesn't do much to further the overall development of the Marvel Cinematic Universe; much like Ragnarok only has a scene of two that props up Infinity War, any longstanding ramification of Love and Thunder are either unclear or nonexistent. Not that that's a problem; the main focus should always be on the film at hand and not the tie in possibilities (looking at you, Age of Ultron). Still, while the fourth phase of the MCU continues to remain murky after the events of Love and Thunder, there are hints of future antagonists for the God of Thunder to clash with down the road.Starring Chris Hemsworth in his eighth outing as the Thor Odinson, Love and Thunder brings a return to form for the chiseled Australian actor. Gone is the flabby dad bod of Avengers: Endgame as the character emerges from his slump and continues to find his purpose in the galaxy. With director Taika Waititi choosing to tap into the previously unharnessed comedic abilities of Hemsworth, Thor as a character has become immensely more charming, if not a bit dumber for the sake of the jokes. This dumbing down of a person who was initially presented with the Shakespearean gravitas of a demigod wrestling with becoming king has ultimately suffered for the drastic change of tone. While Hemsworth seems to enjoy this lighter, campier version, the silliness of his nature juxtaposed against the seriousness of events can at times create a tonal imbalance that was present in Ragnarok and is again present here in Love and Thunder. Still, Hemsworth is never more loveable or dashing then when he's playing Thor and if it's a role he wants to continue to revisit, then it's a role that's guaranteed to keep the audience returning.As for returning, Natalie Portman makes her way back into the MCU as astrophysicist Jane Foster, the first character Thor meets while banished on Earth back in the franchise's first film. Initially unsatisfied with the direction of Thor: The Dark World, Portman departed and has only reappeared through cut footage in Avengers: Endgame during the time heist. Fortunately, lured back by the promise of becoming The Mighty Thor, Portman's grand reentry into the franchise is a bittersweet one: years have passed and when we pick up with Jane Foster, time has not been kind to her. As Jane suffers her battles, Portman once again proves that she's a top-notch actress, delivering the gravity, the humor, and holds her own in action scenes with Hemsworth. The chemistry between the pair is better here in Love and Thunder than it ever was in the first two Thor films; whether that's due in part to having new writers and directors that understand the source material or due to the time the characters have spent apart is inconsequential, it's great to see Thor and Jane mix it up again in both action scenes and in the classic will-they-won't-they trope that only works as good as the actors' commitment to it. Thankfully, in this film, both Portman and Hemsworth commit fully and almost all of their best scenes together over three films are collected in this one outing.Unfortunately, the restoration of Jane Foster's character comes with certain sacrifices, namely by way of Valkyrie, our favorite scrapper from Sakar. King of Asgard, thanks to the denouement of Avengers: Endgame, Tessa Thompson's presence is almost completely overshadowed by the return of Jane Foster. Thompson, equally as charming and charismatic as Hemsworth, doesn't have much to do in the film; a good bit of her time is spent observing Thor and Jane from the sidelines as the pair attempt to figure their relationship out. What little screentime she gets is mostly as a background character with a handful of lines. There's no development to her whatsoever beyond being a beleaguered ruler of her tiny fiefdom who longs to still mix it up in a good fight. Thompson's talents are mostly wasted in this film, which is a shame since she's featured so prominently in Ragnarok.Possibly the most underserved character in the film is its villain, Gorr the God Butcher. Played by Christian Bale of Batman fame, the actor jumped universes to embody one of the most menacing and problematic villains of recent Thor history. With a moniker like 'the God Butcher' and the means to do so, Gorr could easily have joined the ranks of Thanos or Killmonger in terms of threat level and sympathy, but the end result is instead a weak performance backed by weak writing. Far from Bale's best work, Gorr the God Butcher goes missing from the film for entire swaths of time as the heroes traverse the galaxy looking for help in defeating him. He comes alive far too late in the film's third act in a brilliant black and white set piece but by then the damage is done. Instead of a fascinating and complex antagonist, we get something akin to a Phase 1 villain with decent motivation but little development. Bale suffers for it and the film itself suffers for it.Written and directed by Taika Waititi, his second entry into the MCU, Thor: Love and Thunder once again has his fingerprints all over it. Waititi's trademark humor and oddball characters are on full display throughout, delivering a movie unlike any other in the cinematic universe. Where the filmmaker has stepped his game up, however, is in the cinematography department; he, director of photography Barry Idoine, and the visual effects team have managed to create some of the most visually stunning interstellar scenes the audience has been privy to within the MCU so far. While the Phase Four films continue to suffer from some spotty CGI, and Love and Thunder is no exception to this, it's clear that Waititi has thoughtfully crafted a movie that, while less colorful than Ragnarok, is still full of Walt Simonson-inspired treats.Overall, Thor: Love and Thunder takes the zaniness and camp of Thor: Ragnarok and doubles down. Taika Waititi's love of classic rock shines through again as the audience is treated to a number of well placed needle drops and cheer worthy moments. With a visual palette that completely differentiates itself from the rest of the MCU, Waititi has created a film that manages to stand out as one of the more distinct looking films in the oeuvre. Chris Hemsworth and Natalie Portman's chemistry is undeniable, and after almost a decade apart, it's a delight to see the pair together again. Even with its botched first act and underdeveloped villain, the film is still a fun ride in theaters.

This movie should have been entitled Jane Thor: a feminist movie about ultra-strong masculine women, and weak, bumbling, buffoonish men, whose only purpose in this satirical comedy... ahem movie... is to serve as props to showcase how "strong" and "awesome" the females are.Can this movie even be called Thor!?...
I mean... I know he's in it, but it's a female empowerment movie; it's not even about him.Damn!This agenda-driven push, to make men more feminine and women more masculine, is having terrible implications on society: women have become undatable/unmarriable, all because greedy corporations wanted to make more money, by being able to sell more to women.

Cinematic thrill ride. Expecting nothing, everything was a surprise and welcome. Crazy, trippy, movie. I thought they held nothing back in Doctor Strange Multiverse and they continued that approach here. I know some people don't like the Thor movies. I think they are the best. 11 out of 10.

ipc-title__text: CGI and demeaning superheros does not a movie make
ipc-html-content-inner-div: If they wanted to make a movie that would kill of the superhero franchises, I guess this is what they tried to do. But then again, this comic books based CGI action theme was always destined to go the way of all the other 'popular' themes like musicals, westerns, 3D, etc etc. What we started to see during Covid and are seeing more now, especially with Spider Man, Thor and Jurassic World is the declining end-game of the CGI based action hero movies. I guess Iron Man saw it coming and got out in time with his dignity intact - end game indeed. I wonder what will become popular next. I hope it involves mainly adults and intelligent dialogue (mostly) and rational plots that are well directed and produced, with quality actors giving their all for their art - you know, like it used to be. I am sick of western teenage girl targeted movies - hopefully they will grow up soon.

I'm a huge marvel fanboy, and hardly ever have anything bad to say to about the MCU, but this was a huge letdown. Ragnarok is easily one of my top 5 marvel films , so was very excited to see this one, but this was really really bad. It was boring as hell and none of the jokes landed for me. First time in a marvel movie I really wanted to leave or wished it would end already. Huge waste of Gorr the god butcher. And the whole Zeus and Olympus part were so cringe worthy. I don't know how this got made. It was garbage.

Nice try but no. You can't just remake Korg with two dads when in Ragnarok you said he had a mom. But typically cancerous woke agenda: stupid af.The rest of the movie is meh .. Jane is a nice take on Thor but also the transformation ... Which didn't happen when someone else picked up the hammer.Valkyre is just a sad filler in the show.Zeus is a disappointment and seeing Russell Crowe in it , the gladiator would cry.Keep throwing money and cgi.

ipc-title__text: Another reminder that actor writer directors shouldn't be a thing
ipc-html-content-inner-div: I won't bore you with a summary of the plot or a reason why this is a bad entry into the MCU (boy am I eating my words on Multiverse of Madness aren't I) but this.This has to be one of the worst movies ever made, from plot to acting to editing to directing and writing nothing works.I said it minutes ago to another guy but this is hands off the wheel at 90 mph levels of crazy. What is Marvel thinking?!

Taika Waititi took another stab at the Thor movies after his huge success with Thor:Ragnarok, and while it was a fun ride, it wasn't able to top its predecessor. Thor: Love and Thunder was everything but boring. The jokes are shot off at every chance given, and the majority land well. In my opinion, it did the one thing Marvel fans are scared of: became a comedy. It was a fresh take on superhero movies in the sense that it didn't just have comedy, but can be classified under the comedy genre. Waititi has a brilliant, zany mind, and this movie really showed that. Christian Bale's Gorr the God Butcher was excellent, and truly a scary villain. Every character had good development as the movie progressed, and Chris Hemsworth was clearly putting a lot of effort into Thor's personality, which payed off. Plus, Natalie Portman's Jane Foster made an epic return, something anyone can get excited for. The movie also gave us a lot of new, exciting characters and things to look forward to in the future - something every Marvel fan loves. While the plot itself was a bit fast paced, and it kind of felt hard to keep up with the different scenes and settings at times, it still carried itself well. So while it may not be the best of the Thor franchise, it was still a blast, and definitely something I can't wait to see again.

ipc-title__text: A Comedy Action That Gets Action Right
ipc-html-content-inner-div: Thor Love and Thunder is Ragnarok's much worst sequel. This movie is a 2 hour film with mainly the same 3 or 4 jokes over and over. Thor Ragnarok was one of my favorite MCU movies too date so I was so excited for this. However it misses on 90 percent of the comedy, and while that sounds like an extreme, this film is basically a joke after a joke from the first time we see Thor to the end. It never stops. While the comedy was horrible though you have to give credit to the action and visuals in this movie. They are tremendous and truly fun to watch. The standout here was Christian Bale, his portrayal of Gorr was incredible and he stood out as an actor in this movie. Jane Foster as the Mighty Thor works really well which I wasn't expecting and the universe it starts to make cannon in the MCU is also a huge plus.Overall Thor Love and Thunder is a bad comedy mixed with a great action film and a standout performance. I think that earns it a slightly above average rating and is not worthy of a rewatch for a long time.

To be honest, I am sick and tired of most of the neverending line of even more superhero-movies. More often than not, they are pretty bad "movies" with non-existing plots, but an overload of CGI instead.The first Thor-movies were okay-ish because of their sense of humor and often tongue-in-cheek dialogues.Still, I could have done without any more of them. Or so I thought.Whoever put it into Taika Waititi's hands, will hopefully have a say in more of the coming movies.This was pure comedy, sometimes even slapsick. Neither the movie itself, nor the characters take themselves seriously at any point.I can totally see, where the relatively low rating (6.6 at the time of writing) comes from.If you really liked the "old" Thor movies, or Marvel in general, this might come as a shock to some.It's very different and even more over the top than the "Guardians", but with just as good music.I for one, was entertained throughout and will likely watch it again soon. Not because it was a "Thor"-movie, but because it was just great fun to watch.All I am saying is, GOATS!
